Chapter 2

â€œHermioneâ€¦â€ she heard someone breathe.

Looking up sharply from her manacles, she saw a head poking through the dividing curtain. She squinted and stared. It was Hannah Abbott.

A low gasp of horror escaped Hermioneâ€™s lips.

Hannah only had one eye.

Her right eye was staring at Hermione, but her left eye was gone. There was a black, gaping hole in her head as though it had been plucked out.

Hannahâ€™s hand immediately darted up and covered the left side of her face.

â€œSorry. Itâ€™s always awful for people the first time they see it.â€

â€œWhatâ€”happened?â€ Hermione forced the words out.

She didnâ€™t know of any curse that removed eyes in such a manner. There were plenty of blinding hexes, but none with such grotesque results.

â€œUmbridgeâ€”she popped it out with the tip of her wand whenâ€”when I tried to escape. She made the healers keep it like this. For effect.â€ Hannah turned her head slightly away to conceal her face further.

â€œShe got into trouble for it though.â€ Hannah lowered her face so that she was gazing at the floor. Her voice sounded as if she was somehow dead. â€œShe normally cuts off fingers now. If youâ€™re disrespectful. If you try to get away. If you look at her wrong. Parvati and Angelina, they hardly have any fingers left.â€

Hannah looked hard at Hermione with her remaining eye.

â€œLet your Gryffindor die, Hermione. Donâ€™t try to be brave. Donâ€™t try to be clever. Just keep your head down. People have been trying to get out for months. Anyone who gets caught gets maimed. Anyoneâ€”who gets outâ€”it took too many tries before we realisedâ€”the manacles weâ€™ve all gotâ€”,â€ Hannah raised her own copper encased wrist, â€œtheyâ€™ve got a trace in them. If you get past the wards, they send the High Reeve and hang the corpse in the Great Hall so that we all have to watch it decay.â€

Hermione felt as though sheâ€™d been struck violently in the chest. Her fingers spasmed against the fabric of the blanket covering her. She could barely breathe. â€œWho?â€

â€œGinny. She was the first body they brought back. We all thought maybe you had actually gotten out. Because you disappeared. We didnâ€™t realise theyâ€™d just put you somewhere else...â€

Hannahâ€™s voice trailed off, and she stared at Hermione. â€œYou donâ€™t even know why they brought you out, do you?â€

Hermione shook her head.

â€œThe guards talk a lot. After the war, we all expected the Dark Lord would start enslaving the Muggles. Butâ€”it turns out his ranks were more exhausted than we realised. Apparently being immortal makes him patient. He decided that repopulating the ranks of pure-blood wizards should be first on his agenda. He personally paired off all the pure-bloods. Made them all get married with orders to start reproducing.â€

Hannahâ€™s face was twisted with disdain as she recited this information.

Hermioneâ€™s eyebrows furrowed with surprise. A repopulation effort? The war had dragged on with high casualties given the size of the wizarding population, but Hermione hadnâ€™t thought Voldemort would notice, much less care. Arranged marriages werenâ€™t exactly uncommon among pure-bloodsâ€”but having them mandated seemed extreme. She wondered how his followers had felt.

â€œThere wereâ€”barely any babies. Pure-blood fertility rates have been dropping for years. There were a few pregnancies that set everyone abuzz. Most ended up squib and got terminated before the end. Or miscarried. Well,â€œâ€”Hannahâ€™s voice grew bitterâ€”â€œapparently facing the extinction of the European wizarding world has opened the Dark Lordâ€™s mind somewhat in regard to blood purity. Magic is might, you know. Heâ€™s decided to start a breeding program with all these half-blood and Muggle-born prisoners he happens to have on hand. Just us girls, since itâ€™s a fate worse than death to have a Muggle-born male touch a pure-blood female. Weâ€™re all to be made to produce babies until our uteruses give out.â€

Hannah looked as sick as Hermione was beginning to feel.

â€œSo thatâ€™s why they finally let you out,â€ said Hannah, gesturing helplessly. â€œTheyâ€™re using school and medical records to decide which of us are eligible. That healer you were speaking toâ€”sheâ€™s the head of the whole thing. Apparently she specializes in magical genetics. Weâ€™re her lab rats. Theyâ€™re checking everyoneâ€™s fertility.â€

Hannah was crying now. Hermione stared at her, feeling faint with shock. It couldnâ€™t be true. It was all just too horribly dystopian. Some nightmare she was dreaming up inside her cell.

â€œWeâ€”have to get out,â€ Hermione said in as steady a voice as she could manage.

Hannah shook her head.

â€œWe canâ€™t. Didnâ€™t you hear me earlier? Unless you can chop off your hands, youâ€™ll never be able to leave with those manacles. They donâ€™t even keep the trace here. Angelina lost her pointer finger to find that out. The Dark Lord keeps it personally. Thatâ€™s why whenever anyone gets away, itâ€™s always the High Reeve who goes after them. â€œ

Hannah looked quickly around, tilting her head to get a slightly better view of the floor beyond the privacy curtains.

Hermione followed Hannah's gaze. There was nothing there.

â€œWho? Who is the High Reeve?â€ Hermione asked. She didnâ€™t remember that title.

Hannah looked up. â€œI donâ€™t know. None of us have ever seen him without his mask. Everyone talks about him. Heâ€™s the Dark Lordâ€™s right hand. Voldemort doesnâ€™t go out much, so the High Reeve appears instead. They held public executions a few weeks agoâ€”more than twenty people. He killed every single one with the Killing Curse. He didnâ€™t take breaks. He just went straight down the line. No one has even seen the Dark Lord cast that many in a row.â€

â€œThatâ€”shouldnâ€™t be possible,â€ Hermione said, shaking her head doubtfully.Â 

Hannah leaned forward and lowered her voice. â€œI know. But Iâ€™ve seen the bodies after he catches the runners. He always catches them. McGonagall, Moody, Neville, Dean, Seamus, Professor Sprout, Madam Pomfrey, Flitwick, Oliver Wood; those are the ones youâ€™d know. There have been more. Loads more. The Order members were the ones who tried hardest to get away. They all came back corpses. Itâ€™s always the Killing Curse.â€

Hannah hesitated and stared intently at Hermione. â€œDonâ€™t do something stupid, Hermione. Iâ€™m not telling you all this so youâ€™ll try to escape. Iâ€™m trying to warn you. Itâ€™s hell. You need to be prepared for that becauseâ€”if you arenâ€™tâ€”youâ€™re going to walk out there and get maimed, and it wonâ€™t even mean anything.â€

Hannah seemed about to say something else, but footsteps sounded beyond the curtains. An expression of terror rippled across her face, and the dividing curtain fell as she retreated.

The curtain on the other side of Hermione snapped open, and the healer from earlier reappeared, looking harried.

â€œThe Dark Lord wants to watch your examination himself,â€ the healer said, reaching out and grabbing Hermioneâ€™s arm forcefully.

Hermione tried instinctively to get away. She jerked her arm out of the healer's grip and dropped off the other side of the bed in order to create distance.

â€œOh, you stupid little witch.â€ The healer sighed, and gestured to someone standing out of Hermione's vision. â€œStun her and bring her.â€

Two guards appeared from behind the curtain and shot two successive stunners at Hermione. The first she dodged, but the second nicked her shoulder. She dropped like a stone.

When she re-awoke, she was strapped down on a table in a dark hall. Her arms and legs were restrained, still twitching from torture. More straps went over her forehead and chin, holding her head in place. There was a small wizard standing on one side of her. Voldemort himself was standing on the other.

The small wizard was speaking in a thin, trembling voice, gesturing up at a projection of Hermioneâ€™s brain.

â€œItâ€”itâ€™s unlike anything Iâ€™ve ever seen b-before. Normally magical m-m-memory loss occurs q-q-quite generally across the brain when it is s-s-self generated. A p-person canâ€™t even tell you their name. But this is t-targeted. Like obliviation spells. A dissociative fugue, or in this case m-many of them. Almost like self-obliviation. Her magic has hidden specific memories inside what I can only describe as almost a c-c-calcification of magical layers. It probably could never have happened without the specific cir-circumstances of her imprisonment. This t-t-took time. Her brain has been slowly shoring up a line of d-defense over the course of months. Almost like a clam making a pearl, sheâ€™s been slowly burying them under layer after layer. You c-can tell some have been more extensively protected than others based on how brightly they g-g-glow.â€

Voldemortâ€™s eyes were narrowed. â€œCould these memories be recovered with legilimency?â€

The small wizard looked more nervous. Faint droplets of perspiration had collected on his upper lip.

â€œItâ€™sâ€”itâ€™s unlikely. This is like an individual occlumency wall of exceptional strength around each specific memory. Itâ€™sâ€”it's p-possible if the legilimens is sufficiently p-p-powerful.â€

â€œI like to think I am,â€ Voldemort said, looking down into Hermioneâ€™s eyes. She squeezed them shut instantly, but it was too late.

She thoughtâ€”she might have known occlumency before. With her magic mostly stolen away, she had no ability to create a wall around her mind. Voldemort shot in like an arrow, burying himself deeply among her memories and then sifting slowly through them. It was as though her mind were being crushed under his.

Her childhood. Hogwarts. He wasnâ€™t concerned with her locked memories of her parents. After fifth year, when everything grew hazy, his interest sharpened. He examined her memories of healing. All those bodies. All those injuries. So many people. The closer he got to the end of the war, the more memories were locked. He tried driving into them. He tried stabbing his way through the magic with sheer force. None of them would give away to his violent, insistent attacks.

It was breaking her. The force was mind-numbingly painful, and somehow the pain continued to increase until it felt impossible that she wasnâ€™t dying from it. Hermione was writhing as she sought to get awayâ€”to escape the invasion. Screaming surrounded her and just kept going on, and on, and on.Â 

Finally Voldemort withdrew from her mind. Furious. She slowly became aware that the screams had been hers. By then, they had been reduced to tiny mewling wails of pain past shredded vocal chords. Guttural sobs that kept choking out as her chest kept spasming from pain, and she struggled to breathe.

â€œI do not like secrets kept from me. With Potter dead there should be nothing left to conceal. What are you hiding?â€ Voldemort hissed. His bony fingers seized her face and turned it so that she met his eyes.

â€œIâ€”donâ€™tâ€”knowâ€”,â€œ she said. Her voice was rasping and broken, and she weakly tried to pull her jaw free from his hold.

â€œCall Severus! And the Warden. She shall be punished for this,â€ Voldemort said. He viciously probed Hermioneâ€™s mind until she lay limp and barely conscious on the table.

Umbridge arrived first, looking appropriately terrified.

â€œMy Lord, my Lord,â€ she said, dropping to the ground and crawling toward him.

â€œ Crucio .â€ Voldemort cast the curse, his fury evident in his tone.

Umbridge screamed. She screamed, and screamed, and writhed on the ground. Hermione almost felt sorry for her.Â 

After several minutes, he finally stopped.

â€œDid you think, Warden, that following the letter but not the spirit of my commands would spare you?â€

Umbridge only whimpered.

â€œI knew of your dislike for the Mudblood, but I had hoped your obedience to me would be sufficient motivation for you to restrain yourself. Perhaps you need a permanent reminder.â€

â€œMy Lordâ€”â€

â€œWhat is that punishment youâ€™re so fond of doling out among your charges? Knuckles, isnâ€™t it? Tell me, Warden, how many fingers will you have left if I take a knuckle for each month you spent trying to drive the Mudblood insane?â€

â€œNoooooooo.â€ Umbridge voice rose in a shriek. She was still shaking and spasming on the ground.

â€œPerhaps I should be lenient,â€ Voldemort said, walking slowly toward her as she sniveled and grovelled at his feet. â€œYour work has been mostly good. Instead of sixteen, Iâ€™ll halve it. Eight knuckles as a reminder I said I wanted Potterâ€™s Mudblood left fully intact.â€

â€œPleeeease...â€ Umbridge was pushing herself up off the ground, sobbing.

Severus Snape swept into the room.

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong? Unable to endure consequences of your own devising?â€ Voldemort sneered, and waved a hand as he turned away from Umbridge. â€œTake her away. Drop her back at her prison when youâ€™re done.â€

Two Death Eaters came forward and dragged Umbridge from the room as she begged and wailed apologies.

â€œSeverus, my faithful servant,â€ Voldemort said, turning toward the Potion Master. â€œI find myself with a puzzle on my hands.â€

â€œMy Lord,â€ Snape said, folding his hands respectfully in front of him and lowering his eyes.

â€œYou remember the Mudblood, I presume.â€ Voldemort moved back toward Hermione, staring down at her and running a skeletal finger along his lipless mouth.

â€œOf course. She was an insufferable student to teach.â€ Snape walked over to survey Hermione, who was still strapped down on the table.

â€œIndeed, and a good friend of Harry Potter, the boy who died,â€ Voldemort said, caressing his wand lightly. â€œShe was also a member of the Order as Iâ€™m sure you recall from your many years as my spy. When Potter died, she was captured, and I ordered her imprisoned but left intact in case I ever had need of her. Unfortunately, the warden at Hogwarts saw fit to dole out her own punishment for past offenses. She imprisoned the Mudblood all this time in a cell under sensory deprivation.â€

Snapeâ€™s eyes widened slightly.

Voldemort rested a hand on Snape's shoulder. â€œAccording to the mind healers, the experience enabled the Mudblood to lock away her memories. Sealing them off from herself and from me. The identities of her parentsâ€”which is of no consequence. More vitally, a great many memories from the war, particularly near the end. This memory loss occurred after Potter diedâ€”after the war had ended. What is it that she would be hiding?â€ There was menace in Voldemortâ€™s low sinuous voice. He paused for a moment and then looked down at Hermione. â€œPerhaps as someone who knew her during that time, you would have some insight into what is missing.â€

â€œOf course, My Lord.â€

Hermione found Snapeâ€™s cold, bottomless eyes peering down at her. She didnâ€™t have any strength left to try resisting as he sank into her consciousness.

He didnâ€™t bother with her early memories. He went directly to the war and swept through the memories quickly but thoroughly. He seemed to have specific categories he pursued. Healing. Potion brewing. Order meetings. Research. Conversations with Harry and Ron. Fighting. The final battle. Whenever Snape came upon a locked memory, he seemed to pause and consider its surroundings before trying to break into it.Â 

His invasion was dramatically less traumatic than Voldemortâ€™s, but Hermione was still weeping and shuddering by the time he finally slowly withdrew. Her hands clenching spasmodically where they were strapped in place.

â€œFascinating,â€ he said, staring down at Hermione with a somewhat conflicted expression.

â€œAny insight?â€ Voldemort's hand tightened on Snape's shoulder, and his tone was suspicious.

Snape turned from Hermione and lowered his eyes. â€œTo be honest, My Lord, the Mudblood and I had very little contact during later years of the war. The Order meetings I was privy to are all there. The little else I knew of her was that she was kept away from the fighting, acting as a healer and potion mistress. Those memories appear intact. I am at a loss as to what she could be hiding.â€

â€œIf the Order had any remaining secrets left, I want to know them,â€ Voldemort said, his scarlet eyes narrowing.

â€œIndeed,â€ Snape said, his tone silken and demure. â€œUnfortunately, most of the highly informed Order members are dead now. Either during the final battle, or from torture or escape attempts. Aside from Miss Granger herself, there is likely no one else still alive carrying the information.â€

Voldemort stared down at Hermione. His red eyes were enraged and calculating as he ran a finger slowly along his mouth. Then he looked sharply over at the mind healer.

â€œIs there any way to recover these memories?â€ Voldemort said, his wand hanging from his fingertips with casual menace.Â 

â€œWell, th-thatâ€™s very difficult t-to s-s-say.â€ The healer paled. â€œItâ€™s p-p-possible. Now that the circumstances causing it-have been removed. With t-t-time, th-they may restore themselves.â€Â 

â€œWhat about torture? I have broken through to obliviated memories with torture in the past.â€

The mind healer looked green.â€œIt m-m-might work. B-b-butâ€”thereâ€™d be no telling which ones youâ€™d unlock. You m-m-might only get a f-few b-before she went insane.â€

Voldemort stared speculatively down at Hermione. â€œThen I want her watched. Carefully. By someone who will know the instant they begin to return. Severus, I shall leave her in your charge.â€Â 

â€œOfâ€”course, My Lord.â€ Snape bowed low.

â€œYou object?â€ Voldemort using his wandtip to force Snape upright. He tilted Snape's head back until their eyes met.

â€œNever. Your wish is my command.â€ Snapeâ€™s collected expression rippled under the scrutiny.

â€œYet you have objections,â€ Voldemort said, withdrawing his wand and turning back to stare down at Hermione.

â€œI am departing tomorrow for Romania,â€ Snape said, â€œto investigate the rumors of insubordination we have heard about. The trip, as you noted when you assigned it to me, will be a delicate task, complex and rigorous even without the addition of a prisoner who requires careful monitoring. Iâ€”am reluctant to disappoint you in either of these matters.â€ He placed his hand on his chest and bowed again.

Voldemort paused and seemed to be considering, resting his hands on the table beside Hermione and leaning over to study her. As he stood there, a movement on Hermioneâ€™s other side caught her attention. The female healer in charge of Voldemortâ€™s breeding program had approached and was whispering a question to the mind healer.

â€œM-My Lord,â€ the mind healer said, stepping hesitantly closer, â€œHealer Stroud has brought to my attention a p-point that m-m-may interest you.â€

â€œYes?â€ Voldemortâ€™s interest appeared negligible. He did not look up toward either healer.Â 

â€œMagical pregnancy, My Lord,â€ Healer Stroud said with a proud smile. â€œThere are a few cases on record which indicate that such pregnancies have an ability to break through magical fugues. The magic of a child is compatible but dissimilar enough to its motherâ€™s to have a corroding effect on built up magic. Itâ€™s nothing conclusive, given the rarity. Itâ€™s possible, however. Miss Granger has exceptional magical abilityâ€”you yourself noted this and wanted her included in the repopulation effort. If you leave her within the program, there is a chance that a pregnancy may result in unlocking her memories. Butâ€”,â€œ she hesitated slightly. Â Â 

â€œWhat?â€ Voldemort looked up sharply at Healer Stroud, causing her to pale and flinch.

â€œYouâ€”you would be unable to inspect her mind during the pregnancy.â€ Healer Stroud said, speaking quickly. â€œInvasive magics such as legilimency carry a high risk of miscarriage. It's often so traumatic that it can result in permanent magical infertility. You would have to wait, even if you knew the memories were returning, until the baby was born. Unless the father, who would share a familiar magical signature with the child, were the one performing the legilimency.â€Â 

Voldemort stared down at Hermione thoughtfully, his fingers sliding over his chest as though he were soothing an injury.

â€œSeverus.â€

Â â€œMy Lord.â€

â€œThe High Reeve is an exceptional legilimens, is he not?â€

â€œIndeed, My Lord,â€ Snape said. â€œHis skill is likely equal to my own. You had him trained quite carefully.â€

â€œHis wife has been found magically barren, has she not?â€

The question was directed toward Healer Stroud.

â€œYes, My Lord,â€ she answered immediately.

â€œThen send the Mudblood to the High Reeve. Let him breed and monitor her.â€

Stroud nodded eagerly. â€œI can have her there in two weeks. I want to ensure her condition and have her trained.â€

â€œTwo weeks. Until she is found pregnant, I want her brought in every other month so I can examine her mind personally.â€

â€œYes, My Lord.â€

â€œTake her back to Hogwarts, then.â€ Voldemort dismissed them with a wave of his hand.

Hermioneâ€™s body was still spasming slightly as the restraints on her were spelled off. She felt as though she ought to doâ€”something. Spit. Or refuse. Orâ€”beg.

Anything but just lie there while Voldemort casually delegated her off for breeding.

Her body refused to cooperate. She couldnâ€™t do anything as careless hands dragged her up off the table and levitated her down a hallway.

Chapter 3

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

The bed Hannah had occupied was empty when Hermione was returned to the hospital ward in Hogwarts.

Healer Stroud poured a potion down Hermioneâ€™s throat as soon as she was placed in the bed. The pain in Hermione's mind subsided slightly. She blinked, and the dancing black spots that kept obscuring her vision finally started to fade away.

Hermione felt nauseous. Her insides were roiling and cringing like she had poison inside that her body couldnâ€™t expel. She was still shaking. She wanted to roll over and curl into a ball, but she couldnâ€™t summon the strength to manage it.

â€œGuard her with your lives. If anyone wants to touch her or so much as look at her, they will require permission from me,â€ she heard Healer Stroud say.

Hermione turned and could vaguely make out two large men standing behind Stroud. Their eyes were cold as they stared down at Hermione.

Stroud cast several monitor wards on Hermione that rose up, shimmering around her body. After she had inspected the projections for a few minutes, Stroud turned and strode away, her healer robes billowing out behind her.

Hermione stared up at the ceiling, trying to absorb everything that had happened to her that day.

She felt like she should be crying, but she couldnâ€™t summon the tears.

Resignation and hopelessness had entwined themselves with her soul since the moment she watched Harry die.

After watching most of the people she loved die in agony, sheâ€™d known her turn to suffer was lying in wait.

Now it had come.

Death had never frightened Hermione. Her fear had always been in the manner of death. She had watched the worst ways to go.

Harryâ€™s death had been a mercy killing compared to the torture the Weasleys, Remus and Tonks had been subjected to.

Lucius Malfoy had been standing mere feet from where Hermione was caged when he looked up at Ron and snarled â€œThis is for my wife!â€

Then he cast a curse that turned Ronâ€™s blood gradually into molten lead. Hermione watched as the curse slowly crept through Ronâ€™s body, destroying him from the inside out. Sheâ€™d been helpless to do anythingâ€”helpless to spare him in any way.

Arthur Weasley had been left permanently addled by a curse during the war. He cried, not even understanding why he was in pain or that he was dying.

They had left Molly for last. So sheâ€™d watch all her children die.

Remus had lasted hours longer than anyone else. His lycanthropy kept healing him until he just hung there, unresponsive. Finally someone shot the Killing Curse at him out of boredom.

The deaths had replayed themselves before Hermioneâ€™s eyes so many time she would have thought that eventually the pain of them would ease.

It never did.

Each time felt just as sharp. Just as fresh.

A wound that would never heal.

Survivorâ€™s guilt, she thought, that was the Muggle term for it. Such a paltry description. It didnâ€™t capture even a fraction of the breadth of agony in her soul.

For Hermione, being bred by a Death Eater was a fate that had never even occurred to her. Being rapedâ€”the risk had been considered. This felt like rape in slow motion. However, the situation was far more complex than simply that. Whatever she had hidden in her mind, it had been important. More important to her than anything else. She couldnâ€™t let it fall into Voldemortâ€™s hands.

She wasnâ€™t afraid of having her corpse rot in the Great Hall. That fate was nothing compared to giving up what she was protecting. Or compared to being raped and forced to carry a child that would be torn from her the moment it was born.

Escaping, she realised, was likely a luxury she couldnâ€™t afford to pursue. The important thing would be to die quickly. Before she could be stopped and kept from further attempts.

She lay quietly in the bed and schemed.

The days passed slowly. None of the prisoners brought into the hospital wing dared speak to Hermione with the guards constantly beside her bed.

Healers arrived several times a day to appraise and treat her. They took vials of blood and a bit of hair away for analysis. A therapist arrived to treat Hermione for the torture. For the tremors.

Eventually most of the intermittent spasming stopped. Hermioneâ€™s fingers still tended to twitch spastically at unexpected sounds.

She wasnâ€™t used to noise anymore.

She remembered life being full of noise in the past; in classes, at meals, in the hospital ward after battles. Now any unexpected sound caught her off-guard. The banging of a door or clatter of boots, the sound waves from themâ€”they felt like physical sensations on her flesh.

Sheâ€™d twitch.

The nervous mind healer came frequently with Healer Stroud to examine Hermioneâ€™s brain and psychological condition. There were concerns about her overall stability. Theyâ€™d cast simulation spells on her brain to see how sheâ€™d react to crowds, tight spaces, physical contact, gore. If she was going to mentally snap, they wanted her to do it in the hospital wing.

Apparently, despite the twitching, Hermione was regarded as stable enough. When the most severe torture tremors stopped after four days of therapy, they decided she was ready for training.

On the fifth day, she was released from the hospital wing. The guards took her straight to the Great Hall.

There were rows and rows of chairs arranged facing the front of the hall. The chairs were filled with women dressed in drab grey dresses.

Umbridge was standing on the platform in the front, speaking with saccharine cheer. She was dressed in a subdued shade of pink with a large pendant hanging from her neck. One of her hands was heavily bandaged.

â€œYou have been chosen to help build the future that our Dark Lord has envisioned. You have been granted the privilege of bringing it forth,â€ she said, and simpered. â€œYou are the few found worthy of it.â€

Umbridge sounded mechanical, staring down at the girls with eyes glittering with hatred. The false smile plastered firmly across her face. Her eyes kept flickering up toward a corner of the room.

Hermione turned slightly to look and saw two Death Eaters standing there unmasked; Corban Yaxley and Thorfinn Rowle. They were watching Umbridge with expressions of bored amusement.

â€œThe Dark Lord has commanded that you be trained in order to fulfill your duties without fail. This is a great honour he has bestowed upon you; you do not want to disappoint him. You are important to the Dark Lord. Because of that, you must be protected from others as well as from yourselves.â€

Umbridgeâ€™s smile suddenly sharpened, showing a malicious edge. She gestured toward the back, and Yaxley and Rowle came forward. Umbridge turned to the prison guards lined up along a wall.

â€œStun them all. Be thorough about it.â€

A few of the seated women cringed or tried to shy away, but most of them barely moved as guards started hexing them. The bodies slumped down in the chairs or fell forward onto the ground.

Hermione was standing toward the back. She watched the girls fall. She recognized a handful of them; Hannah Abbott, Parvati Patil, Angelina Johnson, Katie Bell, Cho Chang, and Romilda Vane. Hermione thought some of the others might have been in the older and younger years in Hogwarts. There were a few slightly older women too, although no one who appeared over thirty. There were nearly a hundred of them.

Umbridge saw Hermione standing toward the back.

â€œStun her too,â€ Umbridge said, glaring venomously at Hermione.

They hesitated.

Healer Stroud appeared from the periphery of Hermione's vision.

â€œDo it,â€ she said with a sharp nod of approval.

Hermione was knocked out before she could brace herself.

â€œRennervate.â€

Hermione sat up groggily. She'd been moved, and found herself lying beside the rest of the girls.

They were laid out in rows. Some were still unconscious, and the guards went down the line waking them. Others were sitting, staring at the manacles around their wrists. Hermione looked down at her own. The magical bracelets looked different; a bit wider, and now without any clasp. A perfect circle of copper wrapped around each wrist.

â€œProperty of the High Reeveâ€ was engraved into the shining surface of both of the manacles.

Of greater concern to Hermione was the cold object beneath the metal that she could feel pressing slightly against her inner wrists. The manacles were so closely-fitted she couldnâ€™t peer under to discern what it was. It was clearâ€”the reason they had been stunned was in order to remove and replace the manacles. Presumably with something worse than what they already had been.

The clock on the wall indicated that hours had passed since the stunning had started. Whatever the process had been, it had taken time.

A large table had appeared in the Great Hall, covered with weapons.

It couldnâ€™t have been a more obvious trap.

Everyone stood cautiously and just stared.

â€œCome forward,â€ Umbridge said in a coaxing voice, beckoning from beside the table. â€œCome on. Come see.â€

No one moved.

Umbridge looked disappointed. She had clearly hoped someone would be foolish enough to rush toward the table and try arming themselves.

â€œYou there. Come here.â€ Umbridge pointed at a girl in the crowd. Hermione thought the girl might have been in Hermioneâ€™s year. Mafalda, she thought, from Slytherin.

The girl obeyed slowly, cringing in apprehension.

â€œLift something up,â€ Umbridge ordered her.

Mafalda reached forward slowly, but when her hand got within a few centimetres of a knife, she abruptly snatched it back with a cry.

Umbridge smiled in triumph.

â€œEveryone now, come reach. See what happens.â€

The women all shuffled forward reluctantly. Hermione approached in growing dread, her mind speculating. There must have been a barrier charm added to the manacles; something that prevented them from getting close to certain objects.

She extended her hand from a considerable distance and approached slowly. When her fingers were within ten centimeters of a dagger on the table, a burning sensation began enveloping them. She pulled her hand away bitterly. Her options if she needed to resort to suicide were suddenly dramatically limited. She surveyed the various objects: crossbow bolts, knives, swords, axes, kitchen knives, letter openers, even large steel nails. The spellwork to create the punishing barrier appeared to have been comprehensive. She catalogued each item carefully.

That couldnâ€™t be all the new manacles did. Inlaying a barrier charm was simple enough magic. There was something more complex about the new set.

Hermione looked down and fidgeted them again.

â€œThese new bracelets will keep you safe and ensure the households you are sent to can take good care of you. The head of each household will carry a charm that allows them to always find you and know if you are ever in any danger. Givenâ€œâ€”Umbridge smiled sweetly,â€”â€œthe dangerous, volatile nature common among Muggles, they will keep you from committing any acts of violence on anyone, including yourselves. They will help you to unwaveringly obey the Dark Lord in this generous opportunity he has given you.â€

Several women were audibly sobbing.

â€œThese are such important wizards that you will be serving, after all. We donâ€™t want any mistakes or accidents inconveniencing them.â€

A barrier charm, possibly some kind of compulsion spell, and paired with a monitor enchantmentâ€”that was what Hermione felt under the manaclesâ€”a monitor piece, tracking her physical well-being.

Monitor enchantments were commonly used in the psych wards of hospitals to alert healers when patients were likely to injure themselves or act out. It tracked heart rate and hormones, picking up spikes and surges. Complex ones even tapped slightly into the consciousness. It wasnâ€™t mind reading exactly, but it gave an impression on the wearerâ€™s state and inclinations.

Trying to commit suicide or escape without any type of weapon, trapped under a sort of compulsion spell, without any mental indication or spike in heart rateâ€”it would be nearly impossible.

Hermione stood frozen in the Great Hall as she absorbed it.

The days merged together into a haze of dread.

They were trained.

Umbridge would hold what looked like a small lantern and issue an instruction. When she finished speaking, the lantern would glow slightly and the manacles would grow warm as magic sank in.

Ingraining compulsions into their minds.

It was done gradually. It seemed that each instruction needed time to take root in their psyches. To mould their behavior.

You will be quiet.

You will be obedient.

You will not hurt anyone.

You will not offend the wives.

You will not resist when bedded.

After being bedded you will not move for ten minutes.

You will do everything to get pregnant quickly and produce healthy children.

You will not have sex with any man but the one designated.

As the days passed, Hermione could see the effect of the instructions on the other women.

They grew quieter and quieter. During the first few days, there were hushed whispers at night. By the third day, the rooms were mostly quiet aside from the muffled sobbing.

Hermione was kept slightly apart from all the others. There was always a guard flanking her.

Umbridge stayed far away from Hermione, although her eyes would flash toward Hermione in triumph each time a new compulsion was laid.

Whatever the Dark magic being used to enable the compulsion spell was, it was delicate. With each new instruction, the healers would sweep in and run diagnostics over the girls. Â 

One day, one of the girls abruptly snapped and stood up screaming. She seized her chair and whipped it up into the air before smashing it down onto the woman beside her. By the time the guards had stunned the screaming girl and dragged her away, the womanâ€™s shoulder was shattered.

There may have been further instructions planned, but after that event, Healer Stroud decided that what had been programmed with was sufficient.

Hermione lay in the dark each night and plotted.

If she couldnâ€™t escape, her best hope would be of dying at the wand-point of the High Reeve.

He was, from what Hermione had been able to gather, very quick to murder. If she could provoke him to act without thinking, he might kill her before he could stop himself.

If sheâ€”succeeded, Voldemort might then kill the High Reeve. Making the world a better place by far.

She would have to be quick about it. Clever. If he were as good a legilimens as Snape claimed, the High Reeve would find the intention in her mind.

Perhaps it wouldnâ€™t matter.

Someone so hate-filledâ€”they were probably far quicker with their emotions than their reason. She could use that to her advantage and draw a noose around both their necks.

â€œStrip,â€ Umbridge said several days later.

Hermione wasnâ€™t sure if it was the compulsion or merely the futility of resistance that caused her to obey automatically.

Probably both.

She, along with the rest of the women, unbuttoned her drab grey dress and pulled off her undergarments. They stood shivering in the cold room. There were seventy-two of them left. Twenty had been pulled by Healer Stroud out of concern theyâ€™d snap like the screaming girl had.

They all stood nude but for the shining copper bracelets on their wrists, folding in on themselves to hide their bodies from the leering appraisals of the guards.

â€œDress in these.â€

With a flick of her wrist Umbridge unfurled a large pile of clothing. Bright scarlet dresses and robes. Red as blood.

No undergarments.

Hermione was thin enough that she barely missed having a bra but the lack of underwear was keenly felt. Like a raw nerve.

â€œAnd these, for the winter chill,â€ Umbridge said, smirking, as she unfurled another pile of clothing. Wool thigh-high stockings.

Then Umbridge added a pile of white bonnets and scarlet, flat-soled shoes.

Hermione put everything on.

The bonnet was last. The wings of it blocked her peripheral vision almost entirely. Muffled her hearing.

She could only see straight ahead. If she wanted to look at anything to the left or right, she had to turn her head overtly.

It was all carefully crafted to engender vulnerability.

They could barely see, barely hear, couldnâ€™t resist, couldnâ€™t refuse, couldnâ€™t escape.

Their well-being would rely entirely upon endearing themselves to whomever owned them.

So they would be pliant.

â€œIf you leave the home you have been assigned to, you are required to wear these bonnets. You are not to be looked at,â€ Umbridge commanded. Â â€œThis is the end of my training for you. I cannot wait to see the children brought forth.â€

Umbridgeâ€™s eyes were locked on Hermioneâ€™s face, the hatred in them so thick Hermione could almost feel it glazing on her skin. Umbridge smiled a cold, gleeful smile and then turned and left.

Someone brushed Hermioneâ€™s arm. Someone so close that even turning she couldnâ€™t see who it was with the obscuring wings in the way.

â€œIâ€™m so sorry,â€ Angelinaâ€™s voice whispered. Angelina's voice broke, like she was suppressing a sob. â€œYou were right. We should have listened to you.â€

Hermione opened her mouth to ask Angelina what she meant. Before she could get the question out, a hard hand closed around her arm. She found herself dragged away into a small room.

Healer Stroud sat behind a large desk piled high with paperwork. She had a file laid open before her that appeared to feature a calendar. The squares were filled with checks to mark off the days.

Hermione realised it was mid-November in 2004. She hadnâ€™t realised the date until that moment.

â€œMiss Granger,â€ Healer Stroud said as she looked up, â€œI am quite pleased I was able to keep you in the program.â€

Hermione said nothing. She stared woodenly at the woman before her.

â€œI realise that you did not choose this, but given the side you chose in the war, surely youâ€™re pleased to have your magical abilities acknowledged.â€ Stroud studied Hermione, her eyes bright and her expression strangely warm. â€œThere will be no more Sacred Twenty-Eight after this. Future generations will simply be magical. Iâ€™m certain you can see the advantage to it.â€

Hermione stood there, marveling internally at the twisted logic the woman before her employed to clear her conscience.

It took her several seconds to realise that a reply was in order. Judging by Stroudâ€™s expression, expected.

â€œYouâ€™re sending me off to be raped and you want me to see the advantage to it?â€ she finally said, arching her eyebrows up.

Healer Stroudâ€™s eyes flashed briefly and grew cold.

â€œI am not responsible for all the decisions regarding security. It may surprise you to hear it, but I am quite invested in your health and happiness.â€

â€œEven if I were sterile?â€

Hermione looked down and studied the upside calendar, trying to read the numbers and ascertain the exact date. The bright white paper blurred in her vision and made her eyes ache.

Healer Stroud rolled her eyes and sighed. â€œClearly there is no reasoning with you. You are still too emotional about everything. Perhaps someday, a witch with your intelligence will come to appreciate what I am trying to do.â€

Hermione said nothing. She squinted and tried to read the calendar again. Her fingers twitched.

Healer Stroud dropped a file on top of the dates and stood up. Hermione looked up.

â€œThe Dark Lord is eager for you to be under the supervision of someone capable of monitoring your memories. I had requested an extension, in order to see how the training affects you, but youâ€™ll reach your window of fertility in a few days, and the Dark Lord wants you pregnant as soon as possible. I would have helped you prepare physically butâ€”you donâ€™t seem to want my help. The High Reeve is married. Iâ€™m sure he knows what to do and wonâ€™t mind training you to suit himself.â€

Healer Stroud gave a cold, thin smile and Hermione flinched. Her stomach twisted painfully.

Healer Stroud reached into her drawer and pulled out a bag.

â€œThis will take you to the High Reeveâ€™s estate. Theyâ€™re expecting you.â€

She reached toward Hermione. Hermione skittered back.

She dropped her chin down and tried to breathe. She just needed a moment to brace herself. To prepare for what she was about to faceâ€”and what she was about to do.

â€Put out your hand,â€ Healer Stroud said as she walked around the desk toward Hermione. Hermioneâ€™s heart was pounding painfully in her chest as she bit her lip and tried to swallow the dread rising up in her like a tide.

Helpless. Defenseless. Obedient.

You will be obedient.

Hermioneâ€™s hand began to raise itself. A coin fell onto her palm. Instantly she felt a tug behind her navel as she was whisked away.

Chapter End Notes

"You will be quiet. You will be obedient." by keerthi_draws.

Hermione in uniform by graciek_217

Chapter 4

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Hermione reappeared in a dark foyer. It was an immaculate, empty room. A black, lacquered, circular table sat in the center of the room. There was a large bouquet of white flowers on the table.

She turned slowly. She didnâ€™t want to miss any details, but the stupid wings of the bonnet acted like blinders. She could only see straight ahead.

A large stairway lay to the right. Cold hallways led into darkness and further into the house. It was a manor, and an enormous one based on the width of the staircase.

â€œHello, Mudblood.â€

A cold voice made her freeze.

Slowly turning all the way around, she found Draco Malfoy.

He was older.

Her last memory of him was fifth year when he was on the Inquisitorial Squad. He had grown taller. He towered over her, and his face had lost every trace of boyishness. There was a dangerous, refined brutality in the way he held himself.

The way he looked at her...

His eyes were like a wolfâ€™s; cold and feral.

The deadliness in him was palpable. As he looked down at her, she felt certain, he could lean forward and cut her throat while staring in her eyes. Then step back, only caring that she not get blood on his shoes.

He was the High Reeve.

Voldemortâ€™s right hand. His executioner.

The number of her friends that he had murdered: Ginny, McGonagall, Moody, Neville, Dean, Seamus, Professor Sprout, Madam Pomfrey, Flitwick, Oliver Wood... the list went on and on. Aside from those who had been tortured to death immediately after the final battleâ€”every person that she knew to be dead following the warâ€”the High Reeve had killed them.

The girls had whispered to her during the first few nights. Telling her about the world of horror she had missed while locked under Hogwarts.

She hadnâ€™t thought he could be someone she knew.

Someone so young.

Terror welled up inside her. She wasnâ€™t sure what to do to handle the shock.

Before she could reactâ€”or even process the realisationâ€”his eyes locked into hers, and he abruptly slammed his way into her mind.

The force almost made her black out.

His mental intrusion was like a blade, driving straight into her memories. He sliced through the fragile barrier that she tried to erect with the shreds of internal magic she could summon. He drilled into her blocked memories.

It was like having a nail driven into her head.

The precision and the unrelenting force.

He wouldnâ€™t stop trying to break through. It felt almost worse than the cruciatus curse. It lasted longer than the torture curse could without driving the recipient insane.

When he finally stopped, she found herself lying on the ground. Malfoy was standing over her, staring down at her as she shuddered from the trauma of his intrusion.

â€œSo, you really have forgotten everything,â€ he said as he appraised her. â€œWhat is it you think youâ€™re protecting in that brain of yours? You lost the war.â€

She couldnâ€™t answer.

She had no answer.

â€œOh well,â€ he said, straightening his robes slightly. â€œThe Dark Lord was kind enough to send you to me. If ever you do recover your memories, Iâ€™ll be the first to know.â€

He smirked down at her for a moment before his face grew cold and indifferent. Then he stepped over her body and walked out of the room.

Hermione dragged herself to her feet, shaking from the mental anguish and impotent rage she felt.

She hated him.

She had never hated Draco Malfoy before.

He had simply been an indoctrinated bully, a symptom of a disease which others were responsible for. Nowâ€”she hated him. For what he had become. For what he had done.

He owned her.

She was trapped under his heel, and he intended to grind her down until he had what he wanted.

She clenched her jaw as she forced herself to think past her sudden rage. Her plan remained the same. She had to find a way to escape or trick him into killing her.

He wasnâ€™t what she expected. She had hoped that the High Reeve would be driven by emotions, and although the Malfoy she had known in school had been, now he seemed ice-cold.

Which, of course, she should have realised. Legilimency, occlumency; the key to them was control. The ability to compartmentalise oneâ€™s self behind walls.

It would take cunning to make him snap enough to make a mistake like killing her. Whatever she did, she wouldnâ€™t be able to accomplish it immediately. She couldnâ€™t rush it. She couldnâ€™t be careless. She would have to stay there, wait, and endure what was to come until she found an opening.

The thought had her shuddering. Her throat felt tight as she swallowed and tried to think.

A click of heels on the wood floor drew her attention. A petite blonde witch swept into the room. She and Hermione stared at each other for several long moments.

â€œSo, youâ€™re it,â€ the witch said, elevating her nose with a sniff. â€œTake that stupid hat off and come along. We have to review the instructions all together before I can put you away where weâ€™re to keep you.â€

The blonde turned on her heel and marched back out of the room. Hermione followed slowly. The witch was familiar. A Greengrass, Hermione thought. Not Daphne, but maybe the younger sister.

Hermione couldnâ€™t remember her name.

They arrived in a drawing room. Malfoy was already there, reclining in a spindly looking chair and looking bored.

Hermione pulled the bonnet off.

â€œSo,â€ said the witch Hermione assumed must be Malfoyâ€™s wife as she seated herself on one of the other spindly chairs. â€œHealer Stroud sent over a package of instructions. Who knew Mudbloods came with directions? So convenient, isnâ€™t it?â€

The sarcasm in the witchâ€™s sharp little voice was brittle.

â€œJust read it, Astoria,â€ Malfoy said, glancing briefly toward the witch with a sneer.

Astoria. So that was the name of Malfoyâ€™s wife.

â€œLetâ€™s see. No cursing or torturing or physically abusing her. Sheâ€™s to be kept fed. We can make her work, but no more than six hours a day. And sheâ€™s to spend at least an hour outside each day.â€

Astoria laughed somewhat manically.

â€œItâ€™s rather like keeping crups, isnâ€™t it? Who knew? Ah yes. How delightful. Weâ€™ll get an owl every month on the five days youâ€™re required toâ€”perform, Draco. Healer Stroud has included a little personal note here, mentioning that due to the Dark Lordâ€™s specific interest in the Malfoy Family and the Mudblood, she will be coming in person every month to see whether youâ€™re successful.â€

Astoria looked so nearly hysterical that Hermione was surprised she hadnâ€™t started screaming and smashing a chair.

â€œListen to this. Iâ€™m allowed to watch! You know, to make sure everything is entirely clinical between you and the Mudblood.â€

Astoria turned shockingly pale. Her blue eyes looked almost deranged. Her hands were shaking, and she crumpled up the papers in her hands and smacked them down on the tea table.

â€œI will not,â€ she said, her voice razor-edged and vibrating. â€œIf you object, you can drag me in front of the Dark Lord himself before you Avada me. I will not watch!â€

She did scream the last bit.

â€œDo what you wish, just shut up!â€ Malfoy said, his tone vicious as he stood up and strode from the room.

Hermione stood frozen near the wall.

Astoria sat shaking in her chair for several minutes before she spoke to Hermione.

â€œMy mother bred crups. Pretty little things,â€œ Astoria said. â€œSuch fun to see it done now with wizards.â€

Hermione said nothing. She just stood by the wall trying not to move. Willing her fingers not to spasm. I am pretending to be a tree, she thought faintly to herself.

Finally Astoria stood up.

â€œIâ€™ll show you your room. You can do whatever you want, but I donâ€™t want to see you. I understand that those bracelets you have keep you from any trouble.â€

They went down a long hallway and then through a narrow, partly concealed door that led to a winding servantâ€™s stairway. After ascending three floors, they re-entered into a larger, main hallway of the house. They were in a different wing. The windows were all heavily draped. It was cold and shrouded; the furniture all covered with white dust sheets.

â€œThis wing is unoccupied,â€ Astoria said as though it werenâ€™t obvious. â€œWe have more servants than we need. Stay here and out of sight unless youâ€™re called for. The portraits will keep an eye on you.â€

Astoria pushed open a door. Hermione walked in. It was a large bedroom. A canopied bed sat in the center and a single wing-backed chair near the window. A large wardrobe sat against one wall. There was no rug. A portrait hung on the wall. No books.

Everything was cold and bare.

â€œIf you need anything, call a house-elf,â€ Astoria said before pulling the door shut. Hermione listened to her retreating footsteps.

Being suddenly left unsupervised without being in a cell felt disorienting. The sudden change simultaneously thrilling and terrifying, as though sheâ€™d suddenly jumped Â off a cliff.

She dropped her bonnet on the floor next to the door and walked over to a window. The cold, wintry countryside stretched out as far as she could see. As she took it in, she considered the situation.

Malfoy and Astoria clearly disliked each other.

It was hardly surprising. As if pure-blood arranged marriages werenâ€™t already dysfunctional enough, having them arranged by Voldemort for the sole purpose of reproduction had to have smothered any potential spark. Especially after they failed to reproduce.

Astoria did not seem particularly afraid of Malfoy, so presumably he wasnâ€™t so short-tempered as to be violent to her. She seemed largely resentful of and indifferent to him.

He did not appear to be an attentive husband by any stretch of the imagination. His regard for Astoria seemed to be along the lines of finding her to be a pest he was obliged to endure.

Whatever Astoria may feel about her husband or marriage, Hermioneâ€™s presence as a surrogate clearly stung. She seemed determined to ignore Hermioneâ€™s existence inasmuch as she possibly could.

Hermione had no objection. The fewer players she had to worry about, the better. If she had to worry about fending off or appeasing Astoria it would be an additional challenge. If Astoria were attentive to her husband, it would make escaping or finding a way to manipulate Malfoy far more challenging. If Astoria was primarily preoccupied by pretending Hermione didnâ€™t exist, it was the easiest scenario. Hermione would keep out of sight, in the shadows, as much as she could. Until there was an opportunity to act.

The key would be to study Malfoy. Discover what drove him. What his vices were. What she could exploit in him.

He didnâ€™t seem particularly interested in Hermione beyond finding out what she might be concealing in her lost memories. If that were the case, it was a relief. Perhaps he would also primarily choose to leave her alone. She was sure that if he wished to he could come up with any number of ways to torture her without risking her fertility.

Draco Malfoy was the High Reeve.

It was still shocking.

What had happened to him during the war to make him so ruthless?

The hatred required to successfully cast a Killing Curse was tremendous. To inflict instant death tore something out of you. Most dark wizards and witches could only manage it occasionally. That was part of why there were so many other curses used to kill. Sadism factored into it, but the truth was that no other curse was irreversible and unstoppable the way the Killing Curse was. The power necessary to utilise something so final wasâ€”well, there was really nothing to compare it to.

Voldemortâ€™s ability to cast it repeatedly and unfailingly was part of the reason he inspired such terror.

The High Reeveâ€™s reputation for using the curse was already equally legendary. It had vaulted him into the highest rank of the Death Eaters.

And it was Malfoy.

She would have to move carefully. The casualness with which the Malfoys had treated her arrival indicated utter assurance. Leaving her in the foyer. Showing her through the house. Putting her into an unoccupied wing. Hermione was certain there were no easy ways to escape. Until she could get the manacles off, Malfoy would always be able to find her, and sheâ€™d be incapable of fighting off him or anyone else.

She sighed, and her breath made a small circle of condensation on the cold glass of the windowpane.

Lifting a fingertip to the glass, she drew the rune thurisaz: for defense, introspection, and focus. Beside it she drew its reversal, its merkstave: for danger, defenselessness, malice, hatred, and spite.

What she needed. What she had.

She had to reverse her fortune.

She watched the runes fade away from the glass as the condensation evaporated back into the room.

None of the girls had heard any whispers about the Resistance still existing. Aside from Hermione, all of the Order members who survived the final battle were known to be dead. Their deaths publicly witnessed. Their corpses hung up to ensure there was no room for secret hopes. The Resistance had crumbled upon Harryâ€™s death.

Voldemort appeared to have been careful about ensuring that the Order of the Phoenix had no spark with which to resurrect itself. As the war had dragged on over the years, he had grown more cautious and less certain about his infallibility than he had been during Hermioneâ€™s years in Hogwarts.

Voldemort was thorough.

That was troubling. If he had elevated Malfoy to High Reeve, it probably meant that Malfoy was also thorough. Not someone inclined to make mistakes or errors in judgment.

Maybe there was still a Resistance somewhere. The women at Hogwarts had only known what the guards told them. There might still be some factions working against Voldemort. If Hermione escaped, maybe she could find them and eventually give them whatever secret she was hiding.

Since she was in the High Reeveâ€™s house, perhaps if she were clever sheâ€™d be able to glean useful information.

If she kept acting pliant and cooperative.

Broken.

If they thought she was truly broken, they might eventually become careless around her.

She would be waiting for it.

She was very good at waiting.

Chapter End Notes
