Flashback 4

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

April 2002

The next time she arrived at the shack, she had barely gotten through the door before Malfoy abruptly apparated in, nearly on top of her.

He grabbed her firmly, and backed her up against a wall as his lips crashed into hers.

Hermione barely had time to think or react. Her eyes widened in astonishment and as they did, his eyes met hers and he abruptly invaded her mind.

She had been so startled, her occlumency walls had fallen. The terrifying distraction of his body pressed against hers while he kissed her made it difficult to focus solely on the sensation of his mind tearing its way through her consciousness.

He skimmed through her recent memories; brewing an invisibility potion for the ring heâ€™d given her, taking Lee Jordan and dropping him at St Mungoâ€™s. He found her memory of their previous meeting.

She could feel him experiencing it, even while she was also keenly aware of his lips moving away from hers and kissing along her jaw, while his hands slid along her body.

He started moving toward the memory of her conversation with Snape. No. She didnâ€™t want him to see that one. Even though she was confident he would know what she was trying to do, she didnâ€™t want him to have confirmation of it.

She forced herself not to pull the memory away or hide it. Instead she grabbed onto the first thing she could think of and jerked it forcefully back further into her memories. Malfoy had to have known it was a feint, but he gamely chased after it. After keeping it away from him for a few seconds, she let him catch it.

Third year Malfoy stood in front of her, sneering.

â€œHave you ever seen anything quite as pathetic?â€ said Malfoy. â€œAnd heâ€™s supposed to be our teacher!â€

Harry and Ron moved angrily toward him, but Hermione was the quickestâ€”SMACK!

She slapped Malfoy across the face with all the strength she could muster. Her hand felt aflame from the force, and his pale skin immediately bloomed scarlet where she struck him. He staggered, looking at her with a mixture of pain and astonishment. Â 

â€œDonâ€™t you dare call Hagrid pathetic, you foulâ€”you evilâ€”â€ she roared.

Malfoy abruptly jerked out of her mind and stepped away, shaking.

Hermione stared at him, expecting him to be enraged that sheâ€™d tricked him with that memory. Then she realized after a moment that he was laughing.

That felt more terrifying.

â€œWell done,â€ he said, still chuckling after a minute. â€œI expected it would take you longer before youâ€™d be able to do it.â€

Hermione was slumped against the wall, trying to recover herself from his combined mental and physical assault. A migraine was already steadily beginning to creep up on her.

â€œIs this the way you usually teach occlumency?â€ she said after a moment.

His lips quirked faintly.

â€œOnly with you,â€ he said with a thin smile. â€œI canâ€™t have you doubting my sincerity, now can I? I needed to do something to catch you off guard. Soâ€”â€œ he shrugged. â€œTwo gnomes, one kneazle. Iâ€™m sure you didnâ€™t expect me to keep my hands entirely to myself.â€

Hermione fought back the urge to sneer at him.

â€œShould I wear stockings the next time I come?â€ she asked, her voice caustic.

His eyes seemed to darken.

â€œHmm. No. I rather like you like this. Being dirty and bedraggled in muggle clothing suits you. And I intend to savour you. You neednâ€™t start wearing themâ€”yet.â€

Hermione felt a shiver go through her; of fear, but also from the tension between them, a strain of animosity and calculation filled the air.

He stepped closer to her and caught hold of her left hand, lifting it as he slid his thumb across the ring that reappeared on her hand when he stared down at it.

â€œHow does this work?â€

â€œThe potion is based on Magical principles similar to the Fidelius,â€ she said, slipping her hand free. â€œItâ€™s only visible if you know to look for it. Otherwise itâ€™s undetectable. Only you and I can see it.â€

Malfoy quirked an approving eyebrow.

â€œI donâ€™t believe Iâ€™ve heard of that potion.â€

â€œItâ€™s new,â€ she said stiffly.

â€œYours?â€

Hermione gave a reluctant nod. â€œItâ€™s not actually that useful. It only works on metals.â€

â€œInteresting,â€ he murmured, stepping closer.

Every time he drew near, she felt a renewed awareness of how dangerous he was. The dark magic came off of him in waves; it clung to his clothes and his hair and almost emanated from his skin. It was as though he wore a cloak of darkness and rage that he was simply keeping in check around her.

There was so much darkness. All the deaths he was responsible for.

He was drenched in them.

â€œLetâ€™s try again. And see how long you can keep it up.â€ His lips pulled into brief smirk. â€œI wonâ€™t kiss youâ€”this time.â€

He drove into her mind again. She kept him out with her walls for a minute while she organised her mind and memories. Then she pretended to have the shield give away.

She wasnâ€™t sure she was actually good at it, or if he was having the decency to restrict himself from rifling through all her memories. He allowed her strong attempts at distracting him to succeed. After sheâ€™d successfully done it a dozen times, he withdrew.

Hermione felt as though her head were about to crack open; as though the pain were a form of pressure that threatened to break through her skull. The pain was agonising. Her eyes were welling up with tears, and she bit down on her lip to try to keep from crying.

â€œDrink this,â€ he ordered, slipping a vial of pain relief potion into her hand. â€œOtherwise you may black out when you try to apparate. I wouldnâ€™t recommend it.â€

She swallowed it, fairly certain he wasnâ€™t going to poison her.

â€œDid that happen to you?â€ she asked when the pain began easing so she could speak again and her vision was no longer littered with flashing black spots.

â€œMore than once,â€ Malfoy said shortly. â€œMy training wasâ€”rigorous.â€

She nodded. It still seemed hard to believe he was the same school bully she had known.

Coldness and harshness were built up around him like the walls of a castle. All that scarcely subdued rage.

The boy who got boxes of sweets and had a spot bought for him on a quidditch team, who cried and whined over a scratched arm, was gone. Everything soft and indolent and pampered about him was carved away by the war. He hadnâ€™t bought his way through Voldemortâ€™s ranks with galleons. Heâ€™d paid in blood.

Everything was so hard and exacting. His smirking and leering, and the vagaries of his courtesy all felt like an act. Like a mask he was wearing to disguise just how cold he was.

If she wanted to succeed, she needed to get past his mask and coldness and rage. He might be intending to use her just as a form of vindictive or amusing stress relief, but she was still determined to become more.

She needed to draw out his confidence until she could understand his motivationâ€”until she found a vulnerability she could slip through.

No one was pure ice. Not even Malfoy.

There was something about him. In his eyes. Something that looked like fire hidden deep within. She needed to find a way to reach it and then fuel it into something she could utilise.

He expected her to hate him and try to manipulate him with false kindness and sympathy. She had to be clever about it. More clever than him.

â€œWas that after fifth year?â€

He looked at her somewhat sharply.

â€œYes,â€ he said it in a clipped tone.

â€œYour aunt?â€

â€œHmm,â€ he hummed in confirmation.

They were both staring at each other intently.

â€œNot the only thing you learned that summer,â€ she said.

â€œAre you needing a confession for something, Granger? Should I tell you everything Iâ€™ve done?â€ He drew closer so that he towered above her, and sneered down in her face.

She forced herself not to shrink or cower back. She stared up into his eyes.

â€œDo you want to?â€ she asked.

There was the faintest flash of surprise in his expression. He seemed caught off guard by the question.

He was lonely. Sheâ€™d suspected as much, but now she felt certain. Dead mother, insane father. He was high up in Voldemortâ€™s ranks and they were notoriously filled with backstabbing. If he ever had any regrets, heâ€™d never told anyone.

â€œNo,â€ he said, voice sharp as he stepped away from her.

She didnâ€™t push. If he thought she were pushing, heâ€™d shut up like a clam. She didnâ€™t need to know. She just needed him to realize he wanted to tell someoneâ€”

â€”that he wanted to tell her .

It would make her emotionally valuable to him. It would be a hook. An opening.

It would make her interesting.

â€œDid you want to go again?â€ she asked after a moment.

He stared at her, silver eyes flat.Â â€œWhen I was trained, sheâ€™d have someone crucio me while she was trying to break into my mind. Thatâ€™s probably what will happen to you, if youâ€™re ever caught.â€

He didnâ€™t give her time to react to the information before he slammed his way in. When he stopped, he didnâ€™t wait for her to regain her breath before dropping a new scroll of information next to her and vanishing.

That week Hermione went back to Waterstones. She bought books on the psychological effects of loneliness. Books on orphans. Research of the psychology of child soldiers.

She didnâ€™t hesitate as she underlined sections on their vulnerabilities; the ways by which they were prone to being taken advantage of and manipulated.

In a notebook upon which she placed a rather nasty security curse she began to draw up a psychological sketch of Draco Malfoy. What sheâ€™d noticed about him. Questions and theories she had.

The center of himâ€”his motivationâ€”remained a mysterious blank. But she felt as though she were beginning to get a sense of his edges.

The following Tuesday, he did not start by forcing his attentions on her. He set himself to provoking her in other ways.

He did not restrain himself at all when he invaded her mind for another round of occlumency training. He scrabbled into the back of it, and then meandered through the memories he happened to come across. Forcing her to relive some of the deaths she tried hardest not to dwell on. Then, quite by accident, he came across the memory immediately following her conversation with Snape. She flinched when he drew near it, and he immediately pounced.

He watched her examine her facial features critically before stepping into the shower. And when she stepped out and appraised her naked body in the mirror, he stopped and stared, following her mental fault finding. She could feel his condescending amusement as he took her in. She writhed with embarrassment, and he felt that too.

He stayed in the memory for far longer than it lasted and then withdrew entirely from her mind.

â€œWell,â€ he said, looking as though he were about to start laughing. â€œThat certainly is one way to distract a legilimens.â€

She glared up at him. She was sorely tempted to kick him in the groin and then try to stomp his teeth out.

â€œPleased with your purchase?â€ Her tone was corrosive.

He gave a short laugh under his breath. â€œYouâ€™re rather scrawny. If youâ€™d sent me the memory beforehand, I might have asked for someone else,â€ he said as he stepped back to look her over in person.

â€œA pity for us both then,â€ she said, her mouth twisting as she folded her arms defensively.

â€œPerhaps... But then again, if I hadnâ€™t gotten you I would never have had a chance to encounter a brain organized like a filing cabinet.â€ His voice was light and casual, but his quicksilver eyes abruptly hardened. He cocked his head slightly to the side. â€œMoody didnâ€™t train you. Youâ€™re a natural occlumens.â€

Hermione nodded resignedly. She had assumed heâ€™d realise it eventually. When sheâ€™d invented the lie, she hadnâ€™t expected him to spend so much time poking around in her head.

â€œSelf-taught, then?â€Â 

â€œI had a book,â€ she said stiffly.

He gave a barking laugh. â€œOf course.â€

He was staring at her with an expression she couldnâ€™t place. As though he were reassessing her. The realisation seemed to be making him to re-evaluate something about her.

Hermione didnâ€™t want him to re-evaluate. If he did, he might decide to change his strategy. She liked the current way in which she was not having sex with him.

â€œWhat?â€ she snapped at him impatiently, hoping to break his train of thought. It seemed to work, the narrowed expression of his eyes eased slightly.

â€œNothing,â€ he waved her off. â€œIâ€™ve just never encountered one before.â€

He smirked.

She stared at him with her own eyes narrowed.

â€œYouâ€™re one too,â€ she said with rising horror. She was trying to slip past the defenses of someone who could also shutter and isolate their emotions and desires.

He gave a mocking bow.

â€œWhat are the odds?â€ he mused with a faint shrug.

There was a long silence.

They were both re-evaluating.

â€œAre you still going to teach me occlumency then?â€ she asked at length.

â€œYesâ€¦â€ he said slowly. â€œIt would be an oversight to only do it halfway. Youâ€™ll be able to learn quicker than I had expected.â€

â€œRight.â€ She nodded and braced herself.

He drew closer to her. Her heart stuttered.

The movement reminded her of an animal stalking prey. Slow, subtle, gradual and then suddenlyâ€”too close.

She stared at his face so she wouldnâ€™t focus on the physicality of him, on how easily he could break her with his bare hands.

His fingers came up and touched her chin lightly, tilting her head further back so that her throat felt bared.

â€œYou are so full of surprises,â€ he said, his gaze dragging across her face before locking on her eyes.

Hermione rolled her eyes briefly.

â€œDo you say that to every girl?â€ she said in a sarcastically sweet tone.

She didnâ€™t bother with the outer walls as he dived into her consciousness. It was the process of having them breached that made her head ache the most. She already felt reasonably confident in her ability to feign that they were easily cracked.

He didnâ€™t make the invasion painful. Which startled her. She had assumed that legilimency was inherently painful. Instead it felt like her mind was a pensive he was simply dropping into. Her consciousness and his merged.

He seemed to be taking in her natural mental state.

Without the pain of the legilimency attack, Hermione was able to be more nuanced and intentional in her strategy. She shuffled her memories about with false carelessness, drawing his attention and then slipping certain ones off into further corners of her mind.

Itâ€”was like learning to dance. Or perhaps learning martial arts. All the movement was done slowly. Without force.

He gave her time to learn the technique. Feel what it was like to do it properly. Going over the forms. Drilling it again and again until she could do it instinctively, without needing to think.

At length he withdrew and glanced down at his wrist. â€œWeâ€™ve gone overtime.â€

â€œOh,â€ she said quietly, still mentally preoccupied by the technique sheâ€™d been trying to get right.

He stared down at her until she straightened and looked up at him.

â€œDo you have any information this week?â€

â€œNot really. There are more vampires arriving from Romania this month. No specific details yet.â€

â€œIfâ€”â€œ Hermione hesitated.

He quirked an eyebrow at her, staring down and waiting.

â€œIfâ€”we needed something. Would you be able to get it for us?â€ she asked.

â€œIt would depend on what it is.â€

â€œA book.â€

He snorted.

â€œItâ€™s called Secrets of the Darkest Art. Iâ€™ve tried everything I can to find it. But the Orderâ€™s resources are limited.â€

â€œIâ€™ll see what I can do.â€ He gave an irritated sigh.

â€œBe careful,â€ she found herself saying.

He looked surprised.

â€œYou wonâ€™t want Voldemort to know youâ€™re looking for it.â€

â€œHow important is this book?â€ he asked with narrowed eyes.

â€œI donâ€™t know. It might be nothing. Or it might be very important. Butâ€”donâ€™t blow your cover for it.â€

He rolled his eyes.

â€œAs if I would,â€ he muttered before eying her sharply. â€œYou should go. Iâ€™m sure Potter will be pining for you.â€

Hermione gathered up her satchel of potion ingredients and slipped out of the shack.

Malfoy was staring after her contemplatively as she closed the door and apparated away.

When she got back to Grimmauld Place, she was pensive as she bottled and prepped ingredients.

Malfoy was not what she had expected.

He was far less cruel than she had anticipated. She kept expecting his malice to suddenly cut through his facade. But either he was less malicious than sheâ€™d thought, or he wanted something more complex and nuanced from her interactions with him. She already felt almost certain he didnâ€™t have any particular inclination towards hurting her.

She couldnâ€™t place what he wanted.

Severus had been right. Malfoy was already proving to be an excellent spy. All the information heâ€™d given Moody had been high quality and useful. The Order had successfully raided a prison and gotten more than fifty people out.

However, his motive remained a mystery.

She couldnâ€™t understand what he could possibly get from spying. With his placement in Voldemortâ€™s army, heâ€™d surely reap vast rewards with the Orderâ€™s demise.

If the Order won, even with a pardon heâ€™d undoubtedly become a pariah in the wizarding world for the rest of his life. Spies and traitors earned little respect, no matter how vital their contributions were.

Besidesâ€”Lucius Malfoy was a devoted follower of Voldemort. He blamed Narcissaâ€™s death on Ron and Harry, and directed almost all his energy to exacting revenge on them. While Draco might not share that sentimentâ€”setting himself at odds with his father felt dubious. Heâ€™d modeled himself so carefully after his sire back in school, and had been incensed by his fatherâ€™s imprisonment in Azkaban at the end of fifth year.

Hermione laid out a tray full of dittany and cast a heat charm with the tip of her wand. Massaging her temple slightly with her other hand as she watched the leaves steadily dry.

Malfoy was not interested in her; not physically. At least no more than a man tended to be interested in any random woman. Sheâ€™d studied the physiology of sexual attraction and he showed almost none of the signs, even after spending several minutes staring baldly at her naked reflection.

She flushed. The experience ranked unequivocally as the most embarrassing moment of her life.

So what was it all about? Why the kissing and groping? If it was all to provoke and anger her, the question of why still stood.

Why did he want to provoke her? What was driving the various tactics he was employing?

Initially he had clearly expected her to be so filled with hatred for him that she couldnâ€™t restrain it. Then, when heâ€™d aggressively snogged her to break through her occlumency shields, heâ€™d seemed to think he could use it to get her too consumed by emotions to think clearly. The way heâ€™d appraised her in the mirror had also been clearly intended to sting.

He wanted her to hate him.

But when heâ€™d realized she was an occlumens, he'd apparently decided to switch tactics again. Heâ€™d finally realized why he couldnâ€™t easily provoke her, and adapted once more.

But adapted for what? Â What was the point?

She couldnâ€™t understand it.

Hermione placed all the dry dittany leaves inside a large pestle, and began grinding them into powder.

â€œMione?â€ Charlie popped his head into her potion supply closet.

â€œYes?â€

â€œSnape dropped by earlier looking for you.â€

â€œOh. Did he say why?â€

â€œHad a new recipe for you, I think. Gave it to Poppy. To heal some new curse he helped invent.â€

Charlieâ€™s expression was twisted with anger. Many of the Order members blamed Severus for every curse developed in Voldemortâ€™s curse division. They thought that if Severus were really on the Orderâ€™s side, heâ€™d find a way to sabotage the entire thing.

Hermione rolled her eyes.

â€œYou know if he werenâ€™t there, weâ€™d lose dozens more people before weâ€™d figure out the countercurses. His information is vital for giving me time to prepare.â€

â€œYeah, and how many of our people do you reckon heâ€™s killed getting that information? Those are our people theyâ€™re experimenting on to make the spells. Heâ€™s murdering people, but itâ€™s alright â€˜cause heâ€™s sending us intelligence on countercurses. Does it really work that way?â€

Hermione stilled from her dittany grinding.

â€œHeâ€™s a spy, Charlie. Those are the kinds of things they have to do to maintain their cover. If he blew it to save a group of prisoners or tried to sabotage the place, Voldemort would just create a new one and weâ€™d lose the intelligence. The loss would never pay off in the long run.â€

â€œSo you say,â€ Charlie said, his lips thin and his eyes hard, he turned and walked away.

Hermione ground the dittany for a few more minutes before funneling it into a jar.

Severus must have developed a potion for healing the acid curse. She hoped it was different from the one heâ€™d been working on when she stopped by Spinnerâ€™s End.

She had no acromantula venom. Ministry issued identification was required to buy from apothecaries. She would have try to find a source from the black market; it would probably cost several hundred gallons. The Order was low on funds.

The Goblins had taken a neutral position in the war, but while Gringotts remained open to the Order, getting into the bank for money without being arrested was a challenge. Not to mention that being a Muggle-born was an imprisonable offense.

Most members of the Resistance were unemployable, either by blood or association.

It was fortunate that Harry had a large vault, because they probably would have been starved out of existence otherwise.

If the potion required acromantula venomâ€”well, hopefully Severus would be able to give her a few drops. If not, she doubted the Order would budget for her to buy any unless the curse was being used constantly.

She crossed her fingers and went to find Poppy.

The hospital ward was crowded again.

The rescue at the prison had been successful, but many of the prisoners had injuries from torture or were malnourished. There had been a firefight during the escape, and some brutal curses had been used.

Those with minor injuries had been sent to some of the other safe houses, but Grimmauld Place kept the most complex and difficult injuries for Hermione and Poppy to care for.

Poppy was hovering over Rolanda Hoochâ€™s bed. A tiny pinprick incision in Hoochâ€™s trachea kept reappearing and slowly growing despite all their efforts to heal it. Whomever was on duty in the hospital ward had to keep a two minute timer running in a constant cycle to monitor it.

â€œAny change?â€ Hermione asked, leaning down and examining the injury alongside Poppy.

â€œOh, Hermione, youâ€™re back,â€ Poppy said in a sad voice. â€œSeverus came and looked at it. He said it isnâ€™t one of Voldemortâ€™s new ones. Soâ€”itâ€™s likely a miscast curse.â€

Hermione sighed with relief before a sharp wave of guilt struck her. If it was a miscast curse, they were unlikely to encounter it again. But it also meant that theyâ€™d likely be unable to heal Rolanda. Hermione had tried without success to deconstruct the injury with spell analysis, trying to unravel it. The structure was so mangled and inconsistent it was impossible to neutralise.

â€œHow much longer do you think the healing spells will work?â€ Pomfrey quietly asked, staring sadly at her longtime colleague.

Hermione mentally calculated the time that had passed since Madam Hooch had been brought in. It was an obscure piece of knowledge but eventually healing charms ceased working when used in too great a frequency. Even magic couldnâ€™t force a body to keep repairing itself beyond a certain point.

â€œIf we keep healing it every two minutes the spells will probably continue working for another twenty hours,â€ Hermione told her gently.

Poppy nodded and tucked the blankets gently around Rolandaâ€™s body.

â€œSeverus left a new recipe for you,â€ she told Hermione. â€œHe said you should get a flagon ready.â€

Poppy reached into her pocket and withdrew a small roll of parchment and a vial.

Hermione lifted the vial up into the light.

Two drops of Acromantula venom. Probably worth more than fifty galleons.

She couldnâ€™t afford to make any mistakes. She slipped the vial into her pocket and unfurled the recipe to see what it would require to brew.

She had all the ingredients. Except fluxweed, which she had to harvest under a full moon. She calculated the next lunar cycle. Sheâ€™d have to wait for a week before sheâ€™d have everything she needed to make a batch.

If the curse were as serious as Severus had indicated, she would have to hope that there would be no skirmishes before the full moon. Which was likely a delusional notion.

At the end of the recipe, Severus had included the counter spell for the acid curse in his spiky handwriting. She reviewed it. It was simple, as he had said.

Hermione copied the countercurse onto a fresh sheet of parchment. An injury involving acid would need to be countered immediately. Waiting a few extra seconds to call a healer or apparate the wounded could add days to the recovery. The countercurse was simple enough; every Resistance member could learn it.

She wrote a brief note of explanation, and with a flick of her wand folded the note into a paper aeroplane and sent it zooming through the house to find Harry.

â€œWould you be able to take your shift early?â€ Poppy said.

Hermione looked up and realised Poppy was looking grey with grief.

â€œOf course,â€ Hermione said quickly.

â€œI want to write Filius, Pomona, and Minerva. They might want to come say their goodbyes,â€ Poppy said, shoulders drooping. â€œThe notes on what Iâ€™ve done are all in the logbook, and I just resealed the incision. So you can start a two minute count now.â€

Hermione watched Poppy Pomfrey as she walked with slow, heavy steps out of the hospital ward.

Hermione went over and glanced over the logbook. There were no surprises in it. She walked quietly from bed to bed. Everyone was still asleep, and a few were dosed with Draught of Living Death. It was a method of keeping them alive while certain, slow brewing potions were being made to cure them. She ran a precautionary diagnostic on each body, and ran through a mental checklist of which potions she needed to attend to. She needed to send out the first doses of wolfsbane potion to all the Lycanthropes in the Order.

It was a quiet day in the hospital ward. Aside from the constant recasting of the healing charm on Madam Hooch, most of the other injuries simply required careful supervision and time.

Hermione sat and speculated about what Malfoy might be like during their next meeting.

The fact he was also a natural occlumens wasâ€”problematic, to put it in the mildest of terms.

It meant his control ran deep. Trying to find her way in and make him loyal would be nearly impossible if he was able to winnow away and contain any effect she had on him.

If she wanted to have any chance of succeeding, she would have to be slow and insidious. To dig herself so deep into his psyche that he couldnâ€™t drag or filter her out. Find a way into his heart. The one place that no amount of occlumency could block or sequester.

She shivered slightly.

She had never felt cruel before. Cold. Unfeeling. Sheâ€™d been called those things, and believed they might be true. But cruel was a line she had always considered herself above. But what she was contemplating was possibly one of the cruelest things she could conceive of.

She squashed the hesitation.

He was the one who had demanded her.

Now and after the war.

She was well within her rights to ensure he paid full price for his demands. If he didnâ€™t want her, he shouldnâ€™t have asked.

She steeled herself, and summoned a book from her bag.

Chapter End Notes

"Boy with a box of sweets" by _knar.m_

Flashback 5

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

April 2002

Â 

The following Tuesday, Malfoy behaved much in the way he had the week before.

He taught her occlumency, letting her practice the forms and techniques. He didnâ€™t make it hurt. He barely spoke a word to her. He only touched her once, to tilt her head further back in order to make eye contact. And thenâ€”while he was in her mindâ€”she could feel his hand still resting on her neck, his thumb against her throat.

He didnâ€™t need to touch her. She knew. He could easily perform legilimency on her from several feet away.

He didnâ€™t pry. Didnâ€™t poke his head into memories that she overtly did not want him in. He just let her use his presence as a sort of practice dummy for learning evasive mental manoeuvring.

When he withdrew, she stared up at him curiously.

â€œWhere did you learn that? Iâ€™m assuming your aunt didnâ€™t use the technique.â€

â€œShe did not.â€ His teeth bared slightly as he said it. â€œI read about it in a book. Malfoy Manor has a large library. It wouldnâ€™t work with most people, only other natural occlumens. Even though anyone can potentially learn occlumency or legilimency to some degree, itâ€™s always either painful or so subtle they can barely even feel it happening.â€

He looked at her and added with a smirk â€œYou could say Iâ€™m experimenting on you.â€

Hermione rolled her eyes.

â€œDid the book require physical contact too?â€ she said in a sweet voice, eyeing his hand pointedly.

She immediately regretted saying it.

His hand tensed slightly, just enough to shift from resting to holding. His eyes darkened as his irises expanded incrementally.

â€œNo.Thatâ€”is just because I can.â€

He smirked as he pulled her forwards and dipped his head to kiss her.

It was a cold kiss. His lips pressed against hers werenâ€™t wanting or passionate.

It was simply a reminder.

That he could.

That he was being restrained. That, if he wanted to, he could demand anything he desired from her and she had already consented to give it to him.

Hermione didnâ€™t respond to the kiss. She just let his cold lips meet hers without resisting until he pulled away again.

â€œDo you have any information this week?â€ she asked as his hand slid off of her and he stepped back.

He drew a scroll from his robes and handed it to her.Â 

â€œSpell analysis and countercurse information for new curses from the Dark Lordâ€™s curse development division,â€ he said. â€œThereâ€™s a new set being taught currently.â€

Hermione slid the scroll open and glanced over the information listed. Severus had already given the Order all the details about the curses, but Malfoy couldnâ€™t know that. That it had occurred to him was a sign of how useful and proactive he was able to be. If they lost Severus, Malfoy was able to provide both types of intelligence. Â 

An excellent spy.

â€œThis is invaluable information,â€ she said, packing it carefully into her satchel.

He shrugged.

â€œNo, really. This will save lives. I didnâ€™t even think to ask for this. That you didâ€”I donâ€™t know how to thank you enough.â€

Malfoy looked vaguely uncomfortable with the gratitude.

â€œWhatever. It was an obvious piece of information to provide. The death rate in your Resistance is getting noticeable.â€

Hermione felt the blood drain from her face, and he stared at her. â€œHow much longer do you think you all can keep fighting?â€Â 

Her throat tightened. â€œAs long as it takes or until thereâ€™s no one left. Thereâ€™s no plan B, Malfoy. Thereâ€™s no surrendering for us.â€

He nodded. â€œGood to know.â€

Then he paused as though abruptly recalling something. â€œIs there a safe house involving a lot of children up in Caithness?â€

Hermione blanched. â€œWhyâ€”why do you ask?â€

His face grew hard. â€œItâ€™s been noticed. Someone will likely be sent to investigate by the end of the week. Donâ€™t let them find anything.â€

Hermione nodded sharply. â€œI have to go,â€ she said, rushing to the door.

She summoned a corporeal patronus through sheer willpower. Theyâ€™d become a struggle for her ever since sheâ€™d obliviated her parents. It had taken her several years to regain the ability, and theyâ€™d never fully regained the silver luminescence theyâ€˜d had during her fifth year. Â 

â€œFind Minerva McGonagall,â€ she said. â€œTell her to prep for evacuation.â€

As her otter scampered away, she cast another. The sleek, translucent creature stood on its hind legs and stared up at her.

â€œGo find Kingsley Shacklebolt. Tell him we need a new safe house for Caithness.â€

Â Then she apparated away to find Moody.

The process of evacuating children was slow and arduous. All of them were unable to apparate themselves, which meant that all available and easily contacted Resistance members had to be mobilised to carry them to safety via broomstick, repeated side-along apparition, or on the backs of thestrals. Creating portkeys was too time-consuming. None of the safe houses could risk having a floo connection.

The remote location had been a strategic choice. The hope was that it would pass unnoticed by Voldemort despite the presence of a great many odd children in such a small town. In retrospect, it was sheer luck they had succeeded for so long. There were few good options for trying to rehouse so many children in such a range of ages.

They had no backup safehouse for so many. The children had to be split up throughout dozens of safe houses. Ferrying them in small groups to other parts of the UK and then re-settling them, expanding rooms and transfiguring new beds.

Hermione made three trips. After she returned from the last one, she slumped against a wall with exhaustion. Sheâ€™d apparated several toddlers all the way to Northern Ireland. They had vomited, and screamed, and sobbed with each progressive apparition. Sheâ€™d been forced to stop and console them until they would hold still enough for her to safely apparate again without splinching anyone.

Minerva appeared and stopped in front of Hermione, her expression conflicted.

â€œYour information?â€ Minerva asked quietly.

Hermione nodded, â€œMoodyâ€™s going to tell anyone who asks that he learned about it while interrogating a snatcher.â€

Minerva gave a sharp nod of acknowledgement and pressed her lips together, staring at Hermione for several seconds.

â€œYou are a good girl; I hope thatâ€™s never doubted by anyone. Are youâ€”alright?â€

â€œHe hasnâ€™t done anything to me.â€ It was all the reassurance Hermione could give.

Something untwisted itself in Minervaâ€™s expression. She nodded sharply and then swept away to help take down the wards and shrink the furniture.

Hermione glanced at the time. It was a full moon that night and she needed fluxweed.

She stood up and walked out of the manse until she reached the edge of the anti-apparition barriers. Then she began the series of jumps back towards London.

She stopped in a large field she often started foraging at near the Forest of Dean. Holding her wand out, she cast a point me charm and followed it in search of the weedy plant.

The bright light of the moon cast the sea of grass in sharp shadows. The clustered trees nearby rose up like a black curtain against the bright night sky. As Hermione slid down a small slope, a gust of wind shifted across the field, rippling the grass so that it whispered softly. As the sliding, shifting sound faded, a low howl emerged from the trees downwind of Hermione.Â 

She froze.

A werewolf.

There had never been werewolves in the area before. She had been so tired and distracted she hadnâ€™t even thought to take any precautions.

Then another howl emerged. Further away. To her right.

And another howl.

There was a pack of werewolves in the Forest of Dean.

She almost apparated away but paused, hesitating. She needed fluxweed. If she didnâ€™t get it that night, she wouldnâ€™t be able to get any until the next month. She had to make the potion. Severus would not offer advice or take the time to invent potions unless it were urgent.

She bolted down the hill in the direction the locator spell was indicating.

Another howl. Closer.

She whipped the silver knife from her pocket and began slicing sections of fluxweed as fast as she could without affecting the potency. There wasnâ€™t enough.

She recast the locator spell and ran in the direction her wand sent her. As she did so, she looked up to see the sharp elongated shadow of a werewolf sauntering down the slope towards her.

She skidded and nearly fell as she reached a spot with several fluxweed and cut them down in seconds.

The werewolf was less than twelve feet away and crouching into a lunge when she finally spun on her heel and apparated to the closest place she could think off.Â 

Hermione reappeared on the steps of Malfoyâ€™s unplottable shack. Gasping for air, she dropped down onto the top step and sat panting as she tried to recover her breath.

She leaned against the door and closed her eyes as her heart continued pounding violently.

She was terribly out of shape. She couldnâ€™t believe how quickly sheâ€™d tired out from running. Her oesophagus burned, and there was a sharp, stabbing pain through her lungs every time she breathed in.

Aside from tromping through the countryside in search of potion ingredients, Hermione didnâ€™t engage in any physically strenuous activities. After sheâ€™d been pulled from fighting, she hadnâ€™t had time to drill or practice or even worry about her physical endurance.

Merlin, she was useless. If she ever found herself on a battlefield again, sheâ€™d probably be cut down in seconds.Â 

Her breathing had evened, but she remained in place for another minute as she tried to will her heartbeat into slowing.

The door behind her abruptly wrenched open, and she toppled backwards into the shack.

Her head banged into the wood and stars flashed before her eyes as she discovered Malfoy staring down at her, enraged.

â€œThe fuck, Granger, what are you doing?â€

â€œMalfoy?â€ she said, staring up at him in confusion. â€œWhat are you doing here?â€

â€œWhat am I doing here?â€ He snarled. â€œYou activated the wards. I assumed you needed me for something.â€Â 

â€œOh,â€ Hermione said, heat staining her cheeks. â€œI didnâ€™t realize the monitor ward extended beyond the room. I didnâ€™t mean to bother you.â€ Â 

She rolled over and stood up.

Malfoy looked her up and down.

â€œWhat were you doing?â€Â 

â€œI needed fluxweed harvested under a full moon,â€ she said, finding that she was still panting slightly. â€œAnd there were werewolves. I couldnâ€™t wait until next month. So I had to run away and try gathering as I went. But Iâ€™m not very fit anymore. It winded me. This was the closest place to apparate to. So I was trying to get my breath back.â€

â€œWhere were you getting fluxweed?â€ His tone had an edge to it.

She gestured over here shoulder. â€œThereâ€™s a field near here, in the Forest of Dean. Itâ€™s one of the places I usually go to find potion ingredients.â€

â€œUsuallyâ€”â€

There was a pause.

â€œYou wander the countryside at night. Foraging?â€ His expression had become frozen.

â€œYes.â€ Hermione nodded, eying him. â€œI mentioned this.â€

â€œNo... You said you were getting potion ingredients. I assumed that meant you had a supplier.â€ His expression was growing hard and his eyes were accusing as though sheâ€™d lied to him.

Hermione stared at him with disbelief. â€œIâ€™m a terrorist. It costs a small fortune to buy potion ingredients off the black market. Iâ€™m not going to waste my budget when I can get it for free and at better quality by doing the work myself.â€

â€œSo youâ€™re traipsing about the countryside of magical Britain, at night, to gather potion ingredients? Alone?â€

â€œObviously,â€ Hermione said, sniffing. â€œThatâ€™s why we meet on Tuesday mornings after I finish.â€

There was a long silence.

â€œYou cannot.â€ He announced it in a tone of finality. â€œYou will stop. You will stay inside whatever sad little safehouse they keep you healing in, and you will not go foraging again.â€

Hermione stared at him indignantly for several astonished seconds. â€œI will most certainly not! You donâ€™t control what I do.â€

His expression hardened, a predatory glint appearing in his eyes. â€œI do, actually. Have you forgotten? I own you. If I tell you to sit in this room and stare at the wall until next week, you gave your word that youâ€™d do it.â€

Hermione felt rage bloom through her. â€œNo, I wouldnâ€™t. Because you gave your word not to interfere with my work in the Order. Foraging is part of my work. Itâ€™s non-negotiable. If you want to control everything I do, youâ€™ll have to wait until we win. You gave your word too.â€

Malfoy stood glaring at her, his eyes calculating. Then he abruptly changed the subject. â€œSo, you outran werewolves?â€

She flushed.

â€œNo. I meanâ€”they werenâ€™t very close until the end. I only ran maybe a hundred yards at most.â€

â€œAnd youâ€™re still panting from that?â€ he said sceptically.

â€œIâ€”I donâ€™t really do any fieldwork aside from foraging. Thereâ€™s not much of a need to work on my stamina,â€ she said, drawing herself up defensively.

Malfoyâ€™s mouth suddenly dropped open; he snapped it shut and dropped a hand over his eyes for several seconds as though trying to compose himself. Then he dragged his hand away and stared at her.

â€œWhen exactly was the last time anyone drilled you? I assume you practise basic duelling, given youâ€™re so important they wonâ€™t let you fight anymore. Surely, since they let you go out, alone, in the middle of the night; your defence must be second to none.â€

Hermione dropped her eyes and fidgeted with the strap of her satchel. â€œIâ€™m very busy. Part of the reason they pulled me from combat is because there are a lot of other things Iâ€™m needed for.â€

â€œHow long has it been, Granger?â€ His voice was hard.

She glanced around the room. The stupid place didnâ€™t even have anything she could pretend to be looking at. She focused on a knot in the floorboards.

â€œItâ€™sâ€”probably been about two and a half years,â€ she said quietly.

He dropped his face into his hand and was silent, as though he couldnâ€™t even bear to look at her.

Hermione rolled her eyes.Â 

â€œWell, Iâ€™ll be going then,â€ she said at length in a crisp voice. â€œSorry I bothered you. It wonâ€™t happen again.â€

â€œIâ€™m training you,â€ Malfoy said abruptly, straightening and glaring down at her.

â€œWhat?â€ She stared at him in confusion.

â€œIâ€™m going to train you,â€ he said slowly. â€œSince getting you to stop is apparently not an option.
