Given the way they all fight, Iâ€™m sure anyone else I got would be shite at occlumency and likely to eventually be picked up in a skirmish.â€

Well, Malfoyâ€™s Slytherin self-preservation instinct was certainly still strong. Hermione sighed with irritation.

â€œItâ€™s really not necessary. I donâ€™t fight. There are rarely any issues when Iâ€™m foraging. You neednâ€™t worry that youâ€™ll be inconvenienced by losing your precious war prize.â€

â€œReally?â€ he said, his voice airy as he stepped toward her. â€œYou donâ€™t want to? Because youâ€™ll be done learning occlumency shortly. I would think youâ€™d prefer to fill your time with duelling practice rather than some of the other activities I could demand you participate in.â€

Hermione glared at him.

She doubted he had any intention of following through with his thinly veiled threat given that heâ€™d shown no particular inclination. If he wanted to teach her duelling, there was no harm in it. She certainly would prefer it. She needed to keep spending time with him. She wouldnâ€™t be able to succeed in her mission if they werenâ€™t spending time with each other.

â€œFine,â€ she snapped, her expression twisting in faint derision.

â€œYou look so bitter,â€ his expression was vicious with mockery. â€œYouâ€™d think I just demanded you fuck me rather than not. Disappointed?â€

â€œOnly in your dreams,â€ she said, shooting him a glare.

â€œEvery night.â€

She rolled her eyes.

â€œDo you buy all your company?â€ she said, her voice sweet and her expression condescending. He didnâ€™t even blink.

â€œI enjoy professionalism,â€ he said blandly, staring up at the ceiling as though he were reciting a mantra. â€œClear lines. No drama. Iâ€™m not obliged to pretend that I care.â€

He sneered at the last word, as though caring were the most offensive concept known to man.

â€œOf course. How very you.â€

â€œQuite,â€ he agreed with a thin smile.

There was a silence. Hermione wanted to tell him he was vile, but she was certain he already knew. She felt tired and it made her want to be cruel.

â€œDo you talk to them and cry, telling them about how sad and lonely your life is? Or just bend them over without a word?â€ she asked, her voice lilting with the taunt.

His eyes flashed.

â€œWant me to show you?â€ His voice was sharp and cold as a splinter of ice.

Hermione's near run-in with the werewolves had the adrenaline still spiking through her. She was used to the high stress of the hospital ward, but it was always someone elseâ€™s life. She felt high on the rush from her near brush with death. She understood Harry suddenly. She felt like she could do anything. Â 

A sudden thought came to her at Malfoyâ€™s threat.

She stared up at him, raising her chin.

â€œYou wonâ€™t.â€

His eyes got cruel, but before he could respond she continued. â€œIt would be too real for you. Doing it with someone you know. Someone youâ€™d see again. It would mess with those clear lines.â€Â 

â€œTesting me, Granger?â€ His voice was low and caressing.

She stared at him.

â€œI suppose I am,â€ she said coolly, but her heart was beginning to pound at the realisation of what sheâ€™d just done.

He leaned down, his eyes hard, until his face was centimetres from her own.

â€œStrip.â€

Hermione didnâ€™t waver and neither did he, so he stepped slowly closer until she shuffled back. He loomed over her. His eyes glittered.

â€œItâ€™s killing you, isnâ€™t it? Wondering. You expected me to do this to you right off. So waitingâ€”trying to guess when I might get around to itâ€”that bothers you more than the thought of actually having to fuck me.â€

He sneered. â€œWellâ€”you have my attention. Strip.â€

Hermione stared up at him, feeling her face grow hot even as the rest of her body became increasingly cold.

â€œYou donâ€™t even want me. Why did you include me in your demands? What is the point?â€ she asked. Her voice was angry and confused. Â 

He smirked. â€œYouâ€™re right. I donâ€™t want you.â€

It shouldnâ€™t have hurt to hear him say it, but somehow it did. Especially set with the vindictive mockery in his expression as he stared down at her.Â 

â€œHowever, owning you is never going to get old. â€˜Now and after the war.â€™ I canâ€™t wait to see how bitterly I can make you regret those words. So, strip.â€ His voice dropped low. â€œOr did you want me to do it for you?â€Â 

Hermioneâ€™s hands went up to the collar of her shirt and she gripped it defensively. She was terrified and enraged to the point she thought she might start crying. He did own her. Sheâ€™d agreed to it. Her jaw trembled and her hands started shaking.

â€œPower gets you off, doesnâ€™t it?â€ Her voice shook with rage as she forced herself to unfasten the top button on her shirt. â€œHurting someone who canâ€™tâ€”or wonâ€™tâ€”fight back. Using what people care about to torture and cage them, and force them to do things. You are just the same as Voldemort.â€

The malice in Malfoyâ€™s expression abruptly vanished and he paled. The check on his rage suddenly disappeared and darkness and magic poured off of him in waves, filling and writhing through the air.Â 

The ice-cold fury that appeared in his expression was staggering. His eyes turned black, his lips curled in a snarl, and he kept getting paler and paler as he stared at her. Â 

Hermioneâ€™s eyes widened in terror and she cringed away, bracing herself.

There was a tidal wave of fury rising up around him.

â€œGet out!â€ he snapped.

She stared at him, unmoving. Like an animal petrified by fear.

He snarled with rage. Suddenly the door to the shack slammed open so violently the hinges snapped and it plummeted to the floor.

â€œGET OUT!â€ he roared.

Hermione did not need further invitation. She bolted for the door and apparated the second she felt herself clear the wards.

When she got through the door at Grimmauld Place, she collapsed onto the floor of the foyer, shaking with terror.

Stupid. Stupid. Stupid. She berated herself, trying to force herself to breathe. She felt like she was having a panic attack. Â 

She couldnâ€™t understand what had prompted her to try provoking him. If it werenâ€™t the middle of the night she would have banged her head into the floor with frustration over her idiocy.

After all the countless times she had scolded Harry, warning him about the consequences of his stupid thrill-seeking; she might have him beaten.

She was an idiot.

She pressed her hand over her pounding heart and dropped her face into the crook of her elbow. She whimpered quietly.

Draco Dormiens Nunquam Titillandus.

Except she hadnâ€™t tickled a sleeping dragon. Her actions appeared to have been more in the realm of waltzing up and smacking it upside the head with a beater bat.

They needed Malfoy. They desperately needed him, and a bit of adrenaline made her lose her head.

He was right, she couldnâ€™t handle the dread. The constant anticipation. Exhausting herself wondering about what it was he wanted. What he intended to do to her. Constantly waiting for the other shoe to drop. It was eating her alive.

If he was going to hurt her or fuck her, she just wanted to know and have him do it.

Going to him every week, uncertain of what he might do to her nextâ€”

It was breaking her to pieces.

She bit down on her lip as she huddled against the door. She tried not to burst into tears as her rush of norepinephrine lost its hold on her, and she found herself sharply dropped low. She was awash in horror and despair.Â 

She buried her face in her hands and sobbed quietly.

Her anxiety had quite possibly just cost the Order the war. Or at least countless lives.

She had to find a way to fix it.Â 

She wrapped her arms around herself, and tried to calm down and think.

Breathe. Breathe. Breathe.

When her chest finally stopped stuttering, she stood up and brushed away the tears.

She made her way up to her potion supply closet, she stored the fluxweed and spent several minutes trying to organise her thoughts and force her hands to stop shaking.

She went on to her room.

The door was ajar. Which was odd, because both she and Ginny were generally fastidious about keeping their door shut and locked. Grimmauld Place wasnâ€™t broadly accessible to the Resistance, but there were occasionally nosy individuals with little respect for privacy or personal possessions.

Hermione peeked in and then jumped back in surprise.

Ginny and Harry were half-naked and, if they werenâ€™t already, they appeared mere seconds from shagging. Â 

Hermione cast a quick privacy charm on the door and hurried away. On the landing of the steps she paused and hesitated. Grimmauldâ€™s rooms were crammed currently. A number of the older children from Caithness had been brought there.

The parlour downstairs was currently occupied by all the insomniacs. There werenâ€™t many places left to sleep.

She was so tired. Her bout of crying left her feeling internally hollow.

She crawled into a window seat and tried to drift off, but her mind wouldnâ€™t quiet itself. She kept replaying her conversation with Malfoy. Fretting over the potion she needed to brew. Re-living the moment all the rage poured off Malfoy and he roared at her.

He hadnâ€™t hurt her.

Heâ€™d had every opportunity and more than sufficient fury, but heâ€™d held it back and driven her off instead.

A murderous Death Eater with some sort of moral code. An oxymoron if ever there were one.

It had to be connected to his motive for aiding the Order.

What did he want?

It aggravated her deeply that she couldnâ€™t figure it out.Â 

After tossing about on the window seat for half an hour, she sat up with a sigh. She didnâ€™t want to try brewing Severusâ€™ potion until she was rested. She clambered up and went to the uppermost floor of the house. There was a practice room there.

She looked in and found it empty.

She made her way into the middle of the room and, drawing her wand, began making her way through some of the duelling poses.

When sheâ€™d returned from her healer training throughout Europe, sheâ€™d only participated in two small skirmishes before the Order decided the pull her permanently from combat. After the years away sheâ€™d gotten rusty, far less proficient in duelling than anyone else in her age group. The rest of DA were fast and cast powerful spells, dodging and weaving while maintaining excellent precision even from a distance. Â 

Healing was subtle. It almost always required holding back. Close work with attention to tiny details. Â 

Trying to duel again was such a reversal in the technique that sheâ€™d been awful.

Ron and Harry devoted quite a bit of time trying to help her catch up, but before sheâ€™d managed to do so, Kingsley advised pulling her entirely from combat. No one made so much as a murmur in disagreement.

Hermione understood the rationale, but years later the decision still hurt. Sheâ€™d felt as though sheâ€™d failed somehow and was being shunted offâ€”away from everyone else.

The original DA had become a tight-knit combat unit that she was not a member of.

Hermione bit her lip and cast a protego as powerfully as she could. The shield bloomed in front of her. Â 

She sighed in relief as she withdrew the spell. At least she could still manage that.

She cast a series of hexes at the dummies across the room. Half of them hit their targets. None of them precisely.

She flushed and tried again. She was somehow worse the second time.

Hermione berated herself. She was standing still. Not on a battlefield. Not while having any spells directed back at her.

She was shite.

In the unlikely event that Malfoy trained her, he would tear her to pieces for how inept sheâ€™d become.

She squared her shoulders and tried again.

She cast a few more complex curses.

Well, she could manage that.

Â It wasnâ€™t a lack of proficiency when it came to combat magic. She was simply terrible at the actual combat aspect.

That was some consolation.

Well, not really.

She kept going until she was so tired her hands were shaking from exhaustion. Then she dropped onto one the training mats and fell asleep.

â€œHermione, bloody hell? Why are you in here?â€

Hermione squinted the next morning and found Ron standing over her, flanked by Ginny, Neville, Dean, Seamus, Lavender, Parvati, Padma, Fred and Angelina.

She sat up with a groan and rubbed her eyes.

â€œâ€˜My bed got taken in the rehousing shuffle,â€ she lied, shooting Ginny a look. â€œI came here to sleep.â€

â€œOh,â€ said Ron. â€œWell, weâ€™re going to be practising an attack formation before Neville and Seamus have to head out on that recon mission. Soâ€”we need the room.â€

Hermione nodded and stood.

â€œCan I watch?â€ she found herself asking.

Ron furrowed his forehead and stared at her.

â€œSure. I guess. If you have time for it. Justâ€”keep a shield up. Lot of hexes will be going.Â 

Hermione backed into a corner and watched Ron lay out the strategy. She couldnâ€™t track all the terms they used. It wasnâ€™t traditional combat terminology, rather a sort of shorthand that had evolved among the fighters over time. Their own language.

As they scattered across the room, she cast a shield around herself. Ron activated one of the wards on the room with a charm, and then everyone started casting a series of hexes toward the walls.

The spells bounced off and ricocheted back and forth across the rooms. Soon the room was full of flying magic.

Hermione watched as the DA members began running through the attack formation. Their spells were all precise. Their shields powerful. None of them even got nicked by the flying spells. It was instinctive for them. They knew when their shields needed to be renewed. They knew how everyone else fought; who would cover for them. They fought closely and cast nonverbally.

Their combat skills were vastly superior to her own. It would take a miracle for her to catch up.

She watched them run through the formation twice before she turned and slipped out of the practice room.

She went to her potion supply closet, gathered up the ingredients, and got ready to begin brewing.

The following Tuesday she apparated into Whitecroft and approached the location of the shack slowly.

She wondered if Malfoy would be there. She prayed that he would.

She had no idea how to fix things if he refused to even appear. She could only hope that whatever was causing him to spy was sufficient motivation that her actions couldnâ€™t dissuade him.

If he werenâ€™t there, she would wait.

If he was thereâ€”she hoped he would just punish her and get it over with, rather than force her to continuously dread it.

The door had been repaired. She braced herself and pushed it open.

Empty.

After waiting for a minute she went over to the chair by the table. Her stomach was twisting itself in dread, and she tried to distract herself by reciting arithmancy formulas while she sat there.

She just needed to stop thinking about what might happen next.

Suddenly there was a sharp crack and she stood and turned sharply as Malfoy appeared. He stood staring at her, his expression indecipherable. Â 

Hermione didnâ€™t say anything. She just looked at him. She was relieved she wasnâ€™t trembling.

She forced herself to meet his gaze. That needle-like sensation of terror began lacing through her spine. She suddenly felt cold. She could feel the hair on the back of her neck stand on end as she braced herself.

She could see his jaw clench and he glanced away from her.

He was apparently not intending to speak first.

She took a deep breath. She needed him. He was clearly still furious with her but she had to fix it. Whatever it took.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€Â  she said desperately. â€œI lost my head and crossed a line. Iâ€™m sorry. Whatever I need to do to make it upâ€”Iâ€™ll do whatever you want. Just let me fix this.â€

Chapter End Notes

"Because I can," by _knar.m_.

Flashback 6

April 2002

Draco looked sharply at her, something she couldnâ€™t read flickering across his expression.

â€œItâ€™s fine,â€ he said in a hard voice. â€œWhen I said I wanted you willing, that meant you were allowed to say no. Although perhaps try saying it instead of purposely provoking me.â€

Hermione stared at him in shock.

He clenched his hand into a fist and pressed it against his forehead as though he had a headache.

â€œDo you want to continue with occlumency?â€ he asked.

Hermione shifted slightly but didnâ€™t answer. She felt knocked off kilter. The conversation hadnâ€™tâ€”she didnâ€™tâ€”

What did he mean?

Was it possibly a feint, so he could catch her off guard?

If she were allowed to say no to things, he certainly hadnâ€™t bothered to communicate that to her. In fact heâ€™d heavily implied the opposite. Althoughâ€”he hadnâ€™t really done much that wasnâ€™t primarily to just to provoke her.

Soâ€”

She eyed him warily.

Something that she said to him that night had accidentally struck a nerve. Deeply.

What had she said?

That power got him off. Hurting someone who couldnâ€™tâ€”or wouldnâ€™tâ€”fight back. Using what people cared about to torture and cage them and force them to do things. That he was just the same as Voldemort...

That he was just the same as Voldemort.

That was probably it. He probably regarded himself as better than his Master. Maybe he thought that if he helped the Order overthrow Voldemort that it would leave a vacuum of power that he could fill.

The thought made her insides twist.

Was that really it? Was he playing both sides against each other, thinking that he could seize power in the aftermath?

Perhaps he objected to Voldemortâ€™s reign of terror; the attacks used to frame the Order, and all the torture and experiments. Malfoy probably imagined heâ€™d rule in a genteel manner where women were ostensibly â€œwillingâ€ and executions were ceremonial.

Yetâ€”it seemed like heâ€™d been more than just offended. His rageâ€”the rage he carried was surely larger than merely ego or ambition.

Her wary expression seemed to annoy him. He hissed slightly and his teeth flashed.

â€œSuffice to say, Iâ€™m not going to hurt you,â€ he ground out. â€œSo stop looking at me as though you expect me to curse you in the back.â€

The words made Hermione flinch. If she werenâ€™t so desperate to ensure that heâ€™d keep spying for them, she would have sneered and asked why he hadnâ€™t made such an allowance for Dumbledore. He seemed to see the retort in her expression and his jaw twitched.

She bit her tongue and glanced awkwardly around the shack. â€œI do want to finish learning occlumency.â€

â€œAlright.â€

His tone was clipped, and he appeared to have boxed in his anger. His face smoothed into that cold, indolent mask once more. But his silver eyes continued to study her. She could almost feel his gaze against her skin.

He moved toward her.

He felt simultaneously the same, and yet different. As though he were going through the same motions, but more consciously than he had in the past. There was a subtle element of over-precision.

He tilted her head back with his fingertips. When she looked deep into his eyes, she could see a bitterness that she didnâ€™t think had been there before.

He sank painlessly into her mind.

It was more of the same for the next two weeks. More occlumency and a reserved Malfoy. Conversation remained stilted, although the intelligence he provided continued to flow generously and remained sound.

Hermione berated herself internally each week as he apparated away after exchanging less than a dozen words with her.

Her psychological sketch of him had stalled. Each week, she added more questions with no answers. The list of potential motives ranged from the magnanimous to the monstrous.

She could tell that she was almost done with occlumency training. Malfoyâ€™s invasions of her mind were growing agonizingly painful and aggressive as he tested her technique and abilities.

She was tempted to ask if he still intended to train her in dueling, but she was afraid to bring up the subject.

She was beginning to feel desperate.

When she got to the shack she paced nervously, trying to come up with some way of breaking through the awkwardness. There had to be some way to get through to him. Some weakness she could find to get inside.

Malfoy appeared in front of her with an abrupt crack, and seemed to wince slightly as he straightened.

Hermione had seen that subtle expression often enough to identify it immediately, no matter how carefully concealed. Without even pausing to think, she whipped her wand out and cast a rapid diagnostic on him.

Before she could glance down for the results, Malfoy lunged forward, knocked her wand away, and had her pinned to the wall.

â€œWhat are you doing?â€ he snarled.

Right. He probably wasnâ€™t in the habit of letting people cast magic in his direction.

She met his eyes steadily. â€œYouâ€™re hurt.â€

He snatched his hands away from her and stepped back.

â€œItâ€™s nothing,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™ll have it taken care of later.â€

Hermioneâ€™s eyes dropped down to the colours and details surrounding her wand, lying on the floor a few feet away, reading the most obvious parts.

â€œYouâ€™ve got several fractured ribs, a concussion, and internal bruising. Itâ€™ll take me ten minutes to fix it. Andâ€”â€œ she gave him a pointed look, â€œapparating will hurt even more the next time. If you leave the fractures and keep doing it, your ribs may fully break. You could puncture a lung. If there are shards, the ribs would have to be removed and regrown.â€

He stared at her for several moments before rolling his eyes. â€œFine.â€

She knelt down and grabbed her wand. â€œStripâ€”from the waist up.â€

He went still for a moment.

â€œI thought that was my line,â€ he finally said as he reached up stiffly and unfastened his cloak, letting it pool in a careless heap on the floor. â€œIf you wanted me so badly, you only needed to ask.â€

He leered at her in an overtly fake way.

Everyone had methods for handling pain. Harry got very quiet, while Ron would become what Fred and George had termed â€œbitchy.â€ Seamus and Charlie swore in such volume and length that they had to be silenced.

Pain clearly made Malfoy even more sarcastic than he already was.

At least that meant he was talking to her again.

Hermione rolled her eyes. â€œYes. Nothing gets me going like the sight of an abdomen mottled with purple and green bruising.â€

â€œI always knew you were a sadistic bitch.â€

The comment caught Hermione so off-guard she burst out laughing.

Malfoy appeared astonished by the success as he began unbuttoning his shirt and awkwardly trying to shrug it off.

He had a shoulder injury too.

She reached out slowly like she were approaching a defensive animal. He didnâ€™t flinch away, so she set to pulling his shirt off of him gently and taking in the damage.

He appeared to have been flung, extremely violently, intoâ€”something.

His shoulder had been dislocated, but he must have popped it back in place. His entire right side was completely covered in bruises. It was remarkable that his arm wasnâ€™t shattered.

â€œWhat happened?â€ she inquired with sincere curiosity.

â€œNew pack of werewolves,â€ he answered shortly. â€œThere were leadership issues.â€

â€œSo, what? You fought a werewolf alpha?â€ she asked skeptically as she started repairing his ribs.

â€œWell, he was strictly forbidden from biting or clawing, and I wasnâ€™t allowed to kill him. Butâ€”when youâ€™ve got beasts with a pack hierarchy and you try to run them without beating them into submission first, youâ€™re just waiting for an insurrection,â€ Malfoy explained as though such things were common knowledge.

â€œIs all this from winning or losing?â€ she asked as she repaired the fracture on another rib.

He glared at her. â€œWinning, obviously. I wouldnâ€™t have been apparating anywhere if Iâ€™d lost. Fucking animal didnâ€™t even think to use his wand. They all go feral once they start running in packs.â€

He rolled his eyes as he said it and then added â€œNow Iâ€™m ostensibly the alpha of a werewolf pack. Adds to my natural charm, I think. â€

â€œThe alpha is sure to try to kill you,â€ Hermione pointed out.

Malfoy snorted. â€œHe's welcome to try. It will take me less than a minute to take him down once Iâ€™m allowed to kill him.â€ He sneered.

Hermione didnâ€™t reply. With a nonverbal spell she summoned her satchel and pulled out the emergency kit she always kept with her.

â€œSit down and drink this,â€ she instructed as she handed him a potion. â€œItâ€™ll deal with the concussion you have.â€

While he was downing it, she rubbed her hands together to warm them and then dipped her fingers into a small jar of paste.

She eyed him thoughtfully for a moment before lightly setting her hand on his bare shoulder.

He nearly jumped out of his skin.

â€œRelax,â€ she said, feeling the muscles in his shoulders grow taut beneath her fingers. â€œIt wonâ€™t sink in well if youâ€™re tense.â€

Malfoy didnâ€™t relax at all.

She rolled her eyes.

She drew her fingers lightly over his shoulder, spreading the paste and letting him get used to the contact. The muscles in his shoulders flinched and twinged slightly. It reminded Hermione of petting a skittish horse.

Of all the contexts in which she had imagined Malfoy eventually half-naked in her presence, healing him had surprisingly not been one of them. Butâ€”she could use this to patch things and continue working on her initial strategy.

He was assuredly lonely. He seemed unsettled by physical contact that wasnâ€™t either violent or sexual.

She supposed that wasnâ€™t surprising. Who was there to be kind to him? By his account his brutal training with Bellatrix had been unimpeded by anyone, even his mother. The thought made her shiver slightly.

Crucioing a sixteen year old to teach him occlumency and then leaving him to pass out from it.

She could use that emptiness. That loneliness. The need for comfort was written into the human psyche. Malfoy might not even be conscious enough of the absence to be defensive. If she awakened that needâ€”

â€”sheâ€™d be in.

Non-sexual physical contact was something she was comfortable with. Touching bodies. Being soothing and comforting. It was, she realised, an unexpected advantage she held over Malfoy. He liked clear lines. She would blur them and then slip through the gaps.

She leaned forward, just slightly, so that her mouth was close to his ear. His skin smelled faintly of salt, along with subtle, biting undertones of oakmoss and the sharp green scent of papyrus.

â€œThis will hurt a bit,â€ she said softly.

Then she began to knead the muscle in order to force the healing paste deep into the tissue and restore the stretched tendons. If she didnâ€™t get it to sink in fully, the damage could become permanent and Malfoy might become prone to getting his shoulder dislocated.

â€œFuck,â€ he groaned. â€œYou are a bitch.â€

Her hands stilled for a moment before she resumed.

â€œThe claim has been made before,â€ she noted quietly.

That response seemed to catch Malfoy slightly off-guard. He subsided and clenched his jaw while she continued. Within a minute she was done but she continued massaging his shoulder. Gently. In a way that wasâ€”strictly speakingâ€”not medically necessary.

After an extra minute, she paused with her hands resting lightly on his shoulder.

â€œI need to finish up with your ribs now. Itâ€™s easiest if you lie back.â€

He sighed, and lay down on the floor. She stuffed his cloak behind his head, and shifted herself around so that she was sitting beside him.

He was staring at her with intense suspicion.

She busied herself with her healing kit, and fished out a large vial of serum. After a quick spell to clean the paste off her hands, she poured the viscous liquid into her palm. She spread it across his arm, side, and chest in small circular motions. She took note of where it vanished fastest, and added an additional layer of serum.

With her free hand she cast a new diagnostic charm. He had a kidney contusion too. She sighed faintly.

â€œYouâ€™ve got a bruised kidney. I donâ€™t have the potion for it with me, so youâ€™ll have to go see a healer for that. Itâ€™s not severe, but itâ€™ll hurt for a few days if you donâ€™t get it taken care of.â€

The bruises on his chest were slowly vanishing beneath her fingers. As they did, the circular motions she was drawing grew gradually slower as she appraised him.

He wasâ€”quite attractive. Physically.

He must have a genetic propensity toward low body fat because all the muscles in his torso and arms stood out with stark definition. His whole body was hard and angular, without even a hint of softness. He wasnâ€™t a bodybuilder, but he wasâ€”fit.

Most men had at least a layer of fat cushioning their flesh before meeting muscle. Despite how strong all the Weasley boys were, their muscle definition was generally somewhat faint beneath their skin. Harry had an eternal propensity toward scrawniness, regardless of his physical condition.

It wasnâ€™t surprising, she supposed. Lucius Malfoy was well-built and far from portly, while Narcissa had been thin as a lath.

She studied Malfoy thoughtfully.

â€œDo you leer at all your patients, or am I special?â€ Malfoy abruptly drawled.

She started and blushed.

â€œI wasnâ€™t,â€ she said defensively. â€œI was just wondering about your body fat ratio.â€

â€œOf course you were,â€ Malfoy said snorting.

She withdrew her hands.

â€œYouâ€™re done,â€ she told him quietly.

He sat up and rotated his shoulder as he studied her repair work on his ribs. Then he drew his shirt back on, and rebuttoned it quickly.

Hermione looked away and began packing up her healing kit.

â€œSoâ€”how does a person beat a werewolf without killing him?â€ she inquired.

â€œA Bombarda Maxima with the wandpoint against his eyeball seems to do the trick,â€ Malfoy said casually as he picked up his cloak and stood. â€œBut you have to let them get that close. Which obviously did not go entirely as planned.â€

She stared at him.

â€œYou blew up his eye?â€

â€œIt would have killed a wizard, but werewolves never know when to die.â€

â€œHe is most assuredly going to try to kill you,â€ Hermione told him seriously.

â€œIâ€™m counting on it,â€ he said savagely.

She rolled her eyes and stood up.

â€œSo. More werewolves. Any other information?â€

He wandlessly conjured a scroll.

â€œA few new non-lethal curses your Order might deign to use without impugning their precious consciences. Details on a new prison in Cornwall. Also, the Dark Lord is considering making his name into a taboo. You may want to warn all your foolhardy fighters against throwing it around as a demonstration of their Gryffindor courage.â€

Hermione accepted it, and he turned to go.

â€œThanks for the patch job, Granger.â€

He vanished.

Hermione glanced around the shack for a moment before slipping the scroll into her satchel.

She had healed Draco Malfoy.

She had healed loads of people, but somehow healing him felt different.

For a few minutes he hadnâ€™t felt like a Death Eater. He had simply been a person who was in pain.

A person.

She wasnâ€™t used to thinking about him in that way.

It felt safer to make him impersonal. A concept in her mind.

Death Eater. Murderer. Spy. Target. Tool.

That was how she preferred to categorise him.

Not as an injured person. Not someone who winced from fractured ribs. Not someone so unused to physical touch they flinched away reflexively. Not someoneâ€”attractive.

The interaction had appeared to patch the awkwardness; to bridge the space that had formed. But it had also carved away at the â€œothernessâ€ that she had been able to apply to him; as her enemy, the murderer of Albus Dumbledore. The perspective that enabled her to think unflinchingly about potentially manipulating him into his grave.

Thinking about him as a person made him less of a monster in her mind.

She couldnâ€™t allow herself to do that. It awakened the Hermione of Hogwarts, the fourteen year old girl who had knitted hats and started a Society for the Promotion of Elvish Welfare. That righteous teenager would be horrified by how her future self stood rationalising the strategic necessity of intellectually dehumanising Draco Malfoy.

Hermioneâ€™s hands shook slightly as she shuffled the thought into the back of her mind.

Andâ€”he had come to her as soon as sheâ€™d arrived. Despite his injuries. Heâ€™d come.

She wondered if that meant something.

Hermione returned to Grimmauld Place and went immediately up to her room. Before walking in, she peered surreptitiously around the door to ensure the room was empty.

Harry and Ginny were â€œnotâ€ together. Ginny had sought Hermione out several weeks before to assure her of that detail. It had simply been a fling. In the heat of the moment.

There was apparently a lot of heat, given that Hermione had nearly walked in on them a dozen times since.

Hermione, along with everyone else in Grimmauld, was feigning ignorance over Harryâ€™s dramatically improved mood. Heâ€™d bound through the house like a joyous stag.

Hermione pulled her notebook from beneath her bed and muttered the counter-charms for the security measures she had placed on it.

She flipped through the pages carefully. Looking over everything sheâ€™d written, taking note of how her opinions and theories had evolved and scattered. She nibbled on the tip of her quill as she underlined a comment she had made weeks before.

Lonely. Isolated.

She was growing convinced that it was a central pillar to him. Dead mother. Insane father. Ambitious friends all devoted to their own self-preservation.

Whatever was driving Malfoy to cast himself off from Voldemort and throw in his lot with the Order was probably a secret from everyone.

There was no room for honesty and friendship while serving under the rule of a megalomaniac who was the most powerful legilimens in the wizarding world.

Hermione was almost certain that no one on Voldemortâ€™s side knew Malfoy was a spy. He wouldnâ€™t possibly risk it.

Hermione could be a safe repository for his secrets. If she got him to trust her. If her occlumency was good enough, heâ€™d be able to rationalise it to himself. Sheâ€™d turn his strengths into weaknesses she could capitalise on.

She poked her head under her bed in search of a psychology book she wanted to reference. As she looked over the books piled up, she stilledâ€”

They had been moved.

The difference was slight, but she was certain. Someone had been snooping under her bed. She cast a detection spell that came back blank.

She looked back at her notebook. She cast a series of charms and analytic spells on it, looking for tampering. There were no signs.

She stared under the bed again, and then around the room.

Kreacher.

The dratted elf rarely did more than sulk and insult people, but occasionally he would go on a half-hearted cleaning spree.

The room did appear to have been dusted. Ginnyâ€™s generally unmade bed had been straightened somewhat.

Hermione relaxed slightly, but she cast several extra spells on her books and a ward that would notify her if anyone were to disturb the books again. She also added a very thorough self-destruction spell on the notebook if it were tampered with by anyone.

As she was standing up to leave, Ginny walked in.

â€œYouâ€™re back early,â€ Ginny said.

Hermione glanced down at her watch. She was. Her meetings with Malfoy were regularly exceeding the allotted half-hour. It was the first time sheâ€™d returned before 8:30. Normally Hermione had to rush to store the potion ingredients before her 9:30 shift in the hospital ward.

â€œLucky day,â€ Hermione said.

â€œYeah,â€ said Ginny, looking slightly awkward. â€œUm. I wanted toâ€”ask you about something.â€

Hermione waited.

Ginny tugged nervously at her hair. Sheâ€™d kept it cut in a bob just past her chin ever since a long ponytail had been grabbed during a battle, and sheâ€™d been nearly killed by a hag.

â€œIâ€”wellâ€”you, obviously know about me and Harry,â€ Ginny said.

Hermione gave a short nod.

â€œRight. Well. The thing is, I want to be careful. Iâ€™ve been using the charm. Butâ€”thereâ€™s something about Prewetts; theyâ€™re not like other wizarding families. They just get pregnant somehow. Ron and I were both accidents after the twins came along. Soâ€”I was wondering if youâ€™d make me a contraceptive potion. If you have the time. I was always rubbish at potions. If you canâ€™tâ€”thatâ€™s fine. I can ask Padma. I know youâ€™re terribly busy. I justâ€”I didnâ€™t want you to think I didnâ€™t want to ask you.â€

â€œOf course. Iâ€™ll be brewing tonight anyway. It will be an easy thing include. Do you have a preference about taste? The most effective ones donâ€™t taste very pleasant.â€

â€œI donâ€™t care what it tastes like if it works,â€ Ginny said boldly.

â€œWell, Iâ€™ve already got a few vials of one variety. I can give them to you now, if youâ€™d like.â€

â€œYou do?â€ Ginny blinked and stared at Hermione suspiciously. â€œAre youâ€”?â€

Hermione could see Ginny running a list of possible men in Hermioneâ€™s life.

â€œYouâ€™re notâ€”with Snape, are you?â€ Ginny suddenly choked.

Hermione gaped.

â€œGodâ€”No!â€ she said, spluttering and waving her hands as though she were trying to ward something off. â€œIâ€™m a healer! I keep a lot of things on hand. Good grief! Whatâ€”why would you evenâ€”â€œ

Ginny looked slightly abashed.

â€œHeâ€™s just the only person you ever seem to talk to for long. Aside from Fred, whoâ€™s with Angelina. Everyone else you just end up fighting with. And not in the hot and bothered, angsty sex later kind of way.â€

â€œThat doesnâ€™t mean Iâ€™m shagging him,â€ Hermione muttered, feeling as though her face were about it burst into flames. â€œHeâ€™s a colleague. I consult with him about potions.â€

â€œYou just seem lonely,â€ Ginny said, giving Hermione a long look.

Hermione started slightly and stared at Ginny.

â€œYou donâ€™t talk to anyone anymore,â€ Ginny said. â€œYou used to always be with Ron and Harry. But even before you left to become a healer, youâ€™ve seemed more and more alone. â€œCathartic shagging is Ronâ€™s thing. Not mine,â€ Hermione said stiffly. â€œBesides, itâ€™s not like Iâ€™m fighting.â€

Ginny looked at her pensively for a moment, before saying â€œI think that hospital ward is worse than the battlefield.â€

Hermione looked away. She had sometimes wondered if it might be, but it had never been a question she could ask anyone.

Ginny continued â€œI think of it every time Iâ€™m in there. In the fieldâ€”everything is so focused. Even when someoneâ€™s injured. You just apparate them away and then head back. You win some. Iâ€™m always more traumatised after being in there than I am by fighting.â€

Hermione was silent.

â€œYou donâ€™t ever get time off,â€ Ginny added. â€œThey can never spare you long enough to let you grieve.
