Draco's Runes by _knar.m_

Flashback 10

July 2002

Hermione felt paranoid the following Tuesday when she was foraging, but the journey passed again without incident. That morning, when she arrived at the shack, Draco was already there waiting.

â€œSo, dueling,â€ he said, spinning his wand in his right hand as she walked through the door.

Hermione froze and blanched slightly.

She had braced herselfâ€”reminded herself repeatedly that Draco would likely do something incredibly nasty to her as soon as he started feeling better. It was apparently his default method for maintaining distance between them.

Sheâ€™d healed him considerably more from his punishment than she had after his fight with a werewolf. If he regarded her as overstepping recently in the way she had been touching himâ€”if the space between them really had narrowedâ€”she had reminded herself that eventually he might do something horribly cruel to widen it again.

Sheâ€™d knownâ€”

But walking into it still felt like being gutted.

She dropped her eyes, and forced her expression not to change.

â€œRight,â€ she said. She dropped her bag by the door and warded it.

His expression was cool and calculating as he stared at her from across the room.

â€œI want to see if your dodging and evading has improved, but I donâ€™t want to rennervate you every minuteâ€”â€

Hermione flinched faintly.

â€œJust donâ€™t hit my hands,â€ she interrupted him, â€œI canâ€™t workâ€”if you hit my hands again.â€

His eyes narrowed with annoyance.

â€œFuck off, Granger, Iâ€™m not intending to hex you,â€ he snapped. He flicked his wand sharply toward her and she feltâ€”liquid.

She glanced down and found a large water droplet spattered across the back of her hand.

â€œI realize you consider me a total monster,â€ he said flatly, â€œbut I do make a general habit of keeping my word. I presume water will not offend you.â€

Hermione was still staring down at her hand in astonishment. Finally she looked up at him and blushed.

â€œSorry,â€ she mumbled.

â€œRight.â€ His expression was stiff. â€œSoâ€”Iâ€™m primarily interested in seeing how you move. However, do try to land a hex on me, if you possibly can.â€

He entered a very uncommitted dueling stance, and waited for her to do the same.

She did, and then bobbed her head slightly in a bow before she sent a jelly-leg jinx toward him. He blocked it with the faintest flick of his right hand.

He sent a dozen drops of water in her direction and she easily blocked them with a nonverbal shield.

She sent a series of stunners and he blocked them without moving.

â€œWhy are you so concerned with how I move when you never do?â€ she inquired as she sent several leg lockers and jelly leg jinxes toward his feet.

â€œIâ€™m not dueling,â€ he said, shooting her a thin smile as he blocked her spells and caught her feet with several drops of water. â€œYour shield isnâ€™t comprehensive. Stop maintaining it and dodge, or make sure itâ€™s full-body.â€

She flushed and physically dodged the next twenty water droplets while shooting several mild hexes in his direction.

â€œYou arenâ€™t even trying to hit me,â€ he said, frowning. â€œYou do realise I basically duel for a living. I fight werewolves, your Order, Death Eatersâ€¦ Especially lately, everyone in the Dark Lordâ€™s ranks thinks that my injury is an open invitation to try to steal my spot.â€

Hermione nearly tripped and stared at him in horror.

â€œWhat?â€ she said with a horrified gasp. If he were Harry or Ron sheâ€™d be smacking him upside the head.

He shot her squarely between the eyes with a drop of water.

â€œFocus!â€ he barked, before laying his hand across his brow in apparent despair but still blocking the leg locking jinx she shot. â€œYouâ€™re hopeless. Merlin. This is why you lot are losing.â€

â€œIâ€™m a healer,â€ she snapped defensively. â€œIf you wanted me to try harder at hexing you, you should have talked about how you enjoy killing kneazles kittens.â€

â€œEvery night before I go to sleep,â€ he deadpanned as he filled the air with shooting drops of water. The floor was growing littered with puddles.

â€œAre you really saying that youâ€™ve been dueling ?â€ Hermione demanded. She stopped trying to jinx him and was simply staring at him in outrage while she knocked aside all the water he was sending toward her.

Draco rolled his eyes.

â€œYou may recall, Iâ€™m a Death Eater,â€ he said. â€œI am at a loss as to how this surprises you.â€

â€œYou are injured! I assumed there were some basic tenets of human decency even among Death Eaters.â€ She was seething.

â€œWell, youâ€™d be wrong. Despite its Muggle origins, the Dark Lord is a firm believer in promoting the survival of the fittest. Hence his aspiration to subjugate all Muggles. If myâ€”chastisementâ€”leaves me vulnerable to overthrow then I ostensibly deserve it.â€

â€œSoâ€”what? They just get to attack you whenever they want to?â€ she asked angrily, continuing to ward off the rainstorm he was directing at her. The entire floor was covered in water.

â€œOf course not,â€ he said, his lips curling condescendingly, â€œconstant infighting weakens military cohesion. Thereâ€™s a designated time each week before the Dark Lord, at which point challenges are permitted. And there are generally restrictions on killing, or doing anything to permanently impair ourâ€”usefulness.â€

â€œThat is vile.â€

â€œThe civilized man is a more experienced and wiser savage,â€ Draco said.

Hermione squinted at him in confusion.

â€œHow is it that you know Darwin and Thoreau?â€

â€œOh, you know. â€˜Know thyself. Know thy enemy. And you shall win a hundred battles without loss,â€™â€ he said with faint smirk. â€œWe savage Death Eaters do know how to read. The Dark Lord doesnâ€™t care what I do so long as I continue providing him victories.â€

He sighed abruptly and stopped shooting water at her.

â€œYouâ€™re really not even going to try to hex me, are you?â€ he asked in irritation, as he banished the pool of water they were both standing in.

Hermione flushed faintly.

â€œIâ€™ve spent a lot of time trying to heal you. I donâ€™t want to make you fall,â€ she admitted begrudgingly.

â€œYou fucking moron,â€ he said, glaring at her. â€œDo you expect Death Eaters to extend the same courtesy to you? If youâ€™re injured on the ground, cursing you additionally would be funny.â€

â€œI think itâ€™s generally understood that I would be a pretty piss-poor Death Eater,â€ she snapped.

â€œObviously. But I would hope you could be pragmatic enough to duel competently.â€

â€œI can be pragmatic. When it comes down to the line, I donâ€™t baulk. Butâ€”I canâ€™t try to injure you right now.â€

She bit her lip and looked away from him.

â€œYouâ€”â€œ she started, â€œyouâ€™ve saved several hundred people now. Thereâ€™s a chance no one will ever know. And you were punished for it. Soâ€”Iâ€™m not going to try to hurt you. Not when youâ€™re already injured.â€

She stood there awkwardly. He sighed and stared at her. There was cold calculation to his expression as he stood considering her. Then a long silence.

â€œDid you know,â€ Draco said in an airy tone after a minute, â€œthat I was there when the Creevey family was dragged out of hiding?â€

Hermione couldnâ€™t have been more stunned if heâ€™d just stepped up and backhanded her. She looked up at him sharply while he continued.

â€œTwo Muggle-born wizards from the same family. Quite an anomaly. They were considered high priority. The Dark Lord wanted their deaths spectacular.â€

â€œYouâ€”,â€œ Hermione choked. The words died in her throat, swallowed by her rising horror.

â€œYou should have heard how the Muggles screamed. Dear Aunt Bella had such a fondness for the cruciatus. You recall how she drove the Longbottoms insane? She considered the Creeveys her encore performance. The boys tried to bolt. Good little runners. Smart enough to know they couldnâ€™t save their parents.â€

Hermione felt as though sheâ€™d been punched. Repeatedly. She tried to breathe, but her lungs wouldnâ€™t function. Her throat felt as though something were closing around it.

Draco continued in a relentless voice, â€œOf course your Order came eventually, but they were rather late. The father bit through his tongue and drowned in the blood. Bella cut out the motherâ€™s womb, just in case the woman was still sane enough to understand what she was being punished for. While they were stringing her organs up around the parlor, I was set to track down the boys. It was easy, since they were blubbering and trying to stay together. Putting them in the countryside miles from another farm was quite an oversight for two wizards who couldnâ€™t apparate. Then the littler one stepped in a badger hole and broke his leg. He started crawling through the grass. An easy target for a killing curse. The second person I cursed in the back with it.â€

Hermioneâ€™s wrist snapped forward without thinking as she shot a slicing hex at him. It grazed Malfoyâ€™s cheek. He didnâ€™t flinch as the blood welled up from the razor fine cut and streamed down his face. He stepped toward her.

â€œYou knowâ€¦â€ he said softly, â€œthe killing curse. It takes something out of you. Itâ€™s not something just anyone can throw around. Not repeatedly. Colin could have kept running. If he had, he might still be alive today. But he stopped. For his dead brother he stopped, ran back, tried to drag the body with him.â€

â€œDid youâ€”,â€œ Hermione croaked, feeling as though she might die from the horror currently welling up inside her. â€œAre youâ€”â€œ

Malfoy arched an eyebrow and smirked coldly down at her.

â€œAre you wanting to know if Iâ€™m the one responsible for that nightmare in your head?â€

Hermione felt that if she opened her mouth again, she might vomit. Her wand was shaking in her fingers, and she felt torn between a desire to scream and sob. She had never felt capable of crucioâ€™ing someone, but as Malfoy closed in on her, his grey eyes glinting, she was sure sheâ€™d mean it.

â€œNo,â€ he said softly, and Hermione started slightly. â€œThat was Dolohov. Heâ€™d just invented it. He came specifically with the hope of testing it that day. But itâ€™s difficult to aim. Useless long range. You have to be within a foot of the target. If Colin had just runâ€”he wouldnâ€™t have been hit with it.â€

Hermione clamped her hands over her mouth and dropped to the floor with a muffled sob.

Malfoy knelt down, forced her chin up, and stared coldly into her eyes. Â 

â€œThat is what Gryffindor sentiment looks like. All those noble ideals of not leaving people behind, not even the dead; of not using the Dark Arts; of not hitting someone because theyâ€™re already down; of trying to ascribe heroism to peopleâ€”when you feel like believing in any of that, remember just how and why Colin died in front of you. You have no idea how many of your Resistance fighters Iâ€™ve killed because they believed the lie that goodness is an advantage in war.â€

He let go of her face and stood.

â€œIf you donâ€™t learn to fight now, you will die. The fact you havenâ€™t already been killed foraging is from the sheer benevolence of Fate. Iâ€™m sure you are too pragmatic to continue relying on such a thing. If you have any sense whatsoever, Iâ€™ll expect some true resolve from you next week.â€

He dropped a roll of parchment beside her and apparated away.

Hermione sat shaking on the damp floor of the shack for a long time.

No one talked about Colin.

Out of a combined consideration for both Hermione and Harry, the topic was assiduously avoided. Anything that even vaguely broached it was treated with utmost delicacy.

After it had happened, Hermione had hidden the memory in the recesses of her mind and it had festered like a wound. Malfoy had come across it while teaching her occlumency.

Having him drag it out and use the trauma to berate her was such a staggering blow she felt as though she were going into physical shock from it.

There were very few things that still felt sacred to Hermione.

Not her body.

Not her soul.

But Colinâ€™s deathâ€”it had always been such a private agony. It had driven her from her friends. It had taken her across Europe and back. It had driven her all the way into the shack in which she sat. All the way to Malfoy, who had used it to belittle the last pieces of herself that still remained.

She pressed the heels of her hands into her eyes until they ached. Trying to recentre herself.

She was late for her shift in the hospital wing when she finally dragged herself from the floor and headed to Grimmauld Place.

She felt as though she were floating through the day. Weirdly detached. As though there were glass between her mind and the rest of the world.

Hermione went through the motions of healing and then a long evening of brewing.

The Order needed large batch of Draught of Living Death. It was their method for dealing with prisoners. They wouldnâ€™t kill them, and had neither prisons nor enough people to be able to spare some as guards. So Death Eaters they caught were kept in an unplottable location in suspended animation. Bill Weasley and his wife Fleur were in charge of it, using their skills as former Curse Breakers to weave elaborate enchantments and wards in order to accommodate the considerable number of prisoners the Order had accrued over the years.

As she sat waiting two and a half minutes for the potion to settle, she glanced at her watch. It was almost eight oâ€™clock.

She sighed and buried her face in her hands. She did not want to see Malfoy again. If she did, she would probably punch him in his cruel face.

He probably wasnâ€™t expecting her to show up anyway.

Her wand chimed to indicate that the time had passed, and she dropped the last bit of Valerian root in.

The potion turned pale pink.

She warded it, and put it carefully aside.

She picked up her jar of salve and rolled it about in her hands. She was almost out of Essence of Dittany. Sheâ€™d used most of it treating his runes. She tried not to calculate how many other injuries she could have healed with it if she werenâ€™t using it on Draco; tried not to quantify his value against the lives of others. How many heâ€™d saved, how many heâ€™d killed, how many lives his intelligence was or was not worth.

Heâ€™d killed Dumbledore. The number of deaths he was responsible for because of that act alone was sufficient to damn him. Heâ€™d never rebalance the scales, no matter how many people he saved.

Unless he helped them win. If they won, it might be enough.

She smiled bitterly to herself.

Draco Malfoy was exactly the same person he had been the night before. The only difference was that her knowledge of him had broadened slightly.

She couldnâ€™t understand him.

Why get so angry and monstrous because she didnâ€™t want to hurt him when he was already severely injured? He was so unreasonably angry and bitter. It felt as though sheâ€™d shattered the fragile peace between them.

But provoking her with Colinâ€™s death was low, even by her standards for him.

Maybe he was actually concerned that she was going to die.

She scoffed to herself. If he were, it was probably only because he didnâ€™t want to risk having a non-occlumens as his contact.

Before she could think more, she slipped the salve into her pocket and then headed to the shack. She was four minutes early.

Being there again felt exhausting.

She sat down on a chair and pulled a picture from her pocket. It was of herself, Ron, and Harry in the Great Hall, all mid-bite and looking up, faintly annoyed over being photographed. Colin had taken it.

She always stared at it when she felt depressed.

She put it back in her pocket and then leaned across the table and buried her head in her arms.

Maybe she would dose herself with Dreamless Sleep potion when she got back. She could feel the nightmares in the back on her mind. Just waiting for an opportunity to claw their way to the surface of her consciousness.

Sheâ€™d already taken the potion eight times that month. She was still having nightmares from all the victims from the curse development division that were brought to her.

Sheâ€™d tried. Sheâ€™d tried so hard to save them.

There had been nothing she could do. Almost every single one had died. Those that didnâ€™t, she euthanised; to spare them the endless agony theyâ€™d been magically trapped within.

If she took Dreamless Sleep Draught, it would be breaking the rules she held everyone else to. Barring injury, no one was permitted more than eight vials a month.

Not that anyone would know. Hermione was the one in charge of regulating the potions. The Resistance was too overdrawn to afford the redundancy of having a supervisor over her. Even if they tried to, unless the person also had a Potion Mastery, there was little chance they could stop Hermione from slyly doing whatever she pleased.

But it was a slippery slope to abuse the rules. Nine times a month. It would be so easy to rationalise ten after that. Then eleven.

Until it stopped working.

Until she wanted something stronger.

Severus had warned her. The number of ways a Potion Master could abuse their skills were endless.

Maybe when she got home sheâ€™d go get high with Neville, or see if Charlie would share his firewhiskey supply.

But she didnâ€™t really want to get high. And she wasnâ€™t allowed to be, even if she did want to. She was always on call in case of a healing emergency.

She could get drunk. She always kept sobriety potion carefully stocked in her stores. But she hardly got along with Charlie when she was sober.

Hermione felt desperate for someone to talk to.

Almost every interaction with Malfoy felt like an emotional punch in the gut, and she had to walk away from them and pretend theyâ€™d never happened.

She lived in a house crammed with people and she felt utterly isolated.

There was faint crack of apparition. She looked up dully to find that Malfoy had arrived. Cold and indolent-looking as always.

She wanted to cry and bolt. Or to hex him nastily and just leave him there.

She swallowed it and stood up.

He unbuttoned his shirt and straddled a chair. She didnâ€™t say a word as she pulled the fabric off his shoulders and set to work.

â€œIâ€™m going to use the cleansing charm now,â€ she said in a mechanical voice. She counted to three and then cast it.

Then she swiftly reapplied the salve. The dittany had made progress in neutralising the poison. The cuts appeared almost ready to begin healing. She would probably be able to start closing them within the next week. The process would take several hours to do properly and ensure the scar tissue wasnâ€™t taut and wouldnâ€™t pull when he moved his shoulders.

She didnâ€™t want to talk to him but she forced herself to open her mouth.

â€œIf you have time in the next four to seven days, I can close the incisions. It will probably take three hours. After eight pm and before five am are the best times for me. I have hospital shifts and other duties during the day.â€

He didnâ€™t say anything.

She recast the protective spells and dropped his shirt over his shoulders. Then she turned and walked out of the shack without a word.

The summer evening was cool. She shivered slightly and walked down the lane. She had decided. She was going to go get well and truly smashed.

She stopped outside a pub and hesitated. She was a talkative drunk. She couldnâ€™t go into a muggle pub and start crying about everyone who had died. Even if she managed to pass herself off as a doctor in a casualty ward, she was a terrible conversational liar.

She continued until she found a market and bought herself a bottle of port. Her parents had always liked to drink port in the evenings when on holiday.

She carried it to the creek where her prayer tower stood, and then stared in surprise. There were reeds growing along the banks that she didnâ€™t remember being there before, and the area felt slightly warmer. Magical. She cast several more muggle repelling spells and a privacy charm over the area and then opened the bottle and started drinking.

She remembered someone telling her that a person could get drunk faster using a straw. She didnâ€™t know if it was true, but she conjured a long one and started sipping. She calculated that she had several hours before anyone would think to look for her. More than enough time to get drunk, cry under a bridge, and then sober slightly before heading back.

She hadnâ€™t had any dinner; the alcohol hit her rapidly.

She was curled up in a ball among the reeds and was sobbing in short order.

She hated Malfoy. How dare he demand her, and isolate her, and talk about the Creevey family. She hoped she was the one who killed him.

She stood up and pulled the topmost stone off her tower, and tossed it back into the creek.

She did it too carelessly. The whole tower wobbled slightly and then fell crashing into the water. She gasped with horror and tried to rebuild it.

Rock stacking required more finesse and steadier hands than she currently possessed. After several tries she gave up, sat down in middle of the creek and cried and shivered.

She hadnâ€™t felt so pathetic in a long time and she didnâ€™t even care. She should have bought two bottles of port.

â€œThe fuck are you doing, Granger?â€

Â 

Flashback 11

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

July 2002

Hermione looked up sharply and found Malfoy staring down at her from the road. She was too tired and angry to even feel embarrassed about being found drunk and crying in a creek.

â€œBugger off, Malfoy,â€ she said, smacking at the water with her hand so that it sprayed in his direction.

â€œAre you drunk?â€ he asked.

â€œNo, you tosser, I am sitting in a creek entirely sober,â€ she said with an eye-roll. â€œGo away. I donâ€™t want to talk to you. I donâ€™t want to see your nasty face. If I could obliviate your existence from my mind without risking the Order, Iâ€™d do it in a heartbeat.â€

She started crying again.

â€œFucking hell,â€ he said, staring down at her with the same expression of irritation heâ€™d had when he told her about the unwanted manticore he found himself in possession of.

â€œGranger, you cannot sit crying in a creek,â€ he finally said.

â€œI actually can,â€ she retorted. â€œAside from you, thereâ€™s no one to see. I already warded the area. None of the Muggles will come around or notice me. I have planned my emotional breakdown carefully and you are ruining it. Soâ€”bugger. Off.â€

Her head felt very heavy, and she dropped it down onto her knees. It was growing very cold in the creek, but she was determined not to move until Malfoy went away.

There was a muffled thud, and then a hard grip suddenly closed around her arm, and she found herself being dragged up out of the water.

â€œLet go!â€

She smacked Malfoy across the arm and kicked him in the shins as she attempted to wrench herself free.

â€œLeave me alone. You and Voldemort have ruined my life. Am I not even allowed to occasionally feel sad about it?â€

â€œGranger, you idiot!â€

Malfoy dragged her into his arms and apparated. They reappeared in the shack.

She stared around the room dazedly, clinging to him for balance.

â€œWhy are we here?â€ she demanded, her voice wobbling as she stepped away and tried to draw herself up. â€œI hate this place. One of the richest wizarding families in all of Europe, and you make me come see you in this miserable house. As though Iâ€™m not already well-aware of the disdain you have for all of us Mudbloods. God, why didnâ€™t you just buy a whore house or a salt mine and make me visit you there?â€Â 

â€œI told you there was a taboo and you used the Dark Lordâ€™s name,â€ Malfoy snarled. â€œThat is why you cannot get drunk in a fucking creek regardless of how many damn Muggle repelling charms you cast.â€

Hermione blinked and stared at him.

â€œI hate you,â€ she finally said.

â€œThe feeling is decidedly mutual,â€ he said, looking at her with an expression of disdain. Â 

She dropped into a heap on the floor.

â€œI hate you so much,â€ she said. â€œI was already all aloneâ€”and then you demanded me and made it even worse. At least beforeâ€”if anyone cared enough to ask me if I was alright I could tell the truth. But nowâ€”I canâ€™t even do that. And nowâ€”even if we win I wonâ€™t have anything to look forward to. Everyone else will be free and Iâ€™ll still be owned by you. Iâ€™m just going to be alone foreverâ€”â€

She buried her face in her hands and cried afresh.

â€œHarry and Ron are never going to forgive me,â€ she said, and her whole body shook with the force of her sobs. â€œEven if this wins the warâ€”theyâ€™ll never forgive me.â€

Her crying subsided slightly after several minutes.

â€œIâ€™m really not clear on why you expect me to care.â€ Malfoy stared down at her with an indifferent expression.

She glared up at him. â€œYou brought me here knowing that I was drunk. If you didnâ€™t want to hear about it, you could have just left me alone the way I repeatedly told you to. I donâ€™t see why you wonâ€™t just fuck off.â€

He arched an eyebrow. Â 

â€œHexing and swearing at me all in one day. It would seem I finally got to you. I wondered what it would take to make you give up your sweet caresses and tell me how you really felt.â€ His expression was taunting.

â€œShut up!â€ she snarled before dropping her head onto her knees and hugging herself.

â€œBut reallyâ€”weâ€™re just scratching the surface, arenâ€™t we? Perhaps I should list everyone Iâ€™ve killed,â€ he said, stepping slowly around her with a malicious smile. â€œThere were several Muggles first, practice runs before I went back to school. Aunt Bella said it was necessary to be used to killing before doing it to someone I actually knew. Then Dumbledore. And more Muggles. Did you know I was even assigned to find your parents? You must have hidden them yourself because there wasnâ€™t even a trace to be found. No sloppy details or secret goodbyes like many of those other Muggle-born families. Although, that ignorance still didnâ€™t spare your neighbors. Bella was crushed by how thorough you were.â€

Hermione was staring at him in horror.

â€œThen the Creeveys. And the Finch-Fletchleys. And my Aunt Andromeda and her husband Ted. That one was rather personal for Bella, having a Muggle-born marry into the Black family was such a stain. It remained her sincerest regret that she never got to kill Nymphadora, especially after word got around that sheâ€™d gone and married a werewolf. Then after thatâ€”well, the dead tend to bleed together after a while but I believe it was more Muggles...â€

Hermione could feel the warm fuzziness of her intoxication draining away from her as Malfoy kept talking. Listing name after familiar name. The glint of his silver eyes and the cold set expression on his face as he continued in his disdainful drawling voice. Â 

â€œYou know, Malfoy,â€ she said quietly after a minute, â€œyou spend so much time making sure I have just an excess of good reasons to hate you. Itâ€™s odd.â€

He paused, and she stared up at him.

â€œItâ€™s not how humans work,â€ she said. â€œOur brains are wired to rationalise things, so that the guilt doesnâ€™t eat us. We excuse. We blame. We find some explanation for ourselves that helps us sleep. People donâ€™t think of themselves as villains. Theyâ€™re killing to protect themselves, or their families, or their money, or their way of life. Even your master, he doesnâ€™t think heâ€™s a villain. He just thinks heâ€™s better than everyone else. He thinks he deserves to rule over everything. When he tortures and kills Mugglesâ€”itâ€™s alright because theyâ€™re not really people. When he carved runes into your back for hoursâ€”it was alright, you deserved it because you failed him. In his mind he isnâ€™t a villain, heâ€™s a god. But youâ€”you do think youâ€™re a villain. You think you deserve to be hated.â€ She cocked her head to the side as she studied him. â€œI often wonder why that is.â€

Malfoyâ€™s face had grown colder and more closed as she was speaking.

â€œIâ€™ll save you all the effort,â€ she said, and her mouth quirked up at one corner. â€œI hate you. I donâ€™t require you to do anything more to convince me. I hate you. More than anyone else aside from your master. I hate you. I hold you partly responsible for every person who has died so far in this war and every person who will die. You donâ€™t need to convince me that youâ€™re a monster, I already know it. Healing you when youâ€™re injured is not because of my bleeding heart. And not hexing you when youâ€™re severely wounded isnâ€™t sentiment. Itâ€™s simply the last bit of decency I have left. All the rest of my goodness has already been destroyed by you. Soâ€”despite what you fling in my face, I will not let you have it. Nowâ€”fuck off.â€Â 

Goodness, it felt nice to have finally gotten that off her chest. Sheâ€™d probably regret saying it all later, but in the moment she only felt relief.

Malfoy smirked faintly. â€œGood to know.â€

Hermione laid back on the floor and stared at the ceiling.

After several minutes of silence it was clear he was not going to go away. She gave up driving him off. She was overwhelmed by her desire to talk. She sat up on the floor.

â€œWhat are you like drunk, Malfoy?â€ she said, turning her head to look at him. He was standing beside her and staring down where she sat at his feet.

He looked surprised by the question. â€œQuieter. And angrier.â€

She snorted. â€œOf course. Heaven forbid you be anything interesting.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t have you down as a weepy drunk.â€ He raised an eyebrow and conjured a chair, which he straddled beside her. It occurred to her that he probably couldnâ€™t lean against anything. She wondered how much it might have hurt to pull her out of the creek and then apparate when she was struggling and trying to fight him off.

â€œI wasnâ€™t always,â€ she said wistfully. â€œTalkative, always. But alcohol makes me emotional. I used to be a happy drunk. I was justâ€”ridiculous. I went to a party where the punch was spiked and I got so smashed. Harry had to silence me while he and Ron were dragging me through the halls. I was giggling so uncontrollably. Peals of laughter justâ€”bouncing off the walls. Filch nearly caught us.â€Â 

â€œWhen was that?â€ he asked.

â€œMy birthday. I turned seventeen. It wasâ€”it was the day before you killed Dumbledore.â€ Her jaw trembled slightly, and she looked down at her fingers as they traced a knothole on the floor. â€œIâ€”was supposed to have been in the hallway the next day. Prefect duty, to help the first years. But I was so hungover. I slept late. Iâ€™ve often wonderedâ€”if it would have made any difference...â€

Â â€œIt wouldnâ€™t have,â€ he said.

â€œIâ€™ve always cried since then. Always. Not that I get drunk often. I tend to say things that piss people off.â€

Â â€œYou always do that,â€ he said, giving her a pointed look.

â€œI say more things that piss people of,â€ she amended. â€œAnywayâ€”tonight it was drunk or high or abusing potions.â€

â€œAnd the creek?â€

â€œI donâ€™t have anywhere to go. I canâ€™t go to a pub. Or get drunk around anyone in the Order. Itâ€™s not like Moody is a shoulder to cry on.â€

â€œPotter and Weasley?â€

â€œSince they donâ€™t know about youâ€”how would I explain anything?â€ She wasnâ€™t going to mention that they had both gone off without her to hunt horcruxes.

â€œI canâ€™t believe you couldnâ€™t just leave me alone,â€ she said. â€œWhy were you even there?â€

â€œI had a feeling you were going to go do something asinine. Call it a sixth sense.â€

She rolled her eyes. â€œI donâ€™t see why youâ€™d care. Your secret would die with me. Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ll still find a way to get whatever it is you want without me.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure anyone Moody sent to try to replace you with would only be more irritating,â€ he said with a faint grimace. â€œThink of it as an additional favour to your Order. Iâ€™m keeping their healer and Potion Mistress alive.â€

She snorted. She was starting to feel incredibly sleepy. The thought of sleeping made her think of Colin. Tears welled up in her eyes. She covered her face with her hands and sobbed.

â€œWhat now?â€ Malfoy said as her sobs subsided. He sounded bored, but when she looked at him, he glanced away. He'd been watching her.

â€œIâ€™m going to dream about Colin tonight,â€ she said sadly, dropping her head against her knees.

â€œYou were delusional when you said you could ever kill anyone. You canâ€™t even handle them dying at someone elseâ€™s hand,â€ he said, shaking his head dismissively.

Hermione stiffened and stared up at Malfoy. Â 

â€œI donâ€™t think thereâ€™s anything particularly awful about dying. I know itâ€™s war. People die,â€ she said. â€œWhat I care about is the manner. You have no idea, Malfoy, what itâ€™s like to have someone die while you are doing everything in your power to save them. He died slowly, screaming the whole time, and I was trying to save him. Thatâ€™s what haunts me. All those deaths in my mind... thatâ€™s the type they are. Thatâ€™s why they haunt me. They were in my handsâ€”I was trying to save themâ€”and I failedâ€”â€œ

She choked slightly and her voice cracked at the final words.

Malfoy looked at her and seemed considering for the first time.

â€œWhy does Colin matter so much? You werenâ€™t close. Why is that death the one that still remains so significant to you? Youâ€™ve seen worse deaths since then.â€

She hesitated. She had never spoken about it to anyone. Not really. Not for years.

â€œHis death was the beginning of the end of everything,â€ she said, looking down and noticing a snagged thread on her shirt. She tugged impulsively at it and watched the knitted fabric tighten and bunch until the thread suddenly snapped and a hole appeared. She repaired it with a flick of her wand. â€œHe was the first person who died entirely under my care. Harry saw it happen. And after thatâ€”I realised that what the Order was doing wasnâ€™t enough. That defense wasnâ€™t enough. And I started saying so. But Harry disagreed. To himâ€”dying is the worst thing. Itâ€™s leaving. So, killing in any way is evil. Self defense. Mercy killing. Any kind. Thatâ€”disagreementâ€”sent us in different directions in the war. Nothing was the same after that. Thatâ€™s why I ended up a healer while everyone else went to the battlefield together.â€

â€œSomewhat ironic.â€

â€œOne person using Dark Arts in the battlefield isnâ€™t enough to make a difference. And if Iâ€™d been insubordinate and tried to recruit people into my thinkingâ€”it might have split the Order.â€

â€œIf you were fighting again, how would you kill?â€œ

â€œQuick. There are spells to stop hearts. Curses that suffocate. Slicing hexes to the throat. Iâ€™d do things like that. Iâ€™d probably even use the killing curse if I had it in meâ€”but Harry would probably never forgive it.â€

â€œHow does Potter plan to defeat the Dark Lord?â€

â€œItâ€™sâ€”thereâ€™s a prophecy. Harry thinks the answer is the prophecy.â€ she said vaguely. She wasnâ€™t sure if the Power of Love was a real Order strategy, but Malfoy didnâ€™t really need to know the details.

â€œFantastic. Weâ€™re all betting our lives on the-boy-who-wonâ€™t-kill and a prophecy. Weâ€™re doomed.â€

â€œDumbledore defeated Grindelwald without killing him,â€ Hermione said.

Malfoy looked unimpressed.

â€œWhere did you study healing?â€ he asked her. She looked over at him with surprise.

â€œFrance at first,â€ she said, â€œbut the war crossed the channel quickly and it was safer for me to transfer than risk being found there. So I went to Albania; their Old Magicks Department had the best fundamentals for healing Dark Magic. I was there for a while. Thatâ€™s where I learned the treatment Iâ€™ve used on your runes. Youâ€™re luckyâ€”Iâ€™m probably one of the only healers left who knows the treatment since the hospital was destroyed. Then Denmark, for spell analysis and deconstruction. After that I went to Egypt; their hospital was the most specialised for curse breaking, but the situation wasâ€”unstable, so I got transferred to Austria within a few weeks. I was in Austria until the Order brought me back.â€

â€œA lot of people thought you died, or ran,â€ Malfoy said, studying her with hooded eyes. â€œUntil the Dark Lord wanted to know why the Resistance was surviving after their hospital was razed, and Severus mentioned that Potterâ€™s little Mudblood friend had been recalled from her journey abroad, healer and potion mistress to boot. It caused a slight stir among the upper-ranks.â€

She looked at him sharply. So heâ€™d known what she was when he made his demands. She wondered if that had played any part in his decision.

The conversation stalled. After a few more minutes Hermione stood up.

â€œIâ€™m sober enough to apparate now,â€ she said.

â€œYouâ€™re not going to go off and get drunk somewhere else are you?â€ he asked, staring at her suspiciously.

She shook her head.

â€œNo. You have quite thoroughly killed my buzz. And Iâ€™m sufficiently cried out.â€

He looked faintly relieved. â€œDonâ€™t splinch yourself,â€ he drawled after her as she went out the door.

Hermione didnâ€™t. When she got back to Grimmauld Place she went up to her potion cabinet and downed a sobriety potion. The headache and nausea promptly dropped down upon her with all the subtlety of a sledge hammer.

She dropped her head down onto the worktop and groaned.

Trust Draco Malfoy to not even allow her to get drunk in peace. Sodding bastard.

She had expected sobriety to fill her with horror, but she felt surprisingly unrepentant for finally lashing out at him. It certainly hadnâ€™t seemed to surprise or upset him. Heâ€™d been waiting for it.

She found herself entirely at a loss about how to interpret or process all that had occurred.

She fumbled through the cabinet for a vial of headache relief and downed it, trying to focus.

Draco thought of himself as a villain.

That was an important realisation. Possibly the most important one she had yet made regarding him. The inconsistency that was in the heart of him.

She wracked her mind replaying everything he had said that day. Now that sheâ€™d vented all of her rage at him, her mind felt suddenly crystal clear.

â€œ Then the littler one stepped in a badger hole and broke his leg. He started crawling through the grass. Quite an easy target for a killing curse. The second person I cursed in the back with it. You know...the killing curse. It takes something out of you. Itâ€™s not something just anyone can throw around. Not repeatedly. Colin could have kept running. If he had he might still be alive today. But he stopped. For his dead brother he stopped, ran back, and tried to drag the body with him.â€

Hermione froze.Â 

He could have killed Dennis Creevey in an innumerable number of crueler, slower ways than the killing curse. With a broken leg, Dennis was no flight risk. He would have been the perfect lure to draw Colin back. Butâ€”rather than just stand over injured Dennis and catch both boysâ€”Draco had killed him, humanely. Possibly in the hope that a dead brother would drive Colin off and spare his life.

Hermione felt ready to fall over at the dual realisation that struck her.

Malfoy had been trying to spare Colin.

But, possibly of greater significance for Hermione, Malfoy didnâ€™t regard that detail as redeeming.

Heâ€™d been certain sheâ€™d become completely mindless with hatred for him once she knew heâ€™d been involved at all. The unintended admission that heâ€™d been trying to let the boys escape wasnâ€™t a way of trying to excuse himself. She suspected he didnâ€™t even register it as such.

Malfoy considered himself a villain because of what he did. Which implied that he didnâ€™t want to do it. Which implied that his desire to aid the Order might be sincere and not merely a means to some other end.

Hermione drummed her fingers on the worktop thoughtfully, re-evaluating once more everything she thought she knew of Draco Malfoy.

Chapter End Notes

Additional Illustrations:

  • Drunk in a creek by _bite.art_
