Flashback 12

August 2002

â€œFind each personâ€™s â€œhandle,â€ his weak point. The art of moving peopleâ€™s wills involves more skill than determination. You must know how to get inside the other person...First size up someoneâ€™s character and then touch on his weak point. â€

Hermione stayed up half the night re-analysing Draco. She scrapped her entire notebook and started a new one.

She felt as though she were brimming with new theories about him. She wasnâ€™t sure if any of them were based on reality or merely brought on by her sleep deprivation, but she felt as though she had hit upon something. As though she were breaking into a muggle vault and finally heard the first tumbler click into place. A warm sense of elation made her smile to herself while she brewed potions that day.

Her heart felt almost light.

This could work. She could win. She could bring him to heel. Seal his loyalty.

She hadnâ€™t realized how much the belief that he was simply a monster with a moral code had convinced her that she could never succeed. Sheâ€™d had a sense of certainty that eventually heâ€™d turn and kill her along with everyone else; it had been entrenched. Despite her heavy reliance upon occlumency the conviction had bled into how she thought and treated him as a whole.

Despite the game they played. Heâ€™d kissed her and taught her occlumency. Heâ€™d told her she could say no. And she healed him and followed his instructions about dueling and exercising. Beneath the learning and the partial niceties, it always felt like they were two vipers waiting for the other to finally strike.

Now she was reconsidering.

He was not a monster. Not entirely. He was trying to fix something. There were some sort of amends that he was trying to make. Not for killing Dumbledore or anyone else, but for something.

He knew he was fallen. Somewhere along the way something had happened that he was willing to suffer for, even die because of. Something he was trying to make right. He wasnâ€™t a spy out of ambition. He wasnâ€™t just playing the Order and the Death Eaters against each other in order to come out on top. He was trying to fix something.

Not the war. Not the killing. But there was something he was trying to make amends for.

Her initial assessment had been right. Draco Malfoy wasnâ€™t all ice. Under the death, rage and darkness there was more to him. She could use it.

Hermione doubted heâ€™d tell her what was driving him. He was clearly determined not to reveal it. Playing a game of misdirection until her head spun. But she could be patient. Now that she had figured out that spying was some sort of penance forâ€”something. If she refused to really hate him now; if she continued to be kind and comforting and interesting and clever to him. She could find a way in.

She could win.

As evening drew on and she got ready to go tend to his back, she took a moment to pause and steady herself.

Sheâ€™d have to start over again.

There was something between them thatâ€”that she had difficulty letting herself think about too carefully. A tension between them that sheâ€™d likely wrecked with her outburst.

Sheâ€™d have to begin cultivating it again carefully.

She had to be subtle.

Subtle as poison.

Hermione closed her eyes and shifted through her memories; winnowing out her strongest feelings and setting them aside.

Tamping down on her elation, on her bubbly sense of inner-confidence; stifling them until she was clear-headed. Focused.

She apparated to the shack one minute before eight.

When Malfoy appeared, she stared at him for a moment before dropping her eyes, biting her lip and awkwardly fidgeting with her cuticles.

â€œSorryâ€¦â€ she mumbled. â€œYou were right. I was careless last night. It wonâ€™t happen again.â€

She looked up through her lashes to see if Malfoy was even remotely convinced by the apology.

â€œGood,â€ he said, staring across the room. â€œIâ€™m not your keeper. Iâ€™m not interested in having to monitor you in order to keep you alive.â€

â€œIt wonâ€™t happen again,â€ she reiterated.

He eyed her for a moment and then looked away, summoning a chair from across the room and straddling it while starting to unbutton his shirt. Hermione drew it off his shoulders and surveyed the runes.

She rested her fingers lightly on the top of his shoulder as she leaned forward to get a better look. Malfoy didnâ€™t flinch when she touched him. He tensed though, slightly.

â€œDo you have a time when you want me to close the incisions?â€ she asked in a low voice as she used her fingers and wand to ease the salve out and inspected the raw edges of the cuts.

It still looked unbearably painful. She wasnâ€™t sure how Malfoy was even functioning, much less apparating, much less dueling. Every time she saw the wounds it made her cringe.

He didnâ€™t say anything.

She rested her hand on his spine. â€œIâ€™m going to use the cleansing charm now.â€

She felt Malfoy tense under her hand and saw his knuckles whiten slightly. She counted to three and cast.

His whole body shook faintly.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ she said. â€œIf there were any way for me to repair this faster or at least relieve the pain, I would.â€

â€œI am aware,â€ he said in a tight voice.

She applied the salve as lightly as she could.

â€œWould Monday work?â€ she asked, drawing her fingertips along his bare shoulders trying to get him to release the pained tension that radiated through him. â€œI can skip dinner if you need me to come earlier.â€

â€œMonday,â€ he said after a pause. â€œEight is fine.â€

â€œAlright.â€

She recast the protective spells. Then she studied the runes again, brushing her fingers near them. She could barely feel the magic in them. It had sunk in; become a part of him.

She could barely feel any Dark Magic around him at all. Not anymore. Not for weeks.

â€œDo youâ€”feel the runes?â€ she asked. â€œCan you tell if theyâ€™re affecting you?â€

He seemed to be considering.

â€œYes,â€ he said after a moment, straightening. â€œThey donâ€™t countermand my own behavior, but itâ€™s as though new elements have been written in. Itâ€™s easier to be ruthless. Somewhat harder to dissuade myself from impulses. Not that I had much distracting me before, but now everything else feels even less consequential.â€

Hermione read the vow again.

â€œDid you know when he was cutting them which runes he was choosing?â€ she asked.

â€œI chose them,â€ he said, pulling his shirt up and rebuttoning it.

Hermione looked at him stunned.

â€œIt was my penance. I already had to grovel. If I chose them I was able to ensure he wasnâ€™t going to insert anything problematic. Thatâ€™s why there are so many, I didnâ€™t want to leave any room for additional promises. He had to be convinced of my remorse,â€ he said as he stood up. His eyes reminded Hermione of a storm.

â€œAlthough,â€ he said, and his lip curled faintly, the rage in his eyes becoming obvious, â€œhe failed to mention that they would take so long to heal until after the fact. In retrospect, I should have anticipated that additional punishment.â€

â€œWhen I close them, it will take a while in order to ensure the scar tissue wonâ€™t restrict your movement. Youâ€™ll have to stay awake to tell me. Youâ€”may want to bring something to drink.â€

Malfoyâ€™s eyes narrowed and he stared at Hermione for several seconds.

â€œIâ€™m not going to drink around you, Granger.â€

She shrugged.

â€œItâ€™s just a suggestion. Iâ€™ll bring something in case you change your mind. But I imagine the alcohol I can afford is more inexpensive than youâ€™ll appreciate.â€

He snorted.

â€œIâ€™ll keep it in mind.â€

He vanished without another word.

The following night he was in a tetchy mood, and Hermione refrained from speaking to him as she treated him. However, she noticed that he had begun relaxing slightly into her touch. She doubted he was even conscious of it.

Hermione, for her part, had realised that she had grown comfortable with him. With the taint of Dark Magic no longer hanging about him, her instinctive fear had faded. She didnâ€™t hesitate to touch him, didnâ€™t experience any tingle of dread in her spine. She no longer tensed, bracing herself that he might lash out.

He felt familiar.

On Saturday, a soothing charm finally stuck to the incisions when she cast it and Draco shuddered significantly less when she cast the cleansing charm.

â€œThe venom is finally gone,â€ she told him with relief. She summoned her satchel over and dug through it for an analgesic potion that she had developed. She drew some cloths out and, after placing a barrier spell on her hand so that it wouldnâ€™t go numb, poured the analgesic out until the fabric was drenched.

â€œThis will feel cold and sting for a moment, but then it will numb the incisions,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m going to start on the top of your left shoulder.â€

She rested her fingers just above the first rune for a second before she gently laid the cloth over his shoulder and lightly pressed it against the incisions underneath. He shivered.

She set a timer for the left shoulder and turned to attend the right.

â€œThey shouldnâ€™t hurt now but theyâ€™re still open wounds on your back,â€ she said. â€œDonâ€™t go do something stupid Iike getting into a fight with a werewolf just because you arenâ€™t in agonising pain anymore.â€

â€œWill you sign off on my werewolf fighting Tuesday?â€ he asked in a snide voice.

Hermione rolled her eyes.

â€œIâ€™d advise giving the scar tissue at least three days to set before fighting any werewolves.â€

He chuckled faintly.

The conversation stalled after that, but the evening ended on a surprisingly cordial note.

Hermione was in a somewhat cheerful mood when she apparated back to Grimmauld Place. As she landed on the steps, her bracelet suddenly grew red hot.

She flung the door open and found it in chaos. There was blood smeared across the floor.

â€œHermione,â€ Neville shouted. â€œItâ€™s Ginny.â€

Hermione bolted up the steps as quickly as she could, avoiding the blood spilled across the floor.

Harry, Ron and all the other resident Weasleys were there. Pomfrey and Padma were hovering over a bed where Ginny was lying.

â€œWhat happened?â€ she demanded, dropping her satchel and rushing over. Ginny was unconscious and had a large, ragged gash along her face. Blood was pouring from it.

â€œNecrosis curse hit her on the cheek,â€ Pomfrey said, between spells. â€œThey cut it out as quick as they could, but weâ€™ve never had anyone make it back after being struck in the head.â€

â€œPadma! Blood replenishing potion!â€ Hermione barked as she cast her own spells. Brain damage was not one of Hermioneâ€™s specialties. Normally when curses reached the brain the damage was beyond healing.

She cast the most complex brain scan spells she knew and studied them.

â€œIt didnâ€™t reach her brain,â€ she gasped with relief. Then she cast another diagnostic over Ginnyâ€™s head. The ragged, hurried cuts made it hard to read any other details. She couldnâ€™t see any obvious indicators of remaining necrosis, but Hermione didnâ€™t trust Fate to be kind. She snatched Pomfreyâ€™s wand from her hand without asking, muttered a charm and began using the second wand tip delved into the diagnostic layers, looking for any remaining traces of rot hiding beneath all the tissue damage she was reading from the removal process.

Thereâ€¦

â€œThereâ€™s necrosis in her zygomatic and frontal bones. I have to remove them now,â€ Hermione said. â€œEveryone get out!â€

There was protesting which she ignored as she cast more blood staunching spells, trying to see exactly where the curse was still eating into Ginny.

â€œGive her one drop of Draught of Living Death,â€ she ordered Padma who had just poured blood replenishing potion down Ginnyâ€™s throat. â€œIt will slow the recovery but we canâ€™t risk her moving.â€

Hermione grit her teeth and prayed as she summoned potions from the cabinet and began to cast a series of Â intricate spells and wards over Ginnyâ€™s head. Many of which she had never used before or only used once.

Trying to remove any sections of the skull was horrendously risky in any situation, but far worse when trying to accomplish it rapidly. It was going to expose the sinuses, Ginny would lose her entire eye socket, and part of her frontal lobe would be exposed until the bones grew back.

Staring at the black spots on Ginnyâ€™s exposed skull that were now growing before her eyes Hermione cast a hair removal charm and then spread a thick, purple potion very carefully around the edges of the gash and then out across more than half of Ginnyâ€™s head and face. When it was carefully and evenly spread Hermione cast a setting charm. The potion grew hard and shell-like. An exoskeleton.

Hermione took a steadying breath and banished each section of Ginnyâ€™s skull.

The exoskeleton potion externally held the areas which no longer had bone structure supporting them. Hermione recast the diagnostic and checked repeatedly and thoroughly. The necrosis was gone. The bones had been removed before the curse reached through to Ginnyâ€™s brain.

Hermione collapsed slightly and felt tempted to sob with relief. It had been so close. So very close. Closer than she would ever tell anyone.

She steadied her hands and administered Skele-Gro. She added several monitor wards and several more protective wards around Ginnyâ€™s exposed brain. Then she set a timer.

With the interference of Draught of Living Death the bone regrowth would take ten hours. She couldnâ€™t start repairing the gash until the bones had been regrown completely or the repaired tissue would have nothing to form over. Ginny would carry a cruel looking scar for the rest of her life, but she would live. Whoever had cut out the necrosis had done it quick enough to save her.

Hermione took Ginnyâ€™s hand in her own and stroked it gently. She was covered in blood. Hermione cast cleaning charms across Ginnyâ€™s body and changed her into into hospital robes with a few flicks of her wand. Then Hermione cast diagnostic charms over the rest of Ginny to ensure she wasnâ€™t injured anywhere else.

There was a scrape on her calf and bruising on one arm. Hermione fixed them in a few minutes.

Hermione stood and picked up both of the wands beside her.

â€œSorry,â€ she said, handing Poppy her wand back. Grabbing a personâ€™s wand without permission was grossly offensive.

Poppy stashed her wand with a shaken expression.

â€œI had already cast four diagnostics before you came and none of them showed the remaining bone necrosis. Iâ€™ve never seen a diagnostic dissected compositionally before. Iâ€™m glad you didnâ€™t waste time asking permission.â€

â€œI read about it in a book on healing theory. Brain diagnostics are difficult. Thereâ€™s so much activity that the magic picks up. Theyâ€™re hard even for specialists to read quickly. It was just luck it worked.â€

Hermione sighed and wanted to sit down. Now that the crisis had passed, she was able to feel her heart pounding and her hands shaking. She felt light headed and on the verge of falling over backwards.

â€œI should go let everyone know sheâ€™s alright,â€ she said shakily.

Harry and Ron and almost everyone else in Grimmauld Place were waiting outside the doors of the hospital ward.

â€œSheâ€™s alright,â€ Hermione said as she opened the door. â€œSheâ€™ll be alright.â€

Harry gave a sob and slumped back against the wall.

â€œOh, thank Merlin,â€ Charlie muttered.

Ron rubbed his eyes and Hermione saw blood on his hands and all over his clothing. She approached him and cast a subtle diagnostic as she did so. He was uninjured. It was all Ginnyâ€™s blood.

â€œDid you remove the necrosis?â€ she asked Ron.

He nodded and his pale blue eyes flooded briefly with tears. His whole body was shaking as though he were going into shock.

â€œYou saved her, Ron,â€ she said, pulling him down into a hug. â€œYou bought her enough time to get back. If you hadnâ€™t, it might have been too late, or she might have lost her eye. Sheâ€™ll have a scar, but sheâ€™s going to be fine.â€

â€œOh Merlin,â€ Ron collapsed slightly in Hermioneâ€™s arms. â€œLucius showed up. We apparated but when we landed we realized Ginny was hit. When I saw itâ€”â€œ

He dragged his hand across his eyes and it smeared blood across his pale skin. His hands were shaking uncontrollably.

â€œAll I could think of was when Dad came back. And after George. And now Ginâ€”and Iâ€”she looked at me and I knew I had to try. It wasâ€”it was worse than anythingâ€”â€

Ron sobbed and buried his head into Hermioneâ€™s shoulder. She wrapped her arms around him tightly.

â€œI just kept trying to tell myself it was to save h-her,â€ he mumbled into her shoulder. â€œMumâ€”I promised Mum Iâ€™d keep her safeâ€”told her Iâ€™d never let anything happen to Gin.â€

â€œYou did save her,â€ Hermione said into his ear. â€œYou did exactly what you needed to do.â€

â€œI am going to kill the Malfoys,â€ he muttered into her ear. â€œLucius and Malfoy, Iâ€™m going to kill them both. I donâ€™t care if I have to wait until after the war to do it.That family deserves to die.â€

Hermione didnâ€™t let the circles she was rubbing into Ronâ€™s shoulders falter. She just hugged him tighter.

The oath to kill the Malfoys was an increasingly common refrain among the Weasleys; the primary exception to their firm opposition to killing. It had started after Dumbledoreâ€™s death, but grown more frequent after Bill returned from a mission dragging his wailing father with him. Lucius Malfoy had made a point of identifying himself immediately after cursing Arthur with some obscure spell that had resulted in giving Arthur the mental capacity of a toddler.

Hermione had gone through every healing manual and obscure book of curses that she could get her hands upon but she never managed to find out what the curse was or any means by which to reverse or lessen the effects.

In some ways, Hermione sometimes guiltily thought, it was worse than if Arthur had died. Which was probably what Lucius had intended. Arthur Weasley was gone, except not. His friendly, curious, affectionate self remained, trapped in the body of a middle-aged man and a childâ€™s mind. He needed to be watched constantly. He would only mind a few people, and was prone to having explosions of accidental magic and minor seizures when upset. His effective loss was a staggering, dual setback for the Order. Molly had to step away almost entirely to care for her husband full time. She had taken him to live at one of the hospice safe houses. When George was able to leave the hospital ward at Grimmauld Place, he had joined his mother in helping to care for his father.

â€œYou are a good brother,â€ Hermione murmured to Ron.

When his shaking finally eased she pulled back slightly in order to ask the question pressing in her mind.

â€œRon, can you tell me what you used to remove the necrosis? Was it spellwork or a knife?â€

â€œA knife. One of the ones from Harryâ€™s vault,â€ he said.

â€œCan I see it?â€ she asked steadily.

â€œSure,â€ Ron said, somewhat confused. He glanced around looking slightly dazed still. â€œI think itâ€™s downstairs. Neville has our stuff.â€

Hermione stepped back and poked her head into the hospital ward.

â€œPoppy, can you check Harry and Ron for injuries? And administer a Draught of Peace? Double for Ron. I need to check something.â€

Hermione made her way downstairs. Neville and Hannah Abbott were mopping up the floor with magic.

â€œNev, can you show me Ronâ€™s rucksack?â€

He nodded over toward the corner.

â€œItâ€™s the one with all the blood on it. I havenâ€™t cleaned it yet.â€

Hermione went over and started going through it carefully. The contents had been flung in haphazardly. There was blood drying on everything. Shoved into a outer pocket she caught sight of a knife handle.

She pulled it out carefully. It was goblin-wrought, as she had suspected.

She carried it into the kitchen and washed the blood off. Then she pulled a small piece of raw chicken from the stasis bin and ran the entire blade of the knife lightly across the meat. The magically sharp edge sliced effortlessly. Then Hermione laid the knife carefully aside and stared down at the chicken.

A minute passed. Then two. Hermione wondered if sheâ€™d been mistaken. Then, a small speck of darkness appeared on the chicken. Hermione stared and watched as it slowly grew larger and larger over the next several minutes.

Hermione cast a stasis charm but it had no effect on the rot steadily spreading across the meat.

She cast a barrier charm on the blade of the knife, and several protective wards. Then she wrapped it in several towels and put a repelling charm on the whole thing. Then she placed it in a drawer which she locked and booby-trapped with several stinging hexes and an alarm.

She turned and went back up to the hospital ward.

Harry was sitting next to Ginny, holding her hand. His eyes were huge and devastated and his face was pale. He was chewing nervously on his lip. When Hermione laid her hand lightly on his shoulder, he started and looked sharply up at her.

He smiled thinly. A hospital smile. A rictus. The faint, wan tightening across the face that givers made with the intention of appearing encouraging or stalwart, but which alway just looked fractured.

When Ginny woke she would wear the same expression while she reassured everyone that she was fine; that she didnâ€™t mind her scar; that she really was fine.

Hermione smiled sadly down at Harry and conjured a chair in order to join him

â€œShe shouldnâ€™t have come,â€ Harry said after a minute.

â€œThe Order decided what the best unit would be, she wasnâ€™t there because of you two,â€ Hermione said. â€œLuciusâ€™ grudge doesnâ€™t have anything to do with whether you and Ginny are together.â€

â€œIâ€™m going to have to tell them not to pair us anymore,â€ Harry said, looking up from Ginnyâ€™s hand to stare into the distance.

His expression was dazed and his bright emerald eyes didnâ€™t seem to see the hospital ward. Hermione recognized the expression. He was back on the mission, reliving it over and over, in order to berate himself over what had gone wrong.

â€œIt was all my fault,â€ he said. His voice was small, quavering slightly. â€œI should have put the wards up sooner. The mission was so easy. Pointless. It was like a trip with her and Ron. Like we were camping for fun. I let my guard down.â€

Hermione said nothing. It was confession. He was so stunned and grieved that he had things he needed to say. He just needed to verbalise it. He couldnâ€™t tell Ron. He felt too guilty to direct it at Ginny beside him.

Hermione had listened to a lot of confessions from those on bedside vigil in the hospital ward. Sometimes she felt like a priest.

â€œAfter we got awayâ€”when I saw it on her faceâ€”I froze,â€ he said after several moments of silence. â€œWhen I saw sheâ€™d been hit. I didnâ€™tâ€”She started crying. And Ron stunned her. And I was just standing there. I just stood there while he was cutting her face up. I barely snapped out of it enough to apparate us back. Ron had to do almost everything. It was just like Colin. I just stood there.â€

â€œNo one could have saved Colin,â€ Hermione said quietly.

â€œI could have helped save Ginny!â€ Harry snapped suddenly furious. â€œWhat if she had died? And I had just been standing there? The woman I loveâ€”my best friendâ€™s sister. I just stood there and watched her face rotâ€”â€

He dropped Ginnyâ€™s hand and shoved his glasses up, rubbing his eyes.

â€œWhat if sheâ€™d died? Or become like Arthur? Because I was careless and didnâ€™t put the wards up?â€ Harryâ€™s voice was trembling and his hands were clenched into fists. Hermione could feel the magic shivering around him as his guilt and emotions continued to grow.

Hermione summoned a flagon of Calming Draught and transfigured a piece of cotton dressing into a cup which she filled. She held it and waited for a moment in which to give it to Harry. If she handed it over too soon, it would be thrown into a wall.

â€œNo one responds perfectly every time,â€ she said.

â€œIt canâ€™t happen again,â€ Harry said flatly. â€œIâ€™m not going to risk it.

Hermione said nothing, and after a minute Harry slumped against her. She slipped the cup of Calming Draught into his hand. Then she rested her head on top of his.

â€œSheâ€™s going to be alright,â€ she said. â€œI promise. Sheâ€™s alright.â€

Harry nodded, and Hermione gave herself a moment to just be with him. Her best friend.

Most days it felt as though they lived in separate worlds.

The boy who saved her from a troll. Who sheâ€™d brewed polyjuice potion for. Who she travelled back in time with in order to save his godfather. The friend sheâ€™d taught the accio spell. Who sheâ€™d set up Dumbledoreâ€™s Army with.

He had carried on as a hero, but somehow Hermioneâ€™s path had split off from his.

He turned to her as a healer, but rarely as a friend.

She laced her fingers through his chaotic hair.

â€œGinny is in love with you, you know,â€ she said. â€œDonâ€™t push her away. Donâ€™t do that to her. Donâ€™t do that to yourself. Youâ€™re already both in danger because of this war. You shouldnâ€™t give up the happiness you have. Donâ€™t let Tom take that from you.â€

Harry didnâ€™t say anything, but he downed the Draught of Peace while he kept staring at Ginny.

â€œCan she hear me?â€ he asked after several minutes, his voice sad and hopeful.

â€œNo, sorry. I put her in stasis until her bones regrow and I can fix the cut. It would be dangerous for her to move when her brain is exposed. Sheâ€™ll be awake tomorrow.â€

They sat together in silence for several minutes until a silvery bulldog came barreling into the hospital ward.

â€œPotter, Granger, mission debrief in five minutes,â€ growled Moodyâ€™s voice before the patronus vanished.

Harry sighed and stood up.

â€œI guess Iâ€™ll see you in there,â€ he said, stroking Ginnyâ€™s hand one last time.

Hermione watched him walk out and then turned to Ginny. She cast a few diagnostics to confirm that everything was stable and regrowing the way it was supposed to. Then she went downstairs and got the knife out of the kitchen drawer before going to the dining room where Order meetings were held.

Remus and Tonks were already there, and smiled at Hermione when she entered and found her seat. Bill walked in a few minutes later. He and Fleur alternated meeting attendance so that one of them was always monitoring the prison. Charlie followed, still looking as pale as he had been when Hermione had announced that Ginny would be alright. Neville entered next, followed by Amelia Bones. Then Ron and Harry. Kingsley Shacklebolt and Alastor Moody entered behind them.

It was less than a quarter of the current Order. Only a handful of members were informed about the horcruxes. The Order had learned through hard experience the danger of letting too many know too much when their opponent was an accomplished legilimens. Molly and Minerva rarely attended any meetings although they were technically still in an intelligence tier high enough to receive all information. Severus only attended top level meetings scheduled with more advanced warning.

â€œHarry, Ron. Weâ€™d like a full report on your horcrux hunt,â€ Kingsley said without any preamble.

â€œThereâ€™s nothing to report,â€ Harry said flatly. â€œWe went all the way to Albania and couldnâ€™t find anything. We didnâ€™t see anyone or have any trouble until Lucius showed up.â€

â€œHow did Lucius find you?â€ Moody asked, his eye rolling across Harry and Ron slowly.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Harry said, â€œweâ€™d just started to set up camp. The wards werenâ€™t up but weâ€™d been there less than fifteen minutes.â€

â€œWhere were you?â€

â€œSomewhere either in France or Belgium, I think. Some forest. We were planning to apparate back the rest of the way tomorrow.â€

There were several seconds of silence.

â€œDo you have anything else to report?â€ Kingsley asked.

Harry and Ron looked at each other and shook their heads.

Everyoneâ€™s expressions hardened in disappointment.

Hermione took a deep breath and steeled herself. There was a chance that she was just being pessimistic, but given her track record in Order meetings she was not feeling particularly hopeful about the reaction to what she was going to announce.

â€œI have something to report,â€ she said quietly.

Flashback 13

August 2002

Everyone looked sharply over toward Hermione.

She laid the knife on the table and cast a quick spell to unwrap it.

â€œThe mission wasnâ€™t entirely pointless. I think Iâ€™ve figured out how we can destroy the horcruxes, assuming we can find them. Iâ€™ve been studying how goblin-wrought weapons absorb anything that makes them more powerful. I wasnâ€™t sure exactly how the absorption worked; whether it involved a spell or not. But when I was healing Ginny, I noticed that the spots where the necrosis was still spreading had slight nicks in the bone. It gave me an idea, so afterward, I went and found the knife that was used to remove the curse.â€

She lifted the knife up carefully.

â€œThis goblin-wrought knife has the necrosis curse in its blade now. I confirmed in the kitchen and I can demonstrate it if anyone needs to see it. When the curse was cut off Ginny, the blade must have touched the necrosis somewhere and absorbed the magic. So when it touched the bones of Ginnyâ€™s skull it spread the necrosis to new locations.â€

Ron paled and looked ready to be sick. Hermione shot him an apologetic glance.

â€œGinny is going to be fine. And no one could have known that would happen. A goblin-wrought blade was a logical choice because it would cut more reliably than a non-magical knife,â€ she said firmly to him.

â€œBut it gave me an idea,â€ she continued, â€œabout how we might be able to destroy the horcruxes. We know theyâ€™re dangerous and hard to destroy because even Dumbledore got terminally cursed destroying one. Harry destroyed the journal with a basilisk fang, but we canâ€™t access those unless we can break into Hogwarts and get down into the Chamber of Secrets. But we have the sword of Gryffindor, and I think it might be able to destroy the horcruxes if we used it.â€

The room was staring at Hermione blankly.

â€œItâ€™s goblin-wrought,â€ she pointed out, â€œand Harry used it to kill the basilisk. So, that means it should be infused with basilisk venom.â€

She glanced around trying to gauge the reactions. Moody and Kingsley both looked thoughtful. Ron still looked ashen.

â€œIt could be true,â€ Remus said slowly, rubbing his chin thoughtfully. â€œWhat you said about goblin-wrought materials is certainly accurate.â€

â€œDo we know where the sword of Gryffindor is?â€ asked Bill.

â€œI think Minerva has it,â€ Neville said. â€œI think I saw it when I was helping with the garden at Caithness.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll ask Severus about the venom,â€ said Moody. â€œHeâ€™ll know if anyone does.â€

Harry and Charlieâ€™s faces soured visibly at mention of Snape.

â€œI can meet with him.â€ Hermione volunteered. â€œI need to discuss some details regarding potions and curses anyway.â€

â€œAlright. Report to me afterward. We wonâ€™t reconvene until next week,â€ Moody said with a nod.

â€œWe should do something with that knife,â€ Remus said. â€œIt wonâ€™t be safe, someone might pick it up.â€

Hermione pushed it into the middle of the table.

â€œIt has some protective wards on it, but Iâ€™m not sure how well they stick.â€

â€œIâ€™ll deal with it,â€ Moody said, summoning it over to himself. â€œIâ€™ll send word to Severus.â€

Moody turned and stumped out.

When Hermione returned to the hospital ward after a late dinner, Harry was sitting beside Ginny again. All the lights dancing around Ginnyâ€™s body were in normal, reassuring hues, but Hermione paused to cast a diagnostic to make sure everything was still alright.

â€œYou shouldnâ€™t have done that,â€ Harry said, while she was in the midst of casting.

â€œWhat do you mean?â€ she asked, pausing mid-spell to look at him. Her breath caught slightly in her chest and her grip on her wand tightened.

â€œUsing Ginnyâ€™s injury like that.â€ Harryâ€™s voice hard and tight. â€œYou made it sound like it was somehow a good thing she got hurt.â€

Hermione sighed, and fought against an urge to roll her eyes.

â€œI didnâ€™t mean it like that,â€ she said. â€œYou know I hate it when anyone gets hurt.â€

â€œYou should have waited. You could have brought it up at the next meeting when Ron wasnâ€™t feeling so awful. Did you even comfort him because you cared, or just because you wanted to know where the knife was?â€

Hermioneâ€™s hands dropped to her sides and her eyes narrowed as her irritation with Harry bloomed into offense.

â€œI wanted to make sure he hadnâ€™t cut himself with it. I wanted to make sure no one else found it and got injured with it,â€ she said in a steely voice.

Harry sighed and glanced over toward her sharply.

â€œBut thatâ€™s what you were thinking about. When Ginny was hurt and you were healing her, what you were thinking about was â€˜Oh look, nicks in her skull. I wonder if this information will be useful for destroying horcruxes.â€™ Your roommate was lying there while you treated her, and thatâ€™s what you were thinking about. One of your best friends was crying in your arms because he had to cut up his baby sisterâ€™s face, and all you were thinking about was that fucking knife.â€

Hermione balled her left hand into a fist so tight she could feel her nails biting into her palm and the shape of her metacarpal bones under her fingertips.

â€œI am capable of thinking of multiple things at once, Harry.â€ Her tone was icy. â€œOr would you rather that the mission had been entirely pointless? That Ginny got hurt and it didnâ€™t mean anything?â€

â€œDonâ€™t treat it like that, Hermione. Donâ€™t treat people like theyâ€™re nothing but an equation to you.â€

Harry stood up abruptly and stared angrily at her.

Hermione twitched slightly. She couldnâ€™t understand the emotional reasoning that Harry employed. It was exhausting to try to figure out where he was coming from. It ate into mental resources she couldnâ€™t afford to give him.

â€œEither this all happens for a reason or it doesnâ€™t,â€ she said with cold rage. â€œYou canâ€™t have it both ways. If this is all supposed to be meaningful then you canâ€™t get offended when I point it out and accuse me of being callous.â€

Harry paled further and dragged a frustrated hand through his hair. He stared at her with his eyes flashing for a moment before turning away, his lips curled slightly.

â€œThe way you treat peopleâ€¦ sometimes, I feel like I donâ€™t even know you anymore,â€ he said.

â€œMaybe you donâ€™t,â€ she said in a clipped tone, staring down at her wand, finishing the diagnostic on Ginny.

â€œYou should have waited, you shouldnâ€™t have talked about the knife tonight. Itâ€™s not like we have a horcrux. You could have waited,â€ he said again as though it were the final conclusion of their conversation.

Hermione pursed her lips slightly and took a breath before responding.

â€œThe war isnâ€™t going to wait for us to grieve, Iâ€™m sorry you disagree with my decision. I didnâ€™t mean for it to hurt anyone.â€

Harry turned away from her.

Hermione walked into the next room and leaned against the wall, feeling somewhat frozen.

Her hands were trembling slightly. Her stomach felt as though it had been twisted viciously. She regretted eating anything.

She took several deep breaths through her nose and pressed the palms of her hands hard against the wall as she tried to recentre.

She shook her head and tried not to let herself dwell on what Harry had said.

After another minute she straightened and glanced down at her watch to check the time. Ginnyâ€™s bones still had hours to regrow.

Hermione mulled over the procedure. She should have Padma watch her perform it.

After Malfoy demanded her, Moody and Kingsley had decided to pull one of the field healers and have them trained to help with hospital shifts. Padma was the best field healer they had and a fair hand at potions; she was chosen to apprentice under both Hermione and Poppy.

When Kingsley informed Hermione that Padma was being assigned to the hospital, he framed it as support for Hermione because she was stretched too thin. But Hermione had been stretched too thin for years. She knew why they had reassigned Padma. They needed the redundancy because Hermioneâ€™s function as healer had become secondary to her status as Malfoyâ€™s possession.

Padma was her replacement.

Now, with all the prisoners the Order had broken free recently, they could afford to give up a few more fighters to specialise in healing. Poppy was in charge of training fifty new field healers. Padma was slowly taking over Hermioneâ€™s assigned hospital shifts and all the basic potions with the goal of Hermione only being on call in case of emergencies and advanced potion making; freeing her up to research and work on Malfoy.

When Hermione had informed Moody of Malfoyâ€™s intention to train her, Moody reminded her to do anything Malfoy required.

Hermione had felt slightly ill as she had agreed.

It wasnâ€™t as though she didnâ€™t agree. It was justâ€”hard sometimes. Deep down, she wanted Moody to still seem conflicted; to show remorse over what he was steering her toward.

She wanted someone to care. To object for her. So that she wouldnâ€™t feel like such a whore as she did it.

It wasnâ€™t really rational. Strategically she knew Moody was right. Even if he didnâ€™t order her to do whatever Draco wanted, she was still intending to.

That was the bargain.

But sometimes she still wished someone would try to say no for her. So that Hermione could be reassured that the sick, clawing sensation inside of her was reasonable. That it was indeed as horrible as it felt to be sold to a Death Eater in exchange for information. Because, while Malfoy wasnâ€™t generally abusing Hermione or forcing her to have sex with him, if he were, Moody would give her the same instructions.

After all, theyâ€™d all expected Draco rape her when theyâ€™d sent her.

Somehow Hermione hadnâ€™t been prepared for how devastatingly lonely it would be to process everything alone. How her solitary mission would slowly eat her inside. Like a sinkhole inside her chest.

Of course, she could go to Minerva. Minerva would care. Sheâ€™d object on behalf of Hermione. But it would be selfish of Hermione to turn to her for solace. It would just make her former Head grieve more. Hermione wasnâ€™t going to stop. She wasnâ€™t going to be dissuaded. Even if by some miracle Moody and Kingsley were.

She just wanted to stop feeling alone. To have someone tell her that what she was doing was meaningful. That it was alright that it hurt.

It was silly. Emotional. Wishing other people would be emotionally tortured on her behalf. She tried to squash it. But it kept rising up inside her.

Sheâ€™d always been too desperate for verbal affirmation. To have someone tell her that she was clever, to reassure herself of her value with grades and praise.

She bit her lip. No one would ever praise her for what she was doing.

If most members of the Resistance were to learn, theyâ€™d probably accuse her of corrupting the war effort.

The war between Good and Evil was won by Goodâ€™s refusal to compromise. Not by using Dark Magic. Not by selling a healer to a Death Eater for information.

Moody and Kingsley played along by allowing the Resistance's policy against Dark Art to remain in place in accordance with the Weasleysâ€™ and Harryâ€™s wishes. The public face of the Resistance was still Goodness and Light.

Hermione wondered just how many things Moody and Kingsley were doing without most of the Order knowing. Things that Hermione had also grown complicit in. Such as how Kingsley intercepted some of the snatchers and Death Eaters that Hermione was occasionally called in to heal before they were interrogated. How Bill and Fleur kept the the Orderâ€™s prisoners. How prisoners were sometimes interrogated. Where certain supplies came from.

There were so many logistical details that the rest of the Order never seemed to ask about. Much in the way they never asked about where all the new information was coming from. How, after so many months and years of decreasing intel, they suddenly had much better information regarding Death Eater prisons, impending attacks in Muggle Britain, and raids against the Order. How theyâ€™d known to evacuate Caithness or that Voldemort was traveling.

Everyone seemed eager to ignore details like that.

The only thing they couldnâ€™t ignore was having Severus as a spy; even after five years, they still hated it. There was a recurring argument put forth by Charlie or Ron or Harry to have Severus cut out.

Hermione sighed and went to find Padma. Even if she could sleep, it was going to be a long night.

Late the next morning she placed the final enchantments on the healing spells she used to repair Ginnyâ€™s face and then administered a vial of Wiggenwald potion.

That room in the hospital ward was currently empty. Hermione had kicked everyone out over the furious objections of Harry and Ron.

Ginnyâ€™s body was still for a moment and then gradually stirred. She cracked one eye and glanced around blearily.

â€œNgghhh,â€ Ginny groaned and rolled over and buried her head in her pillow.

After another moment she lifted her head and glanced around. Her hand immediately darted up to touch her bald scalp and then moved to her face. She fingered the wide scar that now lay there.

â€œWhat happened?â€ Ginny asked. Her voice sounded dry.

Hermione handed her a glass of water.

â€œLucius Malfoy hit you with a necrosis curse on your cheek,â€ Hermione said as gently as she could. â€œRon saved you by cutting it off before it could reach your brain.â€

Ginnyâ€™s fingers ran along the length of the scar. It started near her hairline. The gashâ€™s topmost edge began at the top of her forehead and all the way down to her jaw. It was wide and cruel looking, and it caused certain spots on her face to divot and pucker slightly.

Ginny sat up slowly and put her hands in her lap. Staring down at them as she clenched them into fists and then opened them. She was quiet for a minute.

â€œCan I have a mirror?â€ Ginny finally asked.

Hermione had a mirror ready for Ginny, but she paused before handing it over.

â€œIt will fade. In a few months, with treatment, it will fade to silver.â€

Ginnyâ€™s lower lip trembled, and she pressed her mouth into a hard line. She held her hand out for the mirror.

â€œDo you want me to go while you look? Or stay with you?â€ Hermione asked.

Ginny hesitated. â€œStayâ€¦â€ she finally said.

Hermione handed the mirror over and said nothing while Ginny took a deep breath and then turned it over to survey her face.

There was a long silence.

Ginny stared, growing paler, turning her head slowly to take in the entirety of it. Her fingers rose up slowly, tracing over it, as though she couldnâ€™t believe it was her face she saw reflected.

After a few seconds, Ginny pressed her lips together and jerked her head as her eyes welled up with tears. She stared for a moment longer, running her fingers along the scar before pushing the mirror away.

Then Ginny took a sharp breath in through her nose like she was trying not to cry. Her lips twisted slightly and she kept pressing them together harder as she rocked in the bed.

Ginny kept drawing sharp, quick breaths through her nose. Her head jerked up with each one.

Finally her shoulders slumped.

â€œOh Merlin, Iâ€™m so shallow!â€ she said with a slight sob. â€œIâ€™m alive but Iâ€™m crying because Iâ€™ve got a scar."

Hermione felt her own jaw tremble as she rested a hand on Ginnyâ€™s shoulder.

â€œScars are hardâ€¦â€ Hermione said, and her voice faded away as it tightened in her throat. â€œAnything that changes how we see ourselves is hard. You can be sad about it. Youâ€™re allowed to grieve for yourself. You donâ€™t need to pretend itâ€™s okay.â€

â€œI know,â€ said Ginny in a thick voice. â€œI just want to be. I want to be fine with it. I donâ€™t want to care. Or see it as changing me. Butâ€”I feel like part of me has died. Like Iâ€™m ruined somehow. And that feels so shallow and selfish. George lost his whole leg and Iâ€™m crying because I have a cut on my face.â€

Tears streamed from Ginnyâ€™s eyes and she smeared them away with the backs of her hands.

Hermione waited for several minutes and when Ginnyâ€™s breathing and trembling finally started to ease slightly, she reached out and took Ginnyâ€™s hand.

â€œHarry and Ron are waiting outside,â€ Hermione said. â€œBut you can take as long as you want before you see anyone.â€

Ginny jerked.

â€œHave theyâ€”didâ€”, Ginny stuttered and shifted uncomfortably. â€œHas Harry already seen it?â€

Hermione nodded.

â€œHarry has been with you the whole time. I forced him to leave. I thoughtâ€”you might want some time.â€

Ginny nodded.

â€œMaybe five more minutes,â€ said Ginny after a moment.

Hermione sat down on the edge of Ginnyâ€™s bed.

â€œYouâ€™re still one of the prettiest girls I know,â€ Hermione told her.

Ginny snorted. â€œShut up. Youâ€™d say that even if Ron had cut off my nose.â€

Hermione rolled her eyes. â€œI wouldnâ€™t. The redness will fade. If you let me treat it regularly. And use a few potions. It will become more elastic so you wonâ€™t feel it. And it will fade a lot. But if youâ€™d like, I can help you glamour it.â€

â€œItâ€™s fine. I always wanted to be a badass when I was little. Can you imagine how scary Iâ€™ll look now on a battlefield? All bald and with this crazy thing on my face,â€ Ginny joked weakly. The frozen hospital smile curled across her face for a moment. Then the forced humor faded from her expression and she looked almost childlike.

â€œI miss Mum,â€ Ginny said in a small voice.

Even when her children were injured, Molly could rarely afford to come see them.

Hermione hugged Ginny and Ginny sniffled into her shoulder.

â€œDo you want to go there today?â€ Hermione said.

â€œNo. Sheâ€™ll just feel awful,â€ Ginny said, shaking her head. â€œIâ€™ll go see her when itâ€™s faded a bit. Do you have a hair regrowth potion?â€

â€œSorry. Not on hand. I had Padma start brewing some though. It will be done in the next hour.â€

â€œWell, thatâ€™s a relief. At least I wonâ€™t have to be both bald and ugly forever.â€

Hermione shook her head and hugged Ginny again. Ginny always tended to break out terrible jokes about herself when she was in the hospital.

When Hermione departed, Ginny was fully ensconced in the attentions of Harry and her brothers and under the watchful eye of Poppy and Padma.

Moody sent word that Severus would be home at two oâ€™clock so Hermione apparated there a few minutes early and then approached Spinnerâ€™s End carefully. How any place could be so dreary even in summer never ceased to baffle Hermione. It was as though Severusâ€™ personality were contagious.

The door was shut. Hermione rapped quietly and then waited. Since he was no longer a professor, even Severusâ€™ most basic courtesy had entirely vanished. He would occasionally leave Order members waiting at his doorstep for an hour. Fred and George had once tried to just break in and came back to Grimmauld Place sporting boils across their entire bodies.

Hermione stood waiting for two minutes before pulling a book out and resigning herself.

She had made it through two chapters of her psychology book before the door abruptly jerked open. She stood up quickly and followed the billowing robes that were already vanishing around the corner into the sitting room.

Severus was already seated in one of his agonisingly uncomfortable armchairs when Hermione arrived. She perched on the very edge of another chair and looked at him

â€œA goblin-wrought blade infused with basilisk venom. Would it be enough to destroy a horcrux?â€ she asked, similarly choosing to skip the basic courtesies of small talk.

Severus blinked, his onyx eyes always inscrutable. She could almost see the occlumency walls behind them.

â€œThe sword of Gryffindor,â€ he said after a moment.

Hermione nodded.

â€œI believe it would,â€ he said slowly, steepling his fingers and looking thoughtful. â€œAlthough we wonâ€™t know for sure unless we find a horcrux.â€

Hermione nodded with a faint sigh. Severusâ€™ lip curled slightly and he snorted faintly.

â€œAt times like thisâ€¦ I wonder just how much Albus manipulated events over the years,â€ he said.

Hermione stared at him in surprise. â€œYou think second year was intentional?â€

He waved her off with a flick of his wrist.

â€œWith Albus, itâ€™s impossible to say.
