â€œWhat do you mean?â€

Severus looked at her.

â€œYou are aware his injury from the ring was terminal. I had been preparing potions to keep the curse at bay, but his death was inevitable the moment he placed it on his hand. He planned his demise for the end of sixth year. He even requested that I kill him, rather than leave him to the final ravages of the curse. He also suspected before the term began that Draco had been assigned to try killing him as well.â€

Hermione stared in shock.

â€œAlbus was so confident that he had everything in hand that he didnâ€™t take sufficient precautions,â€ Severus continued, â€œI cannot imagine that he would have neglected to mention the horcruxes after being cursed by one. He likely intended to inform Potter through a series of vague hints. He knew far more about the Dark Lordâ€™s early years than anyone, but he never deigned to confide such things to others.â€

Severusâ€™ expression grew bitter and far away as he fell silent.

â€œHe knew Draco was going to try to kill him?â€ Hermione asked, floored by the revelation.

â€œKnew. Suspected,â€ Severus said with a faint nod. â€œIt was hard to differentiate when it came to Albus, but yes, he was anticipating it. Unfortunately for all his plans, Draco acted much more quickly and decisively than even Albus anticipated. You would think a wizard so old would have been more meticulous, but clearly not. His overconfidence was to the detriment of all who survived him.â€

Severus glanced at Hermione.

â€œWhat made you suddenly think of the sword of Gryffindor?â€ he inquired, his tone suspiciously casual.

Hermione met his eyes.

â€œAn injury that I encountered gave me the idea,â€ Hermione said.

â€œIndeed,â€ Severus said with an arch expression.

Hermione gave him a look. â€œYou know about Dracoâ€™s punishment.â€.

â€œOf course. I had the delightful task of milking Nagini for the venom. Alastor mentioned that youâ€™ve been treating him. I was surprised to hear it.â€

â€œItâ€™s not as though he could hide the injury. Did you realise how severe it is? Tom intended to poison his magic with it. By the time I found outâ€”,â€ Hermione fell silent for a minute. â€œI wish you would have informed me, so I could have started sooner.â€

Severus was silent and appraising as he studied Hermione.

â€œYouâ€™re using it,â€ he finally said.

Hermione flushed faintly and met his eyes.

â€œYes,â€ she said. â€œIt seemed like the logical thing to do. You were right, he is isolated. He nearly jumped out of his skin the first time I put my hands on him to heal him.â€

â€œIf you had been trained by Bellatrix Lestrange for years, you would probably flinch when touched too,â€ Severus said dryly.

Hermione paused to consider. Â â€œWhat do you know about his training? Heâ€™s said things thatâ€”I donâ€™t understand. The cruelty employed seems excessive. Even by Death Eater standards.â€

Severusâ€™ mouth twitched. â€œHe was initially recruited as punishment for Luciusâ€™ failure. Consequently, I believe the Dark Lord gave Bella a rather free hand in choosing training methods. She was suspicious of my loyalty, so it was not a process I was consulted over. I do know that despite the brutality, Draco was determined. He took it and he kept coming back, even when it was no longer necessary. He was determined to climb rank. He was the youngest person to ever take the Mark. Being the lowest tier does not sit well with Malfoys.â€

â€œWas there anyone he was particularly close to in the past? Someone who died? That he cared about? His motiveâ€”it feels like atonement for something, at times.â€

Severus steepled his fingers and pressed them against his lips thoughtfully.

â€œNot that I ever observed. At least, not among his housemates,â€ he said after a minute.

Hermione sighed.

â€œWhat about his mother? He mentioned her when he first made the offer.â€

â€œNarcissa became reclusive following Luciusâ€™ arrest. I rarely saw her, and when she did appear she was quite withdrawn. If she ever had objections, I never heard her make them.â€

â€œShe seemed doting back in Hogwarts,â€ Hermione said, tilting her head to the side as she tried to remember details about Narcissa Malfoy. â€œBut that was all by Owl Post. It doesnâ€™t seem like she intervened on his behalf at all during his training.â€

â€œLuciusâ€™ imprisonment seemed to have a rather profound effect on her. Much in the way her death affected him.â€

Hermione shivered slightly at the thought of Lucius.

â€œSo Draco just fell to the wayside for them both,â€ she concluded, feeling sorry for him. She stifled the pity and changed the subject. â€œLucius nearly killed Ginny last night. We still donâ€™t know how he tracked them down.â€

â€œThere are genetic trace spells,â€ said Severus thoughtfully. â€œThey are extremely Dark Magic, and they take quite a toll. However, I would not underestimate Luciusâ€™ determination.â€

â€œAre there ways to evade them?â€

â€œIâ€™ll send a book to Moody. I donâ€™t imagine the Weasleys will be receptive to any protective rituals recommended by myselfâ€”or you, for that matter.â€

Hermioneâ€™s mouth tightened and she looked away, feeling stung by the fair assessment. Her advocacy for Dark Magic and her defense of Severus had cost her a great deal of credibility among her friends.

She swallowed the hurt and changed the subject abruptly.

â€œI finally neutralised the venom in the runes. Iâ€™m going to close the incisions tomorrow night. Do you have any suggestions?â€

Severus snorted. â€œIâ€™m sure your planned treatment will be the best he can hope for.â€

Hermione stared at Severus and felt as though she were missing something.

â€œAlright,â€ she said, standing up.

â€œTell me, what do you think of Draco now?â€

Hermione paused and looked back at Severus. His eyes were narrowed. Almost suspicious. Her lips twitched to move before she felt ready to speak, and she pressed them together for a moment while she gathered her thoughts. She tucked a loose curl behind her ear.

â€œHeâ€™s lonely. And angry about something. I think he wants to be better than he is. You were right that thereâ€™s something about me that draws him in. He tries not to, but he canâ€™t seem to help giving in when he has a chance to.â€

Severus studied her, and Hermione wondered what her expression betrayed.

â€œDonâ€™t interpret that as loyalty,â€ he said after a moment.

â€œI donâ€™t,â€ she said, fidgeting with the hem of her shirt. â€œI realise that itâ€™s not meaningful yet. Itâ€™s not any kind of leverage. But Iâ€™m hopeful that if Iâ€™m careful, eventually I may be able to capitalise on it. Emotionallyâ€”heâ€™s vulnerable. Thereâ€™s no one he can trust. I donâ€™t think he has anyone who cares about him at all. I think with time, he wonâ€™t be able to stop himself from feeling like he needs me. He mentioned that because of the runes, when he wants things nowâ€”itâ€™s harder to dissuade himself. I thinkâ€”I might be able to use that eventually.â€

Severusâ€™ mouth twitched, the suspicion faded from his eyes but his expression tensed. â€œIn that case, if you manage to succeed youâ€™re as likely to destroy the Order as save it. I hope you realise by now how dangerous he is. If you superseded whatever his current ambition is in that mannerâ€”â€œ

Severus paused for a moment. â€œIf the Dark Lord could not leash him, I would not advise deluding yourself into thinking you can master him.â€

Hermione jerked slightly and she stared into the cold fireplace, tensing until her legs trembled while she struggled not to snap. Anger flared through her like an explosion.

â€œ You told me to make him loyal. You are the one who recommended exploiting his interest,â€ she said in a clipped voice. â€œNow youâ€™re calling me delusional and accusing me of endangering the Order.â€

â€œI said to hold his interest. You are trying to make him depend on you,â€ Severus said, his tone suddenly icy. â€œThe difference is profound. In some respects, the Malfoys are closer to being dragons than they are wizards. They do not share. They are obsessive about what they regard to be theirs. Do you know who Lucius needed? Narcissa. If you succeed in what you are attempting, he will never let you go. And he will not be content with being secondary to anyone or anything in your regard.â€

Hermioneâ€™s heart shuddered slightly. She could feel cold terror slide down from the nape of her neck and bleed across her trapezius muscles. She squared her shoulders, and met Severusâ€™ eyes. She took in a sharp breath.

â€œHe already owns me,â€ she said in a bitter voice. â€œâ€˜Now and after the war.â€™ Those were the terms. Barring his death, when exactly was I ever intended to be let go? We need the intelligence. I canâ€™t hold him with half-hearted effort. It was all in for me from the moment you all agreed to sell me to him. Did you really think I was going to get to come back from it?â€

Her shoulders shook slightly. â€œI donâ€™t know how to keep his interest without connecting with him. Itâ€™s the only vulnerability he has. If you believe it to be that much of a risk you should speak to Moody because Iâ€”donâ€™tâ€”seeâ€”anotherâ€”way .â€

Her voice was shaking and cracked repeatedly as she forced out the last words. She breathed sharply through her teeth as she tried to steady herself.

â€œHeâ€™s a natural occlumens. And far better at it than me. Thereâ€™s no halfway option in the cards,â€ she added.

Severus looked startled.

â€œThat does change things,â€ he said after a moment.

â€œNow you understand my difficulty,â€ she said, looking down at the floor. â€œThere isnâ€™t an option of doing something I can back out of later. If you think Iâ€™m making the wrong choice you should tell Moody now.â€

He said nothing.

â€œIâ€™d best be going then.â€

As she left Spinnerâ€™s End, she felt dazed and unsteady. It was too warm and enclosed. She needed space to breathe. She closed her eyes and apparated to the stream in Whitecroft.

She hopped down the bank and seated herself on a large boulder among the thickly growing reeds, slipping her shoes off and dipping her toes into the cold water. The sharp sensation of the water felt like clarity.

She didnâ€™t know why she kept ending up here. She supposed it was the only place where she didnâ€™t feel like she was hiding anything.

She stared at the flowing water, replaying Severusâ€™ warning. She felt at a loss. All her hope from earlier in the week felt as though it had died somewhere inside her and started to decay. She pressed her hands against her eyes and fought to breathe evenly.

She couldnâ€™t waver now. If Severus had any alternatives or objections, he could raise them with Moody. She couldnâ€™t change tactics now that sheâ€™d finally found one that worked.

She stared down at her fallen prayer tower.

She felt soâ€¦ angry.

Angry with the whole world until she felt like sheâ€™d shatter from it.

She was angry at Severus for accusing her of endangering the Order; at Moody and Kingsley, for deciding to ask her to become a whore, knowing sheâ€™d feel she had no choice; at Harry and the Weasleys, for refusing to use Dark Magic and bringing the war to the point where Hermione felt she couldnâ€™t refuse; at her parents, for being helpless and needing her to protect and give them up; and even at Minerva, for being so distraught on Hermioneâ€™s behalf that Hermione felt she had to protect Minerva from Hermioneâ€™s own grief.

Hermione had always thought that she could do anything for her friends. Anything to protect them.

Somehow all the things she had done had left her all alone until she felt as though she was dying of a broken heart.

There should be a limit. A point at which it stopped hurting at least.

But it never seemed to stop. It just kept growing and when someone fractured the facade the way Harry and Severus each had...

She didnâ€™t know how to fix herself anymore, and no one else seemed inclined to even notice she was breaking.

She let herself cry for five minutes before using her occlumency to cram the distracting emotions into a corner of her mind. The crying made her feel light-headed and made her temples ache. She pulled a pain relief potion out of her satchel and downed it.

She closed her eyes and forced herself to stop thinking about other people.

The afternoon sunshine had seeped into the stone and felt warm under her hands. The smell of the creek water and mud and the green biting scent of the reeds filled the air. After several minutes, she closed her eyes and tilted her head back to soak in the rays. She couldnâ€™t remember when sheâ€™d last felt warm sunshine on her face. The light from sunrise was always cold, despite its beauty.

Everything in her life was cold.

After a few minutes, she roused herself. She pulled her feet from the water and flicked the droplets away before heading back to Grimmauld Place.

Flashback 14

August 2002

That night she and Malfoy were both subdued. He didnâ€™t flinch as she cast the cleansing charm and was quiet while she was applying the analgesic and then the salve.

â€œDid the Weasley girl survive?â€ he abruptly asked as he stood up.

Hermione stared up at him startled. She tried to guess why he was asking. Did Lucius want confirmation?

He hadnâ€™t pulled his shirt back on, and he was standing so close to her she could almost feel the heat from his body as he looked down at her. His eyes were stormy, and when she stayed silent, his expression flickered briefly.

â€œIâ€™ll assume she did then,â€ he said, stepping away and putting on his shirt.

Hermione blinked. â€œShe did. Although not for a lack of effort on your fatherâ€™s part,â€ she said in a bitter tone.

Dracoâ€™s expression hardened slightly.

â€œIâ€™d hope you wouldnâ€™t consider me responsible for my fatherâ€™s actions. Surely Iâ€™ve committed sufficient sins on my own,â€ he said in tight voice as he rapidly buttoned his shirt.

â€œI just donâ€™t know why youâ€™re asking,â€ she said. She felt too drained to have the current conversation.

â€œIt may surprise you, Granger, but I have no particular wish to see your friends dead.â€

Hermione said nothing. She had no idea what kind of response to make to the comment.

â€œMy fatherâ€”,â€œ he started and then hesitated; his face became a cold mask. â€œNevermind.â€

Hermione slumped internally. She needed to have this conversation with him. She reached out and caught his wrist. He stilled and looked back toward her, his expression closed.

â€œIâ€™m sorry. The question caught me off guard. I donâ€™t fault you for what your father does. Itâ€™s justâ€”,â€ her voice broke off briefly and her hold on his wrist tightened. â€I know you never had anything but contempt for the Weasleysâ€”but what heâ€™s doing to them is horrific.â€

Malfoy was silent.

â€œI am sorry,â€ he said. â€œI doubt youâ€™ll believe me, but I donâ€™tâ€”there is no reasoning with his vendetta.â€

â€œYou disagree with him?â€ Hermione asked, studying his face cautiously.

He used his other hand to take hold of hers and pulled his wrist free. â€œIf I blamed them for my motherâ€™s death, I wouldnâ€™t have asked about the Weasley girl.â€

â€œThank you for asking,â€ she said, glancing awkwardly around the room. â€œIt must be difficult for you. I know you admired your father.â€

Draco looked distinctly uncomfortable with the direction the conversation had gone in.

â€œRight. Wellâ€”later, Granger,â€ he said and apparated without another word.

Hermione stood there for several moments, reviewing the conversation before she headed back to Grimmauld Place.

When she got there, she found her room occupied by Harry and Ginny. She fidgeted in the hallway and then started up toward the uppermost floors of the house. As she passed one of the smaller rooms, she caught sight of a shock of red hair bent over a table of maps. She paused and tapped lightly on the door.

â€œHey Mione,â€ Ron said distractedly as he moved pieces across the maps and then scratched his head absentmindedly with the tip of his wand. His expression was tense.

â€œGot a minute?â€ she asked.

â€œSure.â€ He stuffed his wand into his back pocket and looked up at her. â€œJust reviewing whatâ€™s been happening since I left. Lot of raids while we were away, you must have been busy.â€

He was giving her a penetrating look. Hermione dropped her eyes.

â€œIâ€™m sure you see the strategy,â€ she said quietly.

â€œKingsleyâ€™s using the horcruxes to keep Harry off the field,â€ he said.

Hermione gave a short nod. â€œYou understand why, donâ€™t you?â€

Ronâ€™s expression hardened further as he shrugged and nodded.

â€œNo good risking him in a skirmish when we need him for the final blow. Yeah. I get it. That doesnâ€™t mean I like it. And some of theseâ€”,â€ he pulled a few scrolls over and glanced down at them. â€œTheyâ€™re pretty much suicide missions. I hadnâ€™t realized how safe Kingsley has been playing it because of Harry. Seeing what heâ€™ll do when weâ€™re gone for a few weeksâ€”â€œ

He broke off as he stared angrily down at the reports. â€œWhat exactly were the casualty rates while we were gone?â€

Hermione opened her mouth to answer, and he cut her off.

â€œI donâ€™t need you to tell me. I can see the numbers right here. Fuckingâ€”fucking bloody unbelievable. If Kingsley were here, Iâ€™d punch him.â€

His face was growing scarlet with rage.

â€œRon, we canâ€™t afford to play it safe anymore,â€ Hermione said, her stomach knotting itself as she thought about all the people whose eyes sheâ€™d drawn shut during the past several weeks, the new hospice safe house sheâ€™d helped Bill ward. â€œI donâ€™t think you realise how depleted our resources are. How many years do you think Harryâ€™s vault can feed an army? The hospital ward is running on fumes. Europe is getting locked under Tomâ€™s control. The only option we have left is to take risks. And we canâ€™t risk Harry.â€

Ron was silent. Hermione could see the muscles of his jaw working as he kept clenching and releasing it.

â€œWe need to find the horcruxes,â€ he finally said. Hermione let out a low, deep breath that sheâ€™d been anxiously holding and nodded.

â€œWe do,â€ she said. â€œTom and Harry are the linchpins. Ideologically, the Death Eaters are too diverse. Itâ€™s Tomâ€™s power that keeps the army cohesive. If we can kill him, permanently, there should be enough infighting to give the Resistance the upper hand.â€

â€œI guess thatâ€™s the one upside to Tomâ€™s delusions of immortality, he isnâ€™t bothering to groom a successor,â€ Ron said woodenly as he looked over another mission report. Hermione could see her signature on the bottom, verifying the injured, calculating the losses in neat, impersonal numbers. â€œAlthough I donâ€™t doubt the Malfoys will think theyâ€™re first in line now that Bellatrix is dead. Fucking psychopaths.â€

â€œYou need to convince Harry that the horcruxes are the first priority,â€ she said, staring at Ron intently. â€œEspecially now, after Ginny. Iâ€™m worried he just wants to ignore them.â€

Ronâ€™s expression grew strained.

â€œYeah,â€ he said quietly.

Hermione hesitantly drew closer.

â€œRon, I hope what I said at the meeting last night didnâ€™t make you feel like it was your fault. You saved Ginny. I didnâ€™t think it would be appropriate to withhold the information but I didnâ€™t mean to hurt you by disclosing it.â€

â€œItâ€™s fine,â€ he said, expression stiff. â€œYou made the right call.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€”â€

â€œDonâ€™t. I donâ€™t really want to talk about it,â€ he said in a shaking voice that brooked no argument.

Hermioneâ€™s eyes darted across his face, recognising the tension around his eyes, the scarlet tipping his ears while his face grew so pale his freckles stood out like drops of blood across his face.

If she pushed, heâ€™d explode.

Hermione felt her heart sink.

â€œRight. Well, Iâ€™ll leave you to review,â€ she said turning to leave.

She made her way up a flight of stairs slowly.

The number of subjects she avoided with Harry and Ron in order to not fight with them had slowly created a chasm.

Trying to stay focused. Stay on mission. All those personal issues and arguments sheâ€™d put off for another day. Assuming the war would end and theyâ€™d have a chance to deal with it all without compromising their focus and risking someoneâ€™s life.

But the war had rolled on for years.

Now they barely knew how to speak to each other at all. There was so much unspoken resentment. So many things theyâ€™d waited too long to say. Every disagreement was about a thousand more things than merely the issue at hand.

The notion that they could ever go back and fix it felt impossible.

Maybe there had been a chance before Malfoy. But nowâ€”

Hermione felt almost certain that she had crossed a line that they would never allow her to come back from. To them, the magnitude of the betrayal would permanently sever things.

Just thinking about it made it hard to breathe.

She found herself in a practice room. She went over, slotted her feet under a wardrobe used to store equipment and started doing sit-ups until her abdominal muscles felt like they had been injected with acid.

She had discovered that Dracoâ€™s exercise regime was an excellent way of channeling her stress, frustration and grief. She never intended to tell him, but she wished she had started exercising years ago. The physical symptoms of stress could not be suppressed with occlumency. Funneling it all into exercise was an excellent means to burn it off.

The surge of endorphins afterward was an additional upside.

After doing so many sit-up repetitions that she could barely peel herself off the floor, she rolled over and started doing push ups. She was rubbish at them, but she was also resolved. She was determined to work her way up until she actually did as many in a row as Draco had instructed.

She was slick with sweat and felt as though sheâ€™d been struck by a full body jelly-jinx when she finished all the various repetitions. She was only doing a quarter of the quantity, but she had finally managed to work through all of different exercises.

She stumbled down the stairs and fell asleep in the window seat.

When she woke the next morning, her whole body was protesting. Every bit of her ached. She scuttled down the stairs into a bathroom and took a long shower before anyone else was up.

That night she carefully reviewed her mental checklist of what she needed for Dracoâ€™s procedure. Sheâ€™d bought a cheap bottle of tequila in case he decided he wanted something. She doubted heâ€™d have ever tasted the muggle alcohol, and sheâ€™d decided that he deserved to suffer if he chose to ignore her advice about bringing his own.

While she was packing up several potions, she felt someone breach the wards on her potion closet and turned to find Harry standing awkwardly behind her.

â€œHermione,â€ he said, only meeting her eyes for a moment before dropping his gaze.

â€œYes?â€ she said cautiously, slipping a few more vials into the pockets in her satchel.

â€œIâ€”,â€œ he started and then stalled.

She glanced at her watch. She was due to meet Draco in seven minutes.

â€œDid Ginny send you?â€ she said with a faint edge to her voice. Even before Ginny and Harry had started shagging, Ginny had made it her business to force Hermione and Harry to try to patch things after they fought.

â€œYeah,â€ he said awkwardly, shoving his hands into his pockets. Hermioneâ€™s jaw tightened.

â€œWell, you can tell her we talked. Itâ€™s fine. No hard feelings. Iâ€™m sure you were just tired and looking out for your best friend,â€ Hermione said in a dismissive tone, glancing at her watch again.

Harry said nothing, and Hermione started stepping around him to leave. He caught her arm.

â€œHermione,â€ he said firmly. â€œI am sorry. And not just because Gin sent me. I crossed a line. I was angry because of how upset Ron was, and I vented it at you. I questioned how you treated Ginny and Ron, even though I know your first priority is always your patients. Iâ€™m sorry for that.â€

Hermione paused and stared at Harry, her expression closed.

It was a apology for insulting and doubting her as a Healer. It wasnâ€™t an apology to her.

He studied her face for several seconds.

â€œYouâ€™reâ€”one of my best friends,â€ he added.

Hermione felt something inside of her fade away. As though she carried a flame in her heart and it had abruptly guttered and left her in darkness.

The words wereâ€”a second thought. Something to say because heâ€™d said it before. Because it was a thing he was supposed to say to her.

She felt her jaw tremble.

She stared at him. Something showed on her face because Harry abruptly stepped forward and hugged her tightly.

She clung to him for a minute.

â€œSorry. Iâ€™m really sorry,â€ he spoke into the side of her head, his voice muffled.

She tried to collect herself. She had no time or capacity for emotions right then.

She fisted her hands and shook for a moment as she hugged him back, before forcing her mental walls back into place. There was no room for Harry inside them.

â€œIâ€™m just tired. It was right for you to look out for Ron. You were right, I wasnâ€™t thinking about him when I brought it up.â€ She pushed herself out of Harryâ€™s arms. â€œYouâ€™re a good friend to him.â€

Harry stared at her carefully.

â€œAm I a good friend to you?â€ he asked.

Hermione met his eyes.

â€œThe best,â€ she said in a steady voice. â€œ Always my best friend.â€

Harryâ€™s face grew relieved.

â€œGinny says she wants to test run her face in a Muggle pub so a few of us are going out tonight. Pomfrey said youâ€™re not on shift tonight. Do you want to come?â€

Hermioneâ€™s heart rose for a beat and then sank.

â€œI canâ€™t,â€ she said. â€œI promised one of the hospice houses Iâ€™d come tonight for checkups and inventory. Iâ€™m already late.â€

â€œOh... Alright. Just wanted to ask,â€ Harry said.

â€œHave fun.â€

Harry nodded. â€œIâ€™ll go let Gin know.â€

She nodded and watched him walk away. When he had gone, she shut the door of her potion closet and stood for a minute trying to rein in everything.

She let out several sharp puffs of breath through her nose and then kicked the baseboard until the pain in her toes grew sharp.

She couldnâ€™t cry. She had to perform a complex healing procedure. There was no space in her head for emotions. She had no time to cry about Harry.

She pressed her lips into a hard line and tried to recentre.

After a minute she managed to shove the maelstrom down. Stifling it in the back of her mind. She waited until her breathing was even. Then she walked out of Grimmauld Place, smiling and giving a quick wave to everyone heading into London.

She was four minutes late when she walked into the shack. Draco appeared a minute later.

He stared at her.

â€œI almost thought you were standing me up,â€ he said wryly.

â€œSomeone wanted to talk. I didnâ€™t have an excuse to rush away,â€ she said as she conjured a small table and began pulling supplies out of her satchel.

Malfoy watched her work in silence for a minute.

â€œYouâ€™re a walking hospital,â€ he said.

â€œI have to be.â€

She arranged everything in the order she would need it and then summoned one of the chairs.

â€œItâ€™ll be easier for you to test dexterity in a chair than on a medical table,â€ she said. â€œYou should remove your shirt entirely.â€

He began unbuttoning it while Hermione straightened her supplies and ran her eyes over them carefully one last time.

â€œThere are two ways to heal incisions as deep as yours,â€ she said, looking up at him. â€œPainlessly, but the scarring of the muscle tissue can result in long term limitations to your shouldersâ€™ mobility. Or painfully, in order to ensure the scar tissue doesnâ€™t bind in ways that will interfere with your dexterity. I assumed you would choose the latter.â€

He nodded. Watching her carefully.

â€œI can use pain relief charms on the incisions that Iâ€™m not healing, but I canâ€™t use any potions that will reduce your sensations or you wonâ€™t be able to tell me if the scar tissue is forming properly. This is going to hurt.â€

â€œI am aware,â€ he said in a hard voice.

Hermione pulled out the tequila and set it on the table. â€œAlcohol helps. Assuming you donâ€™t get totally smashed, it will help keep the pain manageable without reducing the sensation in your shoulders to a degree that interferes with healing. This is a muggle alcohol called tequila. It was very cheap. I donâ€™t have a large alcohol budget.â€

She pulled out Draught of Peace. â€œA double dose of of Calming Draught helps too. Being tense wonâ€™t help.â€

She handed Draco the large vial of Calming Draught and watched him take it.

â€œReady?â€ she said. She hadnâ€™t felt so nervous about a healing procedure in a long time.

He straddled the chair, and she began.

She carefully grew a section of scar tissue and then made him fully rotate, extend and stretch his shoulder. It pulled. She cast a spell to help relax the tissue but it still pulled. She had to cut part of it away and grow it again.

Bit by bit.

Blood was streaming from the other runes as the movement continuously agitated them.

She set the scar tissue for four runes before Draco finally broke down and wandlessly conjured a bottle of vintage firewhisky.

She didnâ€™t say anything, pausing while he wrenched the cork out with his teeth and then guzzled it for several seconds. Then he set it firmly beside the bottle of tequila and dropped his head down onto the back of the chair.

â€œFuck. Fuck. Fuck,â€ he muttered.

â€œSorry,â€ she said awkwardly, placing her hand lightly on his shoulder as she started to work again.

â€œSave it, Granger,â€ he snarled. His face was pale, and he was gripping the back of the chair until his knuckles turned white.

He drank in between every rune after that.

By the time she started on his other shoulder, he was moving steadily beyond buzzed and into the early stages of drunkenness.

â€œFucking hell,â€ he groaned in a low voice. â€œI always said you were a complete and utter bitch. You donâ€™t have to show me.â€

Hermione pressed her lips firmly together, torn between offense, amusement, and sympathy.

â€œThe bitch who heals you,â€ she said.

He chuckled.

â€œApparently.â€

He didnâ€™t speak again except to answer her questions about the scar tissue until she finished. She cleaned all the blood off his back.

She gently applied several analgesics and a final layer of a creamy potion to help the new tissue set properly. The scars were an angry red.

She glanced at her watch. It was well past midnight. It had taken longer than sheâ€™d expected.

â€œAlright,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m finished.â€

Malfoy sighed with relief and gulped the last of the firewhisky before shoving the second emptied bottle onto the table beside the first.

He was still for several seconds as though regaining his bearings. Then he cocked his head to the side and eyed the tequila.

â€œWhat even is this?â€ he said grasping it by the neck and inspecting it.

He showed almost no signs of drunkenness. His words were unslurred and his hands remained steady. Hermione had never seen anyone drink so much alcohol and remain so externally unaffected.

It was terrifying how controlled he was.

â€œDonâ€™t drink it. It was so cheap. Youâ€™ve just imbibed a hundred galleons worth of vintage alcohol. Donâ€™t top it off with that.â€

He wasnâ€™t inclined to listen. He unscrewed it, sniffed it and then took an inquiring sip. He spat it immediately on the floor.

â€œThe fuck! This is varnish. Poisoning me now, Granger?â€

â€œI was thinking of it as a punishment if youâ€™d chosen not to believe me and didnâ€™t bring your own,â€ Hermione said wryly. â€œIâ€™m told it tastes better if consumed with salt and a lime wedge.â€

â€œTold?â€

â€œI donâ€™t drink much, especially not out in the Muggle world,â€ Hermione reminded him.

â€œYou donâ€™t even know what you bought.â€ His mouth was still twisted as though he couldnâ€™t get the taste off his tongue.

â€œI just went for inexpensive and high alcohol content,â€ she said.

â€œI shouldnâ€™t be surprised. Your idea of getting drunk is drinking port and pretending to be a troll under a bridge,â€ he said, chuckling faintly.

Hermione made a sour expression as she finished packing up her healing supplies. She rummaged through her bag and cursed inwardly. Sheâ€™d forgotten to bring sobriety potion. Sheâ€™d had it on her mental checklist, but it had slipped her mind when Harry appeared.

â€œWell. Iâ€™m done. Are you safe to apparate?â€ she asked, eying him carefully. She didnâ€™t think he possibly could be.

He appeared to be considering the question for several seconds. Tilting his head from side to side and cocking an eyebrow.

â€œI donâ€™t believe it would be a medically advisable,â€ he said at last.

She sighed with relief. She had no idea what sheâ€™d do if he had tried to insist that he was sober. She wondered if sheâ€™d be able to stun him if he wasnâ€™t letting her.

â€œRight. Well, do you want me to conjure a bed for you? Iâ€™m pretty good at them,â€ she asked.

â€œEager to be off?â€ he said, standing and giving her a piercing look. He did not appear to be drunk at all. â€œGot someone waiting for you?â€

The question caught her off guard. She blinked and thought of everyone else at a pub without her.

â€œNo,â€ she said shaking her head.

â€œNeither do I,â€ he announced. Then with a wandless, nonverbal wave of his hand, another bottle of Ogdenâ€™s Reserved appeared. â€œLetâ€™s drink.â€

She stared at him. She hadnâ€™t anticipated the evening going in this direction.

He had to be just ridiculously drunk. With the amount of firewhiskey he had imbibed, he should have been insensate.

â€œI donâ€™t think thatâ€™s a very good idea,â€ she said, sidling toward the door.

â€œCome on, Granger,â€ he said cajolingly and stalked forward, closing in on her, bottle in hand. He was still shirtless. â€œThe Orderâ€™s lonely little healer. Try drinking somewhere that isnâ€™t a creekbed.â€

Hermione bumped into the wall as she backed away from him. He loomed over her, and she tilted her head back in order to maintain eye contact. He smirked down at her.

â€œYou should feel privileged. I hardly drink with anyone. I never get drunk around anyone. Itâ€™s such a terrible idea. Occlumencyâ€™s shoddy. Slowed reflexes. Terrible idea.â€

â€œYou said that,â€ Hermione pointed out, sliding her hand behind her back and trying to find the door knob.

â€œDid I...?â€ He blinked. â€œSee? Somehowâ€”when it comes to youâ€”,â€œ he sighed and rested his forehead on the top of her head. Hermione stood frozen in astonishment.

His empty hand came up and he grazed her cheek lightly with his fingertips. Gliding his thumb along her cheekbone. Hermioneâ€™s breath caught in her throat.

â€œYou inspire terrible decisions. Something about you. I canâ€™t understand it.â€ He lifted his head and leaned back just enough to stare at her. â€œWhat makes you so special?â€

Hermione found the doorknob and turned it, trying to pull the door open. It wouldnâ€™t budge. She glanced down and found the toe of Dracoâ€™s shoe lodged against it.

She looked up at him, and he smirked.

â€œCome on, Granger. Whereâ€™s your Gryffindor courage?â€ he said, his voice low, coming from the back of his throat so that it sounded husky. â€œHave a drink with me. Iâ€™ll even call you Hermione.â€

She shivered at the sound of her name dripping off his lips. The clipped, to-the-point manner in which he usually spoke was gone. He was terrifyingly playful. Like a kneazle with a gnome in its claws.

She tried the door again. He seemed to be getting closer. There was barely any space between them. She could feel the heat of his bare chest on her face. His eyes were hooded but glittering as he stared down at her.

Her heart rate started to steadily spike. She was on the verge of asking him to let her leave. Of telling him that he was scaring her.

She opened her mouth to say it. Then she caught herself.

She should stay.

Draco Malfoy was handing himself to her on a drunk platter.

If she had ever hoped for an in, this was it. The opportunity would never repeat itself. Even he was admitting he was making a mistake. That it was a risk.

Staying was a risk for her, a corner of her mind whispered. She shook slightly and ignored it.

She had to stay.

She tried not to be overt about her change of mind.

â€œIâ€™m not afraid,â€ she said, jutting her chin out and pulling her hand off the doorknob.

He smirked. â€œReally?â€

â€œReally,â€ she said taking a minuscule step toward him. There was barely space to move.

She grabbed the bottle of Ogdenâ€™s from him and appraised it. It was an eighty year old reserve label. She pulled out the cork and sniffed it.

She was a lightweight, but she doubted she could fake drinking. Draco would notice.

And she needed the courage. She had no idea what a Draco Malfoy with lowered inhibitions might do. The thought made her feel cold with terror.

She met his amused gaze as she took a swig.

One of them was on a platter. The question was merely whom.

Flashback 15

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

August 2002

The firewhisky burned brightly down her throat, and instantly the pounding of her heart eased slightly. The hot feeling of courage spread across her chest.

She tilted the bottle toward Draco, and he plucked it from her hand and took a swig of his own. His eyes were locked on hers until he lowered it. Then he glanced around the bare room they were in. Pulling his wand from a holster strapped to his right arm, he flicked it and conjured a loveseat.

Hermione gave him a look.

â€œIâ€™m not scooting across a sofa every time we pass the bottle,â€ he said. Then he added in a mocking tone, â€œI can conjure a courting bench if you require a barrier.â€

His eyes were taunting. He was still shirtless.

â€œOr you could have conjured some tumblers,â€ she retorted, giving him a pointed look. She dropped down onto the small couch and waited for him to do the same.

He leaned down, resting his hand on the back of the couch behind her shoulder and leaned over her, sliding the bottle into her hand.

â€œYour turn. Youâ€™ve got a lot of catching up to do,â€ he said in a low voice before seating himself beside her. He was much closer than he needed to be.

Hermione took another sip, and he watched her. When she tried to hand it back, he demurred and indicated that she continue.

â€œYouâ€™ll regret it when I start crying on you,â€ she said, growing suspicious once again about how drunk he was. She could already feel it starting to hit her. Sheâ€™d picked at dinner and that had been hours earlier. A warm dulling sensation was beginning to creep over her.

â€œYou didnâ€™t cry that much,â€ he said, leaning back gingerly. Then, discovering that it didnâ€™t hurt, he sunk against the back the couch with an audible sigh. â€œI had no idea how much I missed leaning against things.â€

â€œBe careful for the next few days,â€ Hermione said between sips. â€œIf youâ€™re careless while theyâ€™re setting, the skin might tear, and Iâ€™ll have to redo parts. If you wantâ€”I can keep coming. If I keep treating them for a few days longer, you wonâ€™t even be able to feel them. As leastâ€”not the physical aspect of them.â€

He smirked over at her and shook his head as though in disbelief.

â€œIs there anyone you donâ€™t feel responsible for?â€ he asked.

Hermione didnâ€™t answer the question, and she took another gulp of firewhisky. Tears suddenly pricked at the corners of her eyes.

â€œAll my friends are out drinking tonight. They invited me, but I couldnâ€™t go,â€ she said abruptly.

He was quiet for a moment.

â€œIâ€™m sorry. We could have rescheduled,â€ he said.

Hermione scoffed.

â€œRight. Iâ€™d just leave you with lacerations in your back for an extra day so I could go drinking. Itâ€™s not as though I could even drink with them anyway. Iâ€™d probably get into some raging fight with Harry and Ron.â€

She burst into tears and cried for several minutes. While she was crying, Draco plucked the bottle from her fingers and set to draining it. When her sobbing finally eased to sniffling, he chuckled.

â€œYou know,â€ he said dryly, â€œif I ever had to interrogate you, I think Iâ€™d skip the torture and the legilimency and just pour a bottle of firewhisky down your throat.â€

Hermione started laughing through her tears.

â€œOh god, youâ€™re right,â€ she said huffing and wiping her eyes.

He handed the bottle back to her, and she sipped it for several minutes in silence.

â€œThank you, Granger,â€ he said quietly after a while.

The corner of her mouth curved into a small smile.Â â€œI thought you said if I drank with you that youâ€™d call me Hermione.â€

â€œHermione,â€ he said. She looked over at him. His eyes were hooded; he was staring over at her intently.

â€œYes?â€

He didnâ€™t say anything; he just kept staring at her until she started to blush. It was distracting to look back at him when he didnâ€™t have a shirt on. Her eyes kept dropping, then lingering, and then sheâ€™d catch herself and look up and find he was still looking at her.

â€œI thought you said you were angrier when you were drunk,â€ she finally said nervously.

â€œI normally am,â€ he said. â€œLast time I got drunk, I warded myself in and wrecked the room.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t seem drunk,â€ she said. She was beginning to feel really drunk. Her head felt heavy, and she had an overwhelming desire to both laugh and cry and curl up on the couch.

â€œIâ€™m not a relaxed person.â€

â€œIâ€™ve noticed. And you scold me,â€ she said severely. She felt her face make a more exaggerated expression than sheâ€™d meant to.

He laughed under his breath. â€œMy tension doesnâ€™t interfere with my dueling. I bet I could still beat you in a duel even now.â€

â€œYou probably could,â€ Hermione said with a sigh. â€œIâ€™ve been exercising though. I thought I would hate it, but itâ€™s actually nice.â€

He smirked, and it was loose and crooked. Hermione blushed.

â€œYou should put a shirt on,â€ she finally said, her voice jumping. â€œYou must be cold.â€

Suddenly her hand was in his, and he had pressed it against his chest. She gasped faintly with surprise and felt her heart rate begin rapidly increasing.

â€œDo I feel cold?â€ he asked in a low voice. Heâ€™d sat up and they were suddenly very, very close. So close Hermione could feel his breath against her neck. A shiver rolled down her spine.

â€œN-no,â€ she whispered, staring at her fingers splayed across his chest. Sheâ€™d spent hours touching him as she treated his runes, but being face to face made the physical contact suddenly intimate. She could feel the faintest sensation of his heartbeat under her index finger. Without thinking, she stroked his skin lightly.

â€œYou should go now,â€ he said.

His voice was cold. Hard. Clipped and to the point once more.

His mask had dropped neatly back into place.

Flashback 16

August 2002

Hermione pressed her lips together as she stared over at Draco, breathing raggedly.

â€œIâ€™m too drunk. I canâ€™t apparate,â€ she said. â€œI told you, I cry. I canâ€™t help it. I donâ€™t know how to hold it all in when Iâ€™m drunk.â€

She clamped her hands over her mouth and struggled not to burst into tears. They leaked out of her eyes and slid over her fingers.

â€œBecause Iâ€™m lonely and Iâ€™m snogging you and you donâ€™t even really think Iâ€™m attractive,â€ she admitted tearfully.

Draco looked at her for a moment and then tilted his head back and stared up at the ceiling for a full minute.

She bit her lip as she tried not to start crying again. She snatched the bottle off the floor where it had been abandoned at some point and gulped more of the remaining firewhisky. There was less than an inch left, and she had a lingering hope that if she finished all of it, it would take her to a point of inebriation beyond feeling.

Malfoy looked away from her, and then leaned back and slung his arm over his eyes. When she had finished the bottle of Ogdenâ€™s, she glanced over at him. His arm had slumped down; he was asleep.

She stared at him for a long time, studying his features in a way she had never permitted herself to in the past. Then, gradually, she found her eyelids closing. She didnâ€™t know which of them moved but when they stirred the next morning, they were half entwined with each other. Somehow neither of them had fallen off the small couch. If he could get his other arm free, he could grab the back of the couch and free himself. But when he tried to move his shoulder, it also resulted in wobbling.

Most people her age didnâ€™t even have clearance to access her when she was working on research or potions, and visiting was carefully regulated in the hospital. There simply had never been the time.

They stood at the opening of a narrow cave. Kingsley went over and tapped on a large boulder beside the cave opening.

Rather than formally induct her into the British Resistance or the Order, Kingsley had swept Gabrielle into his secret reconnaissance team; a team even most of the members of the Order were largely ignorant of.

Kingsleyâ€™s recruits were scattered across Europe gathering intelligence. They were mostly free agents. Kingsley left them with vague directions and great deal of leeway regarding what means they should use to extract the information. So long as the information was good he made no move to rein in or question their methods.

They were supposed to bring back their targets to be imprisoned. Hermione was called in to heal them before they were placed in suspended animation.

Gabrielle was exceptionally talented at information gathering. She used her veela allure and entrapped her targets somewhere she could interrogate them however she pleased. She also tended to bring back far more information than prisoners.

But she felt like a monster each time she was brought in to heal someone caught by the reconnaissance team, wondering whether she was enabling future victims by cooperating.

Even if they were Death Eaters, wanting them dead on a battlefield was different from letting them be tortured.

â€œIâ€™m going to fix your hands first,â€ she said softly to the man.

She knelt down beside him then lightly placed her hand under his right hand and lifted it into the light.

With a quick spell she aerosolised an analgesic potion and guided the mist around the fingers and thumb. There had been needles driven under the nail beds repeatedly.

When the skin had absorbed the potion, she lightly took the hand in hers and began performing the spells to repair the tissue damage.

She had worked across three fingers when he spoke.

â€œI know you,â€ he said, raising his head.

She glanced up. He looked vaguely familiar. Solidly built. Dark haired with thick stubble. His arms and hands were hairy.

â€œYouâ€™re Potterâ€™s Mudblood bitch,â€ he said.

Hermione raised an eyebrow and continued onto the next finger.

â€œYou certainly grew up,â€ he said with a leer. â€œI would never have thought a frizzhead like you would have ended up looking like that.â€

Hermione ignored him.

â€œGranger, isnâ€™t it? Iâ€™ll have to tell everyone I saw you. We thought you were dead.â€

He leaned forward until his face was unnervingly close to Hermioneâ€™s.

â€œIâ€™m going to tell you a secret, Mudblood,â€ he muttered. â€œYouâ€™re going to lose this war. And when you do, Iâ€™m going to kill the blonde bitch out there so slowly sheâ€™ll beg me for it.â€

Hermione continued to ignore him as she closed the razor fine lacerations that had been cut into his palms.

She finished with his first hand and then started on the second. She dreaded the thought of finishing, but eventually there was no more work left to do on his hands, and she could avoid it no longer.

â€œIâ€™ll need you to sit back, if you want me to heal what has been done to your genitals,â€ she forced herself to say steadily.

Her whole body felt cold. Her stomach twisted so painfully she wondered if sheâ€™d ever be able to digest food again.

He leaned back in the chair he was restrained in and opened his knees. His expression was taunting, as though he was the one in power.

She wanted to stun him.

She was supposed to leave them conscious when she healed them. It was part of the psychology that Kingsley employed.

She flicked her wand to perform an unbuttoning charm then reached out and opened his trousers.

Gabrielle had used some type of fine blade to carve words into the shaft of his penis. Hermione couldnâ€™t read the French through the ragged incisions and blood. She had a brief moment of gratitude that they werenâ€™t runes.

Then she got to work.

She was determined to try not to touch him which made the wand work more elaborate. She banished the blood and cast a mild cleansing charm.

The young man moaned in pain for the first time. Then she siphoned out essence of murtlap from a vial and applied it magically. It was less precise and gentle but Hermione refused to let herself care.

Hermione murmured the necessary healing charms and cast a second diagnostic. He had a lot of alcohol in his system. It was probably part of how Gabrielle had gotten close. Hermione pulled out a sobriety potion and poured it down his throat. He recognised the potion because he didnâ€™t struggle the way she expected him to.

Then she stepped back and appraised him.

He stared up at her as she reached into her bag and pulled out a hangover relief potion and offered it to him.

After he swallowed it, he sneered at her.

â€œPatching me up for round two?â€ he guessed. â€œAnd here I thought you were all bleeding hearts with a no-kill policy.â€

Hermione gave him a thin smile she had learned from Malfoy.

â€œWeâ€™re not going to kill you.â€

Then she turned on her heel and walked out. As the door shut behind her, she stood for a moment collecting herself.

She felt like a fucking bitch.

She had lied to Malfoy the first time sheâ€™d been drunk; she had no shreds of decency left. The war had ripped them all away.

The only thing she had left was her determination to save Ron and Harry. To win the war.

She would climb over tortured bodies, sell herself, and tear out Draco Malfoyâ€™s heart if it was required to achieve it.

When her friends were safe, she would stand quietly beside Kingsley and Moody, and swallow her damnation without a murmur.

Flashback 17

August 2002

Hermione sat on a rock on the beach while she waited for Kingsley to call her back to administer the Draught of Living Death. As she sat, she kept replaying the previous night over and over, looking for anything she might have missed.Â 

She had concluded upon further review of the night that Draco was attracted to her at some level. Afterall, he had called her lovely, compared her to a rose in a graveyard, and claimed he was blindsided. She snorted faintly and wondered if he would ever have admitted such a thing if he hadnâ€™t been on his third bottle of firewhisky.

He lacked intimacy in his life. Whether or not she met his general standards for physical appeal, he was emotionally vulnerable to her.

She had also determined that it was probably for the best that they hadnâ€™t had sex.

His current interest was like a kindling flame; too much fuel and sheâ€™d smother it. Now that it seemed undeniable that she had his attention, sheâ€™d have to move cautiously. The key would lie in carefully cultivating it into something uncontrollable for him; something he couldnâ€™t stop himself from wanting more than anything else.

It would take time.

Draco was patient. He was willing to lie and manipulate and murder and climb as far as necessary to get what he wanted. The revengeâ€”atonement, or whatever his alliance with the Order was based onâ€”was something he was willing to wait to get; heâ€™d suffer and sacrifice for as long as it took.

To try to direct his ambition and insidiously obsessive nature toward herself was a terrifying risk. As Severus has said, she was as likely to destroy the Order as save it.

She could feel herself panicking at the thought. Her chest tightened, and it felt as though the ocean wind was stealing her breath. She dropped her head between her knees and forced herself to inhale slowly.

She could do it. She could do it because she had to do it. Because there was no other way to win the war.

The very notion of being able to control him had felt delusional and theoretical up until then.

The idea that she could buy the war with herâ€”emotional intimacy had seemed fundamentally absurd until she felt herself dipped into the deep undercurrent of Malfoyâ€™s unrestrained attention.

He was so controlled, even when drunk. Even when he had kissed her. He hadnâ€™t rushed or been over-eager. His passion hadnâ€™t been explosive. It was a smoldering fire; the kind that grew secretly, like a ground fire deep in the earth, spreading and waiting before rising up, destroying the world above. She suspected he burned for things more deeply than even he was aware of.

She laid out her campaign carefully in her mind.

He would be more careful the next time he saw her. He would probably try to force her away and recreate the distance. Perhaps that would play to Hermioneâ€™s advantage.

After all, there was no greater temptation than the forbidden fruit. The more he was thinking about her; about being careful around her, about how he shouldnâ€™t have her, the more sheâ€™d consume him. The more heâ€™d want her.

The fact that she wanted him backâ€¦

Hermione swallowed and nibbled nervously on her thumbnail.

She would use that too. If the tension was real on both sides, it would make it harder for him to resist. She didnâ€™t know how to fake it anyway. She was too inexperienced. The sense of longing she felt would be included in her repertoire.

She smiled bitterly to herself.

Sheâ€™d prostitute her soul to win the war. Using her feelings as currency should be even easier.

Should be...

Somehow rationalising things didnâ€™t always stop them from hurting.

The sharp sound of crunching rocks caught her attention. She turned and found Bill approaching.

â€œKingsley sent me to find you; heâ€™s finished,â€ Bill said.

Hermione stared up at him. The war had aged the oldest Weasley boy. The jaunty, cool Curse Breaker had been ground down into a hard and pensive looking man.

Bill had been the one on a mission with Arthur when Arthur had been cursed. The guilt had smothered something in him. He was cold and reliable and mechanical in his work, and his work was all he did. Hermione consulted with him sometimes over curse research. There was never any small-talk; no jokes, or off-handed remarks. Even Severus was more conversant.

Hermione stood and followed him. As they walked down the beach, Bill abruptly stopped and looked at her.

Hermione waited.

â€œGabrielleâ€”,â€ Bill started and then hesitated. â€œFleurâ€™s worried.â€

Hermione didnâ€™t say anything. She had no idea what she could say about the girl.

â€œWhat exactly is she doing?â€ Bill asked.

â€œShe intercepts messengers that Tom sends to other parts of Europe,â€ Hermione said carefully.

â€œI know that. But how?â€

â€œShe hasnâ€™t told me,â€ Hermione said. â€œYouâ€™d have to ask her or Kingsley.â€

â€œI think sheâ€™s fucking them,â€ Bill said abruptly. His entire face seemed carved from stone. â€œI think she fucks them and then when theyâ€™re asleep she ties them up and tortures them.â€

Hermione pressed her lips together and didnâ€™t say anything.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Hermione finally said after a long pause. â€œI only heal the targets brought in. Iâ€™m not informed about methods.â€

Bill clenched his jaw visibly. â€œA lot of healing?â€

Hermione shifted and brushed at her nose.

â€œNothing permanent,â€ she said quietly.

He stood silent for a moment before turning to continue on. Hermione followed him back to the staircase on the beach.

The prisoner was still under the heavy influence of veritaserum when she entered the room. He was slumped down in the chair with his head lolling to the side.

Hermione walked over and cast a diagnostic charm on him.

â€œWeâ€™re going to winâ€”going to win. Youâ€™re gonna die. All of you are gonna dieâ€¦â€ he was mumbling under his breath.

Hermione examined the diagnostic and found that Kingsley had administered some kind of hallucinogenic along with the truth potion. She looked over sharply at the desk where Kingsley was writing down notes.

â€œThe chemical reaction of those potions can cause permanent mania and obsessive behavior,â€ she said in rebuke. â€œYou should have consulted with me.â€

Kingsley glanced up at her.

â€I consulted with our other Potion master,â€ he said calmly. â€œInterrogation is not your specialty. This one knew occlumency. He required additional measures.â€

Hermione bit her tongue and turned back to the prisoner. His brain showed signs of extreme inflammation. She cursed under her breath and rummaged through her bag for something that might neutralise the effects. It was an unusual reaction; without her full potion supply closet she had limited options for counteracting it.

A tincture of distilled billywig sting slime combined with a drop of syrup of hellebore would have a cooling effect on the brain, she concluded. She amalgamated them quickly in a vial and then tilted the prisonerâ€™s head back to administer it.

His eyes were rolled back in his head, and when she touched the vial the to his lips, he squeezed his eyes and mouth closed.

â€œCome on now,â€ Hermione said gently. â€œThis will help your head.â€

He cracked an eye open to peer at her for a moment before opening both. She watched as his pupils suddenly dilated, and his gaze fastened on her intently.

â€œI remember you,â€ he said, â€œyouâ€™re Potterâ€™s bitch.â€

â€œYou need to take this or youâ€™re going to risk brain damage,â€ Hermione said, unfazed.

He parted his lips and downed the tincture and then hissed and shook his head slightly. Hermione recast a diagnostic and watched the inflammation rapidly fade away.

She looked back at his face and saw that his pupils had contracted into tiny dots in the center of his irises. His gaze was still fastened on Hermione in a way that grew quickly unnerving.

â€œHow do you feel?â€ she asked.

â€œCold...my brain feels cold. My brain is cold, but the sight of you is warming the rest of me right up,â€ he said in a vaguely singsong tone.

He suddenly lunged forward, and his teeth snapped closed on air as Hermione stepped quickly back. He laughed.

â€œWhat do you think you are, a werewolf?â€ she said sharply. The question was rhetorical; diagnostic readings would indicate lycanthropy.

He snickered. His expression was still dazed with veritaserum, but his eyes remained fastened on Hermione.

â€œIâ€™m not a werewolf. But Iâ€™m going to remember you,â€ he said. â€œWhen you lose this war, Iâ€™m going to remember you. Iâ€™m going to kill that blonde bitch, but I think Iâ€™ll ask the Dark Lord if I can have you. He might want to keep you alive. Iâ€™ll keep you alive.â€

His eyes crawled over Hermione, and she shivered. She was coming to regret healing the brain inflammation. Something about the rapid way sheâ€™d counteracted the hallucinogenic appeared to have locked the obsessive tendency sheâ€™d worried about directly upon herself.

â€œThatâ€™s enough, Montague!â€ Kingsley said sharply, standing up and walking over.

Hermione glanced over, finally recognizing the prisoner. Heâ€™d been a few years above her at Hogwarts. Graham Montague.

â€œWe have everything we needed from him,â€ Kingsley said, gathering up several rolls of parchment. â€œYou can put him under.â€

Hermione nodded and stunned Montague. His eyes were still fastened on her face as he slumped back.

As she finished prepping him for stasis, she consoled herself that even if the Order lost the war, it was unlikely that the cave would be discovered. She would never see him again.

When the Draught of Living Death was administered, Hermione handed Montague over to Bill and then headed back to Grimmauld Place.

Draco had left no scroll of information when Hermione returned to the shack that evening. She stood there for several minutes, wondering if heâ€™d show up to have her check the scar tissue.

After ten minutes of waiting, she left.

She wasnâ€™t sure what it meant. It was possible there hadnâ€™t been any new intelligence, but she couldnâ€™t ease her fear that it was retribution for the morning. She tried not to let it stress her and reassured herself that if heâ€™d had anything urgent, he would have mentioned it sooner.

No longer needing to heal Draco each evening made her progress feel stalled. She found herself thinking about him often. Not strategically. She wondered about how he was, whether the scars were irritating him.

She kept reevaluating and re-analysing their snog session and its aftermath until she felt as though she were a bit mad.

The inconclusiveness of it grated on her mind. She found it difficult to focus or sleep that week.

She had given up on using her room for sleeping. Harry and Ginny regularly occupied it for the entire night. Harry slept when he was with Ginny. He could actually sleep peacefully. The effect was dramatic. His mood stabilised in a way that it hadnâ€™t in years, and Hermione rarely encountered him in the sitting room at night. The stress that had been erroding him for years seemed to ease for the first time since Dumbledoreâ€™s death.

Hermione took to sleeping in whatever empty bed she could find or in the training rooms. She kept exercising and building her stamina up dutifully.

The next Tuesday she was so stressed she took a Calming Draught before she apparated to the shack. She had no idea what Draco might do.

When she arrived in the shack, she bounced on the balls of her feet while she stood waiting. Then she realized there was a scroll laying on the table.

She stared at it for a moment before picking it up and unfurling it. Raids for the upcoming week. Counter-curses.

Nothing directed to Hermione.

â€”not that sheâ€™d expected him to leave her a personal note.

She sighed faintly and left.

She didnâ€™t see him for the entire month of August.

She fretted about it. The intentional silence between them gnawed at her. She kept reviewing what had happened, questioning her conclusions and drawing new ones. Maybe sheâ€™d ruined everything. Or maybe he was avoiding her because he was afraid of how she tempted him.

She kept vacillating. Was it a good sign or a bad sign?

The worst part was that she missed him. She hated to admit as much to herself, but she felt forced to acknowledge it. Treating his injury had become a significant aspect of her daily life. Interacting with him had become a significant aspect of her life. Having it so abruptly ended made her feel the absence keenly. She didnâ€™t have many people that she saw regularly.

She kept replaying all their past interactions. She kept reevaluating him and all his behavior. She was obsessing but she didnâ€™t know what else to do. She needed him for the Order.

She had to obsess over him. It was her job.

She didnâ€™t need to miss him though, she told herself firmly. That was a personal failing.

September rolled around and he continued to simply leave scrolls without appearing.

Hermione began to feel fractured.

She didnâ€™t know what she was supposed to do.

It was smart of him, of course. If she were in his shoes, it would probably be what sheâ€™d do. But it didnâ€™t solve the problem of what Hermione was supposed to do about it.

She kept foraging and visiting the shack with increasingly dwindling hope.

As Malfoy had warned her, larger and larger swaths of Englandâ€™s countryside had anti-apparition wards dropped over them. For weeks Hermione tried to avoid the areas and forage elsewhere, but eventually the wards swallowed up all the areas she needed to forage in. She tried to find new spots, but she couldnâ€™t obtain sufficient quantities of certain crucial ingredients.

When her dittany supply ran out, she gave up and ventured into a warded forest. She cast all the detection spells she knew and stayed alert.

She was harvesting her third, large bed of dittany when the forest grew unnaturally quiet. She immediately stashed her supply and turned sharply, casting new detection spells in every direction. Nothing.

She trusted her instincts. She was a good hundred feet from the edge of the anti-apparition zone. She headed for it calmly, trying not to to betray her concern. She held her silver knife in one hand and her wand in the other as she picked her way carefully through the bracken. Â 

They waited until she was close enough to the edge of the ward to feel hopeful.

Razor sharp teeth suddenly sank into the back of her right leg. She screamed slightly and whirled to find that a gytrash had emerged from the darkness and slashed her calf open.

â€œLumos!â€ she snapped. The ghostly dog promptly released her leg and melted back into the darkness of the forest. Hermione didnâ€™t pause to check the injury. She raised her wand and looked for more creatures. Gytrash tended to run in packs.

They also werenâ€™t typically aggressive toward adult humans.

As she was turning around warily, something abruptly dropped on her from a tree overhead. She barely had time to look up and see the pale skin and elongated fangs of a vampire before it knocked her flat. The vampire closed its hand around the wrist of her wand hand and pinned her to the ground as it sank its fangs into her shoulder.

Hermione didnâ€™t even think. She lashed out and buried the blade of her silver harvesting knife into the vampireâ€™s temple, wrenching herself free. She flung herself to her feet and bolted past the anti-apparition wards.

She reappeared and nearly collapsed in the middle of the creek in Whitecroft.

It was not an ideal place to reappear. She glanced around dazedly and wondered why on earth it had been the first place sheâ€™d thought of. She was bleeding profusely. Vampire fangs injected anticoagulant venom into the blood at first contact, and Hermione had torn her shoulder badly as she had ripped herself free. Her entire shoulder grew drenched with blood as she stood, trying to regain her bearings.

She looked down at her leg. She was bleeding badly there too.

She didnâ€™t have the energy to apparate again.

A car drove by and Hermione ducked awkwardly under the bridge until it passed. She had the supplies she needed to heal herself, but she didnâ€™t particularly fancy doing it in the dark under a bridge.

She checked the time. It was more than an hour earlier than she was supposed to show up to pick up Dracoâ€™s missives. She sighed. Knowing him heâ€™d probably left it the night before anyway.

She cast a disillusioning charm on herself then pressed down hard against her shoulder to slow the bleeding as she limped to the shack.

As she had guessed, the scroll was already on the table when she opened the door. She rolled her eyes and stuffed it into her satchel with her less blood-stained hand.

Hermione sat heavily in a chair and cast a diagnostic. She had bled a lot. She would start getting light-headed if she didnâ€™t staunch it quickly. She pulled a bandage out of her emergency kit and used a spell to wrap it firmly around her calf. Sheâ€™d heal the Gytrash bite after she fixed her shoulder.

She arched her neck and tried to see the gashes. The movement twisted the injury; she hissed and conjured a mirror. The vampire had bitten down on the juncture of her neck and shoulder. When sheâ€™d torn herself free, the fangs had sliced long, deep lacerations over to her collarbone, barely missing her jugular vein and carotid artery.

Hermione cut off her shirt and cast a cleansing charm. Using the mirror and awkwardly working in reverse, she crushed and pummeled fresh dittany leaves in her fingers and then stuffed them into the gashes. Dittany wasnâ€™t very effective fresh, especially whole, but she didnâ€™t have a pestle on hand. She chewed on several leaves as she worked.

Holding her bunched up shirt firmly against the gashes with one hand, she set to work mixing together an infusion that could function as a coagulant. She couldnâ€™t brew a potion, but she had yarrow and murtlap essence. She combined them with a few practiced flicks of her wand and swallowed it quickly. After a minute, the bleeding in her shoulder began to ease.

She was covered in blood, and there was a decent sized puddle of it accumulated on the floor beneath her. She ignored it. Sheâ€™d clean up the shack when she was done.

She used the mirror to start plucking the dittany leaves out of the gashes, then she recast a cleansing charm on the area and reappraised the injury. The upside of vampire bites was that they healed easily without causing any scarring.

She started near her clavicles where the laceration was the shallowest and began muttering the spell to knit the skin back together.

Sheâ€™d made it halfway across her shoulder when Draco abruptly apparated into the room.

He appeared to blanch slightly when he saw her, and Hermione blushed and immediately wished she hadnâ€™t cut her shirt off. Then she snorted, because she was covered in blood; unless Draco had a weird fetish he probably wasnâ€™t paying any attention to what clothes she was or wasnâ€™t wearing.

â€œWhat happened?â€ he said after staring at her for several seconds.

â€œI was foraging,â€ Hermione said blandly, refocusing on her reflection in the mirror and resuming her healing. â€œSorry. Iâ€™ll clean up the floor before I go.â€

â€œAre you alright?â€ he asked.

Hermione laughed. She had gotten a lot closer to dying than she had in a long time and she was slightly faint with blood-loss and having such a question directed at her while she was dripping blood on the floor of his dilapidated building was just strangely hilarious to her.

â€œWell, no,â€ she said. â€œBut itâ€™s nothing I canâ€™t fix.â€

Draco grew visibly angry.

â€œI told you to be careful,â€ he finally said.

â€œI have been,â€ Hermione said, her amusement suddenly disappearing. He was the one whoâ€™d said heâ€™d teach her to defend herself and then refused to even lay eyes on her once she finished healing him. â€œBut as you are aware there are anti-apparition wards all over England. I ran out of dittany. Itâ€™s a critical supply for us. I cast detection charms and I tried to leave as soon as I sensed anything. â€œWhy not just buy it like a normal person?â€ he asked as though she were thick.

â€œBecause,â€ Hermione said, her voice tight with a shrill and slightly mocking edge of it, â€œIâ€™m a known terrorist. Perhaps youâ€™ve forgotten. Andâ€”â€ she hiccupped â€œâ€”I donâ€™tâ€”have any money left.â€

He fell silent and just stood staring at her for a minute.

â€œWhat happened?â€ he asked again.

â€œI was foraging in Hampshire. The forest went quiet so I cast detection spells but nothing showed up. I decided to leave anyway though. So I had to come here to fix it manually.â€

Hermioneâ€™s voice was shaking as she finished speaking, and she was on the verge of tears. As she had related what had happened, it abruptly stopped being funny and started being traumatic and horrible and too close.

She started hyperventilating as she thought about how close sheâ€™d come to dying all alone in a forest. No one would have even known where to look for her, and by the time theyâ€™d thought to, she would have been long dead.

She clamped her mouth shut and hiccuped several times as she tried to breathe evenly.

â€œI think Iâ€™m going into shock,â€ she said.

Her voice sounded oddly small and childlike. She swallowed hard.

She wanted to cry, but she refused to allow herself to. Sheâ€™d already cried in front of Malfoy several times. She didnâ€™t want him to think she was someone who just cried over everything.

She was so angry he was there. That of all the times heâ€™d decided to show up, it had to be then. She wished sheâ€™d apparated anywhere else.

â€œIâ€™m not dying. The Order is not in crisis. So you can just go. Iâ€™ll clean up before I leave, you wonâ€™t even know I was here,â€ she said.

It was not the strategic thing to say, but she didnâ€™t want to look at him. Heâ€™d kissed her and then called her a bitch. Heâ€™d let her spend weeks healing him and only thanked her when he was drunk and then told her he intended to go to a different healer the minute he was sober again.

Heâ€™d cut her off.

Heâ€™d made her miss him like an idiot while heâ€™d probably gone and fucked as many high-breasted, curvaceous prostitutes as his heart desired.

She hated him. And she didnâ€™t want him to see her when she was covered in blood and hysterical and traumatised.

Why couldnâ€™t he ever leave her alone when she wanted him to?

After a minute she turned back to healing her shoulder in the mirror again. He kept standing and staring at her.

In a few minutes the gashes were closed and only faint cicatrices remained. They would fade once she had some dittany tincture to apply.

She summoned over the other chair and lifted her foot up and started unwrapping her leg. Then she cut off her jeans at the knee and dropped them alongside the remains of her shirt in the puddle of blood.

She surveyed the Gytrash bite. It was difficult to see all the punctures on the back of her calf. She shifted her hips to get a better view. Two long gashes and several punctures. She cast a cleansing charm over the area to clear the blood away. None of them were very deep. She didnâ€™t think any of it was likely to scar.

She had it all repaired in short order.

The room seemed to be rotating slowly. She sat back and closed her eyes for a minute. Then she reopened them and cast a new diagnostic charm on herself. Sheâ€™d lost a little over a pint of blood, which should have been in an acceptable range of loss, but she was sufficiently underweight that it was over 15% of her blood volume.

She blinked at the diagnostic for several moments and conjured a glass of water. Her lips were tingling faintly.

She rummaged through her bag trying to see if she had any food and found a muesli bar that she had no recollection of. She gulped down the water and set to eating, stubbornly ignoring Dracoâ€™s continued presence. He was still just standing and staring at her.

When she finished her third glass of water and every crumb of muesli, she glanced up at him in irritation.

â€œIâ€™m going to be here for a while before Iâ€™ll be able to apparate,â€ she said as she glared at him.

â€œWhy canâ€™t you apparate?â€ he asked.

She stared at him for a moment and then gestured at the floor.

â€œBlood loss. I had to walk here from the bridge. Thereâ€™s probably a trail, actually. As I mentioned, I was out of dittany, so I have no blood replenishing potion on hand in my emergency kit. Iâ€™ll have to wait until I feel stable enough to apparate. If I stand up now, lâ€™ll probably just faint.â€

Draco appeared to be growing pale with rage. His jaw kept clenching and releasing the way Ronâ€™s did when he was on the verge of exploding. He kept staring at her as though he resented her mere existence.

Heâ€™d clearly managed to get entirely over whatever passing interest heâ€™d had in her. Sheâ€™d been pining, and heâ€™d apparently spent the last six weeks remembering that he hated her, that heâ€™d always hated her, and that her Mudblood existence in the world was an offense to him.

He was a far better occlumens than she was.

Sheâ€™d have to admit to Moody that sheâ€™d misstepped and blown her assignment.

Her lip trembled, and she looked away and started cleaning the blood off the floor with practiced ease. The staining wouldnâ€™t come out of her shirt so she banished it rather than trying to repair it.

She glanced up and discovered that Malfoy had apparated away without a sound. Her mouth twisted. She hadnâ€™t known he could apparate silently.

She found herself simultaneously relieved and devastated that heâ€™d actually left. She shook her head sharply and only let herself sob once, very softly, before she turned back to cleaning the floor.

While she was rummaging through her satchel for something to transfigure into a shirt, he abruptly reappeared.

â€œBlood replenishing potion,â€ he said in a cold voice as he handed a vial to her.

She stared down at it. She recognized Severusâ€™ spiky handwriting in the label. She unstoppered it and swallowed the contents.

The room immediately stopped moving, and her lips stopped tingling.

â€œThank you,â€ she said. She transfigured a piece of cloth into a white t-shirt and, after scourgifying her shoulder, arm, and torso, pulled it over her head. Then she gathered all her supplies back into her kit and stood to leave.

â€œSee?â€ she said, gesturing at the floor. â€œI was never here.â€

He didnâ€™t say a word as she walked out the door.
