Flashback 18

September 2002

When Hermione returned to the shack the following week, there was no scroll on the table.

There was also no table and no chairs. The little bit of furniture that had been there before was gone.

Her stomach dropped, and she felt the doorknob rattle in her hand.

She kept staring, willing a scroll to appear. She looked around the rest of the room. Perhaps sheâ€™d overlooked something.

The furniture was gone.

She walked slowly into the room and glanced around.

Maybe he was just busy. Maybe heâ€™d bring it in the evening, she thought nervously.

But the furniture was gone.

Maybe heâ€™d been injured or killed. It hadnâ€™t even occurred to her until just then; he might die and she wouldnâ€™t even know. Heâ€™d just disappear, and sheâ€™d never see him again.

Surely Severus would let her know if Draco died...

Besides, the furniture was gone.

She stood in the middle of the room, wondering what to do.

Surely he wouldnâ€™t end his arrangement with the Order just because sheâ€™d bled on his second-hand furniture. Heâ€™d had his back carved into ribbons to be a spy. Trailing blood into his safehouse could not possibly be his limit.

Perhaps heâ€™d just burned the furniture.

She turned around one last time and then started for the door. Sheâ€™d come back in the evening. If there was nothing by the next week, then sheâ€™d let herself panic. She wasnâ€™t going to let herself panic yet. There might be some other explanation.

She was halfway out the door when she heard a pop. She turned and found Malfoy standing in the center of the room.

She stared at him, wide-eyed and uncertain. He looked her up and down, as though he expected her to be injured again.

â€œWe should resume training,â€ he said after a moment.

Hermione said nothing. She felt torn between a desire to laugh or cry. The corner of her mouth twitched, and she tried to swallow past a hard lump in her throat. Her hand shook faintly as she fought to hold in all the furious things she wanted to say.

Iâ€™ve been here every week. Youâ€™re the one who stopped coming. I didnâ€™t even want to drink that night. You made me stay and then punished me for it. Why do you even care? Why are you here? Why are you spying for us? Why canâ€™t you make sense so I can stop wondering if youâ€™re redeemable or not? I was here. I was here and you were the one who never came back.

She didnâ€™t say anything. She just stood in the doorway.

She wanted to just turn and leave. To go and try to make sense of why she cared.

She cared. She felt betrayed.

Heâ€™d given her dire warnings, ordered her to work out, practice dueling, and be careful. Heâ€™d made her paranoid and stressed every time she ventured out to forage for potion ingredients until she could hardly breathe when she was out; until she couldnâ€™t even eat the night before because the food tasted like ash, and her stomach knotted so tightly with anxiety that she couldnâ€™t force it down.

Heâ€™d made her realise how much she didnâ€™t want to die.

She didnâ€™t want to die.

Heâ€™d told her heâ€™d train her, ridiculed her for not being ruthless enough, and thenâ€”abandoned her.

He didnâ€™t abandon the Order.

Heâ€™d only abandoned her.

Which should have been fine. It should have been fine with her. It was always only supposed to be about the Order. But it had hurt. Every week he hadnâ€™t shown up had felt like being abandoned all over again.

Was she just that easy to leave behind?

Her chest stuttered, and her cheekbones ached from the effort it took not to cry.

She didnâ€™t do anything; didnâ€™t say anything. She just stared at him wide-eyed and kept swallowing until she stopped feeling like she might burst into tears.

â€œAlright,â€ she said. â€œToday? Or is this just a heads up for next week.â€

â€œToday,â€ he said. â€œUnless you have other commitments this morning.â€

She did not have other commitments. She had time. With Padma slowly taking over more and more of Hermioneâ€™s work, Hermione rarely had other commitments. Unless Kingsley needed her, or there was a serious injury, she was completely at Malfoyâ€™s disposal.

She suspected he knew that.

She was a Dark Arts Healer and curse specialist. She had a Potions Mastery. She had left behind and eventually given up all her friends to become those things; to become an asset in the war effort.

But the contribution the Order most needed from her, was for her to mould herself into a femme fatale capable of emotionally manipulating Draco Malfoy into depending on her; to try to take advantage of his lack of intimacy until she owned him.

Sometimes it made her so angry she thought sheâ€™d die from it.

It was all Malfoyâ€™s fault. Heâ€™d asked for her. Heâ€™d done this to them both, but she was currently the only one paying for it.

There were moments when she resented him so much it felt like her heart might beat itself into dust within her chest.

She stepped back inside the shack and closed the door.

â€œWhen you escaped the vampire, how did you do it?â€ he asked after a moment.

â€œIt had my wand arm pinned, so I stabbed it through the temple with my silver harvesting knife,â€ she said shrugging, trying not to look at him.

It hurtâ€”to look at him.

He nodded, his eyes never leaving her. â€œDo you usually have a knife on you?â€

â€œWell, itâ€™s for harvesting, so yes, itâ€™s usually in my satchel.â€

â€œYou should wear it. You keep your wand in a holster on your arm, donâ€™t you?â€ His gaze dropped down and ran up and down her body as though he were cataloguing her.

â€œWell, sometimes,â€ she said, crossing her arms across her chest, uncomfortable under the attention. â€œItâ€™s almost eleven inches long. My forearms arenâ€™t that long. Wearing it restricts my arm movement. I either lose my wrist mobility or I canâ€™t bend my elbow.â€

She drew her wand from the pocket in her jacket and held it next to her forearm to demonstrate.

Draco scowled and rolled his jaw.

â€œThatâ€™s problematic. Where do you keep it?â€

â€œIf I have a jacket I keep it in an inner-pocket. If I donâ€™t then I have it in my satchel or in my pocket.â€

â€œThatâ€™s not fast enough. If youâ€™re attacked you wonâ€™t be able to draw it in time. You should at least have a knife. Your clothing is shielded now, isnâ€™t it?â€

â€œIt is,â€ Hermione said immediately. â€œEverything I wear when Iâ€™m foraging has shield charms applied to them.â€

George and others in the hospice safe-houses who still had hands steady enough to do spellwork spent most of their time weaving shield spells into spare clothing for the Resistance fighters.

â€œDo you prefer cloaks or jackets?â€ he asked after a moment, his tone almost suspiciously casual.

Hermioneâ€™s eyes narrowed.

â€œCloaks blend in better in the Wizarding world. A jacket on a woman tends to signal that sheâ€™s Muggle-born,â€ she said.

â€œAlright, then,â€ he said, drawing his wand from his wrist but then switching it into his right hand. â€œLetâ€™s see if youâ€™ve improved since last time.â€

Hermione put down her satchel and warded it before entering dueling pose.

Sheâ€™d improved dramatically since theyâ€™d last practiced when heâ€™d been injured. Sheâ€™d exercised to the point that her stamina was decent, and both Kingsley and Moody had drilled her several times.

She was also angry enough that she wanted to hex Draco.

He actually moved to avoid several of her hexes and she blocked most of the water he sent at her. Finally he stopped.

â€œYouâ€™ve gotten better,â€ he said.

â€œI donâ€™t want to die,â€ she said with a shrug. Her voice was only slightly bitter.

â€œGood,â€ he said with a sharp nod. He stashed his wand and reached into his robes. He pulled out a scroll and then a flagon that Hermione immediately recognized as being filled with Essence of Dittany.

She gasped and held out her hands without thinking. Essence of Dittany required such vast quantities of Dittany leaves it was rare that she had any of it. Theyâ€™d gotten a supply of it when the Order had raided the curse division, but sheâ€™d used most of it healing prisoners. What was left sheâ€™d used to neutralise the venom in his runes.

She hadnâ€™t been able to afford to buy or produce more after that. A single drop required a bushel of leaves. She usually made her Dittany into powder or tinctures instead. The efficacy was lower, but her foraging supplies lasted longer that way; stretched to heal more people. Â 

â€œDonâ€™t go into Hampshire again,â€ he said. â€œThere are hundreds of vampires there. You were lucky to have survived.â€

She hesitantly accepted the flagon.

â€œIs this going to expose you?â€ she asked, running her hands over the glass longingly. â€œThis is a suspicious quantity. An individual couldnâ€™t use this much in a lifetime.â€

He smirked dismissively. â€œIâ€™m a General in the Dark Lordâ€™s armies, I can ask for anything I want. Those who question it tend to find their tongues missing.â€

Hermione blanched and Draco rolled his eyes.

â€œIâ€™m being facetious, Granger. I have never cut out anyoneâ€™s tongue. Suffice to say, Iâ€™m not going to do anything that risks blowing my cover just because of you.â€ He sneered at her as he shoved the scroll of information into her hands.

â€œKeep practicing.â€ He vanished soundlessly.

Hermione stared at the empty space for several minutes before she left.

When she got back to Grimmauld, she surreptitiously divvied the Essence of Dittany into dozens of tiny vials and hid them carefully. Most Order members were too ignorant about potions to notice or wonder if Hermione suddenly had an endless supply of it, but Padma would know. Theyâ€™d been trying to invent ways to stretch their meager supply of Dittany for weeks. Â 

Malfoy was quiet and surly when he trained her. He ignored her questions and only spoke to scold her angrily when she did something wrong.

She would have almost thought he hated her, except every time she walked in the door he instantly appeared and looked as though he were bracing himself to find her injured; his eyes ran over her from head to toe as though to reassure himself.

The dueling sessions kept getting longer and longer.

Hermione pretended not to notice.

Several weeks later Malfoy pulled out a shielded cloak. She looked it over carefully.

â€œAll my clothing is already shielded.â€ She held her cloak in front of herself and found that it was perfectly sized for her height.

â€œThis is shielded with manticore blood.â€

She looked over at him sharply. â€œDoes that mean you killed it?â€

â€œNo. Itâ€™s surprisingly difficult to come up with a good excuse for killing them. But it seems that mine is strangely lethargic, McNair cannot understand why,â€ he said with a smirk.

â€œYouâ€™re bleeding it,â€ Hermione said, looking at the cloak again.

He nodded. â€œThey donâ€™t do well in cold climates. Perhaps it will come to an unfortunate end this winter. If Iâ€™m lucky it will mature enough to produce venom before succumbing to the cold.â€

â€œI hope youâ€™re not torturing it,â€ Hermione said, eyeing him. â€œItâ€™s sentient. And even if it werenâ€™t, every living thing should be treated humanely.â€

â€œI am not torturing it. Although describing it as sentient just because it can speak is highly generous,â€ Draco said with a faint sneer. â€œAll it does is croon about how it wants to eat me alive.â€

â€œIf you were keeping me prisoner and draining me of my magical abilities Iâ€™d croon similarly,â€ Hermione said.

Draco laughed mirthlessly.

â€œThank you, for the cloak,â€ Hermione said after she looked it over carefully. It was beautifully made. It had temperature regulating charms woven into it so she could wear it all year round and it was lined with dozens of undetectably expanded pockets for her to stash things inside. The hem was charmed not to be tripped on. Even without the manticore blood protection, the cloak had to be worth a small fortune in craftsmanship.

â€œConsider it my thanks for healing my back,â€ he said without looking at her.

She looked over at him and he stared determinedly out the window. â€œAre theyâ€”,â€ she hesitated. â€œDid the scar tissue set properly? Iâ€”youâ€”you never cameâ€”when I came to check on them.â€

â€œTheyâ€™re fine,â€ he said in a stiff voice. â€œPhysically, I can barely feel them. I had no need for further attention.â€

His jaw was rolling slightly, rippling as he clenched it. Hermione stared at him for a moment before dropping her eyes back down to the cloak.

â€œWell, thatâ€™s good,â€ she said. â€œIâ€”hadnâ€™t ever done the procedure to that extent before. I was worriedâ€”â€ Â 

â€œDonâ€™t be! I have no need for the concern of someone like you.â€

Hermione stared at him wide-eyed. He balled his hands into fists as he stared at her.

â€œI just meantâ€”,â€she started.

â€œJust back off, Granger,â€ he said in hard voice. He wrenched a scroll out of his robes and dropped it onto the ground before vanishing.

Hermione picked up the scroll thoughtfully, tapping her chin after she stashed everything in her satchel.

She left the shack and walked toward the creek deep in thought.

What had he said about the influence of the runes?

â€œ They donâ€™t countermand my own behavior, but itâ€™s as though new elements have been written in. Itâ€™s easier to be ruthless. Somewhat harder to dissuade myself from impulses. Not that I had much distracting me before, but now, everything else feels even less consequential.â€

She had the runic vow memorised, sheâ€™d spent so many evenings staring at it. Unhesitating, cunning, unfailing, ruthless, and unyielding; driven to succeedâ€¦.

But what he was driven to succeed in was unstated; left to his discretion.

He wanted her.

She was almost certain of it. He was currently torn between his determination to push her away and a desire to have her.

That was why he had been so enraged that she had been injured.

He couldnâ€™t dissuade himself to the point of not caring if she died, but he was determined not to give into wanting her and compromising himself. The Malfoys were possessive like dragons, Severus had said.

He knew what she was doing; what she had been sent to do. She could see it in the resentful way he stared at her. There was a vicious rage in his eyes that hadnâ€™t been there before.

But heâ€™d become cornered by the realization that she would likely die if he didnâ€™t train her. The vampire attack had been remarkably good luck. If sheâ€™d tried to stage it it couldnâ€™t have come out better.

If she kept him near her, it was only a matter of time before heâ€™d finally slip; heâ€™d want her too much to keep holding back. The runes would assure it.

When that happenedâ€¦

Hermione sighed.

When that happened sheâ€™d own him.

Unless he was so desperate to free himself of his obsession that he killed her.

In some moments, when she felt his eyes on her as they were dueling, it felt like a coin toss between the two. As though he were constantly weighing the options.

Confident as she had become in his attention, she wasnâ€™t confident enough to say whether she would survive it. There was so much about Draco Malfoy that she did not know or understand. When she looked at him, she could only wonder whether he was the type of person who destroyed the things he loved.

Whatever it was he wantedâ€”his motive for spyingâ€”heâ€™d killed countless people already to try obtaining it. If he thought she was in the way...she might be next.

Unhesitating, cunning, unfailing, ruthless, and unyielding; driven to succeedâ€¦.

Hermione twisted the strap of her satchel as she stood thinking.

She needed to prioritise training Padma during any spare time she had.

Padma had a decent aptitude for healing, she stayed calm under pressure and had a good head for memorising all the spells and variations. She did have trouble with the precision needed in certain healing wand-work, and she tended to rely on rote memorisation rather than embracing the creativity necessary for inventing counter-curses. But Hermione hoped that, with Poppyâ€™s help, Padma would be able to replace Hermione sufficiently.

Hermione had started taking Padma foraging with her. Someone else needed to know how to gather the local potion supplies; with winter approaching they needed to try to stock up. But Hermione was careful not to let Draco know she had a foraging partner. If he found out, heâ€™d probably stop training her.

She foraged with Padma on Thursday mornings. Tuesdays she still went alone, but more cautiously.

Hermione needed to have everything in place before she tried to progress things further with Draco.

She watched the water sliding beneath the bridge and wondered if she was stalling.

She didnâ€™t want to die.

The past few weeks sheâ€™d found herself thinking about dying almost as much as she thought about Draco.

After feeling the vampireâ€™s fangs sinking into her shoulder, she was abruptly confronted with the fact that on primal level she had an absolute determination not to die. She hadnâ€™t realised how overwhelming the drive was.

Rationally she had always regarded dying as something she could face. For a good reason, she would gladly die.

But the instant she felt the terror of hands pinning her to the ground and teeth sinking into her flesh, the instinct to fight her way free and kill anything that got in the way had swallowed her mind. She hadnâ€™t realised how her survival instinct would superseded everything.

She hadnâ€™t realised how much she didnâ€™t want to die.

But if it came down to her and Draco, she probably would die. He could kill her so easily. Another corpse for his body count. Sheâ€™d probably bleed together with all the rest of his dead after a while.

She smiled bitterly to herself as she thought about the contrast between them.

Hermioneâ€™s body count was a representation of her failures. Everyone she hadnâ€™t saved.

Dracoâ€™s body count was an illustration of his achievement. Everything he was and why he was valuable to both Voldemort and the Order.

Their relationshipâ€”whatever it was and wherever it was headedâ€”felt like some cruel form of irony. It was as though they were the reverse of each other.

Yin and yang. They circled inexorably.

Somehow the war had tied them together

She apparated back to Grimmauld Place and went to find Kingsley.

Generally she spoke solely to Moody, but Alastor was in Ireland training new recruits with Remus and Tonks.

Kingsley was standing in the war room, staring at a map on the wall. Hermione knew he was aware of her presence, but he didnâ€™t immediately acknowledge her.

â€œKingsley,â€ Hermione said as she closed the door softly, â€œcould I have a word?â€

He turned with a sharp pivot, his robes fluttering around him and cast several privacy wards on the room before he spoke.

â€œGranger,â€ he said, â€œnew information?â€

Hermione unbuckled her satchel and handed the scroll to him. Kingsley unfurled it and ran his eyes across it for a minute before stashing it inside his robes and looking at Hermione again.

â€œDo you need to speak with me about something, Granger?â€

Hermione stared at him for a moment. Ever since Draco had demanded her, Kingsley had stopped using her first name. She had noticed. He referred to Harry and Ron and most of the other members of the Order by their first names, but he always used her surname to address her. To impersonalise her to himself, she had concluded.

â€œI think Severus has spoken to you and Moody, about his concerns regarding Malfoy,â€ she said.

Kingsley nodded, his expression betraying nothing. â€œYes, weâ€™ve spoken.â€

Hermione nodded. â€œThe way things are goingâ€¦ Iâ€™m beginning to think thereâ€™s at least a chance Malfoy may kill me.â€

Kingsley looked at her squarely and straightened his robes. â€œAre you asking for us to pull you out, Granger?â€

Hermione looked away and stared at a still life painting on the wall. â€œNo. We need the information. Weâ€™d probably all be dead by now if not for Malfoy. I justâ€”I want to know what I should prioritise while Iâ€™m training Padma to replace me. She doesnâ€™t have two years like I did, and there is still too much basic healing she needs to learn before I can teach her advanced Dark Arts healing. And then thereâ€™s potions and foraging. Iâ€™m just not sureâ€”Sheâ€™s not as driven as I was. I know she wanted to stay in the field with Parvati. So I need to know what you and Moody regard as the highest priorities.â€

Kingsley was silent for a minute.

â€œIâ€™ll speak with Alastor and look over the hospitalâ€™s reports. Perhaps make a list of what areas we have no redundancy in. Iâ€™ll have an answer next week.â€

â€œAlright,â€ Hermione said, nodding. Her voice sounded stilted and mechanical.

â€œGranger. Tell me, what exactly is the strategy youâ€™re trying to employ?â€

She looked back over at Kingsley and felt tired.

â€œHe wants me. Heâ€™s obsessive, and he wants me. But he knows what Iâ€™m doing. I can tell, by the way he looks at me, that he knows. I still donâ€™t know what his long term goals are. He doesnâ€™t ever say anything that gives it away. If I keep drawing him in, and it turns out I interfere with his original ambition, he may resort to killing me. But, if he doesnâ€™t kill meâ€”according to Severus the Malfoys tend toward being both obsessive and possessive. I donâ€™t think heâ€™ll abandon the Order at that point. Willingness seems critical, and he knows that mine is conditional on the Orderâ€™s survival. â€

Then she shrugged. â€œOr I could be wrong and heâ€™ll turn on the Order, which is what Severus fears. I honestly donâ€™t know. This is notâ€”I donâ€™t know how to use people like this.â€

Kingsley was silent.

â€œIf heâ€™s growing obsessed with youâ€”Thatâ€™s more than I had expected,â€ he said, glancing over at the table and resting his fingers on the edge and tapping thoughtfully.

Hermione felt as though she should have some kind of reaction to the words; offense or satisfaction orâ€”something. But she felt nothing. It was as though her heart were slowly compacting inside of her chest, growing smaller and harder day by day.

â€œIâ€™m notâ€”,â€ she started and then paused and pressed her lips together. She twisted her head slightly as she felt tension in her neck begin radiating down her shoulders. â€œIâ€™m not lying to him, Kingsley. Iâ€™m not being insincere. The emotional connection between us is real.â€

Kingsleyâ€™s fingers stilled, and he studied her with slightly narrowed eyes. â€œI hope youâ€™re not becoming compromised by him, Granger. The Order is depending on you to stay on mission.â€

Hermione nodded stiffly. â€œMy loyalty will always be to the Order first.â€

Kingsleyâ€™s expression did not ease. â€œHarryâ€”you know I can only keep him away from the worst fights if I know which ones theyâ€™ll be.â€

Hermione flinched. â€œI know. Iâ€™m doing everything I can, Kingsley. I am doing the very, very best that I can. Iâ€™m notâ€”Iâ€™d never do anything that would risk Harry.â€

â€œKeep it up then,â€ Kingsley said, turning back to the map on the wall.

Hermione stared at his back for several moments before she turned and rested her hand of the doorknob; as she gripped it, she laughed quietly.

â€œSomething else you want to say, Granger?â€ Kingsleyâ€™s voice had a slight edge to it.

Hermione glanced over her shoulder. His back was still to her.

â€œI was just realising,â€ she said in a low voice, â€œIf I succeedâ€”youâ€™ll use me to control Malfoy the same way youâ€™re able to use Harry to control me. Itâ€”it almost makes me feel sorry for him.â€

Kingsley was silent for a moment. â€œWell, heâ€™ll deserve it considerably more than you do.â€

Flashback 19

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

October 2002

The next time Hermione arrived at the shack, Draco appeared looking visibly annoyed and carrying a gramophone.

She eyed him carefully. â€œI think Iâ€™m missing something.â€

â€œRest assured, Granger, if I could devise a better solution I would have.â€ He conjured a table and put the gramophone on it. He flicked his wand, and the music began playing.

â€œIs thisâ€”,â€ Hermione choked faintly and stared at him incredulous. â€œAre you wanting us to dance?â€

â€œWaltz.â€ He turned to stare at her. â€œYou move like a penguin when you duel.â€

Hermione felt her cheeks grow hot.

â€œI most certainly do not,â€ she snapped.

â€œIâ€™ve spent considerably more time watching you duel than you have, and believe me, you do.â€ His lip curled derisively. â€œYou're slow and awkward and the only reason I donâ€™t hit you more is because Iâ€™m intentionally not aiming.â€

Hermione bit back a retort.

â€œSo you think the solution is waltzing?â€ she said stiffly.

â€œI do. Aunt Bella was one of the most exceptional dancers I have ever had the misfortune of being partnered with. She dueled with equal fluidity. I know you can dance. We just need to transfer the movement to dueling.â€

Hermione thought about it for a moment, and then nodded as she put her satchel aside. â€œAlright.â€

Draco walked toward her with the expression of a someone who would rather be punched in the face than do what he was about to do.

He raised his left hand for her to take. Then he set his jaw rigidly and slid his right hand under her arm, placing it below her shoulder blade before pulling her closer until there were only a few inches between them. Hermione felt as though she were barely breathing.

She stared up at his face as she rested her left hand on the top of his arm near his shoulder.

They stood in position, not moving, just staring at one another. She could see the tension in his jaw and the hard line of his mouth as he almost, but not quite, sneered down at her. She could also see his eyes and, as she met them with her own, she could see his irises bloom until he abruptly jerked his chin up and stared across the room.

She felt his fingers flinch against her back before he stilled them.

â€œSo.â€ His voice was hard as he stared away. â€œThe dance that best represents the speed and fluidity that I want you to develop is the Viennese Waltz. Itâ€™s an extremely easy step to learn, if the female is responsive and capable of following another personâ€™s lead. Given that neither of those things are qualities anyone would apply to you, Iâ€™ve resigned myself that itâ€™s going to take a considerable amount of time before you manage it with so much as a semblance of grace.â€

He gave her a condescending smile.

Hermione felt her indignation and determination begin rising in her chest and she stiffened slightly before it occurred to her: Draco clearly did not want to be â€˜holdingâ€™ her in his arms; he was trying to provoke her into striving hard and ending their â€œdance lessonsâ€ as soon as possible.

She gave him a thin smile of her own.

â€œIâ€™ll do my best,â€ she said and shuffled slightly and â€œnearlyâ€ stepped on his toes.

â€œThen please donâ€™t tread on me.â€ He sneered down at her. â€œI would prefer not to go to a healer because your clumsiness ends up fracturing a bone.â€

â€œIâ€™ll heal it for you,â€ she said with mock sweetness.

He sneered at her again and abruptly started to move. Hermione tried to follow but their knees collided. She yelped and he swore.

â€œSome warning before you start moving,â€ she said in a tight voice as her right knee throbbed.

â€œTry following my lead,â€ he snapped. â€œThis is for dueling. No one is going to give you â€˜some warningâ€™ before they curse you. You need to have the instinct to just move.â€

Hermioneâ€™s jaw tightened and she huffed.

â€œFine.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll start again.â€

Hermione didnâ€™t need to pretend to be clumsy when dancing with Draco. The speed at which he expected her to waltz at was nearly breakneck. He was not patient. In fact, he seemed determined to make it as unpleasant as he possibly could; probably to motivate her.

Her toes were throbbing, and she was fairly certain his dragonhide boots were steel reinforced in the toes because he accidentally kicked her in the shin, and she thought he might have fractured something.

She dropped to the ground with a howl and hugged her leg.

â€œYou are the worst dance instructor on the planet,â€ she snarled and jerked her trousers up to find a purple bruise already blooming across her shin.

â€œHowever shall I live?â€ he said dryly, without even looking down at her. â€œMy secret ambition is crushed.â€

â€œAre you trying to break my leg? Why are you wearing combat boots?â€ she said in a furious voice.

Malfoy glanced over sharply and caught sight of her leg. His expression wavered for a split second before he regained his mask of indifference. â€œI didnâ€™t expect you to be this clumsy,â€ he said.

â€œYou are a complete bastard,â€ Hermione said as she summoned her satchel and rummaged for her healing kit.

â€œYet most of your precious Order would be dead by now if it werenâ€™t for me.â€ Draco sneered viciously at her. â€œBy now Iâ€™m as much their savior as Saint Potter will ever be, and I own you, so you really have very little room to complain.â€

Hermione felt herself pale as she felt fury ripple through her chest. She hated him. She hated him. She hated him and she still wanted him, and that made her hate him even more.

But she possibly hated him most because he was right about the Order. The war in Britain was at a stalemate currently, after years of slow losses on their side. The Order was still, comparatively speaking, steeply disadvantaged, but Voldemort had had fewer and fewer victories since Malfoy had begun spying. Dracoâ€™s aid had tipped the scales of the war into a balance, and he knew it.

He held the Order in the palm of his hand.

It was the most tenuous form of survival possible because they had no idea if he might someday just let go.

â€œIâ€™m trying,â€ she said in a shaking voice as she spread bruise paste across her skin. â€œIf you had given me some warning, I would have gotten a book and practiced the steps before I came. Itâ€™s not like Iâ€™m intentionally not trying. I donâ€™t know them. You could try communicating a bit more.â€

He glared at her for several moments before looking away. â€œWell, now you know. So practice.â€

He vanished with an angry crack.

Hermione stayed behind. She pulled her shoes off in order to check her toes for fractures and mull over what an unbelievable arse Draco was. She sighed and buried her face in her hands.

The worst part was that she didnâ€™t really blame him. If someone were doing to Hermione what she currently was doing to Draco, and apparently succeeding, she would be hard pressed not to resent and want to hurt them too. It must be eating at him to know she was manipulating him emotionally and still feel drawn to her. It was a viciously cruel thing to do to someone.

Especially him.

Everything she learned about him made her feel more guilty about it.

She swallowed her guilt. Draco Malfoy was a double-edged weapon, just as poised to cut down the Order as to aid it. Unless she leashed him, he was a threat.

It wasnâ€™t as though she was enjoying it. Surely he must know that too.

She wasnâ€™t lying. She wasnâ€™t being insincere. That was why it was working. Having him know her motive didnâ€™t negate the genuine connection theyâ€™d somehow forged. That was why it was so awful. It was real, but she was weaponising it.

She left the shack and apparated to a bookstore to find a book that explained how to Viennese waltz.

The next week Draco was equally surly, but he had the courtesy to wear different shoes. When Hermione arrived, she sat down in front of him and proceeded to transfigure her foraging trainers into a pair of low heels.

â€œPlanning on wearing heels when dueling too?â€ he asked, raising an eyebrow as he stared down at her. His lip curled condescendingly.

â€œThe book I read said Iâ€™m supposed to be on my toes. Itâ€™s easier to get used to the step and fluidity if my feet are already in the right position. Iâ€™ll switch back to trainers again once you think I have a semblance of grace,â€ she said, lifting her chin.

â€œYou need better shoes. Those Muggle things you wear are useless,â€ he said with a sneer.

Hermione flushed. Most of her clothing came from muggle donation bins. Good shoes in her size were difficult to find. Sheâ€™d been maintaining her current pair with reparos.

Draco Rich Wanker Malfoy probably didnâ€™t even know how much a pair of dragonhide boots cost.

â€œThey work,â€ she said in a tight voice. â€œThatâ€™s all I care about.

She stood up.

â€œIf you donâ€™t mind, if you start more slowly and then pick up speed, I think Iâ€™ll be able to follow better,â€ she said.

Draco rolled his eyes. â€œFine.â€

He didnâ€™t even look down at her as he held out his hands and she stepped into them and into position. She was ready when he stepped forward without warning. She drew her right foot back and did a short, quick step as she allowed herself to be pivoted on one foot and he then took a long step back, and she followed him with her left foot.

It was, as he had said, an extremely easy step technically. The difficulty was the speed and trusting Dracoâ€™s lead; forcing herself to relax enough to follow him instinctively rather than reactively.

Following him wasnâ€™t difficult in theory; heâ€™d clearly been taught to dance. He had a excellent carriage and frame and moved with the fluidity of a cat. Unfortunately, he was also an arse who was intentionally trying to make dancing with him as unpleasant as possible, while she was trying to adapt to a new step that involved them rotating as a couple in clockwise circles and moving counterclockwise around the room.

He stepped on her toes eight times within twenty minutes, and Hermione rather thought several of the times had been intentional.

â€œFor heaven's sake, Draco!â€ Hermione kicked him sharply in the shin after he crushed her right foot particularly painfully. â€œWeâ€™ll spend considerably less time dancing together if youâ€™ll just give me a chance to get used to the step. It will take longer if you break my toes.â€

â€œIs there anything you know how to do but complain?â€ he said with a sneer as she bent down to look at the injured appendage.

â€I donâ€™t know. Is there?â€ she said coldly, standing up and squaring her shoulders. She met his eyes as she lifted her arms into waltz position before he could.

His expression flickered and he baulked momentarily. She smirked tauntingly at him, and his expression grew briefly murderous as he pulled her into his arms and against his chest. She looked up at him.

â€œUnless thereâ€™s some reason you canâ€™t, perhaps we could try Viennese waltzing normally,â€ she said in an even but slightly needling tone. â€œAfter all, this was your idea. The sooner I master the fluidity the sooner we can get back to hexing each other.â€

â€œA consummation devoutly to be wished,â€ he said with a cold expression.

He moved more slowly. Hermione was not actually a terrible dancer, just extremely out of practice and in the arms of someone physically distracting and personally spiteful.

After an hour she was able to follow him at full-speed without either of them injuring each other.

Finally he stopped.

â€œGood enough. Start thinking about how to use the fluidity when dueling,â€ he said, shoving his hair out of his face and rubbing his forehead.

â€œRight. Iâ€™ll just waltz around in the practice rooms, Iâ€™m sure no one will notice that,â€ Hermione said acerbically in between panting breaths. She was sweating and she could feel her shirt clinging to her back between her shoulders. Strands of her hair were plastered against her neck.

Malfoy looked cool as a cucumber. He probably had temperature regulating charms in all his clothing. Although he still seemed to be perspiring slightly.

Hermione tugged at her shirt to make it stop sticking to her torso and cast a cooling charm before conjuring a cup and some water.

â€œItâ€™s your life,â€ he said coolly, then he pulled out a scroll. â€œThe Dark Lord is growing frustrated with all the rescues. He has Sussex working on something to prevent it. I donâ€™t have much access to that building, but the Order should begin preparing for the eventuality that they may not be able to save people for much longer.â€

Hermione swallowed hard.

â€œI didnâ€™t realise Dolohov was so multi-talented,â€ she finally said.

â€œHeâ€™s not,â€ Draco said, conjuring his own glass of water. â€œNow that most of Europe is in hand, the Dark Lord is able to bring together quite a number of ambitious scientists with few ethical lines. You know Sussex is expanding beyond curse development. Itâ€™s remarkable the magi-scientific advancements that can be achieved when scientists can do anything they want with their test subjects.â€

Hermione felt as though something inside her had collapsed and left a void. â€œI see...I suppose thatâ€™s hardly surprising. Similar things happened during the second muggle World War.â€

Draco nodded and looked tired. More than tired; it was as though his soul were shining through his silver eyes, and he was almost transparent inside.

â€œHow do you know about World War Two?â€

His eyes glittered hard as diamonds. â€œAs previously mentioned, I can read. Why wouldnâ€™t I study it? Itâ€™s obviously the playbook the Dark Lord is drawing from. The propaganda runs parallel. The same tactics. He learned from Hitlerâ€™s mistakes; heâ€™s not wasting any resources on Russia, and heâ€™s being careful to avoid outright provoking MACUSA for as long as possible. Although, I donâ€™t know what they intend to do if he tries to overthrow the Statute of Secrecy.â€

Hermione nodded. â€œWeâ€™ve tried to reach out for aid, but apparently genocide isnâ€™t enough of a reason to intervene. Other countries need to sort out their own problems, you know; MACUSA isnâ€™t the worldâ€™s aurors. They wonâ€™t even take our refugees. Not without at least a few years to vet them. Even the children. Apparently thereâ€™s too much risk of bringing Europeâ€™s extremism to their soil, and we donâ€™t have any legal records for most of the youngest ones...â€

Her voice trailed off. She looked up at him seriously. â€œDo you think we can win, Draco?â€

She wanted to hear the answer from him more than she wanted to hear it from anyone else. Ron, Harry, Fred, even Kingsley or Moodyâ€¦ theyâ€™d all lie, or choose to take an optimistic view of things. But Draco Malfoy would not lie about it. For some reason she felt certain of it. He would tell her what he really thought was possible.

He sighed and leaned against the wall. â€œDoes it matter what I think?â€

â€œI live among idealists, but all I see are more and more bodies. I want to hear from someone who actually knows what itâ€™s like out there and doesnâ€™t believe that optimism somehow improves the odds.â€

â€œYouâ€™re well aware that I think your Order is largely moronic.â€ His expression was bitter. â€œAlthough I have noticed that Shacklebolt and Moody do make the occasional strategic choice when they can get away with it.â€

He gave Hermione a pointed look, which she returned without blinking.

â€œI donâ€™t see how youâ€™ll win with the continued policy against using the Dark Arts. Then again, Potter is an idiot who is still alive. He has the most unnatural talent for survival Iâ€™ve ever seen; power too, if he were willing to actually use it. If it comes down to a duel between the Dark Lord and Potter, Iâ€™d give the Order one in four odds, on the basis of Potterâ€™s continuously improbable luck. But if the war is about more than thatâ€”â€œ he rubbed his forehead. â€œthe odds are considerably longer. To put it mildly.â€

â€œWhy aid us then?â€

He quirked an eyebrow, and his expression became reserved and mocking. Â â€œDonâ€™t you think youâ€™re worth it?â€

â€œOh yes, your rose in a graveyard.â€ She glanced away, snorting faintly, and straightened her clothes. â€œGet those runes for me?â€

His eyes flashed for a moment, and then he shook his head.

â€œWhy then?â€ she asked as she studied him.

He stared at her and his expression flickered. He looked bitter. Wounded. His eyes were calculating for several seconds as he looked at her, then his expression became closed again.

â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter.â€

Hermione started to open her mouth. She wanted to argue, to point out that it did matter; that if he would stop being enigmatic she wouldnâ€™t be forced to manipulate him. But she couldnâ€™t say that, and he already knew. Whatever his motive, he didnâ€™t trust the Order not to use it against him.

They both knew the Order would.

â€œI suppose not.â€ She sighed and then sat down to transfigure her shoes.

She prepared to leave but looked back at Draco when she was at the door. He was leaning against the wall, his eyes darted away from her as she turned.

â€œDonâ€™t die, Draco.â€

He stared at her for a moment before smiling.

â€œOnly because you asked, Granger.â€ His tone dripped with sarcasm.

He was still leaning against the wall when she closed the door behind her.

Their Tuesdays came to be comprised of the odd combination of dancing and dueling. Draco determinedly drilled her until she could fluidly dodge and move the way he wanted her to. He had been right; dancing and dueling involved a similar type of reactive ability and Hermione picked it up quickly.

It unnerved her slightly when she realised that her movement and techniques were indeed growing reminiscent of Bellatrix's.

She would have almost thought she was getting decent, but Malfoy never used his left hand. She wondered how he dueled when he was really trying.

He arrived with noticeable injuries sometimes but coldly refused to let her heal him.

The amount of time they spent together grew longer and longer. Dueling practice developed breaks every half hour to cool down and rehydrate. Hermione tried to talk to him, but he mostly ignored her, and when he did answer her questions, he seemed to lie.

Occasionally Hermione got called away abruptly following a skirmish, but Death Eaters werenâ€™t prone toward early morning attacks.

The tension of the war felt endlessly strung out, as though the fragile balance would snap at any moment. The tension between Hermione and Draco felt similar.

By December she felt as though the very air between them vibrated when they were together. Angry. Resentful. Desperate.

There was an edge developing to him; as though he were eroding slightly from stress. She wasnâ€™t sure whether it was simply the stress of war or if she were contributing to it.

He arrived one day looking pale, with blood dripping from his left hand. Heâ€™d nearly bitten her head off the last time she tried to heal him, so Hermione attempted to ignore it. When it failed to stop bleeding after half an hour, she finally spun around him as she dodged a hex and cast a diagnostic charm on him. She stared at it for less than a second.

â€œYou idiot!â€ She was forced to retreat across the floor and throw herself into a somersault in order to avoid the angry, rapid succession of stunners he sent after her. â€œYou canâ€™t ignore vampire bites.â€

She shot half a dozen tripping jinxes at his feet and while he was avoiding them, she whipped her wand up and managed to catch him in the forehead with a stunner.

He dropped and she stared in astonishment, half expecting him to suddenly sit up. She was shocked she had actually managed to strike him. Then it occurred to her that the success probably had more to do with his blood loss than her dueling talents. She hurriedly cast another diagnostic on him.

He had lost a concerning amount of blood. He had been bitten somewhere on his upper arm, had internal bleeding and an open wound on his side.

She conjured a bed and levitated him onto it. She only hesitated for a moment before she sat down on the edge beside him. Even unconscious, Draco looked tense. She reached out tentatively and touched his cheek. Then she brushed her fingertip between his eyes, trying to banish the stress from his expression.

She cast a spell to unbutton his robes and shirt and then, with a practiced partial-levitation charm, she pulled him up so that he was leaning against her and pushed all the clothing down off his shoulders and arms. His head dropped against her shoulder, and she couldnâ€™t help but notice the scarring from the runes. They had set well into silver scars across his shoulders. She ran her fingers lightly over them and felt the magic; cold and implacable. Carved into his being. The magic shivered faintly under her touch.

His skin was worryingly cool.

She eased him back down onto the bed and looked him over. Heâ€™d gotten bitten on his bicep, two deep punctures which were easily healed. The more serious issue was his torso which was mottled with deep bruising which Hermione suspected were from a close range Expulso hex, possibly from a skirmish with the Order that had occurred the night before. He had a gash on his side that looked to be several days old but had started bleeding again due to the vampire bite.

She summoned her satchel and pulled out her kit. She poured several potions down his throat and then set to repairing the injury in his side.

He was an idiot, and she felt cold with worry to realise he wasnâ€™t getting his injuries attended to. In the past heâ€™d been in excellent physical condition when sheâ€™d healed him.

He had numerous scars on his arms and torso that hadnâ€™t been there before. She could tell by studying them that he had just ignored them and left them to heal on their own rather than going to a healer.

Perhaps heâ€™d fired his previous healer after they had offered no relief for the runes. Even if the magic was obscure, no qualified healer could have been so ignorant as to pretend there were no options unless theyâ€™d been willfully negligent.

Heâ€™d said he had a new healer. Whenever sheâ€™d offered to heal him heâ€™d insisted he had someone who would take care of it.

He was being intentionally careless.

Perhaps he was doing it to punish himself. If she was making him waver from hisâ€”atonement, or whatever it was. Hermione bit her lip. Perhaps he was intentionally neglecting his physical well-being in order to focus himself. Orâ€”possibly, he was trying to test his limits.

She tried to not to dwell on that possibility.

She pulled out a bruise paste and spread it across his torso and then muttered charms over all his scars to help them heal and fade somewhat.

She cast another diagnostic and studied it carefully to make sure she hadnâ€™t overlooked any injuries.

Once she was sure there was nothing else to tend to she took his hand, entwined her fingers with his and then pressed the back of his hand against her cheek. Waiting as his skin slowly started to warm as the blood replenishing potion took affect.

She brushed his hair off his face and stared at him, tracing along his features with her eyes and watching colour slowly come back.

When he was undeniably warm she withdrew her hands away and cast cleaning charms on his clothing and redressed him. His robes had a taint of Dark Magic in them, as though it had become woven into the fabric.

She wavered over whether she should stay where she was or go across the room before rennervating him.

She stayed.

Sheâ€™d barely finished speaking the spell before he sprang up, grabbed her by the throat, and slammed her down onto the mattress before she could even scream with surprise. His hand stayed on her neck, and she could feel several of her hairpins stabbing into her skull as he pinned her down. His eyes were disoriented, but his expression was enraged. Their faces were mere centimeters apart.

She watched his expression ripple as he recognized her and realised he was on the verge of strangling her. His hold immediately loosened.

â€œWhat the fuck, Granger?â€ He glanced around them and looked more confused as he realised they were in a bed together.

She stared up at him, her heart pounding. It hadnâ€™t even occurred to her that he might attack her like that. â€œYou were hurt.â€

He jerked his hand away from her neck and his expression grew furious. â€œI nearly killed you. You meddlingâ€”â€œ

She interrupted him. â€œItâ€™s possible you are somehow unaware, despite the fact that I have specifically told you, but vampire venom is an anticoagulant. You had some minor internal damage from the skirmish last night. You were bleeding to death inside and out.â€

â€œI would have had it taken care of in due time,â€ he said, but his eyes didnâ€™t meet hers; they were lower, on her neck. His hand slid forward and she felt his thumb brush along her throat.

She shivered faintly and felt her skin prickle as his fingers ran along her neck. â€œReally? Just who was going to heal you? Because I must say, based on all the new scars littering your body, I think that the new healer you keep mentioning is a fraud.â€

His hand stilled. â€œYou removed my clothes?â€

â€œJust your shirt. Donâ€™t look so astonished, Iâ€™m a healer, Draco. Itâ€™s not as though itâ€™s the first time Iâ€™ve seen you shirtless.â€ Â 

His eyes flashed with rage. â€œDo not heal me without permission.â€ His voice was a low growl.

His fury was overt, but the intimidation of it was ruined by the fact he was simultaneously turning her head gently, checking to see if heâ€™d bruised her at all.

Hermione felt the corner of her mouth quirk slightly as she watched him. He was leaning over her, his fingers pressing along her jaw as he kept turning her head from side to side and running his thumbs lightly across her skin.

Her heart was beating harder than it had when heâ€™d abruptly pinned her down.

â€œTry not to be dying in my presence and I wonâ€™t feel like I have to. I donâ€™t want you training me when youâ€™re hurt. You already know that.â€ Her hand went up and closed around his wrist to still him. His eyes flicked up and met her own, and she studied him seriously. â€œGet a healer, Draco. A good one. Put them on retainer, and call them when youâ€™re hurt. Please. Please get a healer.â€

He just stared at her, and it felt like her heart stalled from the intensity. Her pulse thrummed under his fingers and she watched as his pupils slowly expanded, swallowing the silver of his irises. The heat of his skin was bleeding into her, and she could feel his breath against her face.

His face drew infinitesimally closer. Her heart was beating so hard she wondered if he could hear it. Her breath caught, and her fingers tightened around his wrist. Everything was warm, and they were so close. He was so close.

He dipped his head lower, until their lips were almost touching. Then he laughed.

He jerked his hand free of hers and sat up. His expression was cold as ice, and he sneered down at her.

â€œDid you really think Iâ€™d kiss you?â€

Hermione stared at him.

He tilted his head back and chuckled bitterly. â€œYou know, it amazes me that someone like you has managed to stay friends with Potter and Weasley for so long.â€

Hermione flinched. â€œSomeone like me?â€

He stared down at her and quirked an eyebrow, his expression was impassive, but she could see the resentment in his eyes. â€Someone with no lines they wonâ€™t cross. With Potter and Weasleyâ€™s righteousness, I would have expected it to end things for you by now.â€

Hermione stared at him and her mouth twitched. She pressed her lips together hard. He smirked and cocked his head slightly. â€œWhat? Did you think I was referring to your blood?â€

She dropped her eyes. Yes, sheâ€™d go with that. No good would come from admitting that he was right; her ruthlessness had essentially ended her friendship with Harry and Ron.

She sat up and reached back to adjust the pins holding her braids. â€œYou were the first person who ever called me Mudblood.â€

Draco shook his head in faint disbelief. â€œSurely you at least know this war isnâ€™t about blood purity.â€

â€œI know that it isnâ€™t.â€ She jutted her chin up. â€œBut most of the Wizarding world doesnâ€™t appear to have noticed that.â€

He straightened his robes and shrugged. His mask was dropped back into place; his expression was indolent and aristocratic. Hermione stared at him, trying to absorb the profound contradiction that was Draco Malfoy. Assassin. Order Spy. Pureblood heir. Muggle philosophy and history hobbyist. Death Eater General.

The more she knew of him, the less she understood him.

He leaned against the headboard of the bed and eyed her. â€œWar requires easy extremes. Otherness. When I say my name is Malfoy, I immediately contextualise myself within history. The Malfoy name has nearly a thousand years of traceable history in England. People know who my parents are, my grandparents, and my great-grandparents. We have entire history books and hallways of sentient portraits to carry and maintain the legacy. But youâ€”your family history is as muddied as a creekbed. No one knows who your parents are or what kinds of genetic disease you may carry or what your magical potential may or may not be.â€

He tilted his head to the side and ran his eyes over her from head to toe as though he were appraising a horse.

â€œItâ€™s easy to be suspicious of people those you know nothing about. When something is frightening itâ€™s easy to hate. Muggle-borns with odd clothing, and electricity, and rumors of your strange weapons. Your parents are the reason the Wizarding world has been forced to live in the shadows of secrecy for hundreds of years. Yet the moment a Muggle shows a hint of magic ability, weâ€™re expected to welcome them into our world so they can violate our traditions and steal our jobs.â€

Hermione snorted and turned herself so that they were closer to each other once again. Dracoâ€™s eyes widened for a moment before he stifled his surprise. Hermione closed the space between them and stared up at him.

â€œIs that why you hated me in school, Draco, because I was going to steal your job?â€

Chapter End Notes
