Flashback 20

December 2002

Â 

Draco quirked an eyebrow as he met her eyes.

â€œYou stole my class ranking, which was worse. Iâ€™d been tutored at home, prepared my entire life for Hogwarts. My father had my life planned for me: top of my class, prefect, Quidditch captain, Head Boy, internship at the Ministry of Magic, and eventually a member of the Wizengamot and then Minister of Magic. The ministry career he lost due to his participation in the first Wizarding war; I was supposed to do it all. But then, first year of school and an inferior little Mudblood girl managed to exceed my marks in every class.â€

He reached out and laid his hand across her throat. Hermioneâ€™s breath caught slightly, and he tightened his hold, just enough to draw her face closer to his.

Dracoâ€™s eyes glittered, and his tone was almost light, as though he were daring her to flinch. â€œI have to admit, I really hoped youâ€™d die during second year when the Chamber of Secrets was opened. I did actually earn my place on the Slytherin Quidditch team before my father bought brooms for the team, but thanks to your little comment the whole school assumed my father just bought my spot.â€ As he spoke, he slid his thumb up her throat to her jaw and then pushed against the bone to force her head back.

He was trying to force her to flinch. Hermione kept meeting his eyes. They were darkening.

The room felt warmer.

He kept talking.

â€œIt was easy to believe that Muggles and their spawn were responsible for the problems in the world. It certainly felt that way in my life. Between half-blood Potter, whose life was an endless stream of dumb-luck and favouritism, and you, and then the impoverished Weasleys being exhibit A for what happens to blood-traitors. There wasnâ€™t any reason not to believe the Wizarding world wouldnâ€™t be a better place without you and your ilk.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t realise you thought about me that much,â€ Hermione said.

She could feel heat slowly radiating through her body, spreading outward from his hand, but also between her shoulders, across her skin and unfurling somewhere in her lower abdomen. She shivered faintly as she kept meeting his eyes.

His mouth twitched. â€œMy hatred of you paled in comparison to my rivalry with Potter. You were an irritant. Despite your grades at least you were ugly, socially awkward and obviously insecure.â€ His lips curled into a faint smirk. â€œBeating me academically wouldnâ€™t have mattered if you hadnâ€™t been friends with Potter. He dragged you into the spotlight and needed you enough that he couldnâ€™t deny it. If Potter hadnâ€™t mattered, you wouldnâ€™t have either.â€

Hermione felt something in her stomach suddenly drop, thinking back to the initial suspicion sheâ€™d had; that demanding her was some kind of revenge or retaliation against Harry. Sheâ€™d almost forgotten about that fear.

He smiled and leaned forward so that he was looming over her as he continued to hold her by the throat and stare down at her face. Their bodies were almost touching, and she felt a renewed awareness of how much bigger he was, how much he could hurt her if he wanted to. That she was trying to break inside a sealed vault, and she didnâ€™t know if there was anything but rage on the other side.

But it didnâ€™t matter, because it was what she was supposed to do.

Her breath caught, and she trembled faintly. Dracoâ€™s eyes darkened.

He pulled her even closer. Her heart was beating Â so hard it hurt.

Itâ€™s an act, she told herself. When he was drunk, he didnâ€™t hurt her. He was trying to scare her.

His breath was hot on her face, and his voice was so low he was almost whispering to her. The timbre laced through her nerves.

â€œThe Dark Lord doesnâ€™t actually care about blood purity, or his followers, or magic being might. You Muggle-borns just happen to be common enough to seem like a threat. It gives the Dark Lord an excuse to accumulate power and it incentivises dark beings to join his cause. He brought most of Eastern Europe into alliance that way. Romania was the first, and the rest fell in line. There are thousands of dark creatures desperate to see the Statute of Secrecy overturned and the wand ban ended. Most pureblood families are discontent with the way wizards are forced into the shadows for the comfort of Muggles. Thereâ€™s enough resentmentâ€”if not to recruit them to the causeâ€”to encourage them to ignore whatâ€™s happening.â€

Draco gave a thin smile as his face drew even nearer. â€œThe Dark Lord wants power. He isnâ€™t particular about who he crushes underfoot to obtain it. Muggles and Muggle-bornsâ€”â€œ she could almost feel his lips against hers, â€œâ€”youâ€¦ were just easy.â€

Hermione could barely breathe. Her whole body was taut; at the precipice of something that felt like fear. Her heart was beating rapidly. Everything around her was blurring.

She wanted to bolt; she felt scared and vulnerable. She understood human anatomy and physiology, but her body was doing things she wasnâ€™t familiar with. Her physiology wasnâ€™t supposed to be confusing. She needed space to figure it out.

Butâ€”she didnâ€™t want to go; she had never felt anything like it before. Physical touch that was comforting, she understood. But this wasnâ€™t comforting. Dracoâ€™s hand around her throat wasnâ€™t comforting. It was terrifyingâ€”and thrilling.

â€œA means to an end,â€ she forced herself to say. â€œWeâ€™re just a means to an end.

He pushed her back slightly. â€œPrecisely.â€

She studied him. His eyes were black, and the hollows of his cheeks were faintly flushed. He slid his thumb slowly along the curve of her jaw. She licked her lips.

â€œHas killing us solved your problems then?â€ she asked.

His hand stilled. He stared at her for several seconds. Then his eyes glittered and he smiled.

â€œWell, youâ€™re certainly no threat to my job now, are you?â€ As he said it, his free hand slid firmly between her legs.

His eyes were cold and locked on hers. His fingers twisted and pressed knowingly at the apex of her thighs. It felt as though heâ€™d electrocuted her. Sensation shot through her nerves.

She gasped.

As she did, everything crashed down on her with a sense of cold horror.

Hermione jerked away from him.

Dracoâ€™s hands immediately withdrew from her, and he watched with an indifferent expression as she drew further away until she was on the far end of the bed.

She was shaking faintly. She could still feel him touching her; sliding his hand between her legs as he stared in her eyes and reminded her that he had turned her into his property. Not because he had wanted her. But simply because he could. Because it had amused him to do so when he made his offer. Because he had power, and she was a pawn.

Now he got to watch her try to whore herself to him, and anything else she could conceive of, in the hopes of becoming a possession he would at least be unwilling to part with. He didnâ€™t have to debase her further. He could sit back and watch her do it to herself.

Her cheekbones felt hollow. She felt like she might be sick.

Her hands kept trembling no matter how hard she tried to still them. She bit down on her lower lip and drew several long breaths.

When she stopped visibly shaking, she forced herself to speak. â€œDo youâ€”have any information this week?â€

It was almost funny to have to ask that question right then. Althoughâ€”that had always been the meaning of the question. Sheâ€™d just gotten used to it.

Suddenly it hurt again, and the timing was almost amusing in some sickening way. She wasnâ€™t sure if the humor would be categorised as irony or black humor. She just knew it was something bitter, something painful to think about. But somehow also cruelly funny.

Draco smirked and pulled out a scroll of parchment. Heâ€™d driven his point home; as though heâ€™d knifed her and then broken off the hilt so it stayed. That he didnâ€™t reiterate the insult showed that he knew.

Her hand shook faintly as she accepted the scroll and stood up.

She left without another word.

It was just over week until Christmas.

When she returned to Grimmauld Place, she went and took a calming Draught. She stood in her potion supply closet waiting for her hands to stop shaking.

When her hands were steady again, she glanced around the little room wistfully. She straightened a little basket full of what looked like leather pocketbooks. The Christmas presents sheâ€™d planned that year were rather sad. Sheâ€™d made emergency healing kits. Again. She made them every year. The basics, all packed together and shrunk down to be easily carried.

Hermione had no money to buy books for her friends that they would never read, nor the time to knit hats or scarves for them. So she gave them potions and hoped theyâ€™d used them rather than apparating back with easily remedied injuries. The girls did; they would ask for refills. Neville, Fred, Dean Thomas, and Michael Corner would occasionally use their kits too.

But Hermione didnâ€™t think Harry or Ron had ever even opened theirs. Every time she gave them new kits theyâ€™d sheepishly return their old ones untouched. They always either ignored their injuries or apparated back panicking over them. In that regard, Ginny had been an excellent partner for Harry and Ron; both boys tended to return in better condition when Ginny went on missions with them.

Hermione swallowed hard, pulled down vials from the shelves and started assembling an additional kit.

She had a job. How she felt about it on a particular day didnâ€™t matter.

It never mattered.

The next week when Draco apparated into the shack, he and Hermione both paused and stared at each other.

â€œI have a Christmas present for you,â€ she said after a minute. â€œWell, itâ€™s not really. But I suppose contextually it is.â€

She pulled out the small leather case and held it out to him.

â€œItâ€™sâ€”itâ€™s an emergency healing kit. I give them to all my friends.â€

Draco quirked an eyebrow and sighed faintly as he plucked it from her hands; as though accepting it were a favour to her.

â€œIf youâ€™re not going to go to a healer, you should at least carry this.â€ She was speaking quickly, trying to say it all before he cut her off and flung it back in her face. â€œIf you let me teach you a few spells, youâ€™ll be able to heal most basic injuries yourself.â€

He flipped the case open and scanned the contents. â€œYou realise I can buy most of these.â€

Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched. She hadnâ€™t expected him to be grateful; sheâ€™d braced herself that he might not even accept it.

â€œThen you can easily refill any you use.â€ Hermione forced herself to step closer and ran her finger along, pointing at the various vials.

â€œTheyâ€™re all labeled. Thereâ€™s the potion for concussions; any type of blow to the head and you should use a diagnostic to check. Murtlap essence for minor skin abrasions or small bruises. The bruise cream is for deeper and more serious hematomas. The Essence of Dittany is a trump card for most injuries. Unless itâ€™s a cursed wound, Dittany can help with most severe external injuries, werewolf bites, splinching. Unless itâ€™s the eyes or a brain injury, in which case youâ€™ll need to call a specialist. Donâ€™t even think about apparating or any other kind of displacement transport if you injure your eyes or have any type of wound that punctures the skull. The pressure will do irreversible damage. This antivenin will counteract venomous bites or stings unless itâ€™s a class XXXX type beast or above. The antidote here can counteract the anticoagulant properties of vampire bites.â€

Draco snorted faintly.

Hermione continued doggedly. â€œCalming Draught. Blood replenishing potion. This here is for internal organ damage, kidney contusions and the like. Iâ€™ll teach you a diagnostic to check for things like that. And this one, itâ€™s an analgesic for the acid boil curse. Iâ€™m assuming you know the counter-curse. The analgesic will neutralise it completely and it cuts the pain. Youâ€™ll still need to have all the bones removed carefully and then regrown. But it will reduce the recovery times by several days and decrease the likelihood of nerve damage. And a chocolate bar, for dementors. When you pull the items out of the case theyâ€™ll assume their proper size. I shrank them so the kit wouldnâ€™t be too large to carry.â€

Hermione didnâ€™t mention that she had expanded Dracoâ€™s kit far beyond the basics that she gave to everyone else. In the case of her friends she could count on them to come to her if they had an injury. It was not an assumption she could make with Draco. If he wasnâ€™t going to trust healers anymore, at least she could equip him enough to deal with more injuries by himself.

Draco snapped the case shut. Hermione stared up at him seriously. â€œJustâ€”keep it with you. Let me teach you a diagnostic, so you can tell if youâ€™re dealing with anything serious.â€

â€œI know how to perform a diagnostic charm, Granger.â€ His expression was slightly offended.

â€œProbably not the one I want to teach you. Itâ€™s a bit unusual. More obscure. Better for war injuries. The basic ones are household charms, for diagnosing fevers or infections and daily injuries. Most medical textbooks will teach a general diagnostic with the assumption that the healer can then narrow their focus progressively. But if youâ€™re using a diagnostic, itâ€™s probably going to be after a raid or duel. So you can focus on detecting curses and physical injuries, thereâ€™s no need to look for dragon pox or check whether thereâ€™s any partial Transfiguration.â€

She demonstrated the diagnostic by casting it on herself.

â€œSee? The spell is simple. Whatâ€™s complex is reading it, but weâ€™ll just stick to the basics. The colours and locations are indicative. Iâ€™m not cursed or injured so the reading is rather boring. The way I tilt my wand can bring various areas into a focused reading. Everything is a healthy sky blue. If it starts turning turquoise, that indicates a dangerous level of blood loss or drop in body temperature. If it's royal blue, thatâ€™s a fever. It reads from the head down. The brighter the color, the more minor the injury. If itâ€™s black, even the slightest trace of black, itâ€™s potentially a mortal wound. Red indicates an external injury. Purple is for internal injuries. If thereâ€™s purple on your head, that indicates a concussion; on your torso that means you should take the potion for internal damage. Lime green would indicate a minor hex but viridian means curses; get to spell damage or call your healer. Yellow is for poison or venom. Fractured bones will show up pale orange, broken and displaced Â is more pumpkin-toned. If itâ€™s a fracture you should heal it yourself. Itâ€™s an easy spell, Iâ€™ll teach it to you.â€

Malfoy was begrudgingly cooperative and even seemed slightly intrigued at times. Hermione determinedly plowed through as much training as she thought she could get away with and got him to demonstrate that he could do them all himself.

He had a knack for it. She had thought he probably would. A natural occlumens with a razor-edged focus carved into him; the precision would come naturally to him.

She suspected he knew a bit about the theory of healing. She almost asked him why, but his cooperativeness felt highly conditional. She stifled her curiosity and just kept rattling off tips for healing.

â€œAnyway, those are the basics,â€ she finished at last.

He glanced at his watch. â€œYou realise youâ€™ve been talking for almost two hours straight.â€

Hermione blushed. â€œItâ€™s still very basic.â€

There was a pause, and Hermione realised sheâ€™d moved so close to Draco their shoulders were brushing. She could smell the scent of oakmoss that clung to his skin. She looked up at him, and their eyes met.

For a moment everything between them ceased to be so tense and resentful; as though the war faded away for a moment, and it was just them. She almost smiled at him. Because he could be kind to her when he wanted to be, and she was so tired that day.

She tried not to think about how pathetic that made her.

Then Draco pressed his lips into a flat line, and she saw his jaw clench. His eyes flashed, and she watched them sharpen; like a gaze of a bird of prey, they began to grow cruel.

She stepped back and dropped her eyes. Â â€œHappy Christmas, Draco.â€

He stared at her contemplatively. His expression was unreadable. She felt her heart rate increase. She was never quite sure what he might do.

She tried not to let her fingers fidget.

He rolled his jaw. Hermione felt cold and almost hollow inside as she braced herself.

â€œI have something for you,â€ he said, reaching into his robes.

He pulled out something that was rolled up in oilcloth and held it out toward her. She accepted it and unrolled the cloth slowly to reveal its contents. Inside lay a set of beautiful and deadly daggers, sheathed in delicate mesh holsters.

â€œThey should be small enough to keep one strapped to your forearm. The holsters are acromantula silk dipped in manticore blood; theyâ€™ll resize to you and wonâ€™t restrict your movement at all. You should wear the other dagger on your calf.â€ He looked visibly awkward as he relayed the information. His eyes were avoiding Hermione, but they kept sweeping back to watch as she studied the daggers.

â€œAre these Goblin-wrought silver?â€ she asked after a minute.

â€œYes. Theyâ€™re dipped in manticore venom, as a matter of fact.â€

She looked up at him sharply. â€œDoes that meanâ€”â€œ

â€œIt died. Tragically.â€ The corner of his mouth quirked slightly. â€œThe inclement weather, I suspect. I filed all the paperwork and turned the corpse over to McNair yesterday.â€

â€œBut not before you harvested some venom,â€ Hermione said, pulling one of the daggers out of the sheath and staring at the razor sharp edge, capable of cutting through almost anything. The blade would slide through a shield spell or protective wards as though they werenâ€™t there.

â€œNot much, or it would have been suspicious. But enough for a handful of weapons and an extra vial for a rainy day.â€

Hermione began mentally running the numbers on Dracoâ€™s gift. Two goblin-wrought silver knives: at least a hundred galleons each. Manticore venom: another hundred or so right there. Acromantula silk holsters: another hundred galleons.

Dracoâ€™s Christmas present for her was worth a small fortune. She wasnâ€™t even sure if he knew that or not.

Hermione was obsessive about her budget and her resources. She had to be. She cut every corner and saved every drop of potion and Knut she could. There was a corner of her mind that was endlessly trying to think of new ways to save or conceive of untapped resources.

It staggered her, the casual way in which Draco could hand her an enchanted shield cloak or a set of knives collectively worth more than her annual hospital and potion budget for the entire Resistance.

She would sell them. At least one, possibly both. On the black market she could probably get a decent return, enough to buy more acromantula venom or Essence of Dittany, or to restock some of the other hospital supplies. Or maybe it would be better to turn them over to Moody or Kingsley; they would get good use from knives like that. She might be able to use the daggers to negotiate a permanent budget increase.

â€œThank you,â€ she said, resheathing the blade she was holding and slipping everything into her satchel.

â€œFor the record, you are not allowed to sell them or give them to anyone else.â€

Hermioneâ€™s hands stilled, and her eyes darted guiltily up to Dracoâ€™s face. His eyes were locked on hers, and the silver in them glittered.

â€œIs that clear, Granger?â€ His tone was ice.

She gave a begrudging nod.

â€œI will expect you to wear them every time you forage. I will look for them.â€

She tensed and swallowed hard with irritation. â€œFine.â€

His expression softened marginally. â€œWell, this has been delightful. I cannot even remember how many times Iâ€™ve wished I could spend Christmas Eve getting lectured on how to read a diagnostic charm.â€ He smiled insincerely. Hermione said nothing. There was a pause, and then he added, â€œPer your request, hereâ€™s a warning. Iâ€™m going to start teaching you hand-to-hand combat starting next week.â€

Then he reached into his robes and pulled out a scroll of parchment. â€œMy latest installment for Moody.â€ As she accepted it, he smirked at her. â€œI have to say, youâ€™ve ended up being quite expensive, Granger.â€

He vanished without a sound.

On Christmas Day, Hermione had the morning hospital shift. Angelina had been badly cursed during a raid in Muggle London the night before; sheâ€™d been hit in the knee with the acid curse, and while she was down, a Death Eater had added on an additional internal organ destroying curse. Fred had managed to grab hold of her and bring her back to Hermione before Angelina died in his arms.

The final repair work was too complex for Padma or Poppy.

Hermione sat in the quiet hospital ward and slowly reconstructed the tissue and tendons in Angelinaâ€™s knee. â€œAlright, I need you to bend it, and see if the tissue formed properly. Regrowing bones for injuries like this doesnâ€™t always work properly.â€

Angelina bit her lip. Her skin was grey from pain, but she moved her knee as requested.

â€œUgggghh.â€ She gasped faintly and stopped. â€œInside. It hurts insideâ€”like itâ€™s grinding.â€

Hermione cast a diagnostic and studied it. Due to the urgency of saving Angelinaâ€™s organs, the acid curse had been overlooked for several minutes before being countered. It had destroyed most of the bones in Angelinaâ€™s knee and left huge pockets of lost tissue. It was difficult to repair when there was so little of the original tissue left to build from. Hermione had initially feared sheâ€™d have to amputate it, but there was just enough intact after the bone regrowth for it to be healable.

â€œI see the problem. Iâ€™m going to stun you. You donâ€™t need to be awake for this part.â€

Angelina nodded and closed her eyes.

It took nearly four hours before Hermione rennervated Angelina.

â€œAlright, try moving it again.â€

Angelina lifted her leg and bent it slightly. â€œThatâ€™s better. It twinges a little.â€ Her colour seemed much healthier.

â€œYouâ€™ll need to stay off it for at least a month, but I think youâ€™ll be able to walk on it. It will hurt, particularly on cold days. You may limp a little. Youâ€™ll always feel it. But you can still fight, if you want.â€

â€œIâ€™m not leaving the fight,â€ Angelina said firmly.

Hermione nodded, unsurprised, and began massaging a potion into Angelinaâ€™s new skin. As Hermione worked, she became aware of Angelinaâ€™s intense stare. Hermione glanced up and met her gaze. â€œWhat?â€

Angelina tilted her head, still studying Hermione. â€œSometimes I try to remember you from before the war, and I canâ€™t see that person anymore.â€

Hermioneâ€™s jaw tensed. She tried to restrict her advocacy for the Dark Arts to Order meetings, but her position had become known in the wider Resistance over time. Members of DA regularly took it upon themselves to evangelise to Hermione about the power of Good and the evil of the Dark Arts.

She could tell, by the expression on Angelinaâ€™s face, that she was about to be subjected to a new lecture.

She forced her voice to stay even. â€œWho is it you thought I was then?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. Loud, forward, positive. Rather abrasive, to be honest. When you organised DA, you were a bit ruthless, but there was a honest sort of righteousness to it. Now, when youâ€™re not in healer-mode, you just seem ruthless. Youâ€™re so quiet most of the time, but thereâ€™s this rage around you that I feel sometimes. Like the war turned you into someone else. I feel like you let it.â€

The corner of Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched, and she felt her eyes narrow. â€œWar is a crucible. Do you think any of us will come out on the other side the same as we were?â€

Angelina looked down at her knee and shrugged. â€œIâ€™ll carry scars inside and out, but deep down Iâ€™m always going to be the same person.â€ Angelina looked back at Hermione. â€œBut I donâ€™t know if youâ€™re the same and I just never saw it, or if youâ€™ve really changed that much. I feel like youâ€™ve let go of yourself.â€

Hermioneâ€™s hands stilled, and she sat back. â€œLet go?â€

Angelina shifted and looked uncomfortable. â€œI guess Iâ€™m worried about you. Fred said, when he was visiting George here, that it seemed like something happened to you. Like the last bits of the old you justâ€”disappeared one day. And Iâ€™ve been watching you lately, all I see is thisâ€”I donâ€™t even know what it is. Sometimes I think itâ€™s rage. Other times I think itâ€™s despair. But itâ€™s as though youâ€™re lost in it.â€

Hermioneâ€™s mouth felt dry, and she swallowed repeatedly, buying herself time by recorking vials. She gripped the glass so hard her hands shook faintly.

â€œThis war has eaten me, Angelina,â€ she finally said slowly.

Before she could say anything else, Hermione found herself abruptly jerked forward with a mouthful of hair in her mouth as Angelina pulled her into a tight hug.

â€œOh, Hermione. Donâ€™t let yourself start thinking like that. You have to be able to visualise victory. Feel it. Fight for it. See yourself on the other side of the war. If you let go of that hope, youâ€™re going end up somewhere dark. Light always wins over Darkness. But you have to believe it.â€

Hermione felt something inside her stiffen. She pulled herself away from Angelina, shaking her head, her mouth curling. â€œThatâ€™s not enough to win a war. Iâ€™m not going to bet this war on my or anyone elseâ€™s ability to believe in victory.â€

â€œYou still want us to use the Dark Arts, donâ€™t you?â€ Angelina stared at Hermione with the expression of a disappointed parent.

Hermione struggled against rolling her eyes as she nodded.

Angelinaâ€™s shoulders drooped slightly. â€œIf we lose ourselves to win, is it really winning? If we poison ourselves to get it and become the monsters weâ€™re fighting?â€

Hermione clenched her jaw, as she fought against the urge to shake Angelina. â€œWhat exactly do you think will happen if we lose?â€

â€œWeâ€™ll die.â€ Angelina shrugged faintly.

Hermione suddenly understood why Draco hated Gryffindors so intensely. She couldnâ€™t stop herself from scoffing.

â€œDo you really think weâ€™ll just die? Angelina, theyâ€™re not going to shut down Sussex when they win the war. Weâ€™re livestock. You didnâ€™t see the prisoners they brought from the last curse division. They wereâ€”â€œ Hermioneâ€™s voice shook. â€œThey were dissolving, rotting, skinned and still alive, there were things crawling inside themâ€”â€œ her voice broke off. â€œThe ones that could still speak begged me to kill them.â€

Hermione hissed between her teeth. The choking sense of frustration rose as she was forced to face, once again, the perpetual optimism of Resistance fighters. The stress and despair inside her felt toxic, like acid eroding her slowly at a cellular level. â€œIf we loseâ€”Theyâ€™ll round us all up and use the Resistance fighters as lab rats or whatever else they want to until they run out of us. After we blew up the last curse division, they just made a bigger one. The war isnâ€™t supposed to end with the Resistance. The Death Eaters are supposed to conquer the Muggle Europe next. Thatâ€™s the vision. The deal. All the Dark Beings allied with Tom because he promised them that. I donâ€™t know if heâ€™s insane enough to think he can do it, but thatâ€™s his claim. And heâ€™ll probably at least pretend to.â€

Hermione felt like she might start hyperventilating just thinking about it. Her chest was stuttering and jerking and she kept drawing short, quick breaths.

â€œBut, Hermione,â€ Angelina laid her hand across Hermioneâ€™s, â€œweâ€™re winning.â€

Hermione froze and blinked slowly as she stared at Angelina in disbelief. She almost laughed but then realised with horror that Angelina was entirely serious. â€œWeâ€™reâ€”what?â€

â€œWinning.â€ Angelinaâ€™s jaw jut out, and her expression grew defensive. â€œWe are. Think of all the prison raids. We got hundreds of people out since the spring. Weâ€™ve successfully countered hundreds of attacks this year. Staying true to the Light is paying off. The war is favouring us now. Soon the wizarding world will start to realise that. Thatâ€™s how hope works. It takes a spark.â€

Hermione felt as though sheâ€™d been struck sharply in the head; as though she were mildly concussed and it explained the surreal world she abruptly found herself in. She stared wordlessly at Angelina, who gave Hermione an encouraging smile. â€œYou arenâ€™t out there so you probably donâ€™t see it. I know things were dark for awhile, but itâ€™s always darkest before the dawn, and Iâ€™m pretty sure, weâ€™re at dawn now.â€

Hermione swallowed hard as she struggled against the temptation to scream. She could hear the blood pounding in her ears and a migraine rapidly manifesting.

They werenâ€™t winning.

They were surviving. The Resistance was balanced on a knife edge held in place by Draco. Using intelligence Gabrielle Delacour used her body to tear out of Death Eaters. They were using it to maintain the Resistance while the Order struggled vainly to find Horcruxes that could be anywhere in Europe.

They were not winning. They were not anywhere close to winning.

Angelina was staring at her hopefully.

â€œYesâ€¦â€ Hermione heard herself to say. â€œIâ€”I suppose youâ€™re right. Iâ€™m not out there, so I donâ€™t see it. Iâ€”didnâ€™t realise that weâ€™reâ€”winning.â€

Angelina nodded and hugged Hermione again. â€œThe problem is that youâ€™re too isolated. Pomfrey goes and spends her time with the Hogwarts professors, and Padma has Parvati to keep her in the loop. But you hardly leave this house except to get potion ingredients. I know Harry and Ron arenâ€™t around that much, but you have other friends.You need friends. When everything feels lostâ€”thatâ€™s whatâ€™s going to carry you through and help you hold on. The rest of us, we talk about this. I know youâ€™re really smart, Hermione, but when itâ€™s things like Good and Evil you canâ€™t expect to get the answer from a book. Itâ€™s something you have to feel. Like flyingâ€”well, I reckon thatâ€™s a bad example to use with youâ€”but, you have to be able to believe it will catch you. Itâ€™s all part of the journey, hitting the bottom so you can spring up. Good takes sacrifice. I hope, once the war is over, that youâ€™ll be able to see that. Thatâ€™s how Light and Darkness work.â€

â€œOf course.â€ Hermione said dully, avoiding Angelinaâ€™s eyes. â€œI guess Iâ€™ve just been too lost in my own world.â€

â€œItâ€™s alright. You donâ€™t need to feel bad about it. It can happen to anyone. I was in a pretty dark place after George and Katie both got hurt. Itâ€™s an easy place to go during a war. But then Harry gave everyone in DA a pep talk. He talked about how Dumbledore defeated Grindelwald. And he talked about the Order during the First Wizarding War, how bad things were. Everyone thought Tom was going to win then; the Ministry was using Unforgivables, but the Order held out. There was death and betrayal but Love and Light always shine brightest in those moments. Thatâ€™s why they always win. We just have to trust in them. Right after Harry said all that, I think it was that same month even, we had our first successful prison raid.â€

Hermione stood up sharply. She felt as though she couldnâ€™t breathe. She neededâ€”air. Cold. She needed a Calming Draught. â€œI need something from my supply closet. Iâ€™ll be back in a few minutes.â€

Hermioneâ€™s made her way dazedly toward her supply closet.

She stumbled down the hall and shoved the door closed behind her as she shakily uncorked a vial and downed a dose of Calming Draught. As the potion took effect, Hermione gave a sharp gasp and burst into tears.

She stood there sobbing for several minutes before leaning across the worktop. She buried her face in her arms and tried to come to terms with the conversation sheâ€™d just had.

She hadnâ€™t realisedâ€”it hadnâ€™t even occurred to her how the shift in the war would come across to the Resistance. Of course. Of course, to them nothing had changed. They all thought that by sticking to their convictions about Good and Evil that the war had simply shifted out of inherent inevitability.

They had no idea that Death Eaters were being tortured for information, or that Hermione had sold herself to Draco in order to earn most of it.

Hermione had unwittingly proven their mythos and in the process turned herself into Cassandra giving unheeded warnings at the gates of Troy.

Hermione gave a gasping sob and tried to breathe slowly through her nose as she struggled to think.

She had to move forward with Draco.

Padma wasâ€”passable for potion making and healing. Kingsley had looked over all Hermioneâ€™s notes and somehow recruited a backup casualty healer. She wondered how long heâ€™d been holding that piece back.

Sheâ€™d compiled all her notes on the counter-curses sheâ€™d developed over the years and instructions explaining the curse analysis techniques.

Moody seemed to be growing somewhat frustrated by the lack of progress she was reporting week after week. There had been a shift in both his and Kingsleyâ€™s recent behavior when she reported to them about Draco, a newfound skepticism, as though she were falling short of expectations.

Now she understood. They needed Draco under control.

Dracoâ€™s information was still excellent, but he had set the terms from the very beginning. It was a balance of power they were unwilling to trust and eager to shift.

They wanted him collared.

Hermione was stalling.

Flashback 21

Christmas 2002

The Weasleys spent their Christmas at Shell Cottage. When Padma arrived to take over the hospital shift, Hermione changed her clothes and apparated to join them.

She stood outside in the snow for several minutes as she tried to brace herself. The conversation with Angelina had knocked her off-kilter, and she felt as though she were grasping for a sense of control.

She stared at the front door and mentally rehearsed the day. Christmas would be quiet; a far cry from past holidays. Every year everyone was a little quieter and a little more drunk. The year before, Arthur had become overwhelmed by the number of people and had a fit until Molly was forced to leave with him.

Hermione could go through the motions. Smile. Sing carols. Check on Arthur and George. She took a deep breath and opened the door.

â€œOi! Hermioneâ€™s here!â€ Fred bellowed when she walked in.

Everyone turned and descended on her. They were all in surprisingly high spirits, cheerful and buzzed. A mug of wassail was shoved into her hands before sheâ€™d gotten across the room.

Everyone was decked in Christmas jumpers from Molly.

Hermione surreptitiously lined up vials of hangover potion along the top of the mantel.

Bill was sitting in one corner, quiet among the bustle. Fleur was seated on the arm of his chair, running her fingers through his hair.

Harry and Ginny were squished into an armchair, whispering together. Harry and Ron had returned from another horcrux hunt only a few days before.

â€œHermione dear, so glad you made it. This is for you,â€ Molly pressed a gift, wrapped in tissue paper, into Hermioneâ€™s hands.

Hermione perched on an ottoman and opened it. A green jumper with an H in the middle.

â€œThank you, Molly,â€ she said. â€œThis is beautiful.â€

â€œMum! Why are you sticking Hermione in Slytherin green?â€ Ron said, peering over.

Molly smacked him, wearing an expression of offense. â€œRonald! Itâ€™s emerald green and itâ€™s a lovely colour for her skin tone. It reminded me of Harryâ€™s eyes.â€

â€œLooks like Slytherin green to me.â€ Ron grimaced as Hermione pulled it over her head. â€œUgh. Gives me nightmares just looking at it.â€

Hermione and Mollyâ€™s relationship was somewhat strained. When Arthur was first cursed, there had been a great deal of hope that Hermione and Bill would collaboratively be able to reverse or break it. Molly had been effusive in her appreciation of all Hermioneâ€™s efforts. However, as time passed and hope dwindled, Molly withdrew. It wasnâ€™t blame, per se. It was simply painful. Hermione represented a deep hope that had failed.

Their interactions were still warm, but they kept them limited.

Hermione knew from second-hand accounts that Molly had vehement objections to her advocacy for the Dark Arts, but it was not a conversation they had ever actually had together.

Hermione wasnâ€™t sure if Molly had chosen the colour on the basis of skin tone, or if it was a form of reproof. It wasnâ€™t really worth thinking about. She was so tired of pointlessly arguing about it.

She left Ron and Molly to argue and went to find Arthur.

Mr Weasley was sitting on the floor in the corner, going through a lift-the-flap book. Hermione watched him carefully and cast a diagnostic spell on his brain. Arthur Weasley as an adult was still locked away somewhere. The curse Lucius used hadnâ€™t driven Arthur mad or scrubbed his memory. The magic had suspended Arthurâ€™s mind at a specific point in early childhood. The rest of Arthur was still inside, waiting to get out; Hermione could see it in the diagnostic. But she didnâ€™t know how to break through the magic without causing real and severe brain damage.

The lost parts of Arthurâ€™s brain were slowly deteriorating. His brain activity gradually shrinking smaller as the disused neural connections died off.

There was nothing Hermione could do about it.

â€œArthur,â€ Hermione knelt down beside him, â€œI have a Christmas present for you.â€

He looked up from his book expectantly. Every time their eyes met she felt a pang in her chest and an overwhelming desire to offer apologies he couldnâ€™t understand. Iâ€™m sorry. Iâ€™m sorry I canâ€™t get you out. Iâ€™m sorry I canâ€™t fix this.

â€œI wasnâ€™t going to buy presents for anyone this year, but I saw this in a shop, and I knew I had to get it for you.â€ Hermione reached into her pocket and pulled out the gift. â€œItâ€™s called a rubber duck. It will float on water. You can have it in your baths. Or put it in the sink.â€

Arthur snatched it from her hand and stood up suddenly. Hermione gripped her wand. Sheâ€™d been knocked across a room by him on several occasions when heâ€™d become overexcited or cross.

â€œBill! Bill, do this.â€ His voice was adult, but his words and the insistent tone were childlike. He waved the duck over his head. â€œIn the sink!â€

Bill donned the false expression of cheerfulness that he always wore around his father and leaned forward. â€œWhat have you got there?â€

Arthur carried it over and shoved the toy into Billâ€™s face until it nearly poked Bill in the eye. Hermione winced.

â€œA duck! In the sink.â€

â€œRight, should we see how it floats?â€ Bill stood up. Arthur turned on his heel and proceeded to bolt down a hallway toward the bathroom. â€œNo running, Arthur!â€

Hermione headed further into the house and found Fred and George outside in the gardens. George was attempting to do a handstand on his crutches. As Hermione opened the door, he lost his balance and fell face first into a snowdrift.

â€œGeorge!â€ Hermione went and pulled him out, brushing the snow off by smacking him. â€œIf youâ€™re going to do things like this, at least be sober.â€

â€œSorry, Mum.â€ George said jokingly as he let her pull him upright and fuss over him while Fred picked the crutches up.

Hermione rolled her eyes at him, and he kissed her full on the lips.

She stared at him astonished.

â€œHappy Christmas, Herms. A pretty girl deserves a Yuletide kiss. Fred promised his to Angelina, so I drew the short straw and had to kiss the woman who saved my life.â€ He placed a hand across his heart and smiled beautifically.

Hermione shook her head. â€œYouâ€™re awful. What if that had been my first kiss?â€

George donned an expression of elaborate despair. â€œIt wasnâ€™t? Been snogging other patients of yours before me?â€

Hermione felt the tips of her ears grow warm and looked away. â€œActually my first kiss was with Viktor.â€

â€œCrushed my heart, you have.â€ George stumbled back overdramatically with his crutches. â€œItâ€™s because Iâ€™m not surly enough, isnâ€™t it? Or maybe you only like Seekers.â€

Hermione shook her head and tried not to think about surliness or Seekers. â€œIâ€™m going back in. If you must risk your neck after all Iâ€™ve done healing you, at least do it when Iâ€™m not looking.â€

She went back inside and seated herself on the couch in the corner, watching the festivities with a sense of bewilderment.

Charlie was teasing Ginny and Harry, he tilted his head back and laughed. Hermione couldnâ€™t remember the last time sheâ€™d heard Charlie laugh. Or Ron or Harry.

They were all happy. Happier than she had seen them in years.

As Hermione observed it, a creeping sense of horror came over her.

The cheerfulness brimming inside the cottage was more than Yuletide merriment and alcohol. The house was bursting, nearly vibrating with a sense of hopefulness.

Hermione wouldnâ€™t have understood it if not for the conversation with Angelina.

It wasnâ€™t just the Resistance. The Order members also believed they were on the way to winning the war.

As Hermione sat in the corner absorbing it, she felt as though she were trapped inside a daydream charm while the world around her burned down.

The Order would never change tactics now; they would never agree to use the Dark Arts. She had done this.

If Draco ever turned on them, or achieved whatever atonement he was in pursuit of and ended his service, the Resistance would start to free fall, and there would be nothing to catch them.

And if the Order ever found out about Draco, in any contextâ€¦ it would likely break the entire organization. The trust in Kingsley and Moody would be shattered.

Hermione felt like she might be sick. She wanted to leave.

She sat in the corner like a statue.

Harry came and dropped down on the couch next to her. They watched the room. Ginny was with Arthur. Ron, Fred, and George appeared to be in the middle of a prank of some sort. Molly was bustling about, setting out food and Charlie was helping her.

â€œThisâ€”is everything I ever wanted,â€ Harry said after a minute. â€œThis is what keeps me going. Every day.â€

Hermione was silent.

â€œAre you thinking about your family?â€ Harry studied her carefully. Hermione gave a short nod. Harry wrapped an arm around her shoulder and pulled her close. â€œSomeday your parents will be here with us too.â€

Hermione watched Molly pause to press a kiss on Arthurâ€™s forehead and admire his duck.

â€œTheyâ€”they wonâ€™t; theyâ€™ll never come back from Australia,â€ she said quietly. Harry looked at her with confusion. Her eyes dropped down to her lap. â€œExtensive obliviation only has a certain window for reversal. Otherwise there is a high risk of acute brain damage. There was a long silence.

â€œYou never told me that.â€ Harryâ€™s voice was devastated.

â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€ Harry squeezed her hand. â€œIâ€™m so so sorry, Hermione.â€

â€œItâ€™s fine. Iâ€™ve come to terms with the fact that protecting people may mean losing them.â€

â€œWell, not me. Youâ€™ll always be my family.â€

Hermione couldnâ€™t quite manage a smile. The corners of her mouth curled faintly as Ron and Harryâ€™s heavy arms wrapped around her shoulders. There was a blinding flash.

â€œWhat did you do to it?â€ Hermione said, shaking her head in disbelief.

Harry glanced over at Hermione, and she noticed his expression shift slightly before he spoke. â€œWhen this is over, I hope things will go back to the way they were.â€

He stared at her, and his eyes were young and old at the same time. A lifetime of memories were evoked by those eyes. Hermioneâ€™s heart caught in her throat as she stared back at him.

She started to open her mouth to say she wished that too. Because she did. She would do anything to somehow emerge on the other side of the war and still have something left.

But before she could say it, Harry caught hold of her hand and gripped it. â€œYouâ€™re my family. And Iâ€™ll always be yours. I know weâ€™ve fought with each other a lot lately. Hermioneâ€™s eyes flooded with tears and her whole body shook.

â€œWe havenâ€™t won yet, Harry,â€ she finally said in a hoarse voice.

â€œI know. I know weâ€™ve still got long way to go, but I donâ€™t want to wait to say this.â€ Harry took a deep breath. â€œI havenâ€™t looked out for you, and Iâ€™m sorry for that. Her friend. Her best friend. Her very first friend. She would do anything for him. Anything to protect him.

Anything.

Even give him up.

You already made your choice. If you try to have this, youâ€™ll only hurt him more when he finds out what you did. Youâ€™ll only hurt yourself more if you let yourself believe itâ€™s real.

She swallowed and slowly pulled her hand away. It was like crashing in slow motion. Knowing and doing it anyway.

â€œI donâ€™t think I know how to be friends with you anymore, Harry.â€ Her voice was low and firm.

â€œIâ€™m a realist, Harry. I want this war to be done. I donâ€™t want the Order to think it won and then have everything start all over again in fourteen years, the way it did last time.â€ Her tone was hard. Tired.

She knew exactly where to cut.

â€œDo you have any idea what Dark Magic does to a person?â€ Harryâ€™s voice was furious.

â€œI donâ€™t. Because it will never be worth it,â€ Harry snapped. â€œWe wonâ€™t win that way. I canâ€™t fight that way. When I fight Iâ€™m thinking about all the people I love. â€œYouâ€™re accusing me of wanting easy choices?â€ Hermione was legitimately stunned.

â€œYou want to use the Dark Arts because theyâ€™d be more â€˜effectiveâ€™. Hermione didnâ€™t have to pretend to be enraged or bitter any longer. She scoffed in his face. â€œOf course I believe it. Think of Colin, Harry. He glared at Hermione and she could feel the waves of rage coming off him. It reminded her, in a horrible way, of Draco.

Hermione turned on her heel and walked out of Shell Cottage.

She walked through the garden and into the hills beyond. She kept walking. Her heart was beating so hard it hurt. The blood pounding in her ears was so loud she could barely hear the wind; though she felt the cold of it slicing against her cheeks.

Finally she stopped and looked around at the endless white surrounding her. It was a beautiful Christmas. Hermione couldnâ€™t remember the last time it had snowed on Christmas Day.

Her hands and feet were numb with cold. She wanted to stay there. Stay there and freeze. It couldnâ€™t possibly feel worse than she already felt.

She didnâ€™t want to think about how awful she currently felt. How much her head hurt. And her heart. It felt like a chasm in her chest. As though someone had sawn through her sternum and pried the bone apart with a retractor, the way the Muggles did for heart surgery. She was ripped open and it justâ€”hurt. If she looked down, there would be blood in the snow.

â€œHermione!â€ Ginnyâ€™s voice cut through the wind.

Hermione turned.

â€œHermioneâ€¦â€ Ginny waded through the snow toward her. â€œWhatâ€™s wrong? What are you doing?â€

Hermione stared dully at Ginny. â€œDoing?â€

â€œYou did that on purposeâ€”I could tellâ€”so Harry would be mad and let you leave. Why? He and Ron are all youâ€˜ve got. They might forget that half the time, but I know it. What are you doing? â€œIâ€”,â€ Hermioneâ€™s voice started and then failed for several seconds.

â€œI canâ€™t do this anymore, Ginny. I canâ€™t pretend things will be alright. Even if we won tomorrow morning, Iâ€™m not going to change my mind that we could have done better. Ginny stared at Hermione. Her lashes had ice crystals caught in them, glittering in the light. â€œYouâ€”you donâ€™t expect to be with us,â€ Ginny said slowly, her eyes were wide and sober. â€œAfter the war.â€

â€œI have given myself to this war, Ginny. When it's overâ€”there wonâ€™t be anything left of me.â€

â€œGinny, if I am offered another empty word of encouragement, I may snap.â€ Hermioneâ€™s voice was flat. She drew a sharp breath, then exhaled and watched the condensation vanish into the sky. â€œI canâ€™tâ€”I donâ€™t have the energy to pretend for all of you. Iâ€™m too tired.â€

Ginny opened her mouth to reply, but Hermione apparated away.

She felt frozen the next day as she worked. She didnâ€™t want to talk to anyone. She felt as though her heart had broken. She could occlude the mental aspects, but she hadnâ€™t realised just how much grief could physically hurt.

â€œGranger, Severus wants to see you tonight.â€

â€œTo discuss your progress.â€

â€œSeven.â€

â€œAlright, Iâ€™ll be there then.â€ She turned back to her cauldron. She didnâ€™t look back at Moody as he stood appraising her for several seconds before he turned to leave.

Flashback 22

December 2002

Â 

The house at Spinnerâ€™s End was crammed with bubbling potions.

Hermione turned around the room slowly and paused in surprise as she noticed a cauldron shimmering in the corner. She stepped over and watched the spiraling steam rising from the surface. She sniffed it surreptitiouslyâ€”spicy, earthy scent of oakmoss, smoky undertones of cedar and parchmentâ€”no. She sniffed again. Papyrus.

It felt like receiving a diagnosis sheâ€™d expected but still hoped to be wrong about. Her stomach dropped sharply. She stepped abruptly away and glanced at the other surrounding cauldrons. There was a aching sensation inside her chest that she tried to ignore.

â€œThis is quite a variety of love potions youâ€™re brewing,â€ she said, looking over to where Severus was stooped over a simmering cauldron.

â€œA new project for the Dark Lord. Heâ€™s suddenly developed an interest in trying to weaponise it,â€ Severus said, sneering down at the murky, lumescent liquid he was working over.

Hermione felt her blood run cold. â€œIs that a possibility?â€

Severus shrugged with a faint smile. â€œI am both skeptical and unmotivated, so most likely not. I believe it was more of a passing notion than anything he has a sincere interest in. Iâ€™m drawing up a comprehensive report to present in case he asks about it. And Iâ€™m doing it in my home rather than in the lab to ensure no one offers any groundbreaking ideas.â€

Hermione surveyed the room. There were ten varieties of love potion and a few aphrodisiacs she recognised, as well as an additional fifteen that appeared experimental.

â€œWhat would constitute as a weaponised love potion?â€

â€œSomething of exceptional power that doesnâ€™t require redosage. I believe he imagines himself using it for interrogations.â€

â€œThatâ€™sâ€”obscene,â€ Hermione finally said.

â€œIndeed. Fortunately, or perhaps unfortunately, he has other matters he regards as more urgent for Sussex to focus on.â€

Hermione stood, watching Severus crush ashwinder eggs for several minutes in silence.

â€œDraco says that Sussex is trying to develop a way to prevent further rescues.â€

There was a pause before Severus turned and looked at her thoughtfully.

â€œI didnâ€™t realise he was aware of that.â€

Hermione raised an eyebrow. â€œAn excellent spy. Isnâ€™t that what you said?â€

â€œSo it would seem,â€ Severus muttered, turning back to his mortar and pestle. â€œDo you know why heâ€™s spying yet?

Hermioneâ€™s eyes dropped to her shoes. â€œNo,â€ she admitted. â€œHe says things that seem true, but I canâ€™t make out the motive behind them.â€

There was a pause, filled with the hiss of simmering liquid and grinding stone.

â€œAre you aware heâ€™s climbing rank?â€ Severus said, turning to his cauldron and pouring the powdered ashwinder shells into the liquid in a gradual figure eight across the surface.

Hermione was quiet for several seconds. â€œI hadnâ€™t heard that.â€

â€œI mentioned it to Kingsley a few weeks ago. Climbing higher. Consolidating power. I donâ€™t pretend to know all you do together during your weeklyâ€”meetingsâ€¦ but I sometimes wonder if you even remember that when heâ€™s not with you, he spends his time killing people.â€

Hermioneâ€™s breath caught in her throat while Severus continued in an unsettlingly conversational tone. â€œIâ€™ve rarely seen anyone who used Dark Magic as unsparingly as he has recently. The Dark Lord is thrilled by the exceptional tool he has crafted for himself. Those who make the mistake of getting in Dracoâ€™s way have a habit of dying from suspiciously ingenious uses of â€˜Resistanceâ€™ spells. A few weeks ago, one of the marked Death Eaters, Gibbon, was found with his limbs flayed and dismembered. I helped analyse the corpse; there was an exceptional web of Dark Magic used to force Gibbon to stay alive for nearly a day before he finally died.â€

Hermione froze and shook her head sharply. â€œThatâ€™s notâ€”Draco wouldnâ€™tâ€”you said yourself heâ€™s not a sadist.â€

Severus looked over at her from the corner of his eye. â€œDid you think not being a sadist means heâ€™s never tortured anyone to death?â€ His expression was contemptuous. â€œIâ€™m sure you read his runes. What manner of things do you suppose he does ruthlessly and without fail?â€

Hermione stiffened until her body shook and her jaw twitched. â€œYou kill people too and Iâ€™ve never questioned your loyalty because of it, Severus.â€

He snorted faintly and his lips curled. â€œI have only one loyalty; to the purpose of the Order. The horrors I am obliged to commit, I commit out of necessity. Do you think I enjoy feeling my soul slowly tear itself apart and poison me? All while being derided and doubted by those who would never be willing to make a similar sacrifice?â€ He shook his head slightly. â€œHowever, that is irrelevant. Gibbon was not a necessity. He was not important. He was not powerful. There was nothing strategic or in the interests of the Order about killing him. Certainly not anything to necessitate dismembering him while keeping him alive in the process.â€

Hermione kept steadily shaking her head. â€œIt might have been someone else. You donâ€™t know it was Draco.â€

Severus froze and turned slowly to face Hermione. â€œIt was Draco. I know it was Draco. The reason I know it is because while dissecting the spellwork I came across the signature of an interesting enchantment. One that I personally invented. A containment enchantment I only ever taught one person. You. You were using it to treat his runes, werenâ€™t you?â€

The whole room wobbled in Hermioneâ€™s vision, and she caught the edge of the table to keep from falling.

Severus stared down at her, his expression menacing. â€œI have been a spy for almost as long as you have been alive, Miss Granger. Now stop defending him and listen.â€

Hermione stilled.

Severus pursed his lips as he studied her. â€œHe has gone rogue. If he ever was loyal, he certainly is not now. Whatever he is in the process of doing, it is not solely on behalf of the Order. He is one of the most powerful Generals in the army now. He reports only to the Dark Lord. He has his own web of informants throughout the army, and he has used that information to make the Order heavily reliant on him; likely to prevent us from ever betraying him.â€

Hermione felt as though she couldnâ€™t breathe. Her fingertips were tingling faintly. She gave a shaky nod.

â€œI believe I know why he killed Gibbon,â€ Severus added after a moment. â€œHe concealed it and made the process look like a torture, but once I noticed the enchantment, there were several clues that made what he had been attempting obvious. Draco is trying to find a means of removing his Dark Mark without dying from it.â€

â€œDying?â€

â€œIf the mark was possible flense or remove by chopping off the arm, Igor Karkaroff would be alive today. There were a few who tried to run or become turncoats during both wars and discovered to their detriment what happens. The mark is a connection between the Dark Lord and his servants; severing it results in a cursed wound. The person bleeds to death, unstoppably. There are no spells or potions to prevent it. Yet it seems Draco is determined to find a way, if he possibly can.â€

A horrifying detail struck Hermione. â€œHe was left handed. But now heâ€™s ambidextrous.â€

Severus quirked an eyebrow thoughtfully. â€œThat would be the logical thing to do, for a man intending to eventually cut off his own arm. Do you know how long heâ€™s been that way?â€

â€œAs long as Iâ€™ve been going to him. Iâ€™ve rarely seen him use his left hand.â€ There was a burning sensation in the pit of her stomach.

Severus looked pensive. â€œSo heâ€™s been planning this for years then.â€

Hermione was reeling; trying to reevaluate everything she thought she knew. Draco was playing a long game. She was merely a ripple in it, or a tool. She didnâ€™t even know.

Severus stared at her, his expression more tense than Hermione had ever seen. â€œHe would be quite deadly for everyone involved if the manacles of his servitude were ever removed.â€

Hermione nodded. Without the Dark Mark restricting Draco, it would no longer be necessary for him to appease the Order into maintaining his cover. If he was vying for power, getting his mark off was the next step.

Especially since Hermione had admitted that Harry didnâ€™t intend to kill Voldemort.

Severus gave a faint sigh and suddenly seemed old as he stared down at Hermione. â€œIâ€™ll admit, I expected the June attack to be the beginning of the end for him. With the punishment he submitted to, I assumed heâ€™d be on borrowed time.â€ He eyed her carefully. â€œThat it wasnâ€™t, I suppose, must be attributed to your exceptional care.â€

There was a pause. For a moment it felt as though the world had frozen around her, then it shattered.

â€œYou knew heâ€™d take the fall for the attack in June,â€ Hermione said slowly, staring at Severus wide-eyed. â€œYou, Kingsley and Moody. Thatâ€™s why you were willing to make the attack so elaborate and use so much intelligence. You werenâ€™t concerned about exposing him. You expected heâ€™d be killed for it.â€

Severus said nothing.

â€œWhyâ€”why didnâ€™t you tell me?â€ she finally said. Her voice shook faintly with rage.

â€œWe didnâ€™t think you needed to know.â€ Severus shrugged. Â Hermione felt so enraged she thought she might incinerate the room around her. â€œWe expected you to realise it eventually. â€œYou expected Iâ€™d fail. That heâ€™d be too far gone by the time I got there.â€

Severus pulled a jar of fairy wings from a shelf. Hermione couldnâ€™t breathe. Every sound seemed suddenly a hundred times louder. The bubbling of the potions. Her own quiet, horrified gasps. She could hear her rising heart rate.

â€œYou can imagine our surprise to find that he is instead even more dangerous than before. Our spy of dubious loyalty. So tell me, what did you do to Draco Malfoy?â€

Hermione pressed her lips together for several seconds.

â€œIs that why Moody sent me? So you could ask me that?â€ she finally asked.

Severus said nothing.

Hermione looked away and twitched at the hem of her sleeve. â€œYou helped poison him, right down into his soul. Runic magic is corrupting, always; it doesnâ€™t wear off. If Iâ€™d gotten there soonerâ€”if youâ€™d mentioned what had happenedâ€”I might have been able to treat him less drastically. But by the time I found out, I didnâ€™t have those options. â€œAnd what, precisely, is it that you did?â€

Hermione swallowed hard. â€œI saved his soul.â€

â€œWhat. Did. You. Do?â€ Severus said slowly.

Hermione was quiet and then she reached up and fidgeted with the empty chain around her neck.

â€œWhenâ€”when I was studying in Egyptâ€”before I leftâ€”the hospital head gave me a Heart of Isis. He thought I might need it for Harry.â€

There was a deafening silence as Severus froze mid-motion over his cauldron.

â€œYou didnâ€™t,â€ he said, his voice nearly vibrating with disbelief. â€œDo you know the value? If youâ€™d sold it, you could have fed the Resistance for a decade. The closest thing to a Philosopherâ€™s Stone and you used it on Draco Malfoy?â€

Hermione didnâ€™t blink. â€œI made a calculated decision. I couldnâ€™t have put it on the black market. Can you imagine if Tom got his hands on one? Severusâ€™ rage felt nearly explosive. His sallow features paled further and his eyes were glittering. â€œHe played you for a fool, and more deftly than I would have thought possible. â€œDo you think heâ€™ll inform you before he does? He is deadly. He is not loyal to anyone, and you have empowered him to become a Dark wizard capable of reducing the Dark Lord into obscurity.â€

â€œThere is more to him,â€ Hermione said, jutting her chin up as she met Severusâ€™s eyes. â€œItâ€™s not as though he knew I had it when he asked for me. Or planned his punishment. You should have seen him, Severus; he knew he was going to die from them. He was resigned to it.â€

â€œAre you sure? It never occurred to you that he may have been manipulating you this entire time? After all, what exactly is he getting from having you? You arenâ€™t sleeping with him. Heâ€™s teaching you to duel; he taught you occlumency. What benefit are you providing him?â€

â€œYou have run out of time,â€ Severus said, his expression dismissive. â€œYou have until the end of next month to demonstrate you have some kind of control over him. If you canâ€™t, you will turn over the most incriminating memories you have of him to Kingsley.â€

Hermione stared at Severus, stunned.

â€œYou canâ€™t expose him.â€ Her voice was shaking. â€œWe need him. The Resistance thinks weâ€™re winning and itâ€™s because of him. Harry thinks weâ€™re winning. If we lose the intelligence, the Order wonâ€™t be able to recover.â€

â€œYou canâ€™tâ€”do that to him.â€

â€œWhy? Because heâ€™s yourâ€”? What would you even say you are to him?â€

Hermione swallowed bitterly and refused to answer the question. â€œHe will be tortured to death in the most horrific way possible, and you know that. The curse division victims would be lucky compared to what will be done to Draco. Youâ€”canâ€™tâ€”â€

Severus turned and stared coldly down at her. â€œAre you refusing orders, Miss Granger? Choosing Draco Malfoy over Mr Potter and the Order?â€

Hermione froze and it seemed like time stopped as she struggled to breathe. She was collapsing inward. There was nothing left inside her.

â€œNo.â€ Her voice was defeated. â€œNo. I am loyal to the Order.â€

Severus turned away. â€œIf he hadnâ€™t been so overconfident, he could have protected himself with a Vow from you. Ego always is a Dark Wizardâ€™s downfall.â€ He sneered faintly as he stirred the potion.

â€œ Go ahead. Youâ€™re already more than capable of getting me killed any time you happen to feel like it.â€

â€œYouâ€™re wrong. It wasnâ€™t some ego-based oversight. Heâ€™s known. Heâ€™s known this whole time that my memories could get him killed. Hermione snarled. â€œIt is not! Moody said I should do whatever I could to heal Draco. I followed my orders and healed him.â€ She drew a sharp breath. â€œDraco wants me to stay alive. Severus was unmoved. â€œYouâ€™ve been given time. You have until the end of next month.â€

Hermione felt as though she were dying. Her lungs were shriveling, atrophying inside of her. â€œYouâ€™re putting his death on my shoulders, Severus.â€

â€œYou made this bed for yourself. I did everything I could to give you an exit six months ago,â€ Severus said, looking away from her.

Hermione gave a ragged gasp.
