Hermione balled her hands into fists and glared at Severus. â€œIf you think that counts as consolation, you donâ€™t know me very well.â€ Her voice was shaking.

Severus gave no response.

A sob rose in her throat, choking her as she tried to force it down. She drew a rasping breath and turned to flee from Spinnerâ€™s End.

As soon as she got past Severusâ€™ wards, she apparated.

She reappeared in Whitecroft. She always ended up there. She stood at the road and looked wistfully down the lane toward the shack that slowly bled into view.

She went and stared at the door. It was Thursday. There was no reason for her to be there on a Thursday. It would be suspicious and illogical. Draco would probably be enraged if she activated his wards on a Thursday for no reason.

She pushed the door open.

Draco appeared before she had stepped into the room.

He looked her up and down carefully, and she stared at him. She had felt as though sheâ€™d been starving until she saw him.

â€œWhat are you doing here?â€ he finally asked.

She blinked.

â€œIâ€”,â€œ she flailed for an excuse. â€œThe skirmish on Christmas Eve. Iâ€”was worried.â€

He raised an eyebrow. â€œThat was two days ago, Granger.â€

â€œI couldnâ€™t get away. We lost a lot of fighters,â€ she said. â€œI had to stay in the hospital wing.â€

â€œSo you came at the first opportunity.â€ He was eyeing her with a dubious expression.

Hermione gave a small nod and walked toward him. She stared up at him, studying him, trying to find a sign of something in him. Anything. She just wanted to know what he was. â€œAre you alright, Draco?â€

â€œGrangerâ€¦â€ His tone was a warning. â€œWhat is wrong?â€

â€œNothingâ€¦â€ Her eyes dropped down to his hands. Heâ€™d touched her with those hands. Heâ€™d run his fingers through her hair and over her skin. Heâ€™d wrapped his hand around her throat, and it had aroused her.

Heâ€™d dismembered a Death Eater with those hands, killed dozens and dozensâ€”possibly hundredsâ€”of people she knew, assassinated Dumbledoreâ€¦

He was ambidextrous, because heâ€™d been intending for years to cut off his own arm in order to become a free agent. Someone who wouldnâ€™t need the Order to fight Voldemort for him.

She tore her eyes away from his hands.

â€œI justâ€¦ I wanted to know that you were alright,â€ she said, staring down at her shoes.

He stepped closer, and she looked sharply up at him. His eyes were cold. She started to back away, but he caught hold of her wrist with his left hand and jerked her firmly toward him and then crowded her into the wall until she was trapped against him.

â€œSince when have you worried about me?â€ he said with a sneer. His eyes were hard and glinting like quicksilver.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Hermione felt tempted to cry at the admission. He scoffed.

â€œAnd nowâ€”? You suddenly canâ€™t help yourself?â€

â€œI just wanted to see you.â€

His mouth twitched. â€œWhy?â€

â€œBecause Iâ€™m afraid that someday Iâ€™ll come and you wonâ€™tâ€”,â€ her voice cracked faintly, and she twisted her captured wrist enough to wrap her fingers around his wrist.

His eyes flickered. His hand remained wrapped around her wrist, and his face was inches from hers.

He studied her for a moment, and his expression wavered; something indecipherable in it as she stared up at him.

He drew in a short breath and gave a low laugh. â€œIs this goodbye then, Granger?â€

Her hold tightened. â€œNo!â€

Her breath caught. She stared at him and caught his robes in her other hand as she tried to breathe. She dropped her head and rested it against his chest. He smelled like oakmoss and cedar.

She shook. â€œI justâ€”wanted to see you.â€

She felt his right hand come up to rest on her shoulder, and the heat of it slowly sank into her bones as his thumb lightly ran along her collarbone. She kept gripping his other wrist.

â€œDonâ€™tâ€”die, Draco.â€

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong, Granger?â€

â€œNothing. I justâ€”spent a lot of time making your healing kit. It would be really ungrateful of you to die now. Soâ€”donâ€™t.â€

He gave a hollow laugh, and his hold on her shoulder tightened. Then she felt his forehead drop against the top of her head for a split second before drawing away.

â€œOnly because you asked,â€ he said. The sharp edge of sarcasm seemed faint. He sounded almost bitter.

She held his wrist tighter. She wantedâ€”

She wantedâ€”

It didnâ€™t matter. It didnâ€™t matter what she wanted. It never mattered.

For Harry. For Ron. It will be worth it.

She had promised those words to herself a thousand times, but they suddenly sounded hollow.

Draco wasnâ€™t innocent, but he didnâ€™t deserve the penalty Voldemort would inflict for his betrayal. Easing her conscience and euthanising him would be a paltry form of reparation.

Sheâ€™d be a hero then, she realised bitterly. Sheâ€™d exonerate herself to the world and damn herself privately. She would never forgive herself. It would be unforgivable. The guilt would eat her alive.

She hissed through her teeth as she tried to think.

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong, Granger?â€ Draco asked again when she had been quiet for a minute.

â€œNothing. It was just an unexpectedly bad Christmas,â€ she said in a tight voice.

He snorted and twisted his hand free. Stepping away, he studied her. He gave a deep sigh.

â€œActivating the wards is for emergencies,â€ he said. â€œNot because youâ€™re worried or having a bad day. Youâ€™ll risk my cover, and Iâ€™ll be forced to try to guess whether itâ€™s worth the risk of responding immediately.â€

Hermione felt herself pale. If and when Kingsley and Moody decide to expose Draco, weâ€™ll give you an hour to warn him.

â€œIâ€™m sorry. I wonâ€™t call you again unless itâ€™s urgent,â€ Hermione said. He looked skeptical. â€œI swear it,â€ she said forcefully, â€œIf I ever activate them again, it will be legitimate.â€

He gave a sharp nod. â€œYouâ€™ve given your word, Iâ€™ll trust you to keep it.â€

She gave a small nod back, and he vanished without a sound.

Hermione stayed in the shack; staring at the spot heâ€™d disappeared from. Wondering what to do.


Flashback 23

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

December 2002

The next time Hermione arrived at the shack, Draco appeared wearing only trousers and a shirt. She stopped and stared in surprise.

He quirked an eyebrow and looked down at himself. â€œI didnâ€™t fancy getting you tangled in my robes,â€ he said with a suggestive drawl.

He stared at her for a moment with narrowed eyes before gesturing her forward.

â€œGiven that you arenâ€™t necessarily training for skirmishes, we need to expand your combat abilities,â€ he began in a clipped voice. â€œVampires, hags, or harpies wonâ€™t have wands, but theyâ€™re experienced when it comes to attacking Wizarding folk. They go for close attacks that are difficult to fight off. Most wizards study defense against them assuming distance, but a smart hag will get you within armâ€™s reach as quickly as possible. They know combat spells are difficult to perform close range. Werewolves may have wands, but most that run in packs prefer physical combat. Youâ€™reâ€”small.â€ Hermione snorted, and Draco glared at her mildly. â€œYouâ€™re going to be at a disadvantage in any fight. You need to defend yourself creatively.â€

â€œAlright.â€ Hermione gave a sharp nod.

Dracoâ€™s eyes glittered, and he loomed over her. â€œNow, suppose Iâ€™m a vampire. Iâ€™d be targeting the side of your neck. You donâ€™t have a dueling partner to cover for you. While youâ€™re fighting off a gytrash, Iâ€™ve closed in.â€ He stepped closer until their bodies were touching. â€œWhat would you do now?â€

Hermione whipped her wand upward, but Draco was too close for her to perform the wand motion for most defensive spells. Before she could back away and cast, his hand shot out and struck her wrist sharply. Her wand flew from her fingers and slid across the floor. She turned to dive after it, but Dracoâ€™s hand closed around her wrist, and he jerked her back.

â€œWandless too. Your move, Granger.â€ He started leaning down toward her throat as though he intended to bite it.

Her left hand shot up to shove him away, but his other hand closed around her left wrist. She tried to wrench her arms free, but his grip was relentless.

â€œA word of advice,â€ Draco said conversationally as she continued to try to tear herself free. â€œDonâ€™t leave your wrists open. Once I have you by the wrist, I have a considerable advantage; this a much easier hold for me to maintain than for you to escape from. The same goes for your feet. Be careful kicking above the knee. If you get grabbed by your ankle, youâ€™ll be on the ground in seconds. Stomping or kneeing is much better than kicking. Stomping utilises your weight. Stomp hard and go for the feet, ankles, or the side of the knees. Disabling your opponent is the key. A knee to the groin works on everything: wizards, vampires, werewolvesâ€”even hags hate it.â€

Hermione tried to knee Draco, but he used his hold on her wrists to twist her away and easily sidestepped her leg.

â€œSee, once your arms are trapped, your options are limited, and mine are nearly endless depending on what I want to do to you next.â€

His lecturing was getting annoying. Hermione stomped on his foot and kicked him in the shins. He hissed faintly.

â€œBetter. But if I were a vampire, youâ€™d be drained by now. You clearly lack aptitude for fighting dirty.â€

He released her abruptly, and Hermione tore herself away and faced him. He stared at her seriously. Â 

â€œGranger, if you are attacked, you will be outnumbered. Even if you arenâ€™t outnumbered, physically speaking, you will never be as strong as most Dark creatures naturally are. They will do whatever it takes to kill you. The fight will be stacked against you in every possible regard. Do anything you can to get away.â€

Hermione gave a short nod.

â€œFight smart,â€ he said coldly. â€œBe devious. When your opponent is stronger than you, it is crucial to use it against them. You will never be stronger than a werewolf, but they get lost in bloodlust and attack predictably. If you utilise that knowledge, you may be able to survive it. Also,â€ he shot her a look, â€œpull your punches; this is a practice fight.â€

He returned her wand to her and attacked her again. And again, and again. He was relentless, and annoyingly conversational. Heâ€™d disarm her without even using a spell, and then proceed to trip her, or twist an arm behind her back and force her into a helpless position, while relentlessly drawling what she could have done better.

Hermione grew progressively more and more irritated with him, which he noticed and seemed amused by.

â€œIâ€™m a hag,â€ he announced with a smirk before attacking her for the twentieth time. Hermione shot off a series of stunners as she tried to stay out of his reach, but he rapidly dodged them and closed in. She tried to dive to escape him, but he caught her by the ankle. She whirled and tried to hex him, but he snatched her wand out of her hand and tossed it into a corner, and then proceeded to sit on her hips. â€œI would probably slit you open and start eating your organs at this point,â€ he noted casually, sliding a hand over her stomach. â€œYouâ€™re worse at this than you were at dancing, and you were an abysmal dancer.â€

â€œIâ€™ve never done this kind of fighting before,â€ Hermione said mutinously as she tried to wriggle free. â€œDo you have any idea how many kinds of hand-to-hand combat there are? I browsed through dozens of books, but I had no idea what type of fighting I was expected to learn.â€ She glared and added, â€œI could stab you with one of my knives now.â€

He stared at her thoughtfully and then nodded. â€œWe should use practice knives. Iâ€™ll bring a set.â€

Hermione studied him in bewilderment. â€œWhy are you in such a good mood today?â€

Months of enduring his cold rage, and suddenly he was cheerful and conversational for no apparent reason.

He looked at her for a moment and then smirked. â€œJoie de vivre, I suppose. Or maybe Iâ€™m just unexpectedly fond of sitting on you.â€

Hermione eyed him dubiously and wondered if he was high on something.

He stood up and offered her a hand. She blinked in surprise and accepted it. Then she studied him.

He was strangely happyâ€”borderline affectionate-seeming. Hermione was not. She felt on the verge of a breakdown just looking at him.

A month. She had a month. A month to find a way to control him.

Control him. Even if she could, she had no idea how she was possibly going to demonstrate it.

â€œAfter all, what exactly is he getting from having you? You arenâ€™t sleeping with him. Heâ€™s teaching you to duel, he taught you occlumency. What benefit are you providing him?â€

â€œWhat would you even say you are to him?â€

Hermione felt as though she were going to have a panic attack. She stared at Draco in despair.

â€œDonâ€™t be afraid to use your elbows,â€ he said. â€œWhen youâ€™re fending off close range attacks, punching wonâ€™t have much force. Elbows are hard and ideal for close attacks. Better than something as ineffective as slapping.â€

â€œSlapping worked rather well on you,â€ Hermione retorted.

Draco snorted faintly. â€œIf youâ€™re attacking a thirteen year old, by all means, slap him.â€

Hermione scowled.

â€œAgain,â€ he said, after she had caught her breath.

He lunged toward her. Rather than try to bolt, she moved toward him and then side-stepped at the last minute. He pivoted and turned back, but sheâ€™d already hit him with a stinging hex and caught his ankle with a leg locker. He was too close for more spellwork. She tried to leap away but he grabbed her by the arm, knocked her wand away and dragged her to the ground with him.

Hermione kicked, scratched, and snarled as she tried to fight free, but he weighed at least fifty pounds more than her. She tried to wrench herself away, but in a minute she was entirely pinned beneath him.

â€œIf I were a werewolf, Iâ€™d already have ripped your throat out,â€ he said in a low voice. His mouth was near the base of her neck, and Hermione became abruptly aware that the length of his body was pressed against hers. His breath was brushing against the sensitive skin at the juncture of her neck and shoulder. His legs were between hers, and as she kept trying to get free, she kept bucking her hips against his.

He abruptly tore himself away from her and stood up glaring. His jaw rolled slightly, and his eyes were black.

â€œIf youâ€™re ever fighting off a werewolf, I would not recommend doing it that way,â€ he said in a tight voice as he pulled out his wand and removed the leg locker jinx on his ankle.

â€œHow should I do it?â€

â€œUse your head to break his nose, and when he lets go of your wrists, tear his eyes out,â€ he said stiffly. â€œGo for knees, groin, eyes, ankles. As previously mentioned, youâ€™re trying to disable your assailant.â€

â€œRight.â€ She picked herself up of the floor and stared wistfully at him.

â€œAgain,â€ he said. He attacked her again.

By the time Hermione apparated away, she was covered in bruises. Draco had knocked her down again and again as heâ€™d lectured her on hagsâ€™, vampiresâ€™, and werewolvesâ€™ preferred methods for attack.

She hid in the bathroom when she got back to Grimmauld Place and rubbed Murtlap Essence all over her body. She studied self-defense. She reviewed all her notes on Draco.

She didnâ€™t know what to do. She didnâ€™t know how to control him. She didnâ€™t know how to prove that she could.

She didnâ€™t know what he wanted. Her. In some wayâ€”for some reasonâ€”he wanted her. But she interfered with whatever else it was that he wanted.

She sorted through her memories exhaustively: turning them over, organising them, trying to find something to unravel.

She lay in bed at night and wondered if she were risking the war effort. Maybe she was compromised. Unreliable. Maybe Severus was right, and Draco was better off dead. Maybe if he was such a centralised figure in Voldemortâ€™s army, getting him killed and leaving a power vacuum would be the most effective use for him.

But she couldnâ€™t reconcile it. She refused to believe it.

She curled into a tight ball and felt as though she might die from the sense of despair she felt.

Each successive week when Draco trained her, she was distracted. She went through the motions, but she was uncommitted, and Draco noticed.

â€œIs there any point in my training you if you arenâ€™t even paying attention?â€ he asked, his expression irritated.

Hermioneâ€™s mouth twisted, and the corners of her eyes ached. She looked away from him. â€œI just donâ€™t really see the point anymore.â€

He stared at her for several seconds, looking faintly aghast. â€œI thought you didnâ€™t want to die,â€ he finally said.

â€œIf Iâ€™m ambushed by a pack of werewolves, I doubt Iâ€™ll survive it. If I do, Iâ€™ll be in so many pieces I doubt it would even matter,â€ she said quietly.

He shifted back and stared at her as though he were reevaluating something. â€œWhatâ€™s wrong?â€

â€œIâ€™m tired,â€ she said, staring at the floor. â€œI am tired of this war. Iâ€™m tired of trying to save people and watching them die anyway, or saving them and then watching them die later. I feel like Sisyphus, trapped in a cycle for eternity. I donâ€™t know how to get out, and I donâ€™t know how to keep going anymore either.â€

Draco was quiet for a moment. â€œWhat happened to doing everything for Potter and Weasley?â€ His tone was tinged with disdain.

â€œThe price keeps getting steeper. I donâ€™t know if I can keep paying it.â€

His expression tightened. â€œI suppose even martyrs have limits.â€

Hermione gave a listless smile. â€œOr bad days, at least.â€

She looked up at Draco, studying his reserved, mask-like expression and the intent way he watched her.

Give in. Give in. She urged him. She could see it in his eyes, he was so close.

But he refused to cross the line. To concede it. Whenever she tried to beckon him across it, his malice surfaced.

He was cruelest when he was vulnerable.

Perhaps if Hermione were more dogged, she could find a way to push through the pain, but he seemed to always know where to cut to hurt her most.

Whatever was holding him backâ€”she didnâ€™t know how to sever it.

Her fingers curled, and she almost reached for him before pulling back. She drew a deep breath and forced herself to squash her despair and focus on the situation at hand.

â€œRight. Iâ€™m done moping,â€ she said, straightening.

She grabbed her wand up off the floor and got into position. He stared at her thoughtfully for a moment before suddenly lunging toward her.

She sidestepped and shoved him past her, but he caught himself and spun back. His hand caught her wrist and forced her to drop her wand. She shoved her elbow into his ribs, wrenched herself free, and dove for her wand.

She snatched her wand up as she jumped back to her feet and managed to hit him several times before he closed in again. He grabbed her by the arm and tore her wand out of her hand again. She attempted to hook her foot behind his ankle, but he swept back and dodged it as he twisted her arm behind her. She jerked it loose with a quick lunge, and felt a flash of triumph before realising heâ€™d let her go. Using the force from her escape, Â he spun her, caught her ankle with his own foot, and slammed her to the ground.

Hermione twisted, trying to wriggle free, but he had her wrists locked in his hands.

Hissing slightly with frustration, she stilled while he knelt over her.

â€œYouâ€™re still trying to win by being quick rather than by being clever,â€ he scolded.


He released her wrists and stood.

â€œAgain.â€

Hermione was getting tired, but she still managed to last longer. She knocked him down twice, but she couldnâ€™t outlast him. As he tried to pin her down, she spun to the side using his momentum, and they rolled across the floor.

He still ended up on top of her in the end.

She nearly cursed with frustration.

â€œBetter,â€ he said, panting.

His face was less than an inch from hers, and he was staring down at her. His hands were wrapped around her wrists over her head.

She could feel his heartbeat.

It was January 21st. Next week would be the last time, and she was due to hand her memories over to Kingsley.

Flashback 24

â€œOh,â€ Hermione said.

The Malfoys are closer to being dragons than they are wizards. They do not share. They are obsessive about what they regard to be theirs.

She felt tempted to laugh. She swallowed hard.

â€œAlright then.â€ There was something else she should say. â€œIâ€™llâ€”Iâ€™ll let Moody know.â€

He gave a short nod of acknowledgement.

He didnâ€™t say a word as she stood up and gathered her satchel. His hand twitched forward as she turned to walk away. He didnâ€™t look at her as she stepped through the doorway. When she pulled the door closed, he was still leaning against the wall, staring blankly at the floor, so pale he could have been a ghost.

Hermione stood outside in the rain for several minutes trying to regain her bearings. She drew a ragged breath.

She felt as though she were on the edge of a precipice, and she still wasnâ€™t sure if she was going to fall from it.

She took another deep breath and apparated to Spinnerâ€™s End. The windows of the house were dark. She sat on the step in front of the door.

She was soaked to the bone when the door behind her abruptly opened.

Severus stared down at her with a cold expression. She huddled away.

â€œIs there a reason youâ€™re endeavoring to contract pneumonia on my doorstep?â€

Hermione stood up and looked at him. There was rainwater streaming down her face. â€œWizarding folk are immune to pneumonia.â€

He rolled his eyes and opened the door wider. â€œIâ€™ll assume this is urgent. Given your lack of invitation.â€

Hermione cast a drying charm on herself as she stepped through the door and followed Severus into his sitting room.

He flicked his wand carelessly and started a roaring fire in the hearth without glancing at her. Then he began gathering up strewn books; there were piles on the sofa and armchairs. He started returning them to the crammed shelves where they belonged.

Hermioneâ€™s hands were aching with cold, and she held them out toward the flames for several moments before she spoke.

â€œIt was Narcissa,â€ she finally said. â€œShe was the reason.â€

â€œReally?â€ Severusâ€™ skeptical voice came from somewhere behind her.

â€œTom had her in a cage when Draco returned from school after fifth year. She wasnâ€™t let out until Draco killed Dumbledore. Is it true that she nearly died when she was pregnant?â€

There was a pause. Hermione listened to the sliding sounds of book covers shifting against each other and the faint thump as the books bumped the back of the shelves.

â€œIt is,â€ Severus said after a moment. â€œIt happened near the height of war. Lucius believed he was going to lose her. Even after Draco was born, there was a period when he wasnâ€™t sure sheâ€™d survive.â€

Hermione nodded. â€œDraco said Lucius made him swear heâ€™d always take care of her. He said he tried to send her somewhere safe, but she wouldnâ€™t leave without him. Did any marked Death Eaters die suspiciously, the way Gibbon did, back before Lestrange Manor burned down?â€

The sound of reshelving stopped.

â€œNow that you mention it, there were several who disappeared. Travers, Pettigrew, and Jugson most notably.â€ Severusâ€™ voice was on the other side of the sitting room.

Hermione stared into the fire. â€œHe was trying to find a way to get the mark off so he could run with her. Spying was always just revenge.â€

Severus said nothing and continued reshelving. Hermione wondered if he believed her.

Compromised. Unreliable. He probably thought she was just there to beg. Â 

â€œHe said heâ€™ll make an Unbreakable Vow; whatever Moody wants.â€

There was silence. Then a hand wrapped around her shoulder, and Severus turned her suddenly to face him. His onyx eyes glittered in the firelight. He appeared to be taking in her appearance for the first time. His expression was aghast.

â€œWhat did you do?â€

Hermione looked up at him, her gaze steady. â€œI accomplished my mission: I made him loyal.â€

Severus touched the side of her head. Her braids had been pulled apart and the sections hung haphazardly. She flushed and jerked her head away from his hand. His hold on her shoulder tightened, and he herded her further into the light, tilted her head back and stared at her, his nostrils flaring.

Hermione didnâ€™t want to be looked at. She tried to twist away. â€œCan I use your bathroom? I couldnâ€™t go back to Grimmauld Place like this, and I didnâ€™tâ€”I didnâ€™t have anywhere else to go.â€

Severusâ€™ hand on her shoulder tightened for a moment, as though he were hesitating. His mouth was pressed into a hard line, then he started to speak as his eyes darted down over her again.

Hermione turned her head away to avoid watching his face, hunching her shoulders and curling defensively inward. His hand on her shoulder released, and he slowly stepped back, gesturing down the hallway.

Hermione turned without a word, and walked out of the sitting room into the small bathroom near the kitchen. As she locked the door, she stared in the mirror; she looked so pale she was nearly grey, but her lips were reddened and bruised. Her braids looked like a birdâ€™s nest. Her shirt was torn; she hadnâ€™t noticed it when she had been redressing.

She shoved her trousers and knickers down and banished the mixture of blood and semen collected there. It had grown cold against her skin, and she hadnâ€™t been able to ignore it. Not in the shack. Not in rain waiting for Severus. It was just there, as a cold reminder against her flesh.

Her hands were shaking almost violently as she jerked her trousers back up. She repaired the tear in her shirt and then reached up to remove the hairpins still holding up her hair.

Her lips were trembling, and the corners of her eyes pricked as she rapidly unbraided her hair and then carefully braided each side. She was not going to cry. She was not. She kept repeating the resolution. She tried to occlude everything she didnâ€™t want to think about, but the walls wouldnâ€™t stay. She bit her lip as she coiled the long braids carefully at the base of her neck and repinned them.

She stared at her reflection again. She was thinner than sheâ€™d been when sheâ€™d first seen Draco in March. Her cheeks were hollowed, and her collarbones stuck out starkly. She bruised easily.

Stress had carved her away, bit by bit.

She reached into her satchel and pulled out a small jar of Murtlap essence, spreading it across her lips she watched the colour slowly fade away. Then she dabbed at a few spots along her neck.

She walked back out of the bathroom. Severus was in the kitchen; there were several small cauldrons bubbling. When he turned and saw her, he immediately snatched up a several vials and came toward her.

â€œTake these,â€ he ordered.

Hermione looked at the vials placed in her hands. Draught of Peace to make her hands stop shaking, a contraceptive potion, and a pain relief potion.

â€œI donâ€™t need this one,â€ she said, handing the contraceptive back. â€œIâ€™ve already been taking it.â€

Severusâ€™ expression barely rippled as he took it back and slipped it into a pocket.

â€œWhat happened?â€ Severus asked after she downed the Draught of Peace. His tone was softly murderous.

Hermione avoided his piercing gaze and unstoppered the pain relief potion. â€œI donâ€™t know why youâ€™re upset. Didnâ€™t you expect this to eventually happen from the very beginning?â€

Severus was silent for several moments. â€œIâ€™ve been on call, the evening you first went, and every Tuesday morning until my shift in the labs.â€

â€œOh. I didnâ€™t know that.â€ She glanced around the room, wondering why no one had told her. Then again, apparently they didnâ€™t tell her anything. A useful tool.

She had thought Severus at least had regarded her as more than that. She pressed her lips together.

There was small barrel of Dragon Claw Ooze on the worktop; she stepped over and looked at it. It was Peruvian Vipertooth: expensive, good for restorative potions, strengtheners, and gave an additional kick to pepper-up when dealing with Black Cat Flu.

She removed the cork and sniffed it.

â€œHermione, what happened?â€

She stilled and replaced the cork. Severus almost never called her by her first name.

She looked over at him coolly, but her jaw trembled uncontrollably. Â â€œI told you he wanted me. Today he gave in.â€Her eyes dropped away. â€œIt was justâ€”abrupt. He didnâ€™t know that Iâ€”hadnâ€™tâ€”before. I was afraid if he knew, heâ€™d stop. Last timeâ€”when he kissed me and Iâ€”hesitatedâ€”heâ€”he didnâ€™t come back for over a month. So I couldnâ€™t let on. I was afraid heâ€™d never come back if I did.â€

Severus said nothing.

Hermione pressed her hand against her collarbones. â€œHe was so upset afterward, I thought he might actually faint. Then everything just poured out of him. I donâ€™t think heâ€˜s ever told anyone before. He started crying when he told me about Narcissa. Heâ€™s been waiting for us to sell him out. Thatâ€™s why he kept climbing; he figured the more important he was, the greater the blow for Tom when he died.â€

There was a silence punctuated only by the faint bubbling of the cauldrons.

Hermione didnâ€™t know where to look. She didnâ€™t know what to do. She could feel Severus staring at her, his eyes skeptical.

Compromised. Unreliable. She bit her lip and turned away.

After a minute Severus gave a low sigh. Hermione looked back at him, her heart rate shooting upward.

â€œIf heâ€™s suicidal, why is he offering to make an Unbreakable Vow?â€ Severusâ€™ expression was unreadable.

Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched, and she twisted the edge of her shirt in her hands. â€œWell, now that he canâ€™t deny the obsession to himself, I donâ€™t think he knows how to let go of it. Now that heâ€™s given in. I donâ€™t think he has any kind of moderation in how possessive he is, even before he got the runes. I may not have made an Unbreakable Vow, but I swore myself to him. He regards me as his. I thinkâ€”I think thatâ€™s what changed things.â€ Hermione looked away, twisting her fingers in her hands. â€œWill youâ€”will you tell Moody? I donâ€™t think he believes anything I say now. Butâ€”I did what I was told to. So, you shouldnâ€™tâ€”you canâ€™tâ€”donâ€™t make meâ€”â€

Her hands started shaking again.

â€œIâ€™ll speak to Moody,â€ Severus said. â€œYou did enough. I didnâ€™t expect that you wouldâ€”â€ his voice faded for a moment. â€œIf he agreed to make the Unbreakable Vow, that is more than enough.â€

Hermione nodded repeatedly, glancing blindly around the room. â€œAlright. Alright. Iâ€™ll go then.â€

â€œYou will wait,â€ Severus said firmly.

Hermione stood, feeling awkward and out of place, and he stared at her and seemed on the verge of saying something. He reached towards her but stopped when he got within an inch of her shoulder. He curled his hand into a fist and withdrew it, still peering down at her.

â€œAreâ€”â€ he blinked and started again, â€œWouldâ€”â€

Severus appeared to be at a loss for words for the first time in his life. His mouth twitched repeatedly.

â€œDo youâ€”wish toâ€¦â€ he trailed off for a moment. â€œDo you want to talk aboutâ€”it?â€

Hermione stared at him, horrified. â€œNo.â€

He looked visibly relieved, gave a short nod and glanced around the kitchen. â€œYouâ€™re not injuredâ€”are you? Do you need me toâ€”â€

â€œHe wasnâ€™t violent,â€ she said sharply, cutting off Severusâ€™ question. She folded her arms around herself and jerked her head. Her voice was very tight, as though her throat couldnâ€™t relax. â€œIt was justâ€”abrupt.â€

Severus looked down and straightened the cuffs of his robes for several seconds. Then he turned sharply and swept over to the cauldrons, flicking his wand over several and then swirling their contents with the stirring rods. He peered down at them.

He waved his wand, summoned a set of vials from a cabinet and ladled the potions into the vials, stoppering them all with practiced ease. Severus turned toward her and his expression flickered, revealing a grief that Hermione had only ever caught glimpses of.

He walked toward Hermione and stopped less than a foot in front of her.

There was pause. He looked down and shuffled the vials in his hands. â€œThese should relieve any residual discomfort from theâ€”breaching.â€

Hermione felt her face grow hot and stared at the potions in his hands. She recognized them. Expensive pain relief.

â€œItâ€™s notâ€”that bad,â€ she said, avoiding his eyes. â€œBesidesâ€”I can make my own potions, Severus.â€

His expression grew cold. â€œYou are allowed to have other people care for you. I know you well enough to know you wouldnâ€™t make these potions for yourself, because too many of the ingredients are imported. Take them, unless you prefer I send word to Minerva about what you did today.â€

At the threat, Hermione snatched the vials out of his hands and shoved them into her satchel. She looked up to find Severus still staring down at her. His expression was unreadable.

â€œWhat is it?â€

â€œAre you alright?â€ His voice was soft.

Hermione stood staring at him. No. She wasnâ€™t. She hadnâ€™t been inâ€”she didnâ€™t know when sheâ€™d last been alright. She didnâ€™t know how to be alright anymore.

Severusâ€™ expression was visibly concerned, and it made Hermione flinch and bristle inwardly. She had parents. Parents who were alive and happy, even if they wouldnâ€™t ever remember having a daughter. She had parents. She didnâ€™t need new ones. She didnâ€™t need more people who â€˜caredâ€™ for her by telling her she was making the wrong decisions. She already had Minerva, Harry, and most of the Weasley Family doing that.

â€œIâ€™m fine,â€ she said stiffly. â€œI wasnâ€™t trying to make it seem like I did anything monumental. I just needed a bathroom so I could fix my hair.â€

He sighed. â€œYouâ€”â€œ He hesitated and fell silent.

â€œWhat?â€ she asked, her throat contracting with dread when he stayed silent and just kept staring at her with an expression of conflict in his eyes.

Was it not enough? Maybe an Unbreakable Vow still wouldnâ€™t be enough. Was there something else she could do? She swallowed repeatedly and tried to think, twisting the strap of her satchel tightly around her fingers. Maybeâ€”

â€œYou are without a doubt the most exceptional asset the Order possesses. I am sorry for that.â€

Hermioneâ€™s hands stilled, and she stared at him for a moment. Then she choked and burst into tears.

He stood watching her cry for a several minutes before hesitantly resting a hand on her shoulder.

The next week, Moody accompanied Hermione to Whitecroft.

They stood together silently in the rain until the door swung open, and the shack slowly bled into view.

Draco stood framed in the door, staring at her.

Hermione walked toward him, the uneven tread of Moodyâ€™s steps behind her. When she reached the steps, she paused and looked up at Draco.

He didnâ€™t meet her eyes as he stepped back to give them space to enter.

He looked gaunt. Tired. But she could feel his gaze on her.

If Moody had any reaction to the shack, it was not visible in his expression. He glanced around at the walls and then studied the floor for a strangely long time.

Hermione looked down; as her eyes swept across the room she noticed with horror that there were spots of blood on one of the floorboards. She wasnâ€™t positive, but she thought it was approximately where sheâ€™d been on the floor when she and Draco had sex. She looked up sharply. Draco was also looking at the floor and appeared to have just noticed it too. He paled noticeably, and his expression grew black as he looked up at Moody, who was still silently studying the floor. Â 

Hermione felt ready to die from the embarrassment, while Draco appeared to be on the verge of exploding with rage by the time Moody looked up from the floor and stared at Draco.

The air was tense. Deadly. Like a forest going abruptly silent. Defined by what was absent. The air between Draco and Moody was deathly cold. Hermioneâ€™s heart was pounding as she stood between them. Neither had their wands drawn, but Hermione felt as though an unexpected sound might cause them to whip them out and Avada each other.

â€œYouâ€™ll make a Vow?â€ Moody asked after several moments of silence.

â€œIsnâ€™t that why youâ€™re here?â€ Draco said, sneering.

Moody gave a sharp nod and then, with deliberate slowness, drew his wand. Dracoâ€™s expression tensed further, but he didnâ€™t so much as twitch.

â€œTake each otherâ€™s right hands,â€ Moody instructed in a gravelly voice.

Hermione lifted hers, and Draco reached out and took it. His eyes shone silver as his fingers wrapped around hers.

â€œKneel,â€ Moody said after a moment.

Hermione dropped to her knees, and Draco did the same across from her. Moody lowered his wand and rested the tip against their conjoined hands.

Hermione stared at Draco and her hand shook in his. â€œWill you, Draco Malfoy, aid the Order of the Phoenix in defeating Lord Voldemort to the best of your ability?â€

His eyes met hers. â€œI will.â€

At his words a thin tongue of red flame issued from Moodyâ€™s wand and wound its way around their hands. It was hot enough to burn, but neither of them flinched.

â€œAnd after his defeat, will you promise never to claim his power or become a Dark Lord?â€

Draco didnâ€™t hesitate. â€œI will.â€

A second flame twisted itself around their hands.

Hermione gripped his hand for a moment longer and then let go. The strands of flame tightened around their hands for a moment and then sank into their skin. As Hermione drew her hand away, it almost felt as though there were threads joining them that snapped as their hands parted.

There was a pause, and Draco stood and stared at Moody again.

â€œYou can go, Granger. I believe Moody and I have things to discuss,â€ Draco said without looking at her.

Hermione hesitated.

â€œGo, Granger,â€ Moody said. â€œYou can return to the safe house.â€

Hermione turned reluctantly and left. Draco didnâ€™t look at her as she pulled the door shut. He was glaring at Moody.

Moody returned to Grimmauld Place an hour later. Hermione was waiting on the stairs. She didnâ€™t expect him to tell her what he and Draco had discussed in her absence, but she hoped heâ€™d at least give her some indication.

He stared at her for a moment after closing the door. â€œGood work, Granger.â€

Then he walked further into the house without another word.

Flashback 25

February 2003

Â 

Grimmauld Place was quiet and sombre.

One of the major safe houses had been compromised. It had housed several significant figures in the Resistance, members of DA and the Order. They still werenâ€™t sure what happened. A patronus from Alicia Spinnet had burst into Grimmauld Place in the middle of the night. By the time the Order could mobilise a response, whatever had happened had mostly ended.

It hadnâ€™t even been a Death Eater attack. Hags mostly and werewolves. The house had been overrun with them. According to Ginny, it had been quite literally crawling with hags, more than a hundred. Many of the survivors brought back to the hospital were missing too many internal organs to be healed.

Alicia Spinnet, Dedalus Diggle, Septima Vector, and about thirty other people had died.

It abruptly shattered the high spirits that had been buoying the Resistance. In the process of trying to recover the survivors, Kingsley and several other members of the Order and Resistance used Dark Magic in order to force their way into the house.

It had resulted in an explosive argument between Harry and Kingsley afterward. The whole house was on edge.

The next week, when Hermione returned to the shack alone, she walked in uncertain of what would happen next. The room was empty. She stood waiting nervously.

Draco apparated in a minute later.

They stood staring at each other for several minutes. He ran his eyes over her, cataloguing her appearance in a way that was habitual at that point.

She didnâ€™t know what to say. She didnâ€™t know what was going to happen.

â€œI brought practice knives today,â€ Draco said as though the past two weeks hadnâ€™t happened.

â€œOh.â€

He pulled them out of his robes. One of the knives was small, the same size as the set heâ€™d given her for Christmas. The second was larger.

He pressed the blade into his hand demonstratively. â€œThey have wards on the tip and blade; they canâ€™t break the skin. Although they can bruise.â€

He tossed the smaller knife to her.

â€œKnives are growing increasingly common in the field. Hags regularly carry them. Death Eaters are beginning to pick up on the trend. Theyâ€™re decent backup if you lose your wand.â€

Hermione examined the knife, running her finger along the edge that appeared razor sharp but felt more like the handle of a piece of cutlery.

â€œItâ€™s difficult to win in a knife fight. Even if you survive it.â€

â€œI am aware,â€ Hermione said stiffly. Sheâ€™d treated knife injuries with increasing regularity during the last year. As far as non-Magical injuries went, knives were the worst. Mangled internal organs, severe blood loss, punctured lungs, hemorrhage. Like severe slicing hexes, but always more ragged and difficult to close.

â€œI imagine you are.â€ He had not met her eyes. Not once. Since the moment he made the Vow, his eyes had dropped away from hers. â€œWeâ€™ll start with deflecting attacks. Then I show you how to attack with yours. Use non-lethal hexes to try to stop me. Your goal is to drop me before I make contact, or to deflect it if I get within range.â€

He walked toward her. â€œIn order to avoid a knife attack, you should use your opponentâ€™s weight and momentum against them. If theyâ€™re lunging, dodge and try to disarm them.â€

He demonstrated several techniques in slow motion; showing Hermione how to grab his wrist, guide it safely past her body, and then try to twist the knife free.

â€œWhere did you learn all this?â€ she asked after he demonstrated a tenth method of disarming someone which involved breaking their arm.

His hands froze. â€œBellatrix. I trained under her for over four years. She had a fondness for knives.â€

â€œDid she know about your mother?â€

He stepped away from her and his expression was tense. â€œShe did. She was alway loyal to the Dark Lord, but she cared for her sister enough to want to see me succeed, rather than fail as was expected.â€

â€œD-did your father know?â€ She couldnâ€™t stop herself from asking the question.

Draco swallowed. â€œNo.â€ He looked away. â€œMy fatherâ€”heâ€”he was very protective of my mother. If heâ€™d knownâ€”â€

Draco was silent for a moment. â€œOcclumency isnâ€™t a talent he has. Not to the level he would have needed it. He would have been vengeful, and it would have damned us all.â€

The muscle in his jaw rippled. â€œMy mother insisted we hide her condition from him. There was a potion prescribed by a Danish mind healer; it masked most of her symptoms. Prevented her from panicking when she was required to make appearances. She took it when my father visited. The Dark Lord had mostly kept my father in France and Belgium following his release. He assumed she was cold and distant because she blamed him for my taking the mark.â€

â€œAfter Lestrange Manor?â€

â€œWell, I suppose I could have just told him then.â€ The corner of his mouth twisted. â€œBut I thought I could do more to avenge her if I had more time. I didnâ€™t realise how heâ€™d take the news.â€ He gave a bitter smile as he stared down at his hands. â€œIâ€™m sure the Order wishes I had.â€

Hermione blinked as she tried to imagine what state the Order might be in with Arthur and Molly and George still fighting; but with no Draco, no rescues, no intelligence on which battles they could win, no warnings before they were hit. She twisted the knife in her hands.

â€œThe Weasleys are my family, but we probably would have lost by nowâ€”you werenâ€™t crucial in the army then. Your death and your fatherâ€™s wouldnâ€™t have been enough to affect the outcome of the war. Theyâ€™d probably all be dead.â€

He snorted faintly and continued to avoid her eyes.

â€œDraco...â€ she said tentatively, starting to reach toward him. He jerked sharply away from her.

â€œWe should continue with training,â€ he said in a cold voice. â€œGiven that youâ€™ve now seen first hand the devastation caused by hags.â€

Hermione swallowed. â€œWe still donâ€™t know how they got in. We donâ€™t have any idea. Do you know anything about it?â€

â€œHags arenâ€™t in my jurisdiction. I didn't hear until afterward, or I would have tried to give some warning.â€ He hesitated. â€œItâ€™s possible someone in Sussex is working to find a way around the Fidelius Charm using Dark Creature Magic. If they suspected a safe house location, it may have been an unfortunately successful experiment. There are hundreds programs in Sussex; the branches donâ€™t collaborate often. I donâ€™t have contacts in all of them. You should re-ward your safe houses and move any that you can.â€

â€œWe are.â€

â€œGood,â€ he said as he flipped the knife in his hand. â€œLetâ€™s continue with training.â€

He made her practice the forms and techniques again and again.

â€œAlright, letâ€™s see how you manage with a real attack,â€ he said after an hour of slow practice. He stepped away from her. Â 

He spun the knife in his right hand the same way he spun his wand as he crossed the room and got into position. His expression was cold and intent as he stared toward her.

Then, without warning, he lunged.

Hermione dodged away and shot mild hexes as she evaded his initial attack. He was quick and relentless. He spun around her and brought the knife up to her throat before she could register that she needed to stop hexing him and try to deflect. Â 

They both froze. Their eyes met for a moment, and it was like time stopped. His face was only inches away from hers, and Hermione forgot to breathe.

His expression grew hard, and he stepped abruptly away from her.

â€œAgain. Timing is everything. Youâ€™re still too reluctant to move.â€ His tone was almost vicious. He stalked across the room and attacked her once more.

After an hour, he stopped.

â€œAlright. Thatâ€™s enough for today,â€ he said, walking away from her. He reached into his robes and pulled out a scroll.

Hermione bit her lip, went over to her satchel and withdrew an envelope. She gripped it nervously in her hands as she turned to face him.

â€œMoody said to give you this,â€ she said, glancing down at the floor. It appeared to have been carefully scrubbed.

She looked up in time to see his expression flicker.

â€œOf course, my orders for the week.â€ His mouth twisted briefly as he jerked it from her fingers.

She accepted the scroll in his hand and then stood hesitating. â€œDracoâ€¦â€

â€œRun along home now, Granger. I have work to do.â€ His tone was cold. He turned away from her and ripped open the envelope.

Hermione stood for another minute, studying his back. He didnâ€™t look back at her. He disappeared without a sound.

The next week, he still wouldnâ€™t meet her eyes. He barely spoke to her. Heâ€™d train her for exactly two hours a week, hand over his intelligence reports, take his orders from Moody, and leave.

But he was alive; she got to see him and know he was still alive.

However, being alive did not appear to be something he cared about. He just looked tired. The rage around him felt smothered. He appeared to be existing out of sheer obligation.

After three weeks, she caught him by the wrist as he was accepting the envelope in her hand. â€œDraco, pleaseâ€”look at me,â€ she said, her voice pleading.

He jerked his hand away and looked up at her. His face and eyes were cold. â€œIs all this not enough for you, Granger? Is there something else you want?â€

â€œNo. I justâ€”Iâ€™m sorry.â€

He sneered. â€œPerhaps someday when I have time I can make a list for you of all the things that apologies donâ€™t fix.â€

Hermioneâ€™s hand dropped. â€œDraco, Iâ€”â€œ

He was gone.

She returned to Grimmauld Place. Her chest felt hollow.

Everything felt void.

She wanted to get rid of her books, her journals, everything related to Draco. It felt vindictive and cruel to have a notebook with neat bullet points:

~ Sensitive hands - cruciatus treatment useful context for physical contact

~ Shoulders and neck

~ Scars - very responsive

~ Lower jaw near ears

~ Cheekbones

As well as notes for herself:

~ Definite interest in hair

~ Loosen braids after foraging, pull a few curls free

~ Wrists easy contact - find context for pulling up sleeves

~ Likes neck/throat. Possessive trait?

~ Wear collared shirts partly unbuttoned or v-necks. Borrow Ginnyâ€™s blue boatneck shirt.

All the psychology books. The books on emotional trauma. On attachment disorders. On body language and involuntary physical cues. She wanted to burn it all.

She went up to her shared room with Ginny. Harry was currently on a mission in Scotland. The Order was trying to find a way to break into Hogwarts. It was the only place they were almost certain there was a horcrux to be found, but the castle was impenetrable. The Death Eaters were thorough when the prison was set up.

Hogsmeade had been nearly razed in the early years of the war. There was no Shrieking Shack tunnel or tunnel via the hump on Gunhilda de Gorsemoor. The Order kept trying to find a way past the wards without success. It was Harryâ€™s third mission there. Harry, Ron, Terry Boot, and Zacharias Smith had been sent.

Harry hadnâ€™t spoken to Hermione since Christmas.

She cast the unlocking charms on her bedroom door and pushed it open. As she walked in, she heard a quick gasp.

Ginny was huddled next to her bed quietly sobbing. She turned sharply when Hermione entered the room. Ginnyâ€™s expression as she turned and caught sight of Hermione was anguished; her chest was stuttering sharply as she gasped rapidly through her open mouth. Even her red hair was wet with tears.

â€œGinny,â€ Hermione said. â€œGinny, whatâ€™s wrong? What happened?â€

â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€”,â€ Ginny forced the words out and then started crying harder.

â€œOh god, Hermioneâ€”,â€ Ginny gasped. â€œI donâ€™t know howâ€”â€

â€œItâ€™s alright. Breathe. You need to breathe. Tell me whatâ€™s wrong and Iâ€™ll help you,â€ Hermione promised as she ran her hands up and down Ginnyâ€™s shoulders. â€œJust breathe. â€œItâ€™s alright,â€ Hermione kept saying as she started taking deep demonstrative breaths for Ginny to follow. She held Ginny tightly in her arms so that sheâ€™d feel Hermioneâ€™s chest expanding and contracting slowly as a subconscious cue.

â€œNoâ€”you canâ€™tâ€”,â€ Ginny gripped Hermioneâ€™s shirt roughly to stop her. â€œOh god! I donâ€™tâ€”â€

â€œI didnâ€™t mean toâ€”,â€ Ginny sobbed, â€œI didnâ€™t mean to. I donâ€™t know what to do.â€

â€œGinny, what's wrong?â€ Hermione was growing cold with dread. What had possibly happened to make Ginny cry so much?

Ginny was silent for several seconds. Then she drew a deep breath and held it for a moment. â€œIâ€™m pregnant.â€

Ginny burst into tears again.

â€œHow? D-did the contraceptive potion not work?â€ Hermione felt on the verge of a panic attack of her own. Oh god.

If the contraceptive potion had failedâ€”

She regularly used certain spells countering curses that were in the darker shades of grey. It was cumulative, and the exposure could result in foetal abnormalities. It might have alreadyâ€”if she were pregnant. Now that Padma had mostly replaced her, developing counter-curses was one of the most vital things that Hermione did in the hospital wing.

If Draco found out that sheâ€™d seduced him when she was fertile, heâ€™d probably think she did it on purpose. Heâ€™dâ€”heâ€™dâ€”

Heâ€™d hate her forever.

Even more than he already did.

The tips of Hermioneâ€™s fingers were beginning to tingle as though there were needles pricking them.

Ginnyâ€™s expression furrowed. She stared at Hermioneâ€™s frozen expression as she smeared her tears away with the back of her hands. â€œNo. I didnâ€™tâ€”I was only taking it when Harry was here. Ginny sniffled and buried her face in her hands.

â€œItâ€™s alright. It will only take me a few days to get the ingredients to make an abortifacient.â€

â€œI canâ€™t,â€ Ginny choked out the words and started crying again.

Hermioneâ€™s hands on Ginnyâ€™s shoulders tightened as she stared at her. She drew a quick breath. â€œYou want to keep it.â€

Ginny nodded, sniffling. â€œI have to. Harryâ€”all he talks about is having a family. How after the war weâ€™re going to have children. Hermione gave a slow nod and looked away. â€œAlright.â€ She swallowed. â€œYou can probably stay here until Harry gets back from his current mission. And then we can move you to one of the hospice safe houses. Youâ€™ll want to be with your mum, wonâ€™t you?â€

Hermione stared at Ginny bewildered.

Ginny looked down and her chest shuddered. â€œHarryâ€”Harry isnâ€™t doing very well right now. Everyone has been getting so excited that weâ€™re nearing the end, that weâ€™re at the final haul. Hermione swallowed hard, trying to weigh whether there would be any value in trying to dissuade Ginny. She studied Ginnyâ€™s face. The stubborn set line of her mouth and jaw and the determined fire in her eyes.

â€œI donâ€™t know. Maybe I could pretend to get sick with something and hide at one of the hospice houses.â€

Ginny shook her head. â€œNo. If the war goes that long, Iâ€™ll come clean. But if Iâ€™m pregnant, Harry will just worry. Being pregnant isnâ€™t the same as having an actual baby. Hermioneâ€™s eyes dropped, and she twisted the hem of her shirt in her fingers. Ginny grabbed her hand.

â€œYouâ€™ll help, Hermione. Youâ€™ll help me protect Harry, wonâ€™t you?â€

Negative.

She closed her eyes and collapsed against the door in relief.

She stayed there for another minute until her hands stopped shaking, then she hurried out of the bathroom to the library.

Hermione spent nearly two days straight brewing experimental potions and practicing glamour charms and trying to make sure that every detail was perfect. She gathered up a bagful of potions and went into the bathroom. She downed a small vial and watched the potion take affect.

It took a few minutes. Then a sensation similar to a mild form of polyjuice tingled across her skin and she watched herself transform. Her skin broke out in tight clusters of painful-looking purple pustules across her entire body. She grimaced and inspected herself from all angles. It was a horribly convincing transformation. She pressed and prodded at several of the pustules and felt nothing. The suspended glamour was painless.

She swallowed the antidote and felt her skin tingle again as she watched her skin clear.

She gathered up her potions and went to her room.

Ginny was sitting in her bed, flipping through a magazine. Hermione sat down, and Ginny looked up, her eyes wide and curious.

Hermione fidgeted with the bag in her hands. â€œIâ€™ve developed a potion that mimics the external symptoms of spattergroit disease.â€

Ginnyâ€™s face screwed up. â€œReally? Does it have to be that?â€

Hermione rolled her eyes. â€œItâ€™s the best option I can come up with that meets all your requirements. Itâ€™s contagious; it's known to take up to a year to recover from, so you can stay hidden as long as necessary. It looks convincing; if you donâ€™t look horribly sick, people might be skeptical. Especially since your brothers are the ones who invented skiving snackboxes. No one is going to think youâ€™re faking this. And possibly most importantly, itâ€™s non-lethal. Harry isnâ€™t going to have to worry that you may die from it. Since itâ€™s not a full physical transformationâ€”just an external glamourâ€”I was able to suspend the potion in dragon blood, which means each dose will last for weeks. Ginny nodded.

â€œIf I donâ€™t tell him, he wonâ€™t approve having me as your caretaker. I promise, if I explain it, he wonâ€™t feel obliged to tell Harry. But he needs to know in order to maintain the lie. Ginnyâ€™s â€˜diseaseâ€™ threw Grimmauld into chaos. Hermione and Ginnyâ€™s room was placed under a mountain of quarantine and containment wards. Only Hermione could enter the room without setting off a house-full of screaming alarms.

Kingsley and Hermione coordinated details as much as possible. Once the diagnosis was given, Hermione and a handful of other occupants in Grimmauld Place were also placed under a precautionary three-day quarantine in another room.

Padma was sent foraging and took Parvati with her. The girls fell into a harpy trap. They fought their way out, but Parvati ended up with lacerations down her back, and Padmaâ€™s right foot was almost entirely chewed off. Hermione consulted with Poppy through the quarantine wards, but there was nothing that could be done to restore Padmaâ€™s foot.

Once everyone under temporary quarantine had been cleared, Kingsley placed Hermione in charge of monitoring Ginnyâ€™s condition. She would visit Ginny every four days. The rest of the time, Ginny would have to be kept in isolation. No one would enter her room. Dobby was made responsible for caring for Ginny day to day and getting meals to her.

When Molly Weasley recovered from her indignation at Kingsley for not being permitted to see her daughter, she was effusive in her appreciation to Hermione for how meticulously Hermione had mapped out Ginnyâ€™s care.

Researching midwifery on the sly was folded into the the endless list of things Hermione secretly did when she wasnâ€™t in the hospital ward covering for Padma.

The Resistance was too busy for word of Ginnyâ€™s sickness to cause ripples for long. Once the initial panic that the disease might spread had abated, things slipped back into a tenuous sense of normalcy. Hermione only had to dread Ron and Harryâ€™s reactions when they returned from Scotland.

Her whole life felt tense without any sense of relief. She felt worn through; stretched out until she was nearly transparent.

She worried every day about Draco, but seeing him was just a different kind of agony. He was gaunt and on edge. Heâ€™d barely look at her; heâ€™d barely speak to her. He trained her. He turned over his information. He accepted his orders from Moody. He left.

When she tried to speak to him, he just grew colder.

After several more weeks, he paused and looked her over again rather than just leaving. â€œTell Moody to feed you. You look like a corpse.â€

He vanished before Hermione could say anything.

When she returned to Grimmauld Place, Angelina looked up from a match of Wizardâ€™s Chess with Katie, her expression sober. â€œHarry, Ron, and Terry are back. The Order is debriefing now. No one has told them about Ginny yet.â€

Hermione nodded and went to the dining room.

â€œThe castle has so many wards itâ€™s hard to even find,â€ Harry was saying in a low reluctant voice when Hermione opened the door. He was slumped low in his chair. â€œIt wasnâ€™t Harryâ€™s fault. The lake was my idea,â€ Ron broke in as soon as Harryâ€™s voice trailed away. â€œWhen he tried to go in after Zacharias, I stopped him.â€

â€œThat was the right decision, Ron. Inferi in water are nearly impossible to fight since they canâ€™t be set on fire,â€ Remus said, resting a hand on Ronâ€™s shoulder.

â€œThatâ€™s not enough of a reason to let Zacharias drown,â€ Harry said in a bitter voice, his expression twisted with frustration. Harry glared at Kingsley, crushing the quill in his hand. â€œNo.â€

â€œGood. Anything else to report?â€

Harry was silent.

â€œWe pulled out after we lost Zacharias,â€ Ron said in a dull tone, his whole body seemed limp. â€œMost of the mission was spent surveying and then tunneling.â€

â€œMe too,â€ Tonks nodded.

â€œYesâ€¦,â€ Kingsley said slowly.

â€œWhile you were gone, Ginny Weasley contracted Spattergroit diseaseâ€”â€œ

â€œMonths? A year?â€ Harry looked ready to fall over backwards. â€œYouâ€”you canâ€™t isolate her for that long. Thatâ€™s torture. There must be a way for me to visit her. Some kind of potions. Or spells.â€

â€œGranger, as our most qualified medical professional, is the only one cleared to visit her in order to monitor her condition. Everyone else filed out. After a few minutes, Hermione stood alone with Harry.

â€œSheâ€™llâ€”sheâ€™ll be okay, wonâ€™t she?â€ Harry said once the room was empty. â€œIs she in pain?â€

â€œIn time sheâ€™ll be fine,â€ Hermione said, fidgeting her hands nervously behind her back. â€œSheâ€™s not in any pain. Sheâ€™s taking restorative potions and she spends a lot of time sleeping. â€œOkay.â€ Harry nodded repeatedly. â€œThatâ€”thatâ€™s good. Do you know how she got it?â€

Harryâ€™s eyes got bigger. â€œIâ€™ll be careful. Anything I need to do, Iâ€™ll follow all your instructions. Just once.â€ His voice was both pleading and conspiratorial.

She knew that voice so well.

Flashback 26

Chapter Notes

Warning: This chapter contains an episode of self-harm.

March 2003

Â 

Ginnyâ€™s pregnancy went as smoothly as could have been hoped. She was physically drained from the toll it took on her Magic, but aside from sleeping most of the day and refusing most of the food Hermione had sent, her pregnancy symptoms were relatively minor. After hearing about Narcissa Malfoyâ€™s near death during pregnancy, Hermione was paranoid about what kind of toll magical pregnancy could take. But Ginny seemed to handle pregnancy easily.

â€œItâ€™s a Prewett thing; easily pregnant, easy pregnancies,â€ Ginny said with a shrug when Hermione asked.

â€œThatâ€™s lucky, Iâ€™d hate to be leaving you alone like this if you were as sick as the books say witches can get from pregnancy,â€ Hermione said, studying the bright yellow orb fluttering over Ginnyâ€™s stomach. â€œThe baby has a good magical signature; it seems healthy. But Iâ€™m not very practiced with any of these spells.â€

Hermione flipped to a different page in the Guide to Effective Care in Magical Pregnancy and Childbirth and practiced a charm to check for placenta previa.

â€œHave you heard anything from Harry and Ron?â€ Ginny asked after a few minutes of Hermione manipulating diagnostic charms.

Hermione nodded and cancelled all the diagnostics hanging around Ginny. â€œTheyâ€™re back at Hogwarts again. They havenâ€™t sent any messages.â€

â€œHarry sends his stag at night. I think he must do it when heâ€™s on lookout duty. It came into my room last night,â€ Ginny pressed her lips together and looked on the verge of tears.

â€œItâ€™s alright. You donâ€™t need to worry about me.â€ Hermione gave a weary shrug as she shrank the book and slipped it into a bag.

Ginny leaned forward and grabbed Hermioneâ€™s left wrist. â€œWell, I donâ€™t have very much to do in here. And I think you need someone to worry about you. Youâ€™re so thin.â€ Ginny ran her thumb over Hermioneâ€™s ulna as though to illustrate how the bones jutted out. Hermione jerked her wrist free and pulled her sleeves down. â€œYou donâ€™t look like you sleep at all. You look like youâ€™re made of paper. Donâ€™t you have anyone?â€

Hermione looked away. â€œWell, George has offered,â€ she said with a wry smile. â€œBut I donâ€™t think he really meant it.â€

Ginny poked her. â€œBe serious. You canâ€™t survive this war alone. No one can carry it. We survive together.â€ Ginny looked Hermione over carefully. â€œI mean, maybe you were alright before. Butâ€”youâ€”you donâ€™t look like youâ€™re coping anymore. Ever since Christmas, I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve seen you sleep. Donâ€™t you have anyone at all?â€

Hermione scrunched her nose distastefully. â€œI think Iâ€™ve already mentioned that cathartic shagging is not my thing.â€ She scoffed as she shook her head. â€œAdding a fuck-buddy is hardly going to improve my coping skills.â€

Ginny rolled her eyes and shook her head. â€œIâ€™m not saying get a fuck-buddy. You donâ€™t even have anyone to talk to or get a hug from after a bad day. Whenever anyone tries to reach out to you, you push them away, the way you did with Harry on Christmas. I donâ€™t understand why you donâ€™t let anyone share the load. I know that look in your eyes; itâ€™s the same one Harry gets when the war is crushing him. But Harry knows he has Ron no matter what, and me, and you, and the family, and DA, and Remus and Tonks, and the Order, and even his stupid Muggle fights when it gets too heavy. Heâ€™s got all that to fall back on when he needs to put it down for a little while. You need to do that too.â€

Hermione stared down at her nails and fidgeted with the cuticles for a minute. â€œWhat load do I have that anyone would be willing to share with me?â€ Her voice was bitter.

She turned and looked out the window for a minute before looking back down at her hands. â€œItâ€™s worse, Ginny, to think someone is there for you to lean on and then find they arenâ€™t when you need them most. I canâ€™tâ€”I canâ€™t take that risk. I wouldnâ€™t be able to handle it.â€

Ginny gave a frustrated huff and poked one of the glamoured pustules on her wrist. â€œHarry and Ron get angry at you because they care, though. Hermione twisted her wand in her hands. â€œWhat if they arenâ€™t? When I really need them to?â€

There was a pause, and Ginny gave a sad sigh.

Hermione closed her eyes for a moment before reopening them. â€œThis way has become habit for me, Ginny. I donâ€™t know how to do it differently.â€

â€œWhat about me?â€ Ginny said, with a small smile.

Hermione looked at her. â€œYou?â€

â€œWhy canâ€™t you talk to me? See? Weâ€™ve been friends for years; weâ€™ve roomed together for nearly four years. But you never even considered that Iâ€™m someone for you to talk to. Even before I became an Order member, Harry and I were still able to talk about things. He could tell me enough. You can talk to me. You can trust me. I wonâ€™t judge. Iâ€™m trusting you. Iâ€™m here for you. If you need someone, you can talk to me about anything.â€

Hermione stared at Ginny guiltily. â€œGinnyâ€¦ Iâ€”itâ€™s not a matter of me not trusting you. Iâ€”justâ€”I donâ€™tâ€”â€œ

Ginnyâ€™s expression fell. â€œNever mind. Iâ€™m not trying to make you. I just wanted to you to know you have someone to talk to. If you ever wanted to. Even if I disagree with you, Iâ€™m not going to stop being your friend.â€

â€œThanks, Ginny,â€ Hermione said, looking away. â€œI do appreciate it. If I couldâ€”I would talk if I could. But I donâ€™t even know where to start. Andâ€”â€ she glanced at her watch, â€œI need to go. Padmaâ€™s shift is starting soon, and Iâ€™m still helping her manage it.â€

â€œOkay,â€ Ginny sighed. â€œIâ€™ll let you go then. Is Padma alright?â€

â€œAs well as can be expected. Sheâ€™s still adapting to the prosthetic; it gets sore and she tires easilyâ€”the charm work is not as good as it could be. Flitwick and I are still tinkering with the balance.â€

Hermione gathered her books and potions up and shoved them all into a bag before she walked out of Ginnyâ€™s room; making a show of removing all kinds of protective wards from her body and applying cleansing charms before heading to change her clothes.

On her way to the hospital ward, she stopped and leaned against the wall for a few minutes. She pressed her palms flat against the wallpaper to try to stop the trembling in her hands.

She hadnâ€™t been able to sleep for more than a hour or two at a time since Christmas. She took Dreamless Sleep potion once a week on Monday night, so her hands wouldnâ€™t shake during training with Draco.

Everyone else congregated in the sitting room at night when they couldnâ€™t sleep, but Hermione found herself unable to bear being there. She stalled the conversations; people tried to cheer her up and include her. She was too tired to pretend.

Most nights, when the house was quiet, sheâ€™d sit alone in the kitchen of Grimmauld Place, trying to find something to do to to fill all the cold empty hours until sunrise.

She pulled her hands away from the wall and went to take her shift.

Hermione was on the stairs with Padma, helping her practice ascending the stairs without a cane, when the door of Grimmauld Place burst open.

â€œNo! Let go! Let go!â€ Harry was screaming and trying to tear himself out of Remusâ€™ arms as Remus dragged him through the door. â€œFuck. LET GO OF ME!! We canâ€™t leave them!!â€

Harry punched Remus in the face as he struggled to break loose.

â€œSomeone stun him!â€ Remus snapped as he slammed Harry to the floor and pinned him there in order to keep him from twisting free.

â€œGod, no. Fuck. You left Ron! LET GO! YOU CANâ€™T MAKE ME LEAVE HIM!!!â€

Hermione whipped her wand out and caught Harry in the side of the head with a stunner. Harry slumped down limp.

â€œDonâ€™t wake him unless heâ€™s restrained!â€ Remus snapped, turning and rushing out the door and apparating before anyone could ask questions.

Hermione left Padma on the stairs and hurried down to Harryâ€™s limp body. She cast a diagnostic, checking him over carefully. He was covered in dirt and had a concussion and several fractured ribs; several nails had been torn off, and he was carrying cursed injuries.

â€œSomeone send a patronus to Kingsley and Moody,â€ Hermione said in a sharp voice as she countered the curses. She levitated Harry off the floor and took him up to the hospital.

It didnâ€™t take long to repair Harryâ€™s injuries. Then she poured several strengtheners and restorative potions down his throat.

â€œOh Harry, Harry, Harry,â€ she murmured under her breath and pressed her forehead down against his. â€œPlease, Remus, bring Ron back.â€

She stayed beside Harry until Neville appeared, accompanied by Charlie who was carrying an unconscious Tonks. Padma came in behind them. Nevilleâ€™s wand arm was broken in multiple horrifying angles.

â€œWhat happened?â€ Hermione asked as Padma levitated Tonks into a bed.

â€œFuck if I know,â€ Neville said. He was so pale his skin was nearly translucent. â€œSoâ€”is Ron alive?â€ Hermioneâ€™s voice shook as she removed the bones in his arm. Neville was so dazed he didnâ€™t even react.

â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€”â€œ

â€œWe sent word to Mum,â€ Charlie said in a wooden voice. â€œTo find out what the clock says.â€

Ronâ€™s hand on the Weasley family clock steadily read Mortal Peril.

â€œMolly, thereâ€™s a meeting in an hour, about what to do. Iâ€”can stay with Arthur, if you want to go,â€ Hermione finally said, resting a hand lightly on Mrs Weasleyâ€™s shoulder.

Hermione withdrew her hand. â€œIâ€™ll make you some tea before I go.â€

The meeting was seething.

â€œWeâ€™re not going to attempt any suicide missions to get into Hogwarts,â€ Kingsley said as soon as the debriefing was completed. He was utterly calm despite the tension vibrating through the air. â€œGetting into the school was already a top priority mission and it continues to be. Charlie smacked the table angrily, and the meeting descended into shouting for several minutes.

â€œWe canâ€™t leave him there. Heâ€™s an Order member. Theyâ€™re probably torturing him. What if Lucius Malfoy gets his hands on him?â€ Harryâ€™s chest was heaving with panic and rage despite the Draught of Peace and sedatives Hermione had given him prior to approving his rennervation.

â€œThere is nothing that can be done until we have better intelligence,â€ Kingsley said, unmoved. He was always exactingly calm during meetings. Kingsley drew a long breath and shook his head. â€œIf the Order attempted to open a negotiation channel, we could alert them to the value of their prisoner. Youâ€™re grieving; until you have a new partner assigned to you, you are restricted from further missions.â€

â€œKeep an eye on Harry,â€ Kingsley said. â€œRemus, Fred, Charlie, donâ€™t let him out of your sight.â€

â€œGranger, a word before you go,â€ Kingsley said.

She stopped and turned back. Kingsley cast a privacy charm around them. She curled her hands into fists behind her back.

â€œYou need to speak with Malfoy. I want everything about Hogwarts, immediately.â€

â€œSoon as you can, wait there until you speak to him. Tell him itâ€™s critical. Make clear this is a top priority for the Order.â€

Kingsley nodded slowly as he looked back at her. His expression was closed but his gaze as he studied her was meticulous. She often wondered what conclusions he was drawing.

â€œYes. If he has a chance to get Ron back, that would be preferable to the losses weâ€™ll suffer attacking Hogwarts. Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched at the unspoken implication. It was worth sacrificing Draco to recover Ron. Of course. That was why sheâ€™d consented in the first place. She knew that calculus to be true. Because war was larger than anyone.

Butâ€”butâ€”

â€œNot yet. If we canâ€™t recover Ron within a week, weâ€™ll use it,â€ Kingsley said finally. â€œI donâ€™t want any information getting to them. If weâ€™re lucky, theyâ€™ll preoccupy themselves by trying to gather their own intelligence until Moody and I can find a solution.â€

â€œAlright.â€

â€œThank you,â€ Hermione said, trying to catch his eyes for a moment. What if he died? What if this were the last time she ever saw him?

â€œThank you, Draco.â€

â€œYou want me to look at you, Granger?â€ Draco said, his tone was lightâ€”almost cajolingâ€”but there was a freezing edge to it. He stalked forward and closed in on her. â€œFine. Iâ€™m looking. Itâ€™s delightful, I must say, to see all the guilt in your eyes.â€

He sneered down at her.

â€œYou know, I used to think the circumstances of my servitude to the Dark Lord were as cruel an enslavement as anyone could conceive. But I admit, it pales somewhat beside you.â€

â€œI suppose no one realises how light one set of manacles is until they have two,â€ he said, studying her expression as his tone grew musing. â€œAt least before I could console myself that it wasnâ€™t my fault; that accepting everything was simply the best I could do to keep my mother safe. Itâ€™s different when I have no one to blame but myself.â€

His hand came up and rested on her throat. â€œAfter all, I did choose you. You were so determined to do whatever it took, but you will always be a Gryffindor at heart. Hermione shook faintly.

He reached up and his fingertips ghosted across her cheek. Hermione closed her eyes and drew a sharp breath. He was so close she could smell the oakmoss and papyrus-sedge that clung to his skin.

â€œBy the time I realised Iâ€™d miscalculated, youâ€™d already forced your way in. You were so obvious, and it only made it worse. â€œThen, after you nearly died in Hampshire, I thought, at least I can keep her alive. She deserves to have someone who cares enough to try to keep her alive. I thought eventually youâ€™d give up. â€œSo forgive me if I dislike looking at you, Iâ€™m still adjusting to all the ways the new ones chafe.â€

He turned and apparated silently away.

Hermione sank to the floor and rested her head on her knees while she fought to breathe.

She returned quietly to Grimmauld Place and found her potion closet had been broken into. She checked the inventory and found several doses of polyjuice potion and two whole vials of veritaserum had been stolen. None of the concealed compartments had been touched.

â€œI canâ€™t imagine what anyone needs with eighty doses of veritaserum,â€ Hermione said in a biting tone. â€œYouâ€™ll need to recalculate rationing until the next batch finishes next month. Padma flushed and limped away.

Hermione set to replacing the wards on the closet and then went to check on the occupants in the hospital ward.

Having regular shifts in the hospital while Padma recovered was a relief. Something to do. Something to focus on. Something that was good; that didnâ€™t add to the intricate web of deceit she spent most of her time being strangled by.

It was the only thing Hermione did that didnâ€™t make her want to mutilate herself in penance afterward.

Not that it mattered whether she were penitent or not. Not that anyone cared.

When she sat alone in the kitchen at night she could whatever she wanted.

One line the first time. Sheâ€™d watched the blood well up and slowly turn into a droplet that slid across her skin toward the table.

Sheâ€™d flicked her wand and the blood vanished. Another flick and the cut was gone too.

The next night there had been more. The hours crawled past, night after cold night while she cut and cut. As many razor fine lacerations as she wanted. She could heal them all without so much as a scar.

She was good at it. Fixing external wounds. It was an exceptional talent of hers. It was something to do at night.

When she emerged from a visit withÂ Ginny, she found Harry standing outside the door.

He looked feverish. His skin was pale, but his eyes were glittering brightly.

â€œIs she doing alright?â€ he asked before Hermione had shut the door behind herself.

â€œSheâ€™s doing fine. There isnâ€™t any change yet,â€ Hermione said before Harryâ€™s expression could become hopeful. She removed all the protective wards and cast cleansing charms on herself quickly.

He nodded rapidly. â€œDoes she know about Ron yet?â€

â€œI told her. I told her Iâ€™d let her know as soon as we got him back.â€ She rested her hand on Harryâ€™s arm. â€œWeâ€™re going to get him back, Harry.â€

â€œI know. I know we will,â€ Harry said, then he glanced sharply around as though he suspected someone might be eavesdropping. â€œCan youâ€”can you come with me?â€

â€œWhat do you need me for then?â€

They reappeared at an empty lot. Harry reached out and grabbed something invisible in midair. There was the screech of an old gate and Harry stepped forward, still holding Hermione by the wrist. Harry led the way along a winding gravel path up to the front door. The entry opened into the sitting room with a dining room beyond. Charlie, Fred, Remus and Tonks were all standing around a table. They looked up when Harry entered. Hermione followed him into the room.

â€œAnd the last time she was on a mission was when?â€ Charlie said, arching an eyebrow as he stared at her.

â€œWhat the Order needs is to stop losing people, or there wonâ€™t be anyone left for her to heal.â€ Harry said in a furious voice.

â€œPadma. Padmaâ€™s good with healing, and sheâ€™s used to being on a battlefield.â€ Remus said, studying Harry rather than Hermione.
