â€œNear Cambridge?â€ Hermione echoed. There were no known prisons in Cambridge. Draco would have mentioned it. â€œAnd you got this from snatchers?â€

â€œWe get a lot of information from snatchers. Most of the prison blueprints we use for our rescues come from snatchers, you know,â€ Harry said with a nod, looking down at a rough outline of a building.Â 

Hermione twitched and felt cold. Moody had attributed most of Dracoâ€™s intelligence on prison blueprints as being from snatchers. She stepped closer and stared at the blueprint for a minute before looking back up.Â 

â€œHarryâ€”this could be a trap,â€ she said as gently as she could.

â€œYeah. Any of our intelligence could be a trap. But itâ€™s been pretty good until now. Iâ€™m not going to doubt it the time it could mean getting Ron back. We have to go today. Tomorrow is the full moon,â€ Harry said in a tight voice.

Hermione looked at Charlie, Fred, Remus, and Tonks.Â 

â€œItâ€™s as good as anything else weâ€™ve gotten,â€ Remus said, giving her a small smile. â€œThe Order needs Ron back. The Death Eaters will probably expect us to delay and then use a large force, if we get in and out before they expect us, there will be fewer casualties.â€

Hermione stood, wavering. If she exposed Draco to everyone in the room, there was no guarantee it would even stop them. It could just shatter the Order.Â 

â€œWill you come, Hermione, to help me get Ron back?â€ Harry turned from the table and was studying her seriously.Â 

â€œHarryâ€”,â€ she started in a pleading voice.

â€œI donâ€™t know what they might have done to him after so many days,â€ Harry interrupted her, his voice thick. There was a tremor underlying it. â€œHe could beâ€”really, really hurt. â€œUntil we get Ron back, Harryâ€™s useless. There are no solutions that wonâ€™t be a risk for the Order. Losing Ron could easily be a critical blow for us.â€Â Â 

Hermione swallowed. â€œOf course. Of course Iâ€™ll come.â€Â 

Harry gave a relieved sigh and grinned at her. â€œGood. Come see the plan.â€

The plan wasnâ€™t the Orderâ€™s best. Strategy had always been Ronâ€™s strength and everyone could feel his absence and the need for him as they looked down at the blueprint before them.

Hermioneâ€™s job was to stay down and let everyone else deal with any guards or fighting. She was supposed to heal Ron as rapidly as possible once they found him in case they had to fight their way out. If there was a firefight, she was to get Ron out. Once she had gotten him clear, everyone else would retreat.

Hermione stared down at the blueprint. It was a trap. The layout was too obvious, too detailed for a snatcher to know. She gnawed her lip as she considered what to do.

â€œAlright. Everyone get ready. Weâ€™ll head out in fifteen minutes,â€ Harry said. Â 

Hermione fidgeted nervously. â€œI need to get my kit. You didnâ€™t give me a chance to bring my supplies.â€Â 

Harry turned to stare at her, his green eyes narrowed. â€œAre you trying to sneak back and contact Kingsley so he can stop us?â€Â 

The corner of Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched. â€œNo. I wonâ€™t.â€

â€œPromise?â€

â€œI promise, Iâ€™ll just get my kit from Grimmauld Place and leave. I wonâ€™t tell anyone in the Order or the Resistance.â€

Harry gave a slow nod. â€œAlright. Go fast. If you arenâ€™t back in fifteen minutes weâ€™re going to leave without you.â€Â 

Hermione rushed out of the cottage and apparated to the shack.

She waited for a few minutes. She felt cold with terror.

Moody was in Scotland. Kingsley was out gathering reconnaissance reports. There was no one to contact quick enough. No one who could or would stop Harry.

If she sent a patronus, she had nothing to say but that Harry was walking into a trap somewhere near Cambridge. It wasnâ€™t enough information for Kingsley to act on in time.Â 

If Draco knew something, if he could tell her something concrete, she might be able to use it to dissuade Harry.Â 

She gnawed at her fingernails and twisted at the collar of her shirt.

Finally she swallowed hard. Draco wasnâ€™t coming. It had been nearly ten minutes.

She was out of time.

She conjured a piece of paper and scribbled a note for him with the the relevant details. Location. Strategy. Her suspicions. So if he came, heâ€™d at least know why sheâ€™d called him.

She used a sticking charm to place it in the center of the floor where it was impossible to miss and headed to Grimmauld Place.

She sprinted up the stairs to her closet and pulled out her healing kit. It was almost identical to the one sheâ€™d given Draco but with a few more specialized potions and bandages and splints. She shrank it down and stuffed it into her pocket and then pulled up a floorboard and snatched up her knives; strapping one onto her left arm under her shirt and then the other onto her calf under her trousers. She started to reach for her cloak but drew her hand back. Too obvious. It could raise questions.

She stood up and rushed back out the door.

Harry and everyone else was standing in front of the Tonks cottage when she appeared.Â 

â€œWotcher, Hermione, we thought you split,â€ Tonks said.Â 

Hermione shook her head. â€œNo. I just had to make sure I had everything. I donâ€™t usually heal outside of the hospital ward.â€

Tonks nodded. â€œAlright. Grab on. Iâ€™m apparating everyone since I did the scouting.â€

Hermione gripped Tonksâ€™ arm, and the group vanished with sharp squeezing sensation and reappeared in a forest. A large, derelict, stone house stood in a nearby clearing.

â€œThereâ€™s an anti-apparition ward about halfway across the field. Once youâ€™ve got Ron, Hermione, get him past the wards and take him back to the cottage. That way we can make sure heâ€™s not tagged or traced before we go to one of the safe houses,â€ Harry said quietly.

â€œAlright,â€ Hermione said, nodding as she stared at the building. Her heart was beating so hard it hurt. She fidgeted with her wand and felt through her shirt to reassure herself that her knife was still there.

Harry, Remus, Fred, and Charlie started constructing an intricate detection spell while Hermione and Tonks kept watch. Â 

They cast the web of magic off their wands, and it slowly drifted out of the forest, barely visible unless it was being looked for. It floated across the field toward the house, shimmering slightly at different points to indicate the various wards. As it phased through the building there were small flashes of red lightâ€¦

â€œTwo at the door,â€ Harry said.Â 

â€œFour upstairs,â€ Fred added.

â€œMore than ten in the basement,â€ Charlie said. â€œBet thatâ€™s where theyâ€™ve got Ron.â€

â€œWe go fast,â€ Harry said. His wand was clenched in his fist, and his eyes were glittering as he stared at the building. He was bouncing on the balls of his feet. â€œWith the detection wards in there, weâ€™ve got ten minutes tops before reinforcements show up. Hermione, all you do is get Ron out.â€

Flashback 27

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

March 2003

Itâ€™s a trap. Itâ€™s a trap. Itâ€™s a trap.

It was the only thing Hermione could think as Harry vanished under his cloak of Invisibility to set out across the field toward the house.

They watched the door open, and there were quiet flashes of spellwork before Harryâ€™s head appeared, and he beckoned them forward.

They moved toward the house under heavy disillusionment.

Hermione watched the ripples of Fred and Charlie move soundlessly up the stairs while Harry signaled toward a door that led down to the basement.

She could feel Tonks behind her as they descended the narrow stairs and heard muffled spells and falling bodies as Harry and Remus reached the bottom. They had been in the house for less than a minute.

Hermione heard a door blast open.

â€œClear,â€ Harryâ€™s disembodied voice called softly.

They worked down the basement hallway, forcing the doors open. The quiet felt deadlyâ€¦ it was broken only by the faintest shuffling of feet. Her heart was beating in her ears, louder than the sound of Harry breaking into room after room.

They were halfway down the hallway when the door at the far end flew open. Dozens of spells shot out. Hermione dove to avoid a cruciatus streaking down the hallway. Several curses ricocheted off the walls; the air was filled with magic.

Everything was simultaneously slower and faster. Hermione focused on keeping her shield up and dodging as rapidly as possible. As she spun away from an acid curse that would have caught her in the face, the deadly green of a Killing curse raced toward her.

â€œYou need to have the instincts to just move.â€

She threw herself to the ground, shot up to her feet on the other side of the hallway and proceeded to machine-gun stunners into the room down the hall.

Nothing lethal. If Ron was there, she might hit him.

Finally, the spells stopped. There was a pause.

â€œHeâ€™s in here!â€ Harry shouted.

Hermione moved forward quickly into the room, removing her disillusionment. Harry was breaking through chains that had Ron hanging from the ceiling of the room. There were eight unconscious Death Eaters on the ground.

Ron had been beaten. His face so swollen it was almost unrecognizable. He was clearly shouting, but no sound emerged. His wrists had deep cuts in them where the shackles had sunk into his skin while heâ€™d been hanging. Harry broke through the chains, and Hermione and Tonks caught Ron before he fell.

â€œFinite Incantatum.â€ Hermione waved her wand over Ronâ€™s face as she whipped out her healing kit. Â 

â€œHarry, you fucking idiot!â€ Ron exploded as soon as he was un-silenced. â€œGet out of here! Why the fuck did you bring Hermione?â€

Too easy. Itâ€™s been too easy. The words repeated themselves in her mind as she started healing Ron. She worked as quickly as she could; not everything, just enough, just enough to get him out of the house and able to fight if necessary.

â€œVerify itâ€™s him,â€ Remus said.

â€œItâ€™s him,â€ Harry said.

â€œVerify it,â€ Remus snapped.

â€œHow did Quirrell get past Fluffy?â€

â€œWith a bloody harp.â€ Ron tried to push Hermione away and stand. â€œWe have to get out of here.â€

â€œSwallow this,â€ Hermione forced a potion to counter his internal organ damage down his throat, followed by a restorative and then a strengthening potion.

â€œWe need to go now,â€ Ron said as Hermione smeared bruise paste down his face to reduce the swelling so he could see.

â€œLet me fix your wand hand,â€ she said, pushing back the shackle still encircling his wrist in order to drip Essence of Dittany into the deep laceration that cut to the bone. She repaired the fractures as fast as she could.

As she was performing the spells, the ring on her hand suddenly burned red hot. She gave a choked gasp as she kept working. The sensation had barely faded before it burned again.

â€œThatâ€™s enough,â€ Ron ripped his hand away from Hermione with a wince. â€œWe have to get out. Did you bring me a wand?â€

Harry pulled one out, and Ron gripped it limply and made to stand. He got halfway up and then sank back to the ground.

Hermione pulled his arm over her shoulder. â€œYouâ€™re with me,â€ she said. â€œMy job is to get you out.â€

â€œYou bloody idiot, why the hell did you let Harry talk you into this?â€ Ron sagged against her, and she helped him down the hall.

â€œYou keep Harry alive,â€ Hermione said quietly, â€œand youâ€™re my best friend. Of course I came.â€

She got him up the stairs as her ring burned again. And again. And again.

Fred and Charlie were at the top of the stairs, waiting for them. Â 

â€œNine minutes, we need to go.â€ Charlieâ€™s voice was practically vibrating with tension.

Charlie, Harry, and Fred went out first, followed by Hermione and Ron, with Remus and Tonks covering the rear.

Hermioneâ€™s eyes locked on the edge of the anti-apparition ward.

â€œThe wards end in eighty feet, we just have to reach the centre of the field,â€ she told Ron. Her voice was shaking but she tried to sound assured

They were twenty feet away from the house when the air broke with cracking sounds. The field just outside the anti-apparition ward suddenly filled with Death Eaters.

Hermione froze. There were possibly a hundred Death Eaters, and they immediately advanced through the ward, blocking the escape, a wall of curses streaking ahead of them.

If she tried to turn and run with Ron, theyâ€™d be mowed down. The closest edge of the anti-apparition wards was through the Death Eaters.

The strengthening potion had kicked in for Ron, and he was no longer leaning heavily on Hermione. The spare wand theyâ€™d brought for him still drooped slightly in his hand.

â€œStay down, Hermione,â€ he said as he straightened and moved forward to his place beside Harry.

The Order had nothing left but excellent fighters. The speed and accuracy with which everyone fought was remarkable. Considering the steep odds, it was unbelievable that they didnâ€™t all immediately die. The disparity in firepower was tremendous.

Tonks and Fred were the only ones using truly dangerous spells as they fought.

The â€˜strategyâ€™ for the escape rapidly dissolved. Ron was nowhere near Hermione.

The Death Eaters attacking didnâ€™t seem particularly talented; there was a notable lack of finesse and coordination in their attack. However, the difference in numbers was staggering. There were more than ten Death Eaters to every one of them.

Hermione steadied herself behind the shield she had cast.

She cast a slicing hex at several throats. Tiny little cuts. Simple. Permanent.

Her aim had grown precise.

Three Death Eaters dropped, one after another.

She tried a few more, but other Death Eaters had the sense to keep their shields up.

She slipped low severing charms toward their feet. Quite a few of the Death Eatersâ€™ shields werenâ€™t comprehensive.

There were screams as more Death Eaters fell, their Achilles tendons cut through, dropping their wands as they went.Â 

Hermione followed the severing charm with more lethal spells to ensure they all stayed down.

Her shield charm was beginning to wear through from the number of spells that had struck it. She dove and spun rapidly to the side as she avoided a Killing Curse. She felt it burn through the air near her cheek as it nearly grazed her. She recast her shield as she fought to move toward the boundary of the anti-apparition wards.

She looked for Harry and Ron and the others, but the Death Eaters were so close.

Everyone was spread out.

Hermione turned sharply to avoid an unfamiliar curse. As she did, something struck her left wrist. The pain was searing.

She stumbled back, glancing down, and found sheâ€™d been hit where her shielded shirt had ridden up on her wrist. Cruel, deep pustules were welling up along her arm. The acid curse. If they burst, theyâ€™d spit their acid and spread.

It was so agonising that it was hard to rasp out the counter curse. She was forced to stop and dodge or drop to avoid new curses.

On the third try, she managed to get the counter-curse to stick. The pustules subsided, but the pain was still indescribable.

She fell back, gasping raggedly, trying to find a more defensible spot.

It was so open. Nothing to hide behind but bodies.

She couldnâ€™t stop herself from calculating her injury, like a ticker running in the back of her mind. Non-lethal but severe. Sheâ€™d scar, but she was not at risk of losing her hand. The spots where the acid had eaten away at the bones in her wrist would never recover until she removed and regrew them. Sheâ€™d have to be careful not to fall on it; the bones were pocked with holes and highly fragile.

She cast a powerful confringo to force back the Death Eaters closing in on her. Where were the others?

Remus and Tonks were fighting back to back. Holding their own but nearly thirty feet away, pinned up against the wall of the house.

Harry was closest to her, furiously battling dozens of Death Eaters. His glasses appeared broken, and it looked like a slicing hex had hit him on the forehead. There was blood streaming down half of his face.

Fred, Charlie and Ron were fighting their way toward him.

Hermione tore her eyes away as the flash of a knife caught the corner of her eye.

She dodged instinctively and grabbed the wrist of her attacker, using their momentum to carry them on and bury the knife into the stomach of another approaching Death Eater.

The wielder snarled with rage and spun to attack her again.

Close proximity wand combat was difficult, trying to get the motion right when she hardly had room to move her wrist.

Simple.

Deadly.

With the tiniest flick, she cast upward. A tiny thread of scarlet bloomed beneath the jaw of the Death Eater before his head toppled off. Blood spurted across Hermioneâ€™s face.

It was in her eyes, and she could taste it as she heard the knife clatter to the ground.Â 

Hermione wiped the blood from her face, spitting, and watched as a huge, unmasked Death Eater grabbed hold of Ron and sank his teeth into Ronâ€™s shoulder.

Harry, Fred, and Charlie all shot stunners, but they bounced off the Death Eater. Werewolf.

Ron was screaming in agony as he tried to wrench himself free. The werewolf jerked his head up, tearing Ronâ€™s shoulder open.

The full moon was a day away. The spell power required to take down a werewolf at that point would be considerable. At least seven more stunners.

Too long for Ron.Â 

Spells to bring down a werewolf; Hermione scrambled to think of one.

She reached deep inside of her magic and hissed, â€œ Carbonescrere .â€

Something in her twisted.

The black curse shot from her wand. It was like a cloud of black smoke that zipped across the field and exploded around the Death Eater. The werewolf froze for a second and collapsed into dust. Ron dropped to the ground.

As Hermione stared, everything inside her went cold and dark.

She stumbled and gripped her chest.

As the world swam back into view, she noticed something moving toward her. She turned, jumping back.

It felt like being punched violently in the ribs.

Hermione gasped, trying to inhale and looked down. There was a knife driven to the hilt in the right side of her chest. If she had turned a split second later, it might have gone into her heart, butâ€”as she studied it with surpriseâ€”she thought it had probably missed anything immediately vital.

Her healer mind couldnâ€™t turn itself off.

Her wand slipped from her fingers, and her hands darted down to close over those of the Death Eater who was still holding it. Stopping him before he could try to twist it, or pull it out and stab her again.

She felt the bones in her left hand crack as she gripped his hands in hers tightly andâ€”without letting herself stop to think how much it might hurt to move with a blade still inside herâ€”drove her knee viciously between his legs.

He crumpled to the ground, his hold on the hilt loosening. Hermione stumbled away, gasping raggedly.

Where had her wand fallen? There was blood in her eyes. She shook her head, trying to clear her vision.

She looked down at her chest again. Her right lung was punctured, and she suspected her liver had been nicked. From the angle she was looking down at it, it was hard to tell.

She saw her wand. She tried to reach for it without bending her torso. As her fingers closed around the handle, she felt someone dig their fingers into her braided hair and drag her up onto her feet until she was dangling in the air, her toes barely touching the ground.

â€œI remember you, Mudblood.â€ Rabastan Lestrange chuckled as he pulled off his Death Eater mask. His eyes dropped down, and he noticed the knife still buried in her chest. â€œLook at that. Someone already got started on you.â€

She tried to curse him, but he batted her wand away. She heard it clatter onto the ground.

Her knife, she needed to reach it.

â€œHow many times do you think I can stab you before the light goes out in your eyes?â€ he asked before he jerked the blade from her chest.

Hermione gave a ragged gasp as she tried to stop him. The right side of her body was suddenly slick with the blood sliding down her torso. Rabastan dragged the blade up her chest until it pressed over her heart.

Hermione tried to wrench her head free as she attempted to pull out her knife without drawing his attention.

He pressed the tip in and hit bone. He shifted the blade until it found a space between her ribs. Hermioneâ€™s eyes widened as she stared up at him.

â€œHere? Or should l start lower?â€ His voice was taunting. He was unconcerned with the fighting around him.

Hermione didnâ€™t know whether to try to reach for her knife or stop him from stabbing her in the heart. Â 

Was there even a point in making a choice? She could feel herself bleeding to death.

He started to push it in slowly.

As the tip of the knife began cutting into her skin, Rabastan stilled. His hold on her hair loosened, and his expression went slack as he dropped dead at her feet. Hermione collapsed with him and caught herself with one hand.

Behind Rabastan, just beyond the anti-apparition point, a masked Death Eater was standing alone in the field.

Several Death Eaters nearby froze and turned with surprise when Rabastan fell.

They were dead before they could raise their wands.

Hermione just stared. She suspected her punctured lung was collapsing. She pressed her hand against the wound to keep herself from haemorrhaging and to prevent air from seeping into her chest cavity.

She watched blankly as the Death Eater who had just appeared began making his way across the field.

It was Draco.

Sheâ€™d never seen him fight, not really. But the style was still familiar.

He was as deadly as sheâ€™d imagined.

The influence of Bellatrix Lestrangeâ€™s training was obvious. The fluidity of movement. The wake of bodies he left behind him as he stalked across the field. Bellatrixâ€™s unpredictable style had been driven by her sadismâ€”her insanity.

Dracoâ€™s style was brutal efficiency.

He wasnâ€™t concerned with maiming or causing pain. He didnâ€™t want prisoners. He killed everyone.

He showed no hesitation as he mowed through the panicking Death Eaters around him. The ways he could conceive of to rapidly kill people was terrifying. It was entirely a numbers game. Minimum effort, high return.

It was impossible that he had ever fought to full potential before. If a Death Eater had ever fought that way before, everyone would have known about it.

He cast a spell on the ground that turned the radius surrounding him into liquid. Fifteen Death Eaters immediately vanished beneath the surface. Screaming. He cancelled it, and left them behind to be suffocated by the earth around them.

He cast curse after curse after curse, most of them nonverbally. The Death Eaters steadily dropped.

He conjured a flock of dozens of silver hummingbirds. Several Death Eaters hesitated, visibly confused. Draco whipped his wand forward, and the tiny birds shot through the air like a hail of bullets, burying themselves into the throats and chests of anyone nearby without a powerful shield. He called the birds back, dripping blood, and shot them off again.

He was within a few feet of Hermione.

He reached out and grabbed her by the left wrist. She gave a low scream as she felt her damaged bones fracture in his grip. He pulled something out of his robes. Holding it high over his head, he activated it.Â 

It was like all the air and sound in the area was suddenly sucked away. Deadly silent. Everyone around them dropped to the ground, gasping and clawing at their throats.

Hermione was screaming in pain and panic. She felt her wrist breaking as she tried to get free. The Death Eaters were gasping silently for air as they suffocated.

â€œHarry! Harry. Ron! Stop. Stop! You canâ€™t kill everyone! Stop, Draco!â€ she was screaming. Their faces were turning blue.

The struggling was coming to an end. The bodies went still.

â€œDraco, stop!â€ She renewed her struggles to tear herself free and felt the bones in her hand shatter. â€œStop!â€

â€œYou idiot,â€ he snarled through his mask, releasing her wrist. â€œWait here.â€

He tossed the dark artifact onto the ground. It sizzled and twisted up into a heap of scrap metal. He stalked over to Harry, Ron, Fred, Charlie, Remus, and Tonks. He performed a reviving spell on each of them followed by a muttered â€œobliviateâ€ before he levitated the unconscious bodies up behind him as he turned back. He summoned her wand up off the ground and dragged her up by the arm.

It was hard to breathe.

Moving was agonising. Her left wrist felt like it was being crucioed. Blood was streaming down her side.

It got harder and harder to breathe as Draco pulled her across the field.

She needed to seal the puncture. As soon as she could find someoneâ€”someone who could perform the spells to keep her from bleeding out. Who could remove the air from her chest cavity.

If she could apparate. If she could apparate to Grimmauld Place.

If she could.

She stumbled. Her head was feeling light, and it was hard to think straight. She tried to breathe but felt as though she couldnâ€™t.

Draco dropped everyone just outside the anti-apparition wards. She moved toward their bodies. She didnâ€™t know what resuscitation spell Draco had used. Before she could take a step, Dracoâ€™s grip tightened and he apparated away with her.

They landed in the shack.

He immediately let go of her and ripped his mask and gloves off. She slumped against the door.

â€œYouâ€”you canâ€™t leave them there,â€ she rasped.

â€œTheyâ€™ll wake in less than a minute,â€ he said, his face twisting with fury.

Kneeling on the ground, he used the tip of his wand to draw a series of runes on the floor. The runes glowed for a moment, and a trapdoor appeared. Jerking it open, he reached down and pulled out what seemed to be an entire hospital worth of healing supplies.

Draco turned to look at her. His face was white with rage.

â€œCan you last long enough for me to get a healer for you?â€ he asked. His voice was shaking.

She shook her head.

â€œYouâ€™ll have to tell me how to do it. Iâ€™ve never used complex healing charms,â€ he said, pulling supplies out.

She dragged herself up from the wall and gave a small gesture toward her right side with her broken wrist.

â€œMy liver. Itâ€™sâ€”where the blood is coming from. I think. Thereâ€™s air in my chest cavity. Itâ€™s collapsing my lung.â€

He conjured a stretcher and helped her down onto it.

She gulped a Blood-Replenishing Potion before she had him cast a diagnostic, so she could confirm the injuries were what she thought.

He had all the necessary potions to help stabilise her and keep her from going into shock.

He was steady-handed. He cut off her clothes and performed the spells to staunch the bleeding and repair the blood vessels and biliary ducts in her liver as it started healing,Â following her instructions carefully. Then he handed her another vial of Blood-Replenishing Potion.

The spell to siphon out the air collapsing her lung was tricky. She had trouble showing him the wand movement. Her hands were still shaking despite the pain relief sheâ€™d taken.

â€œItâ€™s more subtle than that,â€ she tried to explain. â€œJust the faintest sideways shiver of the tip, or it will pull too hard and damage the tissue.â€

Wincing, she put both hands around his and slowly moved his left hand in the necessary motion as she said the incantation in time with each movement.

He got it right on the third try.

â€œAnd then after you repair the lung tissue itâ€™sâ€”just a regular healing charm to fix the diaphragmatic muscle and close the incision,â€ she instructed when she could finally breathe again.â€

She slumped down to recover while he cleaned the blood off her. It was crusted on her face, in her eyelashes.

â€œWhat were you doing there?â€ he asked in a low, shaking voice as she turned and transfigured a piece of dressing into a shirt and started trying to pull it over her head.

â€œHarry asked me come,â€ she said with a small shrug. â€œI told you, we need Ron.â€

â€œYou arenâ€™t experienced in combat,â€ he said. He was pale, and his hands were trembling faintly as he helped her pull the shirt over her head, â€œWhy are they bringing you out again without even giving you a partner?â€

Hermione didnâ€™t look at him. She swallowed and slid her right hand down the sleeve. â€œThey needed a healer. Our other healer lost her foot foraging. I was chosen because I could walk faster.â€

He drew a sharp breath.

â€œYou knew it was a trap,â€ he said. â€œYou knew it. But you went anyway. Rabastanâ€™s prison ambush. No one actually thought the Order would be idiotic enough to fall for it. It was a training simulation for the rookies.â€

â€œHarry was going to go.â€

â€œSo?â€

â€œHarry is the point of this war. If he dies, itâ€™s over. I will always follow him. Strategically, Iâ€™m a casualty we can afford. Harry is not. If I improve his odds at all, itâ€™s worth it,â€ she replied in a steady voice as she twisted gingerly and lifted her broken wrist up to slide down the sleeve.

â€œYou werenâ€™t saving Potter. You were saving Weasley.â€

Hermione twitched her shoulder. â€œRon is critical. Harryâ€”needs Ron. If something happens to Ron, itâ€™ll break him. He needs Ron to want to win.â€

â€œWhat about you? Doesnâ€™t Potter need you?â€ Draco said. His eyes glittered with rage.

Hermione looked away. â€œNot like he needs Ron. Iâ€™mâ€”not like that to him.â€

She swallowed the lump in her throat.

â€œThe Weasleysâ€”,â€œ she started, and then she gave a short sigh. â€œTheyâ€™re his family. Theyâ€™re everything he wants. To win, he has to be able to see himself with them afterward. Thatâ€”is what drives him. If he loses itâ€”stops believing that heâ€™ll get itâ€”he wonâ€™t keep going. He wonâ€™t be able to.â€

â€œI thought you were part of the Trio. Wonâ€™t Potter despair if he loses you?â€

â€œNo,â€ she said, glancing away. â€œHeâ€™d grieve, heâ€™ll be angry. But Iâ€™mâ€”Iâ€™m not emotionally vital. I was never very good atâ€”,â€ her lips twitched, â€œâ€”Ron connects to Harry emotionally. Harry is driven by his emotions.â€

â€œSoâ€”what? Potter drags you into a firefight you have no experience trying to survive because youâ€™re expendable enough?â€

â€œRon comes first. Harry will always take care of him first. He doesnâ€™t think clearly when the people he regards as family are in danger. He doesnâ€™t realise heâ€™s risking others,â€ she said, lifting her chin. â€œHeâ€™s always been that way.â€

Draco stared at her. â€œSo who cares for you, Granger, if Potter doesnâ€™t?â€

She blinked.

â€œI donâ€™t need anyone to care for me,â€ she said stiffly, but her voice shook. â€œIt wasnâ€™t an accident, Draco. I chose to reduce my casualty value.â€

His expression hardened. â€œYou let yourself become expendable to Potter.â€

â€œThe more weaknesses Harry has, the more vulnerable the entire Resistance is.â€

She hadnâ€™t thought Draco could look angrier than he already did, but he suddenly looked ready to explode.

â€œWhen I think I canâ€™t hate Potter more, he finds a new way to prove me wrong,â€ he said, pulling out several more potions and handing them to her.

She tried to pull the corks out with one hand but couldnâ€™t manage it. She was pretty sure if she had to move her left wrist again, she would faint.

â€œWhat happened to your left hand?â€ he abruptly asked, snatching back a vial and unstoppering it for her.

â€œYouâ€”broke it.â€

He seemed to get paler.

â€œIt was already injured,â€ she said in clarification, â€œI got hit by that acid curse. By the time I managed to counter it, the bones were pretty much wrecked. You just happened to grab it.â€

â€œYou should have told me.â€

He reached into his robes and pulled out the kit sheâ€™d given him for Christmas. He snatched the analgesic from its slot, doused a cloth, and wrapped it around her wrist and hand.

Hermione nearly gasped with relief as the burning subsided.

â€œDo you need me to remove the bones?â€ he asked after a moment as he watched her cradle her wrist against her chest.

She looked up at him. â€œCould you? Iâ€”I was going to do it myself, when I got a chance.â€

Removing bones with precision, especially shards, was a painful process. Unless she wanted to regrow her whole arm, it was going to be a slow ordeal that would be difficult to remain focused and steady-handed throughout. Sheâ€™d planned to deal with it after she went back to check on Ron.

â€œI know the spellwork. Do you want me to stun you?â€ he asked.

â€œN-no. I should stay awake, unless you already know all the names of the bones in the hand and wrist.â€

â€œNo,â€ he said, glancing away, his mouth pressed into a hard line.

Â Unwrapping her hand again, she cast a diagnostic spell over it and surveyed the damage. Aside from the deep pockets the acid had burned into the flesh, there were four bones that had been crushed and another six with varying levels of corrosion, including her ulna. Sheâ€™d have to debone half her forearm.

She stared at it for several minutes before drawing a sharp breath and looking away.

â€œThe fifth metacarpal first. Quinque metacarpus.â€

â€œQuinque metacarpus ossios dispersimus.â€

The sharp stabbing pain as the bone in Hermioneâ€™s hand abruptly vanished nearly made her scream. She dropped her head against Dracoâ€™s shoulder and shuddered.

Pain without the adrenaline surge of battle was harder to handle.

â€œThen the hamate. Os hamatum.â€ She shivered against his shoulder, trying to brace herself.

She was crying into his robes by the time he had removed all the bone shards. Half her forearm and most of her palm were largely boneless and lay puddled in her lap.

Draco pulled a bottle of skele-gro out. She gagged it down and then winced as the stabbing, needle-like sensation of the regrowing bones enveloped her arm.

He poured Essence of Dittany across her entire arm to repair the pockets of corroded tissue. She was tempted to scream at him.

â€œDonâ€™t!â€ She tried to grab the vial away from him. â€œItâ€™s a waste. I can heal them with spellwork after the bones regrow.â€

Â He glared at her. â€œShut up.â€

Â She fell silent while he doused her arm a second time and then rummaged through more materials from his supplies and assembled a magical cast with surprising efficiency.

â€œWhy do you have all this?â€ she asked, surveying all the supplies as he wrapped the frame around her hand and up around her elbow, so that the bones could regrow straight.

â€œI got it for you,â€ he said. She stared at him in surprise. â€œAfter Hampshire, I was worried youâ€™d show up injured again. I thought if I had everything you might need on hand, Iâ€™d worry less.â€

Hermioneâ€™s heart hurt inside her chest as he helped her get the sling of the cast up over her head.

Â â€œButâ€”this is a lot. This is practically a casualty wardâ€™s entire inventory list.â€

He raised an eyebrow. â€œI didnâ€™t know what kinds of things were crucial for casualty healing at the time. I researched it. Then I got a long lecture on healing common battle injuries as a Christmas present last year. It helped me round it out with anything Iâ€™d missed.â€

Hermione blushed.

â€œYou could become a healer,â€ she told him. â€œYou have a natural talent for it.â€

The corner of his mouth twitched faintly. â€œThatâ€™s one of the most ironic things anyone has ever said to me,â€ he said.

The conversation stalled.

â€œI have to get back. Ronâ€™s injured. And Harry too,â€ she said in a soft voice as she moved to stand.

Draco stood up, his eyes growing cold. â€œDonâ€™t ever go on another mission.â€

â€œThatâ€™s not your call,â€ she said, meeting his eyes.

He paled and his jaw tensed. â€œRemind Moody if the Order wants my continued assistance, they will keep you alive.â€

Hermione stilled, and her mouth twisted as she looked away from him. â€œYou are doing this for your mother, Draco.â€

He turned her firmly by the shoulders and stared down at her.

â€œShe is dead,â€ he said. â€œYou are not. My loyalty was to those least responsible for her suffering. However, if the Order has decided youâ€™re an affordable casualty and sends you out to be mowed down as battle fodder, I will not be noble. I have no compunction against exacting dual revenge. I will make Potter pay if he gets you killed.â€

Hermione froze.

This was dangerous.

She hadnâ€™t factored for this risk. She knew that Dracoâ€™s loyalty wasnâ€™t based on ideology; it was purely a sense of personal loyalty. He hated Harry, he just hated Voldemort more. Hermioneâ€™s careless, emotional confession had just given him grounds to waver. He was possessive. She was his. Harry had endangered her.

She should have felt panicked. She should have been cold. She should have reminded him of his Vow. Reminded him that she would always choose the Order first until they won. If he wanted her, he would have to wait.

Â It was what she should do.

She stared up at him, and her shoulders shook. She was so tired. Life had been cold for such a long time.

Her fingers twitched. She almost reached for him.

Then she slowly curled her hand into a fist and slid it behind her back. â€œDonâ€™tâ€”donâ€™t do this, Draco.â€ Her voice broke.

â€œYou are not expendable,â€ he said in a low, desperate voice. â€œYou donâ€™t get to push everyone away so that theyâ€™ll feel comfortable with using you and letting you die.â€

Hermioneâ€™s hand was shaking, and her throat felt as though there were a stone lodged inside it. She dropped her head and drew a deep breath.

Ron is hurt. And Harry.

She steeled herself and tried to twist free.

â€œThis is war. Itâ€™s not some sort of tragic self-condemnation to be expendable. Itâ€™s a strategic liability not to be. I would've thought youâ€™d have realised it was the case with me. A healer isnâ€™t going to win the war; thatâ€™s why I was available to trade. I even have a replacement in the hospital ward nowâ€”because of you. I had to train her.â€ She gave a bitter laugh. â€œYou did this to me. You made me as expendable as I am.â€ She choked back a sob. â€œAnd you didnâ€™t even want me either.â€

He flinched and his hold loosened.

â€œI have to go now.â€ Her voice shook as she stepped away.

Draco caught her by her right arm and pulled her back.

â€œYou are not replaceable,â€ he said. His hands were shaking as he gripped her. â€œYou are not required to make your death convenient. You are allowed to be important to people. The reason I took that fucking Vow was to keep you alive. To keep you safe.â€

She tried to pull away from him, but he wouldnâ€™t let go. She twisted, trying to get away. She had to go, because he kept staring at her with desperation written across his face, and it was breaking her inside.

She sobbed andâ€”before she had time to thinkâ€”twisted the fingers of her right hand into his robes, pulled him closer, and kissed him.

Flashback 28

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

March 2003

Draco cradled her face in his hands as he returned her kiss, carefully pulling her closer without hurting her left arm. She was half-crying as she kissed him.

She traced her fingers along his neck and pulled at the curve of his jaw to draw him closer. Trying to memorise every detail of him: the scent of the forest and papyrus scrolls, his pulse under her fingertips, his lips pressed against hers, the taste of him.

She had earned this. She pressed her cheek against his hand as his lips caressed hers.

After several minutes, she wrenched herself away.

â€œI have to go,â€ she said.

He didnâ€™t try to stop her, but he reached for her again before catching himself. He stared at her and drew a sharp breath through his teeth.

â€œCome back. Come back to meâ€”if you ever need anything,â€ he finally said, pulling his hand back.

Hermione stared at him and wanted to say she would. She forced herself to swallow the words.

â€œI have to go,â€ she repeated, forcing herself to step away.

He stood, watching her leave.

She took a steadying breath and apparated back to the Tonks house.

â€œWhat are your parents' names?â€ he asked.

â€œWendell and Monica Wilkins, they live in Australia,â€ she answered, meeting his eyes steadily.

â€œGood Merlin, we thought we lost you. You werenâ€™t there when we woke up.â€

â€œIâ€”I was hemorrhaging. I couldnâ€™t wait. I had to find someone who could fix it,â€ she said by way of vague explanation.

â€œHis shoulderâ€™s pretty bad.â€

â€œWell. You wonâ€™t hear any complaints from me. After what happened to George, I say we kill the bastards. Harryâ€™s a bit freaked over it. â€œA third-party Moody put me in contact with,â€ she said without looking up.

â€œHarryâ€¦,â€ she said in a low voice. â€œI need you to give me a hand. I canâ€™t manage Ronâ€™s dressing with just one. I need you to maintain the tension as I wrap it in order to keep the dittany in place.â€

â€œEveryone who wins say they were good, but theyâ€™re the ones who write the history. I havenâ€™t seen anything indicating that it was actually moral superiority that made a difference,â€ she said as she murmured the spells to repair the fractures.

He sounded on the verge of tears. His eyes were so hurt and angry as he stared at her. She felt herself waver.

Hermione sat for several minutes, trying to muster up the energy to climb back across the roof.

She found an armchair and curled up in it, so tired that even the stabbing pain of her arm couldnâ€™t keep her from sleeping.

When she jerked awake hours later, she felt icy. She was freezing cold, to the point that her teeth were chattering. It had been early afternoon when sheâ€™d fallen asleep, but the house had grown dark and quiet.

She shuddered with cold, grasped for her wand, and cast a warming charm on herself. It didnâ€™t provide her with any relief from the iciness she felt.

She feltâ€”watched. As though there were something in the darkness staring at her.

At the base of her spine, and climbing slowly upward like icy tendrils, was a sense of dull pain. Like she was being infected with something that was trying to numb her as it crept through her system.

Her hand was shaking as she cast a diagnostic on herself. She must have overlooked a curse.

There was nothing.

The painful, icy sensation felt like it was spreading. Â Blooming through her body into her sternum and across her chest until breathing felt painful.

It was terrifying and awful but there was also a sort of draw to surrender. Pain for relief. Like sitting in the kitchen, cutting lines until it hurt more than everything else did.

Pain like liberation. Like the taste of blood.

She stood sharply.

It was the aftereffects of the Dark Magic she had used. Self-destructive tendencies. Hallucinations.

Now as she thought about it, the sensations were familiar.

Tonks had been right. She should be with someone. Someone who would help her hold on.

She stumbled down the stairs. It was the middle of the night. She made her way to the room Charlie had been in. They barely got on together, but heâ€™d let her hold his hand. She was so cold. He could talk to her and help her keep focusedâ€”

Empty.

She checked Fredâ€™s. Empty.

She moved on.

Ron was asleep. Moaning in pain. She poured a Dreamless Sleep draught down his throat. As she watched him settle, she pulled out a potion to help reset the ligaments and tendons in her hand and swallowed it.

Harry was asleep in the chair next to Ron. Harry hadnâ€™t slept since Ronâ€™s capture. Remus had the full moon the next night; Tonks would be with him.

She wandered back out of the room and wondered what to do.

The coldness swallowing her was so painful it hurt to even breathe. She wavered and nearly let herself sink into it.

â€œCome back to meâ€”if you ever need anything.â€

She forced herself out the front door and apparated to Whitecroft.

She stepped toward the door, and her fingers grazed the knob, then she froze. The lights were out.

Of courseâ€”he wouldnâ€™t be there. It was just a rendezvous point. He didnâ€™t live there. It had been hours since sheâ€™d left. He was probably asleep. Somewhere with a bed.

Or he could be busy.

She wasnâ€™t supposed to call him unless it was an emergency. Sheâ€™d promised she wouldnâ€™t. She had given him her word.

She didnâ€™t get to call him because sheâ€™d had a bad day.

Sheâ€™d risk his coverâ€”compromise himâ€”endanger the Order.

She jerked her hand back and turned away.Â 

If she could apparate againâ€”there was always someone awake at a Grimmauld Place. She gripped her wand and closed her eyes.

It felt like something grabbed hold of her head. Her knees buckled. Everything vanished.Â 

When the world slowly swam back into focus, she realized she was lying on her back. She stared up at the sky. The stars glittered overhead, dimmed by the moon. Cold.

The day has been so long.

Her skin was crawling. Hurting. Like there was something inside her. In her magic. She wanted to slice it out. If she could just find the spot. She could carve it out with one of her knivesâ€”-so it would stopâ€”stop crawling inside her.

She dug her fingers into her chest and pulled at it.

â€œGrangerâ€”what did you do to yourself?â€

She became conscious of being lifted off the ground. Hot hands closing around her body, driving away the cold. She was so cold. She burrowed into the heat.

She was delirious, because Draco was there, dressed in Muggle clothing. She had never seen him in anything but black robes.Â 

She pressed herself against him, and he felt like a furnace, driving away the crawling, creeping cold inside her.

â€œI killed people today,â€ she said, burying her face in his shirt. Even dressed as a Muggle, he somehow smelled the same. â€œI never killed anyone before. But I didnâ€™t even keep count of how many people I killed today.â€

His arms closed around her back.

â€œTonks saidâ€”the Dark Magic I used today, I shouldnâ€™t be alone. Butâ€”there wasnâ€™t anyone to go to. Everyone else already has someoneâ€”someone they go to afterâ€”â€

â€œBut you donâ€™t.â€

She nodded.

â€œWhat spell did you use?â€ Draco was asking. â€œWhat Dark Magic?â€

â€œI carbonised a werewolf. It was mauling Ron. The day before the full moon, stunners would take so long.â€

She was having her first hallucination in her life. She was possibly dying. Draco was as hot as a furnace and wearing a light grey hoodie that said Oxford on it andâ€”jeans?

It was almost funny how ridiculous it was. She wanted to laugh as she took it in.

â€œNo wonder youâ€™re cold,â€ he muttered.

She felt the pop of apparition, and, looking dazedly around, she found herself in a lavish Muggle hotel suite.

She was bewildered. Of course, hallucinating as a rule made no sense. But this was just bizarre. She stared up at Draco.

â€œDo you think this is what my subconscious thinks I want?â€ she asked. â€œTo be with you in the Muggle world?â€œ

His expression was unreadable.

â€œWhat do you want?â€

Tears welled up in her eyes as she stared at him.

â€œI donâ€™t want to always be alone,â€ she choked out. â€œI want to love someone without feeling like if they know, itâ€™ll end up hurting them. Harry was my first friend. I always wanted friendsâ€”but I was always too odd, too bookish, too awkward. I was always alone. No one wanted to be my real friend. Harry was the first person who let me be his friend. I thought we would always be friends. But nowâ€”I have to push him away to protect him. And Ron. And myâ€”my parents. And nowâ€”thereâ€™s nobody. I have to love everyone from a distance. And Iâ€™m so lonelyâ€”â€ She sobbed into her hand.

â€œWhat happened to your parents?â€

Flashback 29

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

March 2003

Â 

When she woke in the morning, she found that she really was in a hotel with Draco. It was so surprising she thought perhaps she was still hallucinating.

She glanced about the room, trying to wrap her mind around it. She wasnâ€™t dreaming; she was really, actually in a Muggle hotel suite with Draco. A suite that he apparently occupied while wearing an Oxford hoodie.

If she were still composing a psychological sketch of him, the revelation would have required her to start a whole new notebook. Why was he there? Was it something he did often? Why on earth would he be spending the night in the Muggle world?

She turned her head to look at him.

He was asleep, wrapped possessively around her as though he were keeping her from being stolen. His body was so warm against hers it was almost searing.

As she studied him in bewilderment, the full events of the night came back to her.

She flinched.

She shouldnâ€™t have come.

She shouldnâ€™t have come, and she shouldnâ€™t have stayed.

It had been a mistake.

He was like a dragon. The jealous way he hoarded the things he cared aboutâ€”there was no moderation in it. He was possessive and deadly. He held her in his arms like she was his.

The temptation to give into it, to let him have her and to love him for itâ€”it terrified her.

Her need to love people and the desperate desire for them to love her backâ€”she had locked it away. Acceded its place to the coldness of logic, realism, and strategic decisions for the sake of the war. Sheâ€™d shoved it down into a hole where she wouldnâ€™t feel it. Wouldnâ€™t miss it.

But Draco had dragged it up from the well where sheâ€™d hidden it, uncovered it, and set himself to picking the lock. She could almost feel his fingers turning the dial, listening to the drop of every tumbler. Lying in wait for a way in. Â 

His own grief and loneliness, his attention and unwavering constance, and that way he looked at her, the way he touched her; it was slipping through her defenses and coiling around her heart as surely as she had wound around his.

She tried to slide out of the bed before he woke, but his eyes snapped open the instant she shifted. His hold on her tightened, and he pulled her back toward himself for a moment before his expression flickered, and he let her go.

She stilled and looked up at him.

The sense of terror he had inspired in her a year ago had faded entirely. The danger of himâ€”it was still there, cast in even sharper relief now that she had seen how ruthlessly he could kill. But despite realising just how merciless he could be, it made her feel less frightened of him.

Now she knew how much he was holding back. Despite the heights to which he had vaulted himself within Voldemortâ€™s army, he was holding himself back. Wiping out an entire squadron of Death Eaters had barely required effort. He had arrived and killed nearly a hundred people in a matter of minutes.

She studied his face, and he stared back at her. His expression was shuttered. Whatever he might be feeling was carefully concealed. But his eyesâ€”

The way he looked at her was enough to stop her heart.

â€œI shouldnâ€™t have come,â€ she finally said.

â€œYou needed someone. I just happened to be available. You donâ€™t need to worry, itâ€™s not going to complicate things for you,â€ he said, looking away from her, his fingers playing lightly along her wrist. â€œI didnâ€™t expect it to change anything.â€

She felt a hand close around her wrist.

â€œGood god, Granger, your friends have fucked you over. Iâ€™m not angry with you.â€ He pulled her back across the bed. His expression was hard as he dragged her back toward himself. â€œAnd if I were, I would get over it. Butâ€”you didnâ€™t tell me what youâ€™d done. I thought I was dying. Then I thought I was going mad. It didnâ€™t occur to me until December that youâ€™d permanently healed me. It wasnâ€™t something I anticipated. Iâ€™m still coming to terms with it. Do you really walk through life expecting everyone you save to punish you for it?â€

Hermione flinched. â€œItâ€™s easier to anticipate it than to be caught by surprise.â€

â€œDo not presume it with me.â€ His expression was hard as marble.

Hermione gave a tight defensive laugh and pulled away from him with a sharp jerk. â€œWhy not? You do it better than anyone.â€

Her mouth twisted as she stared at him. â€œAfter all, the first time I healed you, you came back the next week and hexed me again and again until I looked as though Iâ€™d been whipped. When I didnâ€™t want to curse you when you were injured, you threw Colin Creeveyâ€™s death in my face. After you kissed me while you were drunk, you left and I didnâ€™t see you for nearly two months. After I healed you in December, you grabbed me by the throat and stared in my eyes as you reminded me that youâ€™d made me a whoreâ€”just because you could. Thenâ€”,â€ her voice cracked, and her head dropped as she turned away from him, â€œâ€”after I went and told the Order youâ€™d agreed to take an Unbreakable Vow and begged them not to kill you, you told me you couldnâ€™t stand to look at me because being sworn to me was worse than being a Death Eater. That was four days ago. Why shouldnâ€™t I assume you wonâ€™t eventually decide to punish me for this too? You always do.â€

She sat on the edge of the bed with her back to him and gave a low sob. â€œIâ€™m not blind to the failures of my friends. But you have no room to claim your treatment of me has been superior in some way. Youâ€”youâ€™re all the same.â€

Draco was silent.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ he finally said.

Hermione gave a low, mirthless laugh. â€œYes, they all apologise at some point too. Harryâ€”Harry was very apologetic yesterday after I went back to the safe house. Draco drew a sharp breath. â€œI am sorry.â€

Hermione just stared at the floor without responding.

â€œI never expected youâ€”anyone like you,â€ Draco said after a minute. â€œI knew what you were doing, but youâ€™d look me in the eye and do it anyway. When Iâ€™d feel it work, Iâ€™d do whatever I could to make you stop. From the moment you walked into my safe house, I expected youâ€™d eventually be the one to sell me out; I expected you to know that. But instead you acted as though I were redeemable. You acted as if you were going to be owned by me for the rest of your life, and you were just determined to live with it if it saved your Order. I didnâ€™t realise they wouldnâ€™t tell you.â€

Hermione bit her lip. â€œI think they must not have thought Iâ€™d play my part well enoughâ€”if I knew.â€

She swallowed, her mouth twisting as she tried to tamp down on the overwhelming sense of hurt and betrayal she felt toward everyone she had done the most to protect.

â€œI thought there would be a point when I was cruel enough, and youâ€™d stop. I assumed youâ€™d have a limit. I figured that once I found it, youâ€™dâ€”youâ€™d stop emotionally blindsiding me.â€ He gave a low sigh. â€œI spent a long time assuming youâ€™d be the one whoâ€™d get me killed in the end. Hermione stared out the window at the Thames below.

â€œWeâ€™re a fucked up pair,â€ she said, the corner of her mouth lifting. â€œI canâ€™t believe it ended up like this. I did want to kill you the first time I saw you. His eyes were dark as he interlaced his fingers with hers and pulled her slowly back toward himself; until she was in his arms, their bodies pressed against each other. He kissed her. He kissed her, and she kissed him.

Life was not cold.

He drew his head back and kissed her forehead, sliding his hands along her shoulders and caressing her throat in a way that had grown familiar. He kissed between her eyes. â€œYouâ€™re a better person than I am.â€

She lifted her hand up to catch his jaw in her palm. She felt as though she couldnâ€™t possibly touch him enough.

â€œI never had to go as far. Like you said, I still had space to be naive. Even though I knew some of what was happening, it didnâ€™t occur to me how far the Order would go. He turned her face up toward his. â€œYou keep people alive. You look at them, and you try to keep all of them alive. That is considerably more difficult than calculating all the ways you can use them or kill them. I imagine it costs you more too.â€

The corner of her mouth quirked sadly, and she looked down. Draco rested his forehead against hers, and she closed her eyes. It felt as though their souls were touching.

She turned her head until his nose brushed against hers, and she tilted her chin up so that their lips met.

She wanted to spend the rest of her life lost in that moment.

She drew back reluctantly. â€œI have to go. Iâ€™m sure the Order is waiting for an explanation.â€

Draco didnâ€™t let go. â€œYou should eat.â€

â€œI have to go,â€ Hermione said, shaking her head.

His fingers twitched as his hold tightened. â€œTake a shower. Iâ€™ll order you something. Any preferences?â€

â€œDraco,â€ she took hold of his wrist and firmly pulled his hand off of her. â€œYou canâ€™t keep me here. I have to go.â€

His expression flickered briefly. Just enough to reveal a shard of possessiveness and something ravenous and desperate that she couldnâ€™t quite place. Then it all vanished as he withdrew his hands and let her stand.

His expression was cold and closed, but his eyes burned.

Hermione reached out and touched his face, tilting his head back. She pressed a kiss on his forehead.

â€œIâ€™ll take you up on that shower.â€ She pulled the flat sheet off the bed and wrapped it around herself as she gathered her clothes off the floor. She could feel Dracoâ€™s gaze as she crossed the room.

The bathroom had an enormous claw foot tub that Hermione gazed longingly at before stepping into the shower. The unmistakable scent of sex hung around her, and she still had traces of blood on her from the previous day. Not all of it was hers. She could feel it in her hair as she started to wash it.

She scrubbed herself rapidly from head to toe before stepping out and drying off. She glanced in the mirror. The bathroom was brightly, almost starkly lit. Designed for women who applied make-up meticulously and wanted to be able to inspect their every pore. Hermione stared at herself in the mirror, clutching the towel against herself.

Grimmauld Placeâ€™s poor lighting was much kinder to her. She barely recognised the person in the reflection.

As she was staring, Draco came and stood at the door. Heâ€™d pulled a pair of trousers on.

â€œYouâ€™re right, I do look like a corpse,â€ she said after another moment.

The hollows of his cheeks flushed, and his eyes dropped to the floor. â€œYou should eat more.â€

She shrugged. â€œItâ€™s stress. Itâ€™s not like they donâ€™t feed me. Iâ€™ll eat again when I can sleep again.â€ She looked over at him with a critical eye. â€œYouâ€™re not exactly sporting a healthy body weight yourself.â€

He looked down at himself and then back up at her, arching an eyebrow. â€œWho do you think causes my stress? You are a nightmare to worry about.â€

She glanced away, her throat tightening slightly as she started to scourgify her clothes. â€œIâ€”do actually have a foraging partner now.â€

â€œThe Patil who lost her foot. The one you trained.â€

Hermione looked up and stared at him in the mirror. â€œHow did you know?â€

He met her eyes coolly. â€œI pay attention to any reports regarding the Orderâ€™s healers. You are remarkably invisible, but Patil is a familiar face in the Resistance. Friendly. And quite talkative. Small details here and there. They add up.â€ He was expressionless. â€œIâ€™m a legilimens. Iâ€™m often the one who pulls that information out.â€

Hermioneâ€™s throat tightened. â€œWhy did you train me then? If you knew?â€

He gave a thin smile and tilted his head to the side. â€œWhen did that start, mid-October? You still went alone too, to maintain your cover. I wanted you to live. After I died, I wanted you to still be alive. I could have just demanded you have a partner. It wouldnâ€™t have been unreasonable, given my terms. But Shacklebolt or Moody wonâ€™t meet my terms once Iâ€™m gone.â€ His expression grew vicious. â€œAs you said yourself: if they sold you once, what would stop them from doing it again? There was a tearing sensation in Hermioneâ€™s stomach, and she looked away. â€œTheyâ€˜re notâ€”theyâ€™re not monsters. They have so few options. They have to work with what they have. â€œI donâ€™t care about the Resistance,â€ he said sneering.

â€œWell, I do.â€ Hermione didnâ€™t waver. She met his eyes as she said it. â€œI care about all of them. I will always care about them.â€

â€œThey donâ€™t even know who you are.â€ His tone was venomous. â€œYouâ€™re a faceless figure in their pain. They love their nurses, the hospice healers, Pomfrey, Patil. Hermione shrugged and pulled her clothes on. She was not accustomed to being naked, not around anyone. Once her shirt and trousers were on, she began braiding her hair with practiced ease.

Draco remained standing in the doorway. She could almost feel the resentment radiating from him as he watched her prepare to leave.

â€œI didnâ€™t do anything Iâ€™ve done because I expected to be seen as heroic.â€ She scoffed. â€œI donâ€™t require laurels. She met Dracoâ€™s eyes in the reflection of the mirror. â€œI will never be a hero. I knew that when I chose to train as a healer. Thatâ€™s never been the reason for any of my choices.â€

She finished one braid and started on the other.

â€œPotter is worth that much to you?â€

The corner of her mouth quirked. â€œIt's more than that. Harry is my best friend, but the war is bigger than Harry or anyone else.â€

Her hands stilled, and she stood silent for a moment.

â€œI wantâ€”,â€ she started and then paused and drew a short breath. â€œI want the next Muggle-born witch with stars in her eyes to come into a world that welcomes her. Flashback 30

See the end of the chapter for notes

March 2003

Â 

Hermione apparated to Grimmauld Place. Her protean charm bracelet had not burned for the entire day; she assumed it meant that she was not urgently required anywhere.

â€œHail the conquering hero!â€ Angelina shouted as Hermione hurried past the sitting room. Hermione paused awkwardly while Angelina jumped up from her seat, and Angelina, Katie, Parvati, Susan, Neville, Dean and Seamus all crowded around, patting Hermione admiringly on the shoulders.

â€I can't believe you went on a mission again.â€

â€œI nearly slapped Fred when I found out he went without me.â€

â€œFuckinâ€™ unbelievable the lot of you got Ron back.â€

â€œMoody and Kingsley are pissed,â€ Neville said, giving her a serious look. â€œKingsley spent ten minutes yelling at Remus when he came to report about the mission.â€

Hermione nodded, cringing inwardly. â€œI need to go report. Where is he?â€

â€œWar room.â€

Hermione nodded. â€œAlright. Thanks everyone. It wasâ€”,â€ she grasped for something positive sounding to say, â€œâ€”quite a thrill being in the field again. Iâ€™m just glad we got Ron back.â€

Kingsley was standing over a table covered with scrolls. Hermione stopped at the door and waited for him to look up.

â€œYouâ€™re back then?â€

â€œIâ€™m back. I needed some recovery time.â€

â€œWill I finally get a version of events that doesnâ€™t involve a deathtrap in which everyone but the intended victims somehow died?â€ Kingsley looked up, and Hermione could see the rage in his expression. He whipped his wand out and cast a privacy charm over the room.

Hermione stepped in and pushed the door shut behind her, leaning back against the frame. â€œI couldnâ€™t send word. I didnâ€™t know the location or anything else concrete. â€œThe information Harry had came from Snatchers. I tried to warn him it was a trap, but he was going to go. I considered revealing Malfoy, but I didnâ€™t think it would stop them. â€œIt was a trap.â€

â€œAnd then?â€

â€œWe were outnumbered. I donâ€™t think many of the Death Eaters there were experienced in combat. Draco said it was mostly trainees. But there was a werewolf, and the numbers were absurd.â€

â€œHe killed at least a third of them dueling. Then heâ€”he had some kind of vacuum curse contained in an artifact. He came across the field and activated it once he had hold of me. â€œWhat happened to you?â€ Kingsley was studying her carefully; his eyes landed on her scarred wrist.

â€œI am already aware of that.â€ Kingsleyâ€™s voice was hard. â€œYou will not ever go on another mission; I donâ€™t care if someone asks you to go save Harry himself. You will not forage. Hermione drew a short breath and felt rebellious rage burn across her chest. She glared at him for several seconds before she forced her occlumency walls into place and swallowed all she wanted to spit at him.

â€œWeâ€™re dealing with a larger situation. He was tagged. Thereâ€™s a trace on his right wrist that we canâ€™t remove.â€

â€œWell, thatâ€™s notâ€”it could be worse,â€ Charlie said after a minute. â€œSnape can get it off then. Or one of our prisoners. A few of them are marked, right?â€

â€œI can remove Ron Weasleyâ€™s, but when I do, Sussex will know, and the next shackle they release may require a more elaborate mechanism.â€ Severus sneered contemptuously at Charlie.

â€œWell, shouldnâ€™t Snape know? Since he works there? I thought that was the whole reason we kept him.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll take a team to the Tonks cottage and get the shackle off Ron.â€ Kingsley rolled up the scroll of information Severus had brought and handed it to Hermione and Fleur to look over. â€œAccording to Alastor, the Death Eaters only have a vague idea of where the cottage is at this point. Hermione gave a short nod and headed to her potion cabinet, leaving the rest of the Order to strategise and debate the remaining logistics for the mission.

Hermione readied the potions and watched a roomful of people transform into her best friend before disillusioning themselves and departing Grimmauld Place.

The waiting was the worst. Hermione stood in the foyer and watched the hands on the clock journey slowly across its face.

She hated waiting.

Kingsley and Moody, Harry, Ron, Severus, and most of the Weasleys and the Order. They were all at the Tonks cottage. Hermione was left behind. Maybe Draco was there, trapped between maintaining his cover and preserving the Order.

Anything could be happening.

Growing up, she would never have thought sheâ€™d be the kind of person whoâ€™d ever agree to be left behind when others were fighting. Gryffindor. Sheâ€™d thought bravery would always place her at the front lines.

Pragmatism had stolen away any lustre of heroism from her.

She pressed her hand against the window and stared out at the dimming street. The full moon would be out in half an hour.

The clock continued to measure out the relentless passage of time.

She braced herself with occlumency. She gathered up all her recent memories, sorted them neatly, and then pushed them away until her mind was clear.

The Death Eaters waiting at the Tonks cottage were not trainees. Fred stumbled through the door with his hand pressed to the side of his head. His ear had been sliced off by a curse. Moody returned with an arm and shoulder so badly maimed that Hermione initially feared heâ€™d lose it. Remus was in the process of transforming when Tonks burst through the door and dragged him down into the basement.

Two Harrys came through the door a few minutes later. One was groaning and leaning heavily on the other.

â€œCome on, Ron. Weâ€™re here. Someone, get him a pain potion!â€ the real Harry said, half-falling as he dragged the Harry-who-was-Ron further into the foyer.

Hermione dropped next to them and whipped out her wand. Ron was burning up and only half lucid. The combination of latent lycanthropy and the full moon had him writhing in agony.

â€œFuck!! Fucking hell.â€ Ron was sobbing as he arched backward until it looked like his spine would snap. â€œMake it stop. Make it stop!!!â€

He buried his nails in his shoulder, clawing at himself. Harry struggled to pin Ronâ€™s arms down and prevent him from maiming himself.

Ronâ€™s arms, legs, and body kept rippling and snapping as the polyjuice wore off. Even once his features re-emerged, the popping and rippling of his body didnâ€™t cease. The bones in his shoulders and arms keep breaking and stretching and then snapping back into place. His fingers were curled into claws, and he dragged them through the hardwood floor, screaming, tearing his nails off. Snarling in agony as his body fought against the partial transformation.

Hermione and Harry both shot stunners at his head. Ron barely flinched. He whirled and swiped at Hermioneâ€™s throat, but she cast a shield a moment before he struck.

â€œStun him! Everyone stun him!â€

Hermione scrambled back as quickly as she could as Ron twisted and lurched and lunged again.

It took ten stunners to knock him out.

Hermione sat in the middle of the floor, panting, as Neville and Seamus and several others took Ronâ€™s unconscious body down into the basement.

Harry was on the floor beside her, gripping her hand so tightly she thought the bones might crack.

â€œI didnâ€™t know. I didnâ€™t know it would be like that.â€ Harry sounded lost.

Hermione looked down at their hands. â€œIt canâ€™t get out. The wolf canâ€™t get out.â€ She stared at the blood and gouges on the floor. â€œWe may need to discuss having Remus actually bite him.â€

They were still sitting on the floor together when Kingsley came through the door, looking weary.

â€œWe lost at least three,â€ Kingsley said. â€œWe wonâ€™t know who until everyone has reported back.â€

Sturgis Podmore, Susan Bones, and five other Resistance fighters failed to return to Grimmauld Place. They were presumed dead.

It was easier to hope for their deaths than fear theyâ€™d been captured.

Hermione ran into Tonks after the Order debriefing. Their eyes met and Hermione studied Tonks' expression. The concern and suspicion that had been visible the day before had vanished.

Moody or Kingsley had obliviated her before sheâ€™d left the cottage.

Hermione lay in bed that night, staring up at the ceiling. Kingsley had brought back a classified scroll of analysis on the shackle removed from Ron. They couldnâ€™t bring the shackle back without bringing the trace.

Hermione had done a preliminary study of the magic. It was solid spellwork. The shackle was made of tungsten, strong but magically conductive. The spell detail for how the shackle recognized a caster as bearing a Dark Mark was based on an ingeniously complex arithmantical formula and a charmwork technique Hermione had never encountered before.

She turned the information over and over in her mind and didnâ€™t know what to do. The information was already partly obsolete. The next shackle would be updated. More difficult or even impossible for the Order to remove.

Even if she found a fault to exploit, the Order wouldnâ€™t necessarily be able to take advantage of it. Theyâ€™d have to decide whether to sit on the information until a vital point, or use it immediately. Any flaw they exploited would result in Sussex redesigning the shackles again.

It was like the Enigma code; if the Order managed to break through the enchantments, it would only result in the Death Eaters perfecting it more quickly.

She rolled onto her side and wondered if the shackles would have been invented if Draco hadnâ€™t enabled the Order to stage so many prison break-ins; if the Order hadnâ€™t made such an elaborate attack in June and destroyed the original curse division.

Was it inevitable? Or had they caused it? If they hadnâ€™t, would there have been any other way for the Resistance to have lasted so long? Or would the war have already ended?

She didnâ€™t know.

She looked at the scroll of analysis again and then stared out the window at the full moon. Luminous, cold silver. She had loved the moon as a child. The monthly evolution and subtle beauty had always entranced her. Since meeting Remus in third year, the moon had grown tragic and ominous. Its beauty a harbinger of pain.

Ron would grow to hate the moon.

She wrapped her hands around her mug and felt the heat seep into her hands.

She felt cold. On the outside. On the inside. She felt cold.

She would always feel cold now. There would always be a trace of it in her.

She laid her head on the table and traced grain of the wood under her fingertips. She missed Draco. She wanted to touch him. She wanted to bury herself in his arms and forget her whole life.

The war had eaten her until she felt as though there were only the meagrest shreds left. As though its claws had sunk into her chest, and she could no more tear herself free than she could rip out her lungs and expect to survive. With Draco, she felt alive. Like she was breathing again after years of forgetting how to do anything but survive.

She held the mug tighter until the heat began to fade.

She didnâ€™t even know how to contact him. Not unless it was on behalf of the Order. Sheâ€™d given him her word that she wouldnâ€™t summon him otherwise.

She spun the ring around her finger.

She wondered if heâ€™d been at the Tonks cottage. If heâ€™d been injured or injured anyone.

She started slightly and made a mental note. Heâ€™d used his analgesic potion on her wrist. Even if he could replace everything else, it was unlikely that Severus had shared that potion with the Death Eater army. Sheâ€™d have to take him a replacement vial when she saw him again.

She also needed more fluxweed. She began cataloguing places sheâ€™d be able to find it growing. Then she paused, her heart sinking.

No more foraging.

Hermione bit her lip and looked down at her hands. Foraging had been hers. It had been terrifying and dangerous, but it had been hers. A chance to escape Grimmauld Place for a few hours; to feel the wind on her face and the cold of the early morning dew on her hands; to notice the seasons slowly emerging.

She looked wistfully out the window of Grimmauld Place.

She felt like bird whose wings had been slowly clipped shorter and shorter until they were nearly shorn away.

She sighed and turned away from the window. She stared at the scroll again, marking notes about potential resources to look up.

The next Tuesday she went to the shack without foraging beforehand for the first time. She felt nervous as she stared up at the door. She wasnâ€™t sureâ€”

It was always impossible to predict what Draco would do next.

Her jaw trembled and her fingers wavered a breath away from door knob. She withdrew her hand, curling it into a fist and forcing herself to take a deep breath.

This was her job, she reminded herself. It didnâ€™t matter what happened from one week to the next. It never mattered. It was still her job.

She swallowed and pressed her lips tightly together as she reached out and opened the door.

Draco appeared as she stepped inside.

He apparated in, nearly on top of her, grabbed her firmly, and backed her into the wall as his lips crashed into hers. She could feel his hunger; in his hands as he dragged them along her body; in his breath as he drew a ragged gasp against her mouth.

Hermioneâ€™s eyes widened with surprise as she was crushed against him. Her fingers caught his robes. Her eyes fluttered closed, and she kissed him back.

His hand came up and captured her jaw, just below her ear. His fingers curled around to the base of her neck, arching her head back as he kissed her more deeply.

She clung to him, and he pulled her closer, wrapping his arm around her waist. The whole world dropped away. Hermione kissed him ravenously. She wanted to pour herself into him.

He pulled her up, and she wrapped her legs around his hips. Her fingers tangled in his hair, and she felt his teeth against her lips and tongue.

It was like falling. He had her pinned against the wall. She hardly knew where she ended and he began. Her lungs were catching fire but she wouldnâ€™t tear her mouth from his.
