Hermione dropped back and shook her head, looking him over as well, trailing her hand along his torso. He had no visible injuries.

â€œI wasnâ€™t there. It was a proper raid; Kingsley wouldnâ€™t bring me out.â€ Â Her jaw trembled, and she looked away. â€œYou wonâ€™t need to worry. Iâ€™m notâ€”,â€ the words twisted in her mouth, â€œIâ€™m not permitted to leave the safe houses anymore, aside from liaising. So you wonâ€™t need to worry.â€

Draco gave an audible sigh of relief and sank down against her, brushing another kiss on her forehead.

Hermione closed her eyes and pressed her lips together.

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong?â€

She looked up and found Draco staring intently down at her, his expression closed.

The corner of her mouth quirked. â€œI liked foraging. It wasâ€”the only bearable thing I got to do sometimes.â€ Her eyes dropped down, and she entwined her fingers with his. She stared at his hand in hers. â€œMy life just keeps getting smaller and darker.â€

There was a pause.

â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

She shrugged under him. â€œItâ€™s not like you ordered it. You said stay alive; Kingsley is the one who decided that meant I wasnâ€™t allowed to forage or leave the safe houses. I understand. Heâ€™s responsible for an entire war effort. Iâ€™m not going to ask him to structure it around my personal feelings. I justâ€”â€ she paused, inhaling. â€œIâ€™m still coming to terms with it.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t realise it was important to you.â€

She was silent for a moment, hesitating. â€œSome daysâ€”it was the closest thing to freedom I still had.â€

She felt his whole body freeze.

â€œJustâ€”just until the end of the war,â€ he said in a tone that was half plea and half vow.

Hermione snorted. â€œJust till then? When will that be?â€ She gave him a bitter smile. â€œWhat end of the war do you think will somehow go well for either of us? If the Order somehow wins, Iâ€™m sure the International Confederation will suddenly be eager to be involved. Theyâ€™ll preside over all the trials. I already told you, a lot of my activity has been largely unsanctioned, and the Order is supposed to be democratic. When it all comes outâ€”â€ she looked away, unable to meet his eyes, â€œâ€”it wonâ€™t paint a very pretty picture.â€ She raised her eyebrows and gave a small sigh. â€œIf Iâ€™m lucky theyâ€™ll just take my wand away for a few years. There are certain thingsâ€”â€

Her chest tightened as she thought about the small room within the cave at the beach. The blood. Flayed hands and feet. Over the course of a year, Gabrielle had gotten crueler and more creative. Injuries were rarely reversible now, and Kingsley did not rein her in because the Order needed the information.

Hermioneâ€™s name sat beside Kingsleyâ€™s in every prisoner file. Her handwriting neatly cataloguing in precise, clinical terms the injuries sheâ€™d healed, the exact condition of each prisoner when she placed them in stasis.

I was there. I knew. I was complicit.

She swallowed. â€œIâ€™m not as good a person as you think. Iâ€”I could very well end up in Azkaban.â€

Draco was silent for a moment as he stared at her. His fingers twitched and tightened around her. â€œRun. Say the word, and Iâ€™ll get you out. You donâ€™t have to stay here.â€

A craven part of herself rose up and unfurled at his words. Out. Free. Far away from the war.

She didnâ€™t know how much she wanted it until she heard it offered by someone who meant it.

The idea of living without the warâ€”she wanted to.

â€œYou know I wonâ€™t,â€ she said, looking up into his eyes.

His expression was bitter, and his eyes flickered, showing tired resignation. He nodded. â€œThe offer stands. Give the word, Iâ€™ll get you out.â€

She studied him. â€œWhat about you?â€

He gave a bitter laugh. â€œIf I could run, I would have vanished while my mother was alive.â€

Hermione nodded slowly. He would never be there if he had any choice. â€œOf course. Would you go now, if you could?â€

He stared at her, his eyes were molten silver and unwavering. â€œWith you, I would.â€

â€œThenâ€”weâ€™ll go together. After the war.â€ She pressed his hand against her chest and felt her heart beat against it. â€œWhen the war is over. Weâ€™ll both run somewhere no one knows us. Weâ€™llâ€”disappear. When itâ€™s over.â€

His eyes flickered for a moment before he met her gaze and smiled faintly. â€œOf course, Granger.â€

He was lying.

They both were.

It was a fairytale to think they could run together. That things would end neatly enough for that.

She squeezed his hand tighter and met his eyes until the illusion faded away.

â€œThere was a trace on Ron,â€ she said after a minute. â€œFrom Sussex. Would you be able to get us more information about how they work? And what other prototypes theyâ€™re working on?â€

â€œIâ€™ll see what I can do.â€ His tone was clipped. He drew away and rolled his neck so that it cracked.

Hermione stared at him. He was impossibly elegant but too thin. Nearly gaunt. His skin was pale as marble, and in the dim morning light, he could have been a figure in a painting. His scars made the scene macabre.

She couldnâ€™t look at him and not see the war. It was carved into him.

She sat up and fixed the pins in her hair.

â€œI hate your hair like that,â€ he said abruptly.

Hermione glanced over and arched an eyebrow. â€œI could crop it instead.â€

His expression grew offended. She gave him a wry smile and shrugged. â€œI have to keep it out of the way when working. Iâ€™m always on call. It makes the most sense to keep it this way.â€

He looked away for several minutes. â€œI want to see you more.â€

The corner of her mouth quirked as her heart caught with relief. â€œAlright. Do you have a time?â€

He turned to look at her, and she could see the hunger in his eyes. Possessive. Ravenous.

He would drag her from the war and hide her the instant she let him. She could see the conflict in his eyes. The sight of Draco restraining himself as he stared at her and weighed his options was familiar.

Want. Want. Want. She felt it like her heartbeat.

If he couldnâ€™t hide her, he would hoard her to himself as much as he was able.

Sheâ€™d fallen for a dragon.

â€œIâ€™ve always been on call for you too. I have a six hour shift in the hospital ward every afternoon, but the rest of my work is flexible. You can call me, and Iâ€™ll come as soon as I can.â€

â€œIâ€™ll call you then, when I can. If the ring activates once, itâ€™s not Order related.â€

Draco pulled his cloak off the floor and pulled out a scroll.

â€œAny new orders this week?â€ he asked as he offered it to her. His mouth twisted derisively as he asked the question. â€œAside from information on the trace?â€

She shook her head. â€œItâ€™s the main priority.â€

As she reached and took hold of the scroll, he pulled it back, drawing her towards him. He closed a hand around her wrist.

She felt the parchment slip from her fingers as his other hand slid up her throat, and he kissed her.

He kissed her, and she kissed him.

Flashback 31

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

April 2003

Draco called her. Often.

Sometimes, his duties in Voldemortâ€™s army came to an end in the late evening, but most of the time he called her in the early hours of morning. Hermione would work in her potion cabinet or research until her ring burned. Then sheâ€™d slip out of Grimmauld Place and apparate to Whitecroft.

Sheâ€™d barely step through the door before Draco would appear, snatch her up, and apparate them elsewhere. Always a hotel. Rarely the same one, even from one night to the next.

Heâ€™d kiss her, cradling her face in his hands, and it felt felt like he was breathing her in.

Then heâ€™d step back enough to look at her.

â€œYouâ€™re alright? Are you alright? Has anything happened to you?â€ Heâ€™d run his hands over her to check as he asked.

Every time the same question, as though he didnâ€™t believe it until heâ€™d verified it personally.

She hadnâ€™t expected him to be so obsessively worried. Sheâ€™d observed his immediate arrival at Whitecroft over the months; the careful way heâ€™d run his eyes over her after sheâ€™d been attacked in Hampshire. She hadnâ€™t considered how deep the fear cut into him.

Sheâ€™d feel herself unwinding under his touch as his fingers ran down her arms, over her hands, and up her spine.

â€œIâ€™m fine, Draco. You donâ€™t need to worry.â€

The words never seemed to have any effect. Heâ€™d turn her face up towards his and stare into her eyes as though he expected to find something in them.

Sheâ€™d look up at him and calmly let him reassure himself.

Whatever had happened to his mother, Narcissa had never told him fully; either because she couldnâ€™t, or in an attempt to spare him. Withholding it had probably been the worst choice.

Draco was like her. He obsessed over what he didnâ€™t know more than anything else.

Sheâ€™d meet his eyes, â€œDraco, Iâ€™m fine. Nothing has happened to me.â€

When he was certain she truly was wholly uninjured, it was like a tension inside him would finally break. Heâ€™d gather her in his arms, sighing with relief while he rested his head on hers.

You did this to him, she reminded herself, and she wrapped her arms tightly around him. You guessed where he was vulnerable, and you exploited it.

Sheâ€™d run her own fingers over him, trying to detect any injuries on him before he kissed her again.

â€œDraco, let me heal you.â€

She never had and never would heal anyone else the way she healed Draco: in his arms, pressed against his body. Sheâ€™d slide her hands along him and press open-mouthed kisses on his shoulders, hands, and face while she muttered spells. Sheâ€™d check him over meticulously until he plucked her wand from her fingers and flung it across the room. Then heâ€™d push her down in the bed and take her slowly.

It was nearly always deliriously slowly. Heâ€™d stare into her eyes until she almost felt their minds touching.

Other times, heâ€™d arrive drenched in Dark Magic. It would cling to his clothes and skin. When he was like that, he was always more desperate. Harder. Faster. Trying to lose himself in something he could feel.

Against a wall. Or just on the floor of the hotel room where they landed.

â€œYouâ€™re mine. Youâ€™re mine.â€ Heâ€™d repeat the words over and over like a mantra. â€œSay it. Say youâ€™re mine.â€

â€œDonâ€™t die, Draco.â€

It was always the last thing she said to him.

He always did.

Each day felt as though the odds were being pushed higher. Steeper. She wasnâ€™t sure how far the runes and his own determination could take him before it reached a point of utter improbability and everything came crashing down.

She could feel it.

He was walking a razorâ€™s edge.

When he slept, she stared at his face and willed him to survive the war.

He clenched his jaw and stared up at her bitterly.

He didnâ€™t care. He didnâ€™t care whether anyone survived the war but her. They could all die, and he wouldnâ€™t care.

Heâ€™d made an Unbreakable Vow. Even if he could get his Dark Mark off, he couldnâ€™t run, not as long as the war continued. Heâ€™d trapped himself in heart of it.

Hermione gave a sad sigh and dropped her head, burying her face in his shoulder. He wrapped his arms tightly around her.

She was almost asleep when she heard the faint whisper of his voice begin once again. â€œIâ€™m going to take care of you. I swear, Iâ€™m always going to take care of you.â€

The rescues ground to a halt. Kingsley put them on hold until more was known about the trace from Sussex. Early prototypes of the shackles were being rolled out to all the prisons.

The Resistance was almost entirely driven underground and into the Muggle world. There were so many dark beings and Snatchers it was difficult to move.

Kingsley began leaning even more heavily in his reconnaissance team and utilising Draco within Voldemortâ€™s army. Misinformation. Sabotage. As though the Death Eater army were a machine to be deconstructed. The envelopes with orders kept growing thicker every time Hermione delivered them.

Draco rarely mentioned what he did, but she could tell he was on the verge of breaking from the pressure. He grew steadily more and more desperate each time he saw her.

It burned in her. To watch him eroding under everything he was expected to maintain and produce for both sides.

Almost all pressure on Hermione from the Order vanished. She was a collar around Dracoâ€™s throat; Kingsley and Moody had nothing more urgent to ask than that she maintain it.

She was simply left to live with it.

She felt like a caged animal inside Grimmauld Place. She travelled from safe house to safe house just for a change of scenery.

When she wasnâ€™t healing or caring for Ginny, she poured her energy into research and experimental magic. She went further into researching Dark Magic than she ever had in the past. Maybe the Order wouldnâ€™t use it, but Draco might.

She tried to find a way around the shackles. Draco regularly brought updated scrolls of analysis for her, and she pored over them, trying to find a flaw, something to exploit. They were ingenious. They were a work of art.

They horrified Hermione with their rapid evolution.

In addition to irremovable traces, Sussex began experimenting with shackles intended to suppress magic. Tungsten inlaid with iron. Tungsten plated with copper or aluminium. Shackles with wand core materials.

Sheâ€™d barely sleep unless she was with Draco. The rest of the time, sheâ€™d just lie in cold terror at the thought of what would happen to anyone captured. The Order might not ever be able to save any of them.

Death Eaters were already being given the shackles to carry in order to more easily apprehend members of the Resistance. Once closed, a shackle couldnâ€™t be reopened without two bearers of the Dark Mark performing an incantation variant of the Morsmordre.

Dean Thomas appeared at Grimmauld Place a day after capture. His wand hand severed. Heâ€™d stolen a knife and sawn his hand off at the wrist in order to escape.

A week later Severus brought word that the shackles were being moved out of Sussex in order to expand production. They would now come in sets of two.

Draco brought Hermione a set of the prototypes one evening and watched her analyse it.

They looked almost like bracelets.

Hermione built an elaborate web of analytic magic around it, dissecting all the components; the alchemy, charms, the arithmancy, the runes set in the iron core.

She spent hours trying to find a flaw, until she fell asleep in the middle of it and woke to find Draco carrying her to bed.

â€œI canâ€™tâ€”there isnâ€™t a way around them.â€ Her brain felt clouded by exhaustion. She was almost shaking with frustration. â€œThere has to be something. Using imperio wonâ€™t work, it shows up in the spell signature and cancels the incantation. I thought, just cut through them, but the core is charmed to explode. Iâ€™m just notâ€”maybe I have to come at it from a different angle. My alchemy is all self-taught. Maybe I just havenâ€™t researched enough.â€

She started to pull away from him and tried to go back toward the stacks of books sheâ€™d brought. Draco stopped her. He slid one arm around her waist and wrapped the other around her shoulders.

â€œYou canâ€™t save everyone, Granger.â€

She stilled and stared despairingly across the room.

â€œI donâ€™t know how weâ€™re going to win this war,â€ she finally said.

Draco was silent. There was nothing to say that wouldnâ€™t be a lie.

She lifted her hand and gripped his arm around her shoulders.

â€œI donâ€™t know how to save anyone. Everything I do just puts it off so that they die in a worse way. I wishâ€”I wish Iâ€™d never become a healer.â€

Sheâ€™d never admitted it to anyone before. That she hated it.

She told him about the horcruxes. She wasnâ€™t supposed to. She hadnâ€™t been cleared to. She told him anyway. Everything she knew, about their creation and destruction, and all the Orderâ€™s ideas about what they could be. About the Foundersâ€™ lost items.

â€œWe think there might be one in Hogwarts,â€ she said when she showed him all her research. â€œBut I donâ€™t know how many he could have. There couldnâ€™t be more than five, could there? Splitting his soul like thatâ€”itâ€™s poison in the body. It will eat him from the inside out. His current form is the best restoration he could manage with a regeneration potion. It should have returned him to his physical prime, but his soul is so deteriorated making a sort of body was the most it could do. So there has to be a limit to the horcruxes. I donâ€™t think he can keep making them. If we can destroy all the horcruxes, heâ€™ll become unstable enough that even if no one kills him, eventually heâ€™ll just cease to exist. But we donâ€™t know where they could be. Thereâ€™s so little information about his past.â€

â€œHe gave one to my father during the first war?â€

â€œWhen the Chamber of Secrets was opened during our second year, it was caused by the soul fragment possessing Ginny Weasley. Your father put the horcrux in with her books in an attempt to discredit Arthur Weasley.â€

â€œIf they were made during the first war, and he entrusted one to his followersâ€”Iâ€™ll look into it. You should have told me sooner.â€

â€œI shouldnâ€™t even be telling you now.â€ She rested her hand over his heart. â€œI wasnâ€™t trying to add something else. I justâ€”I donâ€™t have anyone to talk to. It helps me to think if I can talk aloud.â€

He snorted. â€œIf it ends this, itâ€™s worth it. What is the Order doing? Everything Moody and Shacklebolt assign me is just buying time.â€ His voice was vibrating with fury.

â€œDracoâ€¦â€

He didnâ€™t say anything else, but his rage was palpable.

He didnâ€™t trust Kingsley or Moody or the Order. He was terrified if he died, they might sell her again to try to survive.

And she couldnâ€™t promise him that she wouldnâ€™t. She would do anything to win the war. He knew that. She suspected that fear drove him more than anything else.

He wrapped his arms around her, and she could feel it in his hands, in the way he touched her.

She rested her head on his chest and listened to his heart.

"You should get body-armor,â€ she said. â€œI was researching it. Ukrainian Ironbelly hide. Itâ€™s lightweight, highly resistant to magic, and almost impenetrable to physical attacks. If you wear it under your robes, no one will even know itâ€™s there. It could save your life someday.â€

He didnâ€™t say anything. He was still staring down at her research on the horcruxes.

Sometimes they didnâ€™t leave the shack in Whitecroft immediately. Heâ€™d arrive with so many injuries heâ€™d be going into shock. Other times, sheâ€™d feel the tremors of cruciatus in his hands.

Sheâ€™d heal him and then sit with his head in her lap while he stabilised. Sheâ€™d treat the tremors in his arms and hands while he floated on the edge of consciousness. She muttered apologies to him under her breath as she tapped her wand tip across his hands, bending, and rubbing, and massaging his fingers until they stopped twitching.

Youâ€™re killing him. Youâ€™re killing him. This is because of you.

She let herself cry over him when he wasnâ€™t conscious to see it. She gripped his hands in hers and tried to fix him.

â€œIâ€™m sorry. Iâ€™m sorry. Iâ€™m so so sorry.â€ She said it over and over.

Sheâ€™d wipe her eyes and banish all her tears before she rennervated him. Sheâ€™d feel the tension tear through his body as he regained consciousness and then feel him breathe when he looked up and saw her.

Heâ€™d apparate them to a hotel and sleep with his arms wrapped possessively around her.

When even Dracoâ€™s presence was insufficient to quiet her demons, sheâ€™d study his face and listen to his heartbeat, quietly promising him, â€œIâ€™m going to take care of you. I swear, Iâ€™m always going to take care of you.â€

Flashback 32

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

May 2003

It was near the end of May when the Death Eaters launched an attack on a Muggle town in Surrey. It was a trap. They didnâ€™t even bother to conceal the fact they were luring the Resistance out.

There was no need to. The Resistance would go anyway.

Hermione watched the Order depart to join the fight and worked with Padma to transfer the hospital ward down into the foyer and expand the walls of the sitting room. They called in several of the Resistance members who functioned as healers and nurses at the hospice safe houses.

Poppy Pomfrey had caught Black Cat Flu and was under quarantine. A disease that caused chronic bad luck was one of the last things that the Order could handle sweeping through the Resistance.

The clock ticked relentlessly on while Hermione paced, carefully and meticulously organising her mind. She gathered all her memories of Draco, shoving them into the furthest recesses of her consciousness where she kept her memories of her parents.

She could not think about Draco. She could not worry about whether he was fighting. Whether Kingsley or Moody had him doing anything that put him into extreme danger in order to give the Resistance a slight edge.

She had to work. Thinking about it wouldnâ€™t change anything.

She walled it all away.

Seamus appeared at the door carrying an unfamiliar woman and Michael Corner in his arms.

â€œVampire,â€ he said, nodding towards the woman. â€œI dunno about him.â€

He dropped them and quickly apparated away again.

The foyer began filling with bodies. Muggles, Resistance fighters; they were all being brought to Hermione and Padma.

Hermione poured Blood-Replenishing Potion and the antidote for the bite down the womanâ€™s throat before trying to quickly diagnose what had happened to Michael. A diagnostic charm indicated his organs were shutting down, but she couldnâ€™t figure out why. She started casting an analytic web on the curse signature in order to try to identify it.

Crack.

Kingsley appeared, carrying Tonks. Tonks was screaming at the top of her lungs; her eyes were rolled back in her head.

Hermione cast a stasis charm on Michael in the hope of buying time and rushed over.

Tonksâ€™ arm had been cursed; the skin was sliding away as her body flayed itself. Hermione cancelled the curse and cast a spell to soothe the pain before holding a vial of Skin-Regrowth Potion against Tonksâ€™ lips.

Blood and a black, acrid liquid spattered onto Hermioneâ€™s sleeve. She glanced up sharply.

â€œYouâ€™re cursed,â€ she said, watching a growing stain spread across Kingsleyâ€™s left shoulder through his robes.

â€œI have to get Potter out,â€ he said, turning to leave.

She grabbed his arm. â€œItâ€™s close to your heart. Let me heal you.â€

He pulled her hand off. â€œThereâ€™s no time. Get ready, weâ€™re bringing more your way.â€

There was a crack as Parvati appeared, weighed down with four bodies.

â€œGet them to Padma,â€ Hermione said, chasing Kingsley as he swept out of Grimmauld Place. â€œLet me heal you, Kingsley.â€

She reached out to grab him before he reached the edge of the protective wards. As her fingers closed around the fabric of his robes, he apparated. They both reappeared in the battlefield. It was a town square, hazy with dust, blood and residual magic.

There were bodies everywhere.The Death Eaters were casting curses at the Resistance members who were trying to get the injured away. Dementors were floating overhead, Kissing anyone they came across.

Hermione glanced around with horror.

â€œGo back to Grimmauld Place! Your job is to stay in the safe houses, Granger.â€ Kingsley snarled at her; his expression furious when he realized she was standing beside him. He cast a shield around them.

There was a scream of rage that Hermione recognised as belonging to Ron.

â€œGet back to the safe house, Granger,â€ Kingsley said over his shoulder as he moved toward the sound.

Hermione prepared to apparate but, just before she vanished, her eyes landed on a boy lying on the ground. His stomach was torn open, likely by a hag or a werewolf.

She knelt down and checked his pulse. Too late; he was already dead. There was a wand in his hand. A Resistance fighter. He couldnâ€™t have been fourteen.

A witch beside him had a necrosis curse crawling up her leg. She seemed to have passed out from the pain. There was another body on top of the witch; a young man whoâ€™d fallen across her. Hermione rolled him over to see whether he was still alive too.

Instantly he sprang forward. Hermione felt fangs sink into her shoulder as he pulled her to the ground. Hermione cast a dark curse without pausing to think.

The vampire crumbled.

Hermione staggered to her feet, levitating the injured witch into her arms. She glanced around for anyone else within reach.

A man two feet away appeared to have been attacked by a dementor. Hermione moved towards him to check whether heâ€™d been fully Kissed. His soul was still intact, but he was hypothermic and in need of chocolate.

An icy sensation came over her. She looked up sharply to find several dementors closing in.

Hermione took a deep breath and cast a patronus. A flash of light shot from her wand, but her patronus failed to corporealise.

As her patronus drove away the dementors, she pulled the wizardâ€™s arm over her shoulders and readied herself to apparate.

She sagged under the weight and cast a quick lightening charm. As she did so, there were several cracks of apparition. Hermione gripped the bodies more tightly as she looked up.

Four masked Death Eaters had appeared less than ten feet away. One of them was facing her. He instantly whipped his wand forward.

Hermioneâ€™s eyes widened, and she set her mind to Grimmauld Place. Destination. Determination. Deliberation.

She felt the curse collide with her chest as she vanished.

She reappeared in the street outside Grimmauld Place, dropping the witch and wizard and falling forward with agonised gasp.

She was vaguely aware of swearing, and someone grabbing her and dragging her up the steps into Grimmauld Place. She was flipped over and stared into the faces of Padma and several of the Resistance guards in charge of Grimmauld Place security during skirmishes. Hermione shuddered and tried not to sob.

â€œWhat spell? What spell?â€ Padmaâ€™s eyes were wide and panicked as she leaned over Hermione. Her wand was shaking in her hands.

Hermione gestured wordlessly towards her chest. Padma ripped Hermioneâ€™s shirt open and gasped.

The acid curse had struck Hermione squarely in the sternum. It had been powerfully cast. The boils were already burning deep into her bones and across her chest up to her collarbones.

Padma rapidly cast the countercurse. Hermione lay on the floor and tried not to sob as Padma summoned potions from across the room.

She was burning. The agony from being cursed in the wrist was nothing compared to this. It was in the middle of her. She was barely aware of anything but the corrosive pain in the centre of herself. She couldnâ€™t make out sounds. She couldnâ€™t feel the rest of her body. All she could feel was that she was burning. Inside her chest. In her bones. Her skin. Like there was acid in her throat.

Surely someone would stun her. She was on the verge of pleading.

She closed her eyes tightly and waited for everything to stop.

â€œHermione.â€

â€œHermione.â€ Padmaâ€™s voice broke through the blur of agony.

Hermione forced herself to open her eyes and look up at Padma.

â€œI canâ€™t remove your bones now,â€ Padma said. Her voice was trembling as she poured the analgesic across Hermioneâ€™s chest. â€œThere are too many people dyingâ€”and I need you. There are too many curses here I donâ€™t know how to analyse. Besides the pain potions and the analgesic, what should I give you?â€

Hermione stared at Padma in blank horror for several seconds, struggling to make sense of the words.

She closed her eyes and tried to breathe shallowly before she forced herself to answer. Everything was burning. Even with the analgesic potion, the burning wasnâ€™t stopping. If she hadnâ€™t felt certain that screaming would have hurt more, she would have screamed until her voice gave out.

She swallowed repeatedly before she forced herself to speak. â€œStrengthener. A drop of Felix Felicis. And a Draught of Peace,â€ she said in as low voice as she could manage. She could feel vibrations of her vocal chords in all the pockets of burned flesh.

Padma carefully poured the potions into Hermioneâ€™s mouth and lightly massaged the analgesic into the skin before dripping small drops of Essence of Dittany into each of the boils. Hermione lay on the floor for several minutes, waiting for the moment when the potions kicked in, in the hopes that somehow things would become somewhat bearable.

She could feel the damage in her bones. It inched toward her lungs as she struggled to breathe. She forced herself to stand and shakily flicked her wand to repair her shirt as she made her way across the foyer.

She was dying.

It felt like she was dying.

She forced herself to mentally separate from the pain and set to work, immediately moving to the most difficult injuries while Padma and the other healers tended to everything else.

Every movement was painful. Breathing was agonising. Hermione couldnâ€™t so much as twitch her arm without feeling every bit of damage in her chest. She bit down on her lip and forced herself not to cry; if her chest heaved from weeping, she was afraid sheâ€™d black out.

Her lungs kept agitating her with the urge to cough. Her esophagus contracting, and her chest jerking slightly as she fought against it. If she coughed, she would probably fracture her sternum.

She nearly cast a diagnostic, but she didnâ€™t think she could handle knowing how much bone damage she was ignoring.

She downed a cough suppressing potion and forced herself to breathe shallowly.

Recovering would be slow. Just repairing it would likely take hours.

She turned slowly, taking in the seemingly endless number of hospital stretchers she was surrounded by.

There were so many injuries. Hag disembowelments and vampire bites. Werewolf maulings. Dozens of curses that Hermione had never seen before. Sussex was a death chamber, slowly wiping out the Resistance. She recognised some of them as curses Severus and Draco had warned her about and provided counter-curses to. Deep cuts that wouldnâ€™t close; non-serious looking boils that suddenly swelled and burst, causing the individuals to begin hemorrhaging. She pulled conjured scorpions, vipers, and even a lobster out of stomachs and chests.

The air stank of internal organs and blood and Dark Magic.

She healed and healed, and the bodies brought to her never seemed to stop. She thought she saw Harry and Ron arrive, but they were gone again before she could look away from the injured Muggle boy she was healing.

As she performed a complicated spell to repair a shredded large intestine, she gradually became aware of someone standing beside her.

She glanced over and found Kreacher looking up at her.

â€œIs Potterâ€™s Mudblood alright?â€

She stared at him blankly but didnâ€™t reply as she moved on to the next injury with a wince, downing another cough suppressing potion as she went.

â€œPotterâ€™s Mudblood is hurt.â€ Kreacher said in a tone that was as conclusive as it was derisive.

â€œKreacher, get out of here.â€ Padma said, her eyes narrowed and furious. â€œI need someone with basic healing over here.â€

â€œHow hurt is Potterâ€™s Mudblood?â€

â€œHow about I curse you with acid in the chest too, and you can see?â€ Padma snapped, kicking him out of the way as she bustled past.

Kreacher skittered back and stared at Hermione for another minute as she deconstructed an unfamiliar curse signature on a witch whose bones were slowly dissolving inside her.

When Hermione looked up again, Kreacher had disappeared.

When the witch was done, Hermione stumbled over and took another dose of pain relief, a strengthener, and Draught of Peace as she tried to force her hands to stop shaking.

Her lungs were beginning to rattle. She downed yet another cough suppressant and tried not to think about it. Padma hadnâ€™t indicated that anything about the injury was life-threatening.

She turned trying to see where she needed to go next. Most of the most complex injuries had been dealt with. She went to join Padma in healing the mid-level curses.

â€œDo you want me to try to treat you now?â€ Padma asked, hesitantly touching Hermioneâ€™s wrist.

Hermione paused for a moment, considering, then shook her head. â€œDo you know why our backup healer isnâ€™t here? We summoned her two hours ago.â€

Padmaâ€™s face grew tense. â€œI donâ€™t know. Iâ€™ve sent five more patronuses. I havenâ€™t heard anything back.â€

Hermione flicked her wand and healed an entrail expelling curse. She felt almost numb beyond the searing pain in her chest.

â€œThenâ€â€”she said slowlyâ€”â€œwe should wait a little longer. Until we know no one else is going to be brought in. Kingsleyâ€”Kingsley never came back. I should waitâ€”in case he does. He was cursed.â€

â€œYou should stop moving,â€ Padma said. â€œThere are enough field healers here; we can manage all the treatment that remains. Go rest while you wait for Kingsley. I can stun you if youâ€™d like.â€

â€œItâ€™s more bearable if I have something else to concentrate on. Justâ€”give me something that doesnâ€™t require me to move my arms.â€

â€œWhy donâ€™t you close the cuts? All the ones over there have had the curses removed. Thatâ€™s just a wrist movement.â€ Padmaâ€™s face was grey with worry and guilt as she stared at Hermione.

Hermione nodded and turned to go.

She was beginning to suspect that her injury was beyond Padmaâ€™s abilities. The lung and esophagus damage she could sense would require advanced healing magic and possibly two healers in order to coordinate the spellwork.

With Pomfrey sickâ€”without their healer from St Mungoâ€™s making an appearanceâ€”Hermione was the only person who knew it all.

Hermione would need to stay conscious while Padma removed Hermioneâ€™s sternum and ribs and repaired her lungs and throat in order to instruct her about how to do it. The mere thought had Hermione on the verge of breaking down.

She would probably black out from the pain and have to be rennervatedâ€”

Repeatedly.

Her hands started trembling violently. She closed her eyes and tried to breathe. Her chest spasmed and she gave a low gasp of pain.

She needed to make sure everyone else with serious injuries was healed so Padma could heal her uninterrupted. It would be worse if Padma had to take breaks. Maybe if Kingsley came back, heâ€™d be able to get a healer.

Hermione opened her eyes and blinked dazedly. Kreacher had appeared once again and was standing in front of her.

â€œPotterâ€™s Mudblood is still working,â€ he said, looking her up and down.

Hermione began to move around him. As she passed him, she felt his bony hand reach up and grab her wrist. She glanced down in surprise as she felt herself vanish.

The squeeze of apparition on her damaged bones was mind-bending. She felt them fracturing as she reappeared. She gave an agonised cry and the bones ground together. The cry made her chest abruptly expand and contract, resulting in a sharp, searing pain as something snapped inside her chest. She screamed.

She fell forward and felt herself caught by the shoulders.

Everything hurt, and hurt, and hurt. Blinding, blinding pain. She was barely conscious of anything else. Every time she sobbed, she felt the bones grind together and break again inside her chest. She kept trying and failing to stop.

â€œStupefy.â€

Â When she reawakened, she found herself immobile. Glancing around wildly, she found Draco staring down at her, pale and wide-eyed.

She stared at him.

â€œYou...â€ She felt her jaw clench with anger and had to force the words out. â€œWhat did you do?â€

â€œYou were injured. What do you think I did?â€ His voice was vibrating with intensity.

Hermione tried to look down and found she couldnâ€™t move her neck. She was paralysed. She rolled her eyes down towards her chest. It was wrapped in bandages and an exoskeleton cast that supported her lungs while her sternum and ribs were regrowing. She could feel the sharp, needle-like pricking of the Skele-Gro. It had been hours since she had been knocked out based on the regrowth she could sense.

â€œI was going to be treated.â€ The sensation of having no upper ribs, sternum, or clavicles was horrifying. She couldnâ€™t move her arms, torso, or neck. Her fingers barely managed to shift. â€œI was waiting for Kingsley.â€

â€œYou nearly died.â€ Dracoâ€™s voice was shaking. â€œYou were dying.â€

â€œHe might have come back. He might be there nowâ€”" she gasped and tried to make her head turn. â€œHe was cursed. I have to go back.â€

â€œShacklebolt is dead.â€

Her eyes darted up, and she looked at him, horrified.

â€œHow do you know? What do you know?â€ she said in a voice that shook with outrage.

â€œI killed him.â€ There was not a trace of regret in his face or eyes.

Hermione stared.

â€œYouâ€”you what?â€

The sinking sensation inside made her feel as though a bottomless pit had opened in her stomach, and she was being dragged in. Collapsing into herself.Â 

Somehow she had forgotten. That heâ€™d killed Dumbledore; that he was a Death Eater; that sheâ€™d seen him kill dozens of people at a time without showing a hint of remorse; that his murderousness was why he was a valuable spy for them; that he brought them valuable, vital information because he continued to run successful raids and attacks for Voldemort.

She knew it all. But sheâ€™d also forgotten it.

Heâ€™d killed Kingsley. He had probably been pleased to do it. She knew how much he hated Moody and Kingsley.

â€œYou shouldnâ€™t have brought me here,â€ she finally said.

â€œYou would be dead if I hadnâ€™t. You were bitten by a vampire and took cough suppressing potion. Did you even know you were drowning in blood? You had minutes left when you arrived. Two casualty healers were barely enough to save you.â€

Hermione blinked. She had forgotten about the vampire biteâ€”it had happened so quickly. How had Padma overlooked it? Had she not even cast a diagnostic charm advanced enough to detect it?

She shoved the question aside.

â€œI didnâ€™t know. There was a roomful of dying people. I was in line like all the rest of them. Pomfrey was sick. Our backup healer didnâ€™t come. They needed me. Once someone started healing me, I wouldnâ€™t have been able to move anymore, no matter what kind of advanced injuries came in. It took hours, didnâ€™t it? Repairing everything? There wasnâ€™t anyone available to do it. Do you have any idea how many people died today? How many are cursed so theyâ€™ll never recover? Just because you donâ€™t care about them doesnâ€™t mean they donâ€™t matter.â€

â€œYou are mine!â€ Draco bared his teeth with rage. â€œI turned, and I saw you get cursed as you disappeared, and I didnâ€™t even know if you were still alive. You said you wouldnâ€™t leave the safe houses. You told me youâ€™d be safe. You were in the middle of a massacre. Thenâ€”I learn that you were alive but not being treated.â€

He was so angry he looked ready to explode. She could feel the rage emanating from him.

â€œI even thought I was going overboard by having you kidnapped out of the safe house. I should have knownâ€”I should have fucking known, you idiotic Gryffindor. You would have just let yourself die.â€

â€œThis is war, Draco. People die.â€ Hermione said in a flat voice. â€œGiven your personal death toll, you should know that better than anyone else. If you knew anything about me, you would know Iâ€™m not going to prioritise my survival over everyone elseâ€™s.â€

Draco stared at her for several seconds. He was breathing through his teeth, his hands clenched into fists.

â€œWell, you should.â€ He was suddenly ice-cold. â€œI have warned you. If something happens to you, I will personally raze the entire Order. That isnâ€™t a threat. It is a promise. Consider your survival as much a necessity to the survival of the Resistance as Potterâ€™s. If you die, I will kill every last one of them. Given that the risk of their lives is apparently the only way to make you value your own.â€

Hermione stared up at him in state of shock that slowly twisted into rage.

â€œHow dare you? How dare you?â€

If she could have moved, she would have cursed him, stabbed him, tried to beat him with her bare hands.

She wanted to weep as the full realisation of what his threat meant dawned on her. Â 

He was too dangerous.

Too much of a risk to the Order.

When she reported back to Moody, he would probably decide they had no choice but to kill Draco.

Whether Moody used his memories or hers, the result would be the same.

Tears welled up and streamed down from the corners of her eyes. She closed them so that she wouldnâ€™t have to look up at Draco.Â 

The silence hung between them for a minute before she heard him sigh heavily. She felt the bed shift, and his fingers stroked her face, brushing away a lock of hair and then resting on her cheek.

â€œYouâ€™re thinking youâ€™ll have to kill me, arenâ€™t you?â€ he said. â€œThat Iâ€™m too much of a liability now. If you go to Moody, heâ€™ll order it.â€

His hand trailed down and rested lightly on her chest over the spot where her sternum was re-growing. The heat of it seeped gradually through the cast and into her skin. It made her breath catch.

â€œAnd youâ€™ll do it. Wonâ€™t you?â€

Hermione opened her eyes and looked at him. He was seated on the edge of the bed, staring down at her. The rage had vanished from his eyes.Â 

â€œYou arenâ€™t leaving me any choice.â€ she said in a shaking voice. â€œYou knowâ€”you know I will not choose you over everyone else.â€

He studied her. â€œYouâ€™ll never forgive yourself.â€

Her jaw trembled. â€œNo. I wonâ€™tâ€”â€ her voice broke. â€œButâ€”it wouldnâ€™t be the first unforgivable thing Iâ€™ve done. Iâ€™m already a whore.â€ His hand resting against her flinched. â€œBecoming a murderer will just be an extra line in the history books.â€

â€œIf you did, what would you do then?â€

â€œIâ€™m sure you can imagine.â€ She wanted to turn her head away, but, without her bones, her muscles couldnâ€™t function.

His hand withdrew. Its sudden absence tugged at something inside of her. She struggled not to sob.

She hated this war.

She had thought she could do anything. She thought there would be no limits to what she would be willing to do to save Harryâ€”to save everyone. That she would be able to bear with the consequences for long enough to reach the end.

Apparently Draco had become her limit.

She didnâ€™t know how to endure the war on her own anymore. The thought of watching the light fade from his eyes...

A ragged wail tore itself from her throat.

Suddenly Draco was over her, holding her in as much of an embrace as he could without injuring her. His face only a breath away from hers.

â€œJust live, Hermione.â€ His voice was shaking. â€œThat's all I am asking you to do for me.â€

Hermione gave a low sob. â€œI cannot promise that. You know I cannot promise that. And I cannot risk what you would do if I died.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry...â€ she kept saying again and again as she kissed him. â€œIâ€™m sorry I did this to you.â€

His lips were still against hers when he suddenly stiffened and hissed.

He wrenched himself away, gripping his left forearm until the knuckles of his right hand were white. â€œFuck.â€

He stood up and stared down at her. â€œIâ€™m being summoned.â€

â€œI canâ€™t delay. I have to go. Topsy!â€

A house-elf popped into the room. Hermione started slightly and glanced around, realising that she was not in a hotel room.

â€œAm Iâ€”in Malfoy Manor?â€ Her voice shook with disbelief.

Draco gave a short nod, his expression brittle. â€œI had to bring you here. I canâ€™t summon healers to Muggle London.â€ Draco grabbed a pile of robes. Hermione recognized them as his Death Eater uniform. He pulled them on rapidly. â€œI didnâ€™t expect to leave you here alone.â€

â€œIâ€™ll come back. No one can come here. Youâ€™ll be safe until I get back,â€ he said again. â€œTopsy, take care of Granger.â€

Draco pulled his mask on and looked down at her for a split-second longer before he vanished from the room.

Hermione looked up at the ceiling and heard the house-elf, Topsy, fidget beside her. Hermione pressed her lips together for several seconds, trying to decide where to begin.

â€œDoes Kreacher come here often?â€ Hermione finally asked, turning her eyes to look at Topsy.

Topsy stared back at Hermione with her enormous eyes and nodded. â€œKreacher is coming most months to see the master. Kreacher serves the Noble House of Black. The master is being the last Black left.â€

â€œI see.â€ Hermione was seething internally. â€œWhat does Kreacher do when he comes to see Draco?â€

â€œHe is telling the master about Granger and the Order of the Phoenix. And Kreacher is maintaining Mistress Malfoy and Mistress Lestrangeâ€™s grave sites. That is how the master was finding that Kreacher serves the House of Black still.â€

â€œTopsy is not knowing, Topsy is thinking it was maybe for a year.â€

â€œIs the Miss Granger wanting anything?â€ Topsy stepped closer and stared at Hermione. â€œTopsy can be bringing food, or tea, or broths, or whatever the miss is needing.â€

She lay there while her mind raced. She managed to twitch her fingers slightly and experimented with how much she could move.

Draco returned after an hour. His apparition was silent, but Hermione saw him immediately.

She could turn her head a bit. She studied him, looking for any sign that he might be injured. His expression was tense, but there was nothing that indicated he was hurt or had been crucioâ€™d.

Draco stilled and his mouth twitched. Instead of responding, he drew his wand and cast the diagnostic spell sheâ€™d taught him. They both studied it. There were still at least two hours of regrowth left.

â€œI thought you did it because I healed you,â€ she said after a minute.

â€œI know.â€

Her throat tightened. â€œEverytime I healed you after that, I thoughtâ€”I thought you might hurt me again.â€

â€œI know.â€ His voice was hollow.

There was a long silence. Hermione pressed her lips together and drew a slow breath, feeling as though she might choke on her grief.

â€œI donâ€™t know what to do. I canâ€™t ignore a threat to the Order.â€

Draco sighed and looked down. â€œI was just angry.â€

Hermione scoffed and jerked her chin. â€œYouâ€™re always angry. You canâ€™t make threats like that. Especially not you. It was an accident. I was trying to heal Kingsley, and he apparated. I thought Iâ€™d take some of the injured back with me. My hands were full when I was cursed.â€

â€œYou were still working.â€ His voice was a carefully controlled. Clipped. She could hear the undercurrent of cold rage still in it.

â€œI wanted to,â€ she said firmly. â€œPadma didnâ€™t know the spellwork to heal me. Pomfrey and she could have done it together, but Pomfrey was sick this week. Our other casualty healer never came. Iâ€™m going to have quite a bit to say about healing practice when I get back. It was a lot of factors. You canâ€™t reduce complex situations into a simplistic blame game. Draco gave a long sigh and stared across the room for a minute before he spoke. â€œIf you die, Granger, Iâ€™m done. I wonâ€™t continue this. Iâ€™m tired.â€

Hermione twisted her wrist enough to catch his hand. â€œDraco, donâ€™tâ€”â€

He looked down at her. His expression was closed, but she could see the whole war in his eyes. â€œI mean it. I wonâ€™t kill themâ€”but I will be done. Youâ€™re my terms of service. The contract is void if you die.â€

She shook her head. â€œThere is a life for you on the other side of the war; donâ€™tâ€”donâ€™t reduce your world to me.â€

He quirked an eyebrow, and his upper lip curled. â€œYours hardly seems larger. Or are there post-war plans youâ€™ve forgotten to mention?â€

Hermione swallowed and looked away. â€œDo as I say, not as I do.â€

Draco gave a low laugh, and they lapsed into a silence as empty as the future.

â€œYouâ€”you could become a healer,â€ she said after a minute.

A smile ghosted in the corner of his mouth. â€œI hadnâ€™t considered that.â€

Hermione gave a faint smile. â€œYou should. If you went somewhere else, you could be a very good healerâ€”although your bedside manner could use improvement.â€

â€œIt would be something to balance out that death toll of mine,â€ he said without looking at her.

Her hold on his hand tightened. â€œIâ€™m sorry. I shouldnâ€™t have said that. Itâ€™s not your fault.â€

His eyes flickered away. â€œMaybe once. I believe I own it now.â€

Hermione felt her stomach twist. â€œYou are so much more than what the war has made you into.â€ Her voice shook slightly.

He still didnâ€™t look at her.

â€œYou are,â€ she said, studying his face carefully. â€œJust like I am. There is more to both of usâ€”itâ€™s justâ€”just waiting to get out.â€ Hermione traced her fingers along his. â€œSomedayâ€”somedayâ€”weâ€™ll leave all this behind. The two of usâ€”I think we could.â€

His fingers entwined with hers tightened just a little.

She didnâ€™t know what else to say. She felt her eyes droop.

Draco brushed a hand against her cheek. â€œSleep. You still have a few hours before you can move. Once the bones are regrown, there are restoratives Iâ€™m supposed to give you. Hermione rolled her eyes. â€œTwelve hours is excessive.â€

â€œIt is the bare minimum, as you well know.â€

Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched and Draco snorted. â€œYou are a manipulative little liar. Donâ€™t expect me to trust you.â€

Hermioneâ€™s eyes slid shut, and she suddenly gripped his hand tighter. â€œDonâ€™tâ€”leave me alone in this house.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t.â€

Flashback 33

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

May 2003

When Hermione woke, Draco was still beside her. He had a large stack of books he was cross-referencing. Hermione blinked and narrowed her eyes to read the titles and found he was researching Gringotts regulations and inheritance law.

â€œWhat are you doing?â€ she asked after a minute.

His eyes flicked up from the page he was on.

â€œRodolphus Lestrange was found decoratively strung up in a number of pieces while traveling through Bulgaria.â€

Hermione swallowed. Gabrielle. It had her fingerprints all over it. Gabrielleâ€™s methods had grown increasingly ruthless and extreme in recent months.

â€œIt was the reason for my summons,â€ Draco said as he snapped the book closed. â€œThe Dark Lord is incensed by the audacity of the assassination andâ€”curiously enoughâ€”intensely concerned about who will have access to the Lestrange vault now.â€

Hermione froze, and her eyes widened. â€œDo you thinkâ€”â€

He gave a short nod. â€œThe Lestranges would be an obvious choice to entrust with a horcrux. If my father was chosen, Bellatrix and her husband were equally likely. Old families with heirlooms and excellent security. Bellatrix transferred her inheritance as a Black into the Lestrange vault. Aside from Andromedaâ€™s daughter, whoâ€™s currently a wanted criminal, Iâ€™m the last with Black blood. There are no more Lestranges unless a bastard crawls out of the woodwork. I believe that by blood and technicality, I may be able to access the vault.â€

Hermioneâ€™s mind raced. â€œBribe the goblins. Theyâ€™re highly possessive of anything goblin-made. If you agree to give them some of the Black or Lestrange heirlooms that are goblin-made, theyâ€™ll cover up that you were ever there. Thatâ€™s how we got access to some of the vaults.â€

Dracoâ€™s eyes glittered. â€œUseful.â€

He flicked his wand and summoned several vials from across the room. â€œCan you move?â€

Hermione lifted her arm and tilted her chin downwards to look at her chest. At some point while she was asleep, Draco had banished the exoskeletal cast. The sheets were pulled carefully up to her regrown collarbones. Her fingers caught the fabric, but she hesitated and glanced up at him. â€œIs it bad?â€

He shrugged, but his eyes were fastened on her face. â€œItâ€™s minor.â€

Hermione tensed her jaw slightly as she pulled the sheet back and stared at her chest.

It looked as though a tiny bomb had exploded from her sternum. The scarring was concentrated in the dead centre of her chest and then spattered in tinier scars up toward her shoulders and down over the tops of her breasts. Â 

She could feel Dracoâ€™s eyes on her although he didnâ€™t move. She blinked hard as she studied it.

She swallowed slowly.

The scarring was quite minor considering the injury. She was hardly disfigured. It wouldnâ€™t have any lifelong consequences. With time, it would fade. She knew she could treat it so that it would fade.

She was very lucky. A few scars were nothing compared to the injuries other people in the Resistance would carry for life.

It was fine. She would just wear shirts with a high neckline.

She swallowed again and looked up at Draco, who was still watching her carefully. She forced a smile. â€œHowâ€”how many vials of Dittany did you use on me to manage this?â€ She dropped the sheet and pressed her hands against it.

Draco rolled his eyes. â€œStill not as many as youâ€™ve used on me.â€

She gave a wry smile. â€œYour scars are prettier than mine.â€

He snorted audibly. â€œI had a better healer.â€

Hermione gave a low laugh, but it caught in her lungs. She tried to breathe but instead coughed violently until she spat several blood clots into her hand.

Draco was immediately beside her. He slid his hand behind her head, and there was a vial at her lips. â€œThis is to clear your lungs.â€

Hermioneâ€™s instinctive reaction was to pull away and inspect the potion in order to verify it, but she trusted Draco was paranoid enough for both of them. She parted her lips and swallowed it. The smothering, catching sensation in her lungs vanished.

Draco muttered a spell, and she felt the blood on her hand disappear.

Draco summoned several other potions. Hermione eyed them and mentally catalogued each one. Pain relief. Strengtheners. Potions for lung tissue. Potions to help the tendons and ligaments bond with the new bones. Some were somewhat redundant. Draco was exhaustively, obsessively thorough.

She swallowed every potion without a murmur, gagging down several.

He kissed the top of her head. â€œAre you hungry?â€

She snorted. â€œNot after eight potions. Although water would be appreciated. Do you have my wand? I thinkâ€”I was holding it when I was apparated, wasnâ€™t I? I canâ€™tâ€”entirely recall.â€

Draco pulled her wand from his robes and slipped it into her hand. She could feel the hesitation in his fingers.

â€œIâ€™m sorry. I didnâ€™t realise that disapparation would cause your bones to shatter.â€

Hermione flinched at the memory. She looked down and forced herself to shrug. â€œPressure. Thatâ€™s why I told you that you canâ€™t use displacement transport with brain or eye injuries. It can be similar with damaged bones.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

Hermione glanced up and gave him a small smile. â€œItâ€™s not your fault. It was a lot of bad luck.â€

He stiffened, and his expression froze before he scoffed under his breath. â€œIt wasnâ€™t just bad luck. Does the Order realise how predictable theyâ€™ve become? The losses yesterday were almost entirely one-sided. It was a stunning success. It will be repeated.â€

There was a bitter rage in his voice.

Hermione stilled and then pressed her lips together, hesitating for a moment. â€œIt was yours, wasnâ€™t it? The attack. You planned it.â€

Draco tensed, and there was a pause. He looked away from her, and she saw his jaw ripple.

â€œI have to maintain my position in order to do everything required. The Dark Lord knows there are spies in the army now. Heâ€™s well aware that the Order has infiltrated somehow. Shacklebolt overplayed. Sussex and the various branches of the army are becoming sequestered. There are dozens of counter-espionage measures in place; maintaining rank is the only way to remain informed of them.â€

She slid a hand against his leg. â€œIâ€™m not faulting you. I just hadnâ€™t realised it.â€

There was a long silence.

â€œI had no choice but to kill Shacklebolt,â€ Draco finally said. â€œHe was cursed, as you were aware. Weasley went on a rampage because some girl died. Shacklebolt got Potter and Weasley out, but he was finished.â€ There was a beat. â€œCapture and interrogation would have been worse.â€

Hermione gave a slow nod without looking up.

The Death Eaters would have known the value of Kingsley Shacklebolt. They would have done everything in their power to tear out every piece of intelligence he possessed.

It would have been a slow and horrific death.

It would have risked the Order. It would have risked the entire Resistance.

It would have risked Draco.

â€œWas it quick?â€

â€œIt was quick.â€

There was nothing else to say.

She ignored the weight in her chest and flicked her wand, casting a diagnostic on herself.

The bones had regrown well, but her lung tissue, tendons and ligaments were still delicate and resetting. Apparition would not be advisable for several more hours.

She looked up at Draco. â€œDo you need to work? I can help you research inheritance law.â€

â€œIâ€™ve found what I need.â€

Hermione glanced around the room. It was sterile. Almost bare. The bed, a towering wardrobe, a desk, and a chair.

â€œIs this a guest room?â€

Dracoâ€™s mouth twisted in a brief grimace. â€œNo. Itâ€™s mine. I donâ€™t come here often.â€

Hermione looked around more carefully.

It was as impersonal as his hotel rooms; she didnâ€™t think sheâ€™d ever seen him with anything she could classify as personal possession. â€œI would have thought your bedroom would be green and silver.â€

Draco gave an empty-sounding laugh.

She picked up his hand, entwining their fingers. â€œIâ€™m sorry, Draco, that you had to come here because of me.â€

His fingers tightened, gripping hers comfortingly. â€œI would have come for the books.â€

Hermione lit up, and her eyes widened as she looked up at him. â€œCan Iâ€”can I see your library?â€

Dracoâ€™s eyes glittered, and he chuckled. â€œI had wondered how long it would take you to ask.â€

Hermioneâ€™s cheeks grew hot, and she dropped her eyes. â€œItâ€™s justâ€”I havenâ€™t had access to many magical texts since returning from studying abroad. We brought some from Hogwarts, and the Black library is alright. Iâ€™ve read most of them nowâ€”there isnâ€™t a place I can get books easily anymore.â€

â€œIâ€™ll show you the library, Granger.â€

She dressed, and Draco took her hand. They paused briefly at the door. Draco drew a sharp breath, as though he were bracing himself, before opening the door.

They stepped out into a long dark hallway. As they walked down it, several of the portraits muttered. Draco froze and then turned and stared at the pale, narrow-featured ancestor glaring at them.

â€œA word against her, and I will burn you to ashes. Pass on the warning.â€ Dracoâ€™s voice was deadly calm.

The ancestor turned green and nodded before ducking out of the portrait.

The library was enormous. Aisles and shelves of books with spiral staircases leading to a second story with paths running along more shelves.

â€œDracoâ€¦â€ Hermione felt as though there were stars in her eyes as she took it in. â€œThis isâ€”â€

She hesitated. He hated the house. Being there with her had to feel like a nightmare.

â€Itâ€™s nice library,â€ she finally said.

Draco gave a low laugh. â€œYouâ€™re allowed to like the library, Hermione. You donâ€™t have to dislike the manor on my account.â€

She stepped closer to a shelf and ran her eyes along all the spines. Her fingers hovered a breath away from the leather-bound tomes before she caught herself. â€œCan I touch them?â€

â€œOf course. I wouldnâ€™t show you books you couldnâ€™t touch.â€

She shrugged. â€œSome libraries are cursed against Muggle-borns.â€

Draco leaned against a shelf. â€œI donâ€™t think the Malfoys ever imagined a Muggle-born would be invited onto the estate.â€ He gave her a wry smile. â€œWhat do you want to see?â€

Hermione glanced around longingly before she spoke. â€œSoul theory, if you have any. Theyâ€™re usually a subsection in magical theory. I donâ€™t have much time.â€

Dracoâ€™s expression flickered as he turned and led her through the aisles.

She lost track of time poring over the books. There were so many books there sheâ€™d never seen or even heard of. She raced through one book after another until her eyes burned, and she had to tilt her head back to remove the crick in it. As she looked up, she found Draco watching her.

His eyes were dark as he stared at her. Her skin prickled, and a shiver ran down her spine as she set down her book and met his eyes.

He moved like water as he came towards her. He kissed her, and she drank him in. He slid his arms around her waist, and she drew her mouth back just enough to speak.

â€œWe have to be careful. Everything is still a bit fragile.â€

He nodded and kissed her again.

He was careful. Slow and gentle. He touched her as though she were glass in his hands.

When he pulled her shirt off and looked down at her, she flinched, and her hands darted up to cover her sternum.

â€œTheyâ€™ll fade,â€ she said quickly.

Suddenly she fully understood Ginnyâ€™s tears over her scar. The injury on her chest seemed so much more prominent than the scars on her wrist were. She couldnâ€™t hide it; couldnâ€™t conceal it under the sheets, or behind her back, or off to the side so the scars wouldnâ€™t constantly be visible.

She didnâ€™t think they would affect how Draco regarded herâ€”but maybe they would. The scarring was so present. Dropped right in the middle of her. Perhaps, after a while, being constantly revisited by the sight of them would cause things to change; eventually heâ€™d want something that didnâ€™t have the war so overtly burned into it. Someday, if it was over, he might want something that wasnâ€™t such a constant reminder of the past.

The thought cut through her like a blade. She bit her lip and pressed her hands more firmly against her sternum.

â€œIâ€™ll treat themâ€”so theyâ€™ll fade more.â€ She swallowed, and her fingers fluttered somewhat as she tried to cover them all and make them lessâ€”there.

Draco was still for a moment, then he caught her hands and pulled them away. He stared down, his silver eyes studying her intently until she could feel heat rising in her cheeks and ears and bleeding slowly down her neck.

â€œDo you see my scars that way? When you look at me, are they all you see?â€ he asked.

Hermione flinched. â€œNo.â€

â€œI donâ€™t see you that way either. Youâ€™re mine.â€ He let go of her hand, and his left hand lightly traced along her throat and collarbones and then down her sternum to where the scarring was most concentrated. â€œYou are. It doesnâ€™t matter what happens to you. You will still be mine.â€ His head dipped slowly towards her, and he captured her lips with his as he said the last word.

She twisted her other hand free and tangled her fingers in his robes, drawing him closer. She kissed him and held onto him so tightly her hands trembled.

When she traced her fingers along his body and felt the scars along his torso and across his shoulders, her heart ached, and she kissed along them. She would wish them all away for his sake, but it had never occurred to her to dislike them for hers.

He was hers. She didnâ€™t love him because she wanted to change him into something easier. He was hers.

He pushed into her, and she caught his face in her hands and almost spoke.

I love you.

It was on her tongue, but she hesitated and bit back the words.

There was a part of her that felt she might somehow doom them if she said it. If there were important things left unspoken, then perhaps tomorrow would come.

She kissed him instead.

I love you. She told him in the way she pressed her lips against his; in the manner her tongue slipped against the pulse point under his jaw; with the desperate way she tangled her fingers in his hair and the patterns she traced across his shoulders.

I love you.

I love you.

I love you.

She told him in the way she let go of herself and held onto him instead. I love you. I will always love you.

Eventually it was time to leave. There were no excuses to stay longer. The Order had been dealt a severe blow, and Hermione had to go face it.

She glanced at the library one more time before turning to leave.

â€œIâ€™ll bring you back. Anytime you want,â€ Draco said as they stepped through the doors.

She paused and gave him a small smile. â€œNo, you donâ€™t need to.â€

They walked back to a foyer they had passed through while walking to the library. It was an immaculate, empty room, but dark and cold for being near summer. Hermione looked around.

â€œIs it always this cold?â€

Draco looked up. â€œI think it used to be warmer. I remember it being warmer. The ley lines are corrupted now. It affects the house. There are wards I could use to reduce itâ€â€”he shruggedâ€”â€œthere have always been better things to do.â€

He slid a hand around her waist and side-along apparated her to Whitecroft.

Hermione stepped back and tightened her hold on her wand. Before she could apparate, Dracoâ€™s hand darted out, and he captured her wrist.

He pulled her back. â€œHermione, pleaseâ€”,â€ his voice broke off as he gripped her harder and hesitated. She looked up into his eyes.

She knew what he wanted to ask her.

He swallowed. â€œDonâ€™t get hurt again. Donâ€™tâ€”â€

She rose up on her toes and cut him off with her lips. He held her shoulders, and she could feel his temptation to apparate; to take her away and beg her to stay there.

She caught his face in her hands and gave him a slow kiss before pressing her face against his so their cheeks brushed.

â€œBe careful, Draco,â€ she murmured against the corner of his mouth. â€œBe careful. Donâ€™t die.â€

His fingers around her wrist tightened and almost shook. Then he gave a low sigh and let go of her.

She kissed him again and forced herself to step away. Their eyes were locked on one another as she vanished.

Grimmauld Place was tense when Hermione walked in. There was a palpable sense of despair in the house. She stood in the foyer for several seconds, absorbing it. Now that she was no longer running interference with Dracoâ€™s murderous rage, she had space to realise her own fury.

She headed up to the hospital ward, her jaw tense as she went to find Padma.

Padma burst into tears at the sight of her. â€œYouâ€™re still alive. I turned around, and youâ€™d vanished.â€

Padma hurried over and started casting diagnostics on Hermione.

Hermione shoved Padmaâ€™s wand away. â€œIâ€™m fine. Iâ€™ve recovered. If I were still in any danger, I wouldnâ€™t be standing here. Not that youâ€™d know, since you apparently forgot to use a decent diagnostic spell yesterday. Did you actually diagnose by sight?â€

Padma froze and paled. â€œI didnâ€™t? No. Waitâ€”first I used theâ€”â€ her voice cut off as her eyes widened with horror. â€œYouâ€™re right. Iâ€™m sorry. Iâ€™m so used to you doing the advanced charms when Iâ€™m with you. I did a basic oneâ€”thenâ€”then I think I must have panicked.â€

Hermione stared and then shook her head in disbelief. â€œI had vampire venom in my system, Padma, and unfortunately I wasnâ€™t in a state of mind to recall it. Parmaâ€™s face crumpled. â€œI donâ€™t have any excuse. Iâ€™m sorry.â€

â€œSorry doesnâ€™t bring back a corpse,â€ Hermione said, her voice shaking as she tried to rein in how venomously enraged she felt. Her neck and jaw were tense, straining with the effort of keeping her posture neutral. â€œThere are things that should be rote. â€œI know. I know. Iâ€™m so sorry.â€ Padma started crying harder.

Hermioneâ€™s tongue twisted with all the frustration she wanted to pour out at Padma. She felt so angry she could feel her magic crackling in her fingertips.

She slid her hands behind her back and curled them slowly into tight fists as she forced herself to swallow her fury.

Hermione drew a sharp breath and looked away from Padma. â€œWhereâ€™s Alastor?â€

Padma nodded, her exhaustion visible across her face. â€œA lotâ€”a lot of people died yesterday. I have the records mostly tallied for you. Ronâ€™s a mess. Lavender was killed too. Hermione swallowed and felt her legs threaten to give out. The hospital ward around her swam slightly.

Hermione blinked and felt dazed. â€œWhat?â€

â€œShacklebolt. You were friends, werenâ€™t you? You seemed to meet a lot.â€

â€œOhâ€”weâ€”weâ€”,â€ she swallowed. â€œIt was mostly hospital ward logistics.â€

What could she say about her relationship with Kingsley?

There was void in her chest where her emotions over his death should be. It was a blow, a horrific blow to the Order to lose him; sheâ€™d had sincere admiration for his skills as a strategist, for his capacity to make impossible choices. Yet the things heâ€™d doneâ€”that heâ€™d made her complicit inâ€”his tacit allowance of torture, his disregard for her advice as a healer, his exploitation of Draco. Heâ€™d been a puppet master, who found strings he could manipulate and made the Order dance accordingly. Heâ€™d kept them alive through sheer genius, but Hermione found herself gasping with relief at being free of him.

She didnâ€™t know what to feel over his death.

â€œI donâ€™t think Kingsley thought of anyone as his friend,â€ she finally said, looking away from Padma.

â€œWell, Ron is pretty wrecked over it all. Over Lavender and then everything else on top of it.â€

Hermione nodded absent-mindedly. She hadnâ€™t known Ron and Lavender had become serious. Kingsley was dead. Lost in a battle that the Order should never have let themselves be lured into.

The war was coming down to the line, and the Order had nothing to show for it after six years. All theyâ€™d been doing for the last year was surviving. Without Kingsleyâ€™s deft manipulation reining in Harry and the Resistance, she didnâ€™t know how they were going to manage even that.

Draco would be next.

She could feel it written into the future.

It had been in his eyes as he watched her apparate away.

â€œI need to speak to Moody. Make sure itâ€™s all written down, Padma; Iâ€™ll verify the reports later.â€

Moody was sitting behind a pile of paperwork. His expression hardened when he saw Hermione. He cast a dozen privacy charms before he spoke.

â€œYouâ€™re alive. Iâ€™ve been buried in reports, Patil said youâ€™d been injured and then went missing, and that damned elf came in, sent to â€œinform meâ€ that youâ€™d been removed for your protection. How long has Malfoy been using it?â€

Hermione swallowed and drew a deep breath. â€œLast April. Thatâ€™s what he told me.â€

Moodyâ€™s mouth twisted. He was the most paranoid man sheâ€™d ever known. Discovering that Grimmauld Place had had a latent spy in residence immediately after losing Kingsley had to have been a shock.

â€œI thought it was bound to Potter.â€

Hermione looked down at the floor. â€œHouse-elf magic is complicated. I haven't researched it extensivelyâ€”most of the books only study it to exploit it. They become highly attuned to the signature.â€

Her throat tightened as she thought about the elves that had stayed in Hogwarts. McGonagall had offered to break the ritual bond they had with the castle; Hermione had begged them all to leave when the school evacuated. Some had agreed, but others had declined. Hogwarts and the magic there was their home.

She didnâ€™t know if they were still alive inside Hogwarts prison, or if the Death Eaters had killed them all when the school was purged of â€˜uncooperative magicâ€™.

She stifled the thought. â€œMy theory is that whatever Sirius did to force the inheritance of Grimmauld Place to go to Harry split Kreacherâ€™s ties. â€œI want it gone.â€

â€œI was going to suggest it. His bond with Harry is so weak I think I can break it myself. Heâ€™ll lose the bond and connection to Grimmauld Place.â€

â€œWhat will happen to it then?â€ Moodyâ€™s eye was spinning suspiciously.

â€œHis ties will be solely to Malfoy Manor.â€

Moody seemed to be considering. Finally he cleared his throat. â€œFine. Gone by tonight, or Iâ€™ll be the one who deals with it.â€

Hermioneâ€™s shoulders tensed as she gave a sharp nod. â€œI have something else to report. Rodolphus Lestrange was killed in Bulgaria. Draco was summoned about it. Due to Tomâ€™s reaction to the news, Draco suspects that there may be a horcrux in the Lestrange vault.â€

â€œYou werenâ€™t cleared to.â€

She rolled her jaw. â€œHeâ€™s taken a Vow, Moody. Heâ€™s not going to betray the Order. Weâ€™ve known about the horcruxes for five years, and we failed to find a single one. Moody stood. â€œWatch your tone, Granger.â€

Hermione did not watch her tone. Her voice dropped lower, and it vibrated with intensity as she met his eyes. â€œYou have over-utilised him. She leaned across the table towards Moody. â€œWe lost Kingsley because he allowed the Order walk into a trap for the sake of solidarity. She slammed her occlumency walls more firmly into place and released a short breath.

She straightened and glanced around the room. â€œIâ€™m the only person youâ€™ve got in Grimmauld Place. I have been an obedient foot soldier. She met Moodyâ€™s gaze and gave a thin smile. â€œIf you have a better ally left in the Order, by all means, show me.â€

Moody said nothing.

She released a sharp breath. â€œDraco and I will try to find the horcrux. I need access to the sword of Gryffindor.
