Flashback 34

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

June 2003

Draco brought Hufflepuffâ€™s Cup to Hermione in less than a week.

She recognized it instantly from the pictures sheâ€™d seen researching. â€œYou found it.â€

He looked down at the ornate goblet in his hand. â€œI would have had it yesterday, but Iâ€™m going through the legal channels for vault access as well. It will be transferred to my name within the next month once the Ministry paperwork confirming Rodolphusâ€™ death goes through. Traditionally the process should take months, but itâ€™s being accelerated out of concern that Andromedaâ€™s daughter might try to claim it.â€

Hermione studied him carefully. â€œIs there any record that youâ€™ve been there?â€

Draco gave a thin, closed smile. â€œNone at all.â€

Hermioneâ€™s throat tightened. She didnâ€™t look at Draco as she swallowed and gave a sharp nod.

They couldnâ€™t afford any loose endsâ€”but every death felt like an additional noose around her neck. She shoved the thought away.

She opened her satchel and pulled out the sword of Gryffindor.

Draco raised an eyebrow and studied it. â€œDo you usually carry a sword?â€

Hermione stared down at the blade in her hands. â€œI got it last week. I knew youâ€™d be efficient. I figured I should come prepared.â€

Dracoâ€™s eyes glittered. â€œHow do we do this?â€

Hermione gnawed at her lower lip. â€œIâ€™m not sure. We should probably cast a barrier spell, to try to contain any potential backlash. Then, I suppose I stab it.â€ She gave him a small smile. â€œIâ€™ve never stabbed a cup.â€

â€œIâ€™ll do it.â€ He extended his hand to take the sword.

Hermione shook her head and stepped back, pulling the sword closer to herself. â€œNo. I need to. Thereâ€™s very little information on horcruxes in books. I need to analyse and observe it when itâ€™s destroyed.â€

Dracoâ€™s expression hardened, and he stepped towards her; his eyes were flint-like. â€œNo, you donâ€™t. You said Dumbledore was cursed destroying the ring. Give it to me, Granger.â€

Hermione gripped the hilt more tightly and jutted her chin out as he closed in on her.

â€œDumbledore was cursed because, for some reason, he put the ring on. Iâ€™m not going to wear it, Iâ€™m going to analyse it and then stab it. Harry stabbed the journal without any problem.â€

Dracoâ€™s hand closed around hers. â€œYouâ€™re the healer. If it tries to kill us, you have a better chance of saving me than I have of saving you.â€

She didnâ€™t loosen her hold. She looked steadily up at him. â€œI also specialise in analysing and deconstructing Dark Magic.â€

He stared down at her, his expression a mask. Her heart started pounding, and she tightened her hold on the sword, half-expecting him to try to wrench it out of her hands.

â€œDraco, let me do my job.â€

His expression wavered, and he let go of her hand. â€œTell me what to do if something goes wrong.â€

Hermione unclasped the bracelet on her wrist and held it out to him.

â€œThis charm here,â€ she pointed at a small cauldron, â€œif you activate it, it sends my location to Severus.â€

Dracoâ€™s expression flickered, and his mouth twisted into contempt. â€œSnape is a double agent. I thought the Order had stopped trusting him years ago.â€

â€œHeâ€™s a triple agent. Reducing his official clearance level within the Order is a cover. He has the same clearance I do. Heâ€™s known about you since the beginning. Heâ€™s the one who convinced Moody and Kingsley that your offer was probably legitimate.â€

Dracoâ€™s expression was disbelieving.

Hermione gave a small sigh. â€œYou donâ€™t need to trust him, but if Iâ€™m dying and not conscious to heal myself, heâ€™d probably be the only person who could do anything. Heâ€™s the one who contained the curse on Dumbledore.â€

Dracoâ€™s expression was mutinous, and he refused to touch the bracelet she was offering him.

The corner of her mouth twitched, and she lowered her hand. â€œYou asked what to do, and Iâ€™m telling you. If something goes wrong, heâ€™s the one to call. Whether you choose to use it or not is up to you.â€

The muscles in Dracoâ€™s jaw rippled, and he snatched the bracelet from her fingers.

She set up a barrier around herself and built a web of analytical magic around the Cup. Horcruxes were such a taboo there was no record of the magic ever being analysed. Hermione understood the fundamentals, based on theory, but actually dealing with a suspended piece of mangled soul was a level of Dark Magic she had never encountered in any form.

She ignored the charmwork crafted by Helga Hufflepuff when the Cup was created and focused on the Dark Magic. The Cup was surprisingly unprotected. Voldemort must have assumed that the Lestrange vault had sufficient safety measures on its own.

The soul fragment had interlaced and entwined itself with the other magic of the Cup. Poisonous and malevolent, it seemed to sense it was being disturbed. Hermione worked quickly; if she had enough information on Voldemortâ€™s magical signature, they might be able to use it to find other horcruxes.

Her eyes darted up to Draco. He was still as a statue as he watched her, as though he were not even breathing.

She wrote everything down on a scroll and picked up the sword of Gryffindor. It was a perfectly balanced sword, but it felt unwieldy compared to a knife. She drew a deep breath and drove the blade into the centre of the Cup, splitting it in half.

There was an unnerving moment of stillness. Hermione snatched up her wand.

The air shifted and moved around her.

There was a long drawn out scream, and the soul fragment rose up from the Cup like a black wraith with scarlet eyes. For a second it seemed poised to strike. It appeared to detect Hermione and moved sharply towards her. Then it wavered and dissolved into thin air. Â 

Nothing.

Hermione gave a small gasp and stood clutching her wand, her chest jerking unevenly as she tried to breathe.

She performed a quick spell to confirm the soul fragment was gone.

â€œItâ€™s done,â€ she finally said, flicking her wand and removing all the wards around her. â€œThatâ€”wasnâ€™t too bad. I thought it might be a lot worse than that.â€

She looked up and found Draco was only inches away from her. He dragged her into his arms and gripped her until she was crushed against his chest. â€œNeverâ€”please, not ever again.â€

She wanted to say no, but he was so tense he was nearly shaking. She found herself nodding slowly and saying, â€œAlright. I wonâ€™t.â€

Â 

Harry was like a lost lamb in Grimmauld Place. Ron had been placed on leave. He went to stay with his mother, while he grieved over Lavender and tried to come to terms with the guilt he felt over Kingsleyâ€™s death.

Hermione found Harry standing listlessly near Ginnyâ€™s door more often than not.

She opened the door after a visit with Ginny and found him standing blank-eyed outside the door. He had a black eye and cut lip, and his knuckles were split so badly there was still blood running down his fingers and dripping onto the floor.

His eyes brightened, and he seemed to come back to himself when he saw Hermione. â€œIs she alright? Is she doing any better? Do you think sheâ€™sâ€”do you think Iâ€™d be able to see her soon?â€

Hermione stared at him, her stomach dropping sharply at his appearance. Harry was worryingly fragile. She had tried several times to convince Ginny to come clean and tell Harry she was pregnant, but Ginny was adamant that telling him would make things worse. Hermione had appealed to Moody; to her disappointment, he had sided with Ginny. Harry was in no condition to handle any additional stress, and the Order could not handle the breakdown of trust if the truth came out at such a critical point. Things were too precarious.

Hermione swallowed her guilt while performing all her pantomimed protection and sterilisation charms on herself.

Ginny had a bump that was beginning to require precautionary glamours, if only to fool Dobby, who Harry regularly spoke with.

The baby was a boy. Ginny already referred to him as James.

â€œSheâ€™s the same, Harry. Iâ€™m sorry.â€

His expression fell. He gave a listless nod and started turning to go.

He was deathly pale, and the eye that wasnâ€™t purple and yellow was sunken.

She reached out to stop him and touched his face lightly. â€œYouâ€™re fighting again? When did you last sleep?â€

He jerked. â€œAâ€”a couple days ago. For a few hours.â€

She cast a diagnostic charm on him; he had several fractures in his hands and his eye socket, and his torso was covered in bruises.

She took him gently by the arm and led him down the hallway toward the hospital ward. â€œIs it nightmares again? I can teach you a few more occlumency techniques, it might help. Come on, let me fix you up and get you some Dreamless Sleep.â€

Harry gave a short, hysterical laugh. â€œI wish I had nightmares.â€

Hermione paused and looked at him. â€œWhat do you mean?â€

Harryâ€™s face twitched. â€œItâ€™s not nightmares, Hermione. It hasnâ€™t been nightmares in years. Itâ€™s him. When Iâ€™m asleep, Iâ€™m him. I torture people and kill them, and I feel how he feels when he does it. I donâ€™t even have to be asleep for it to happen, itâ€™s just worse when I am.â€ Harry was trembling with exhaustion. â€œLast time I fell asleep, he was trying new curses and then he drank a goblet of unicorn blood, and when I woke up, I could taste it. I havenâ€™tâ€”I havenâ€™t been able to eatâ€”â€

â€œHarry, you didnâ€™t tell me things had gotten so bad. You should have told me.â€

He twitched. â€œWhatâ€”are we talking again?â€ His expression was wounded as he stared at her. Â 

Hermioneâ€™s hand dropped away, and she looked back at him. â€œTell me what happens.â€

He shook his head, his eyes unfocused. â€œItâ€™s not so bad when I have something to focus on. When Iâ€™m on a missionâ€”when Iâ€™m with Ron and Ginâ€”when Iâ€™m remembering why Iâ€™m doing all this, I can keep him out. Butâ€”itâ€™s like thereâ€™s a place in my mind thatâ€™s an open door, and sometimes I step through it when Iâ€™m distracted. When I wake upâ€”I donâ€™t always know who Iâ€™m waking up as.â€

Hermione hurriedly pulled out several restorative potions. â€œTake these. I donâ€™t care how awful they taste, youâ€™re malnourished.â€

Harry gagged two down and then vomited them both up again. Hermione banished the mess and pulled out a stomach settler and handed it to him more gently.

â€œTry this one. If you havenâ€™t eaten in a few days, it can help. Sip it slowly.â€

â€œHermioneâ€”,â€ he said between sips as she muttered spells and spread bruise paste across his face. â€œI think thereâ€™s something wrong with me.â€

Hermioneâ€™s fingers twitched, and she shook her head sharply. â€œHarryâ€”I really think practicing occlumency could help with this. I can help you with it. Iâ€™ve read several books now, I think I can do it more gently than Severus did; maybe it would go better.â€

She cast another more complex diagnostic on him. He was underweight. He was chronically sleep deprived. He was worryingly frail. He was vibrating with magic in a way that he had for as long as she had known him. His magical signature was blurry and indistinct. It was the way Harry was; how heâ€™d always been, Pomfrey had told her that when Hermione asked during her early years of training.

Harry pressed his hand against his scar and looked away. â€œOcclumency doesnâ€™t help.â€

Hermione gave a frustrated sigh. â€œI know separating from your emotions can be difficult at first, but I think, if you try, it couldâ€”â€

â€œIt makes it worse,â€ Harry said in a hard voice. â€œEvery time I try, it makes it even worse.â€

Hermione swallowed and turned away to summon new restorative potions, her jaw tense. She handed the vials over wordlessly. Harry managed to keep them down.

She pulled out a vial of Dreamless Sleep without looking at him. â€œWell, we can at least agree that undisturbed sleep will help.â€

He gave a small nod and downed the potion.

With all the restoratives in his system, it took longer for the potion to take effect. He sat for a minute before his head lolled, and he dropped it against her shoulder.

Hermione hesitated, and then wrapped her arms around him, and hugged him tightly. â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™ll feel better after you sleep.â€

â€œI miss Gin.â€

Her throat caught, and she rested her head on his. â€œI know. Iâ€™m sorry.â€

Harry gave a low sob under his breath. â€œWhen I was with her, it seemed like everything was easier for a while.â€

Her hands trembled. â€œIâ€™m sorry, Harry.â€

She held him while he drifted off. Then she tucked him carefully under a blanket and went to speak with Alastor.

Fleur was in the war room when Hermione reached the doorway.

â€œI â€˜ave not â€˜eard from Gabrielle so often lately. She â€˜as always sent word on ze wireless so I would not worry. A little joke or phrase so I would know she is alright. But there â€˜as been almost nothing. You must â€˜ave some way to contact â€˜er. She is my baby sister, I am responsible for â€˜er.â€

Moodyâ€™s mouth twitched, and his eye spun sharply. â€œYour sister has always worked on her own terms. Iâ€™ll see what I can do.â€

Fleur gave a stiff nod. â€œThank you. Bill and I â€˜ave replaced the wards on all ze safe â€˜ouses once again, and we are renewing ze wards on ze cave. â€˜Owever, there are limits to â€˜ow much more we can do. We are nearly at ze capacity. We need a secondary location or ze magic quantities may compromise security.â€

Moody gave a low sigh and nodded, his eye rolling suspiciously downward. He seemed to have aged a decade in the two weeks since Kingsleyâ€™s death. â€œIâ€™ll have a team start scouting for new locations. Weâ€™ll need new guards for it. You and Bill will need to train them.â€

Fleur nodded again and departed.

Hermione studied Fleurâ€™s face as they passed each other. Fleur was a lovely, ethereal figure among an army that was increasingly grey and despairing, but the strain of the war was visible in her eyes. Fleur and Bill mirrored each other in their quiet guilt.

Fleurâ€™s parents had been early casualties when the war reached France. Gabrielle had survived by being at school rather than at home, but eventually the war had razed Beauxbatons too. Few members of the French Resistance had survived. Hermione suspected Gabrielleâ€™s veela allure had been what spared her. Gabrielleâ€™s methods had grown more vicious and vindictive over time. Flamboyant. Borderline careless. Hermione had started taking calming draught before even heading to the beach in Cornwall.

Flashback 35

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

June 2003

Hermione completed the bomb in two weeks. The final product was silver, ovoid with a faint luminescent shimmer, slightly smaller than a crystal ball, and freezing cold to touch.

The timing of the construction had been precise. When it was finished, she sent immediate word to Severus. He was due to visit Hogwarts that afternoon, to select new prisoners for use at Sussex.

â€œItâ€™s only visible to those who know to look for it,â€ she said, handing it carefully over. â€œItâ€™s set to activate at exactly noon on July 1st. There are some cushioning charms where I could risk them, butâ€”donâ€™t drop it.â€

Severus had been surveying it carefully until her warning.

He looked up and sneered at her. â€œThank you, Miss Granger, without your warning it would never have occurred to me to be cautious with a bomb.â€

Hermione didnâ€™t blink. â€œWould you rather I not mention itâ€™s delicate?â€ She arched her eyebrows. â€œItâ€™s designed to target the magic keeping us out of Hogwarts, so the higher you can get it, the better. The Astronomy tower would be ideal. It has some combustive power, but itâ€™s primarily designed to break the wards, the lower it is at detonation, the less impact it will have. At leastâ€”well, itâ€™s based entirely on arithmancyâ€”I couldnâ€™t actually test it.â€

â€œIâ€™m overcome with confidence,â€ Severus said, looking down at it again.

Hermione was so nervous her chest felt fractured. Lately it was a constant, grinding pain until she could barely breathe.

â€œI was unaware you had added bomb-making to your repertoire,â€ Severus said after a minute.

Hermione pulled off a heavy dragonhide apron and gloves and looked down at her hands, wincing. Her skin was speckled with burns, and several fingertips were green and withered; sheâ€™d have to carve off the remaining tissue and regrow it. Protective clothing and wards had limited effect when working with materials specifically chosen for their ability to destroy protection.

She rubbed her fingers together and watched as the skin cracked and fell off, leaving the bones exposed in places.

She grimaced and carefully wrapped bandages infused with essence of Dittany around her hands. â€œI started after we heard about the Albanian hospitalâ€”just the theory. I didnâ€™t understand the reports, and I felt guilty that maybe it was partly my fault that the hospital had been targeted. I thought I should at least know what happened to everyone there. Thenâ€”after the raid on the labs of the curse divisionâ€”I had everything, but it wasnâ€™t even worth trying to propose that the Order use a bomb.â€

She shrugged and started packing up her materials into all their carefully sealed and cushioned boxes and containers while Severus watched.

They were in an abandoned barn in the countryside that the Order had sectioned off for Hermione to work in. Initially, there had only been half-hearted objections made when the idea of using a bomb was proposed, but in the end the Order had agreed. No one had a better idea, and after half a year, and dozens of casualties from the attempts, there was a sense of raw desperation in everyone.

Hermione gingerly placed a flask, still half-full of shimmering, silver liquid, into a warded box and sealed it with several protective spells. â€œWhen Bill brought his analysis of the wards on Hogwarts last month, I realised that there was a chance I could combine charmwork and arithmancy with the traditional use of potions and alchemy for explosives. I was rereading Dumbledoreâ€™s collaboration with Flamel on the uses of dragonâ€™s blood and had the idea that it would react with silver nitrate dissolved in unicorn blood powerfully enough to dissolve the wards. The main challenge was finding a way to suspend it in something that could penetrate and adhere to the magic, so I used manticore venom to emulsify it. The detonation is primarily intended to create a blast radius large enough to destabilise and collapse the wards when the solvent hits it. I ran the numbers dozens of times before I brought the proposal to Moody; Iâ€™m almost positive Iâ€™ve calculated it all correctly.â€

She caught herself rambling and stopped, looking up at Severus.

As he studied her, his eyes glittered. Then his mouth pursed, and he stared back down at the bomb between them. â€œAre Potions and healing such tedious wartime careers that you must invent an entirely new field of magic in order to preoccupy yourself?â€

Hermione felt her cheeks warm. Her eyes dropped as the corner of her mouth quirked. â€œI thought it seemed like a logical way to combine the branches.â€

â€œYou would,â€ Severus said with muffled snort. â€œIf this explodes prematurely, I hope you will recall all the occasions in which I answered your incessant questions with the reminder that just because a thing can be imagined by you, doesnâ€™t mean it should be attempted.â€

He sighed. â€œYou always were an insufferable student to teach.â€ There was a pause as he eyed the bomb again. â€œThis is precisely why.â€

Hermione ducked her head to hide a smile.

That night she apparated to Whitecroft and waited nearly half an hour before Draco appeared.

Sheâ€™d barely seen Draco since heâ€™d returned from his trip. Heâ€™d brought the occasional report and renewed warnings that Voldemort was likely preparing for his own final blow. More Death Eaters than merely Lucius were being brought back to England.

Sheâ€™d decided, from the beginning, not to mention her most recent occupation within the Order.

When he appeared in the shack, he was dressed in formal robes, and his expression was braced. It was as though he had expected to find her bleeding to death on the floor.

She traced her fingers down her sternum. With treatment, the scars on her chest had faded so that the injury was less mangled looking. Soâ€”all that to say, if Harry manages to defeat You-Know-Who on Tuesday, you have to go,â€â€”she looked up from his hand and met his eyesâ€”â€œyou have to run.â€

Dracoâ€™s expression didnâ€™t so much as ripple.

Hermione looked down and played with the ring on his hand. â€œIâ€”there will be things Iâ€™ll be needed for, so I wouldnâ€™tâ€”I wonâ€™t be able to go with youâ€”if we win. But you should go anyway.â€


Draco scoffed. â€œIâ€™m not going to leave without you, Granger, Iâ€™llâ€”â€

Her throat tightened. She pressed her fingers to his lips and met his eyes. â€œYou have to run. If youâ€™re caughtâ€”I might not be able to protect you. If youâ€™re put on trial, even with Moody and I testifying for you, you could still be kissed or executed. If he diesâ€”as soon as he diesâ€”go. Youâ€™ll finally be free. It will be your life, Draco.â€

He sat up, his expression contemptuous. â€œIâ€™m never leaving you behind.â€

Hermioneâ€™s stomach dropped, and she shook her head, looking down. â€œIâ€™ve been thinking about this for a while. Draco, I have to stay. My job starts after the battles. At the endâ€”things could be messy. The Death Eaters will be desperate. Youâ€™d be a high priority to catch, and I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™ll be able to protect youâ€”thereâ€”there will be a lot that will come out.â€

He leaned forwards and gripped her hand. â€œYouâ€™re mine. Now and after the war. Your oath, you swore it.â€

â€œI am.â€ She looked up and met his eyes. â€œI promised you always, and I meant it. Always, always, as long as I live. Butâ€”,â€ her chest tightened, and her jaw trembled, â€œâ€”I wonâ€™t be ready to go when youâ€™ll need to. I donâ€™t want you to risk getting caught because youâ€™re waiting for me.â€

Dracoâ€™s eyes narrowed into slits. â€œHow long do you expect Iâ€™d be waiting?â€

Hermioneâ€™s eyes dropped. â€œI donâ€™t know. Thatâ€™s why I want you to go without me.â€

â€œYou have an idea, Iâ€™m sure.â€

She shook her head. â€œI donâ€™t know how fast things will move. It might be that Iâ€™ll have chance to leave once the hospital quiets. Butâ€”if we have prisoners and victims from Sussex, Iâ€™ll be the one responsible to care for themâ€”last timeâ€”last year, it was several months. Trials could start by then, and thenâ€”I might not be able toâ€”to leave. I donâ€™t want to have to worry youâ€™ll try to come for me and get caught.â€

â€œYouâ€™re referring to your trial; for your alleged war crimes.â€ His tone was accusing.

Hermione looked away. â€œIâ€™m sure it wonâ€™t be for long. Once Iâ€™m freeâ€”Iâ€™ll go somewhere you can find me. Thisâ€”it will be good for youâ€”to have some time to find yourself on your own.â€

â€œIs that why you came tonight? Because you wanted to say this to me?â€ There was a derisive drawl in his tone.

He gripped her hand and pulled her towards him until their faces were almost touching and slid a hand up her throat.

â€œYouâ€™re mine. Mine. You swore it. Your fucking Order sold you to me to buy themselves time. If anyone tries to put you in a cell to make themselves heroic, I will kill them.â€

He didnâ€™t wait for her to respond; he kissed her as though he were trying to brand her with his lips. She wrapped her arms around his neck and kissed him back.

When the hands on the clock pointed to five sharp, she drew back. â€œI have to go. I have more work.â€

She redressed quickly and drew her wand to apparate. Then she hesitated and stepped towards Draco.

â€œBe careful, Draco. And justâ€”keep in mind what I said, if you get a chanceâ€”â€

His expression was so hard he could have been carved from marble. â€œIâ€™ll see you after the battle.â€

Her fingers twitched. â€œPlease, be careful, Draco.â€

Donâ€™t die. The unspoken words hang in the air.

She swallowed and apparated away.

Grimmauld Place was almost throbbing with nervous activity. There were dozens of Resistance leaders whose names Hermione didnâ€™t even know in the war room, meeting with Moody and the rest of the Order. The attack was being planned as both a rescue and final confrontation.

Hermione was in the hospital ward working on preparations with Poppy, Padma, and the other field healers and nurses the Resistance had.

In the middle of the afternoon, Billâ€™s Irish Setter patronus came bounding into Grimmauld Place in search of Moody. Alastor left, leaving Remus and Tonks to run the meetings for an hour.

Hermione went to visit Ginny. It was off-schedule, but she didnâ€™t know how much time sheâ€™d have for the next several days.

She handed Ginny a counter-potion for the spattergroit glamour and flicked her wand to remove the additional glamour spells on Ginnyâ€™s stomach.

â€œHow are you?â€ she asked, sitting down as Ginnyâ€™s skin cleared, and her stomach slowly swelled into a bump set low in her pelvis.

â€œBored out of my mind, especially when I can hear everyone rushing around out there getting ready for tomorrow,â€ Ginny said. Her face was pensive and regretful, but her eyes were bright. â€œDo you think it really could be the final battle?â€

Hermione twitched a shoulder and looked away. â€œIf itâ€™s not, I donâ€™t know what weâ€™re going to do.â€

â€œHere, heâ€™s awake. You can feel him kicking.â€ Ginny caught Hermioneâ€™s hand and pressed it against her stomach, just above her hip bone. There was a pause, then Hermione felt a faint flutter under her palm.

â€œFeel that?â€ Ginny said.

â€œYes, I felt it.â€ There was another flutter and then stillness for several minutes.

â€œHe probably went to sleep â€ Ginny said, making a face. â€œYou should feel him at night, I think he does somersaults.â€

â€œI wonder where he gets his insomniac troublemaking genes from,â€ Hermione said in a dry voice as she stroked her fingers along Ginnyâ€™s stomach.

â€œCan you imagine him at Hogwarts someday after the war is over?â€ Ginnyâ€™s eyes were shining.

Hermione met Ginnyâ€™s gaze and managed a wan smile as she withdrew her hand. â€I pity the professors.â€

Hermione waved her wand and brought up all the diagnostics.

Ginny put her hand on Hermioneâ€™s wrist. â€œYou donâ€™t need to. Iâ€™ve been practicing, and I can pretty much do all the checkups. Justâ€”talk to me. Howâ€™s Harry? Is Ron alright? Have you seen Mum lately? Iâ€™ve got all these letters from them, but itâ€™s always just half the story.â€

â€œHarry isâ€”,â€ Hermione hesitated and put her wand away, â€œWell, heâ€™s doing better at the moment. Padma and I have had him in the hospital ward for the last few weeks, to get his weight up and monitor his sleep. So, heâ€”heâ€™s seeming a bit better, I think. He still has a lot of nightmares, Iâ€™ve been trying to get him to practice occlumency, but he wonâ€™t listen to me about it. With the attack coming up, heâ€™s finally stopped sneaking out and getting into fights. But heâ€™s making up for it by smoking more.â€ Hermione gave a small sigh. â€œHeâ€™s been very quiet lately, even with Ron.â€

Hermione fidgeted with her nails. â€œRonâ€™sâ€”Ronâ€™s holding on. He knows Harry is relying on him, but heâ€™s still broken-hearted over Lavender, and he still thinks Kingsleyâ€™s death is his fault. But heâ€™sâ€”heâ€™s holding on.â€

â€œDo you think itâ€™s going to work tomorrow?â€

Hermione felt as though there were a pit of acid in her stomach. â€œWellâ€”the Arithmancy numbers are good. Flitwick and Minerva both looked over my theory, and so far we havenâ€™t heard anything that indicates itâ€™s blown up prematurely.â€ Her heart was pounding violently in her chest, and she kept speaking more and more rapidly. â€œIf it doesnâ€™t go off, most of the Resistance is going to be there waiting andâ€”â€

â€œI wasnâ€™t referring to your part. I meant, do you think the Order can win tomorrow?â€

Hermione swallowed, her mouth dry. â€œWeâ€™re going to try.â€ She looked towards the door. â€œGinny, I really canâ€™t stay. Iâ€™m supposed to take Dreamless Sleep and get a few hours of rest before tomorrow. I still have a thousand things to do.â€

â€œOh right. Of course.â€ Ginny deflated. â€œI wonâ€™t keep you.â€

Hermione pulled out vials of potion to restore the spattergroit glamours and watched carefully to ensure they took effect properly.

â€œIâ€™ll let you know how it goes, as soon as we know,â€ Hermione said, glancing towards the door.

â€œTell Harry I love him. Tell him I believe in him,â€ Ginnyâ€™s voice trembled.

Hermione turned back and gave her a small smile. â€œI will.â€

It was the earliest hours of morning when groups of the Resistance started heading out towards Scotland. Hermione went to triple-check the potion inventories. Padma had already checked the inventory, but there were some potions Padma didnâ€™t know about that Hermione wanted to count the stores on. She was halfway through her count when she felt her personal wards breached.

She snapped a compartment closed and was recounting Skele-Gro vials when Harry appeared at the door.

She paused and looked over at him.

Harry rarely came to see her before he left. Heâ€™d leave on missions without a word, as though leaving things open-ended meant theyâ€™d surely carry on once he came back. Or heâ€™d stop by to give quick, â€œIâ€™m heading out. See you in two weeks.â€

There was never any mention of risk. It was like the summer holidays in school. Just a brief parting. The reunion was always regarded as inevitable.

He looked different. His stay in the hospital ward had gotten his features to fill out slightly, and his eyes seemed less dull and sunken. His colouring was pale but not so grey.

There was a pensive forlornness about him. The skinny boy in oversized clothes with broken glasses, who bought a trolley cart worth of snacks for his friend. He felt bruised. Not physically, but emotionally; as though heâ€™d been beaten into the ground.

Hermione studied him in silence for several seconds.

â€œWhat is it, Harry?â€

Her voice was soft, cautious. A voice sheâ€™d learned in the hospital ward.

The corner of his mouth twitched, and he cocked his head to the side. â€œI think this is going to be it.â€

Hermione gave him a small smile. â€œI hope so. I hope weâ€™re right about this.â€

â€œIâ€”,â€ Harry started to speak and then fell silent. He fidgeted with the knob on the door. â€œIâ€”Iâ€™m going to try to kill him. I havenâ€™t told anyone else. But I keep thinking about the prophecy. If itâ€™s real, I have to kill him. I donâ€™t think I can fight this war again.â€

Hermione stepped over and took his hand, entwining her fingers with his and staring into his eyes.

â€œI believe in you, Harry. I told you when you were eleven that you were a great wizard. Iâ€™ve never stopped believing it.â€

Harry gave her a wan smile, but it faded as quickly as it appeared. He stared at her, and he seemed almost like a ghost. As though her fingers might suddenly fall through his hand.

â€œHermione, I think Iâ€™m going to die today.â€

Hermione stared at him. Sheâ€™d never heard him say anything like that before. No matter the battle, no matter the injury, no matter the odds; Harry had always believed theyâ€™d make it to the next day.

â€œNo!â€ Her voice cracked like a whip. â€œNo. The whole Order and most of the a Resistance is going to be thereâ€”â€

â€œHermioneâ€”â€ Harry interrupted her with a firm voice. He let out a low breath and looked down at their hands. â€œI can feel it. I thoughtâ€”for awhile I thought there would be moreâ€”â€ his shoulder twitched, and his lips pressed together. â€œâ€”that winning would just be the beginning. Butâ€”Iâ€™mâ€”I think youâ€™re right. You were always right. The warâ€”is going to be all there is for me.â€

Hermione felt as though sheâ€™d been struck. She gripped his hand tighter. â€œThatâ€™s not how I meant it, Harry. Thatâ€™s not how I ever meant it. You cannot go to Hogwarts today with this mindset. This will work. I swearâ€”the equations were perfectâ€”I checked them a hundred times. We can win. You can do this. Ginnyâ€™s waiting for youâ€”â€

â€œHermione, stop.â€ Harry cut her off. â€œI need to say all this before I go.â€

He drew a sharp breath. â€œIâ€™m sorry it took me so long to believe you. I wanted you to be wrong about it all. I didnâ€™t realise how angry I was at you just because I wanted you to be wrong. I justâ€”I donâ€™t have time to make it up to you.â€

He was speaking faster and faster as though he were running out of time. As though he could see the remaining minutes of his life, and there were few.

â€œI know I shouldnâ€™t be here asking you for anything butâ€”butâ€”I want to ask you to take care of Ginny for me. In case I die.â€ His hold on her hand tightened more. â€œI donâ€™t know whatâ€™s going to happen today. I want to know someone will take care of her. She canâ€™t protect herself if sheâ€™s sick, but I know youâ€™llâ€”youâ€™llâ€”youâ€™ll do whatever it takes to keep her safe. I want to know sheâ€™ll be alright, no matter what happens. I know if sheâ€™s with you, she will be.â€

â€œHarryâ€”youâ€™ll come back.â€

Irritation flashed in Harryâ€™s eyes, but before he could speak, there was a noise beyond the door.

Hermione looked up to find Ron poking his head through the door. â€œHarry, weâ€™ve gotta go. Everyoneâ€™s waiting downstairs.â€

â€œRight. Iâ€™m coming.â€ Harry let go and stepped back. He gave Hermione one last look and a small salute before headed down the stairs. Hermione watched him until his head vanished from sight.

Ron lingered until Hermione looked back at him. â€œHe alright?â€

Hermioneâ€™s eyes dropped away. â€œHe wanted me to promise to take care of Ginny, in case he dies today. Ron, watch him.â€

Ronâ€™s expression tightened, but he seemed unsurprised. â€œI will. Wherever Harry goes, Iâ€™ll never be more than a few steps behind him.â€

Her mouth opened before she knew what to say. â€œRon. Be careful, Ron.â€ She reached for him. â€œBring him back.â€

He gave her a crooked smile that didnâ€™t reach his eyes.

He was so aged by the war. His narrow face was gaunt. His cheekbones jutted out, and his features were lined. The grey streaks in his hair had grown thicker. He looked so much older than twenty-two. Lavenderâ€™s death had extinguished some of the light in him.

Hermione hadnâ€™t even known. Hadnâ€™t noticed the relationship until it was gone.

His pale blue eyes still had steel in them. â€œI bring him back every mission. Thatâ€™s my job.â€ He glanced towards the stairs, and Hermione could tell his mind was on the day ahead. â€œTake care, Mione. This one could hit hospital ward hard.â€

She gave a shaky nod. Â 

â€œRight. Well, theyâ€™re waiting for me now.â€ Ron rested his hand on her shoulder for a moment and turned to leave.

Hermione stood alone in the potion cabinet, trying to remember when they had stopped hugging each other goodbye.

Flashback 36

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

July 2003

The hours of July 1st crawled past. Hermione and the other healers stood in the foyer, watching the clock. Waiting. There was little conversation.

Hermione stood by the window, drawing runes on the glass, carefully occluding every thought of Draco from her mind. Dread was twisted through her like an invasive vine. Her eyes kept darting over to clock. It was almost noon. Her hands began to tremble faintly. She gripped the window frame as she kept watching the clock.

Seamus had promised to send a patronus.

When the clock struck noon, Hermione stood, too afraid to even breathe as she watched the minutes continue to creep by.

There was nothing.

You did it wrong. You made a mistake. You miscalculated. They all trusted you, and you miscalculated something.

She kept staring at the hands until the room started blurring. Her fingertips and arms began to prick as she kept looking mutely at the clock. Her heart pounding so violently there was a sharp stabbing sensation through her chest.

A white, lumescent fox suddenly burst into the foyer. â€œIt worked! Noon exactly! The bloody thing took off the top of the Astronomy tower and ripped the wards down.â€

Hermione stood frozen until the fox vanished, then she gave a ragged gasp, and her knees gave out. She sat in the middle of the floor, sobbing. Her chest felt as though it were fracturing. She pressed her hands against her sternum and tried to breathe, her lungs jerking painfully.

It worked. She curled her head and pressed her jaw against her shoulder as she kept struggling to make herself breathe. There was burning throughout her throat and lungs. The bomb had worked. She was shuddering with relief. There were voices, but she couldnâ€™t make them out.

She pressed her hands over her mouth and tried to stop crying. Calm down. Calm down. Youâ€™re on duty. She buried her face in the crook of her arm and sobbed with relief until her head began throbbing.

A warm hand wrapped around her elbow and helped her up from the floor.

â€œCome on, dear,â€ Poppy said, wrapping an arm around Hermioneâ€™s shoulders as she kept sobbing against the back of her hand. â€œLetâ€™s get you a cup of tea. Padma will call if anyoneâ€™s brought in.â€

Poppy led Hermione down the hallway into the kitchen and seated her at the table. Hermione brushed her tears off her face and closed her eyes, forcing herself to breathe in to a count of four and then out to a count of six until her chest stopped spasming. Her sternum ached. She pressed her hand against the middle of her chest until she felt her heart rate slowing.

The kitchen was strangely silent. She opened her eyes and found herself surrounded by dozens of diagnostic projections. Poppy was standing beside her, her expression tense as she examined and manipulated all the various spells sheâ€™d cast over Hermione.

Hermioneâ€™s stomach dropped so sharply her hands clenched, tension burning through her spine as though sheâ€™d been electrocuted. She whipped out her own wand, banishing everything Poppy had cast with a sharp, slashing movement.

â€œI thought you said tea, Poppy. Has the definition changed?â€ Her throat was tight, and acid dripped from the words.

Poppy looked up at Hermione, her expression unapologetic. â€œYou may be a healing prodigy, but Iâ€™ve been a healer for decades longer than you. Youâ€”should be on several potions for your anxiety.â€

Hermione pushed her jaw out, then swallowed and dropped her eyes. â€œI canâ€™t. They interfere with my occlumency.â€

Poppy sniffed. â€œOcclumency is a bandage on a bombarda curse. Youâ€™re not fixing anything by dissociating, youâ€™re hiding it. Andâ€â€”her tone grew pointedâ€”â€œitâ€™s growing exacerbated by your use of the Dark Arts.â€

Hermione stiffened and looked up quickly.

Poppy met her gaze steadily. â€œIâ€™m no fool. Iâ€™ve suspected for long time what kinds of spells youâ€™ve been using in order to deconstruct and stop some of those curses from Sussex so quickly. Youâ€”youâ€”â€

Poppyâ€™s voice cut off, and she pressed her lips together for several seconds, her mouth trembling. She drew a deep breath. â€œDark Magic is cumulative. Mind or body, it exacts a price. I havenâ€™t said anything until now because I know you understand the toll better than I do.â€ She placed a tentative hand on Hermioneâ€™s shoulder. â€œYou must know youâ€™re reaching the point where the damage is becoming irreversible.â€

Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched, and she looked away, noting the privacy spells that had been cast on the room.

â€œI know.â€

She stared down at her hands. â€œIâ€”it wasnâ€™tâ€”it didnâ€™t used toâ€”â€ She fell silent and her hand rose subconsciously to her throat, fidgeting with the empty chain there. She shook her head. Â â€œNever mind. It doesnâ€™t matter.â€

She looked up at Poppy with a wan smile. â€œIâ€™ll stop when the war is over. Iâ€™ll stop. I promise. And, Iâ€™ll see a mind healer too.â€

Poppy gave sad sigh and nodded, rubbing small circles on Hermioneâ€™s back. â€œAll of you children should see mind healers. You and Harry especially. I wish Iâ€™d pushed Albus harder about having Harry taken to St Mungoâ€™s.â€

Hermione blinked and furrowed her eyebrows. â€œWhat do you mean?â€

â€œOh.â€ Poppy gave another sigh, and her exhaustion grew visible in her face. â€œDuring Harryâ€™s first year, after that unfortunate situation with Professor Quirrell, when I first examined Harry, I became concerned about his magical signature. It was irregular, almost as though he had two.â€

â€œTwo?â€ Hermione echoed, a cold creeping sensation slowly bleeding over her, as though there was ice sliding through her veins.

â€œYes. Iâ€™d never seen anything like it before. I went to Albus. He said it must be from the Killing Curse all those years before, that it must have split off a small piece of Harryâ€™s signature. Itâ€™s such shame no one thought to have him examined as a baby before he was left with his relatives. Albus looked at the diagnostics himself and said it was nothing to be concerned with. When I pushed, he said Harry would likely be subjected to extensive and traumatic examination at St Mungoâ€™s by researchers wanting to use him to study the Killing curse. Albus said he thought the issue would resolve itself eventually. It seemed that it did, over the years the signatures appeared to rebond.â€

Poppy tilted her head to the side thoughtfully. â€œButâ€”with all the headaches he suffers from, I wonder if perhaps it didnâ€™t happen properly.â€

Hermione felt as though sheâ€™d been struck.

â€œThere were two magical signatures? Not a residual curse signature and a magical signature?â€ Hermione said sharply.

â€œMagical,â€ Poppy said as she nodded and pulled out the chair beside Hermione. She sat down with a sigh. â€œI tried to find record of a similar phenomena in healing history, but thereâ€™s nothing like it that I could find. Then again, Harry is the only person who ever survived the Killing Curse.â€

Hermioneâ€™s hands started trembling. â€œYou saidâ€”I asked you about his magical signature years ago. You said it was fine. That it was normal for Harry.â€

Poppy rested her hand gently on Hermioneâ€™s shoulder again. â€œI didnâ€™t want you to worry. By the time you asked, they were almost entirely bonded back together.â€

Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched, and she struggled to find words to ask the next question. â€œSo it was the same signature? The smaller piece was identical?â€

â€œNot exactly. Due to the split, Albus said it developed uniquelyâ€”â€

Hermione stood up so abruptly her chair fell backwards, clattering on the stone floor. â€œThatâ€™s not how it works. Magical signatures are soul-based, they donâ€™tâ€”develop differently. I have to go.â€

She fled the kitchen and raced upstairs to grab her cloak and satchel and then ran out the door of Grimmauld Place before anyone could stop her.

She apparated with a hard crack and reappeared in the designated spot in the Forbidden Forest that the Order has chosen for approaching Hogwarts.

The castle stood in the distance. Even from where she stood, she could smell the Dark Magic in the air, mixed with the metallic tang of the explosion. She started toward the castle as quickly as she could.

â€œGranger?â€ A broad-shouldered Resistance fighter appeared from next to a tree, a disillusionment charm fading away.

She looked over at him sharply. She recognized him vaguely but not well enough to know his name.

â€œWhat are you doing here, Granger?â€

â€œI need to see Harry.â€ She stared at him, gripping her wand so tightly she could feel the wood biting into the bones in her hand. Her whole body felt cold. â€œI came because I need to see Harry.â€

The man looked bewildered. â€œHeâ€™s at the castle. Everyone moved in. Thereâ€™s no one out here but scouts to keep watch.â€

Hermione swallowed hard and nodded. â€œThen Iâ€™ll go to the castle.â€

They made their way to the edge of the Forbidden Forest. She could see the Astronomy Tower, smoking and damaged from the blast. They stopped near several heavily disillusioned tents.

â€œHermione, what are you doing here?â€ Angelina came out of a tent.

â€œI need to see Harry.â€

â€œNow? Canâ€™t this wait until tonight?â€

Hermione scoffed. â€œIf it could wait I wouldnâ€™t have just apparated five hundred miles.â€

â€œAlright. Fine. Iâ€™ll send word. Stay here at camp. Weâ€™ll send a few people in to get the message to Harry.â€

Hermione swallowed and resigned herself to waiting. There was a burning sensation in the pit of her stomach.

It felt like hours. Hermione joined the field healers in the tent, healing the injured fighters and determining who needed to be sent on to Grimmauld Place. Â 

She got snatches of reports on how things were going closer to the castle. After the bomb went off, the wards had collapsed entirely. The Resistance had moved in quickly. The attack had taken the prison entirely off-guard. Beyond the wards the security was surprisingly lax. The guards had fallen back.

The Resistance currently held the Entrance Hall and the Great Hall. They were trying to strengthen their foothold before the inevitable counterstrike.

There was a nervous energy over how well the attack had gone so far. Harry and the team that had snuck into Hogwarts during the initial attack still had not reappeared.

The air in the tent felt suffocating, filled with the scent of blood, residual Dark Magic, and potions. The salty, coppery tang of blood mixed with spent magic burned in her nose.

Hermione worked silently, her eyes sweeping frequently over to the opening of the tent, looking for Harry.

Finally the tent flap was shoved aside, and Harry burst in, followed by Ron and Fred. Her heart jumped into her throat as she caught sight of Harryâ€™s pale face.

You should have known. Heâ€™s your best friend, you should have realised.

â€œHermione, whatâ€™s going on?â€

Hermione hurried across the tent towards Harry. As soon as he was within reach, her fingers gripped the fabric of his shirt.

â€œWe got word you were here when we rejoined the main force in the castle.â€ Harry was covered in dust and grime. He rubbed at his face and left a band of soot across his forehead. â€œWhat are you doing here? Did something happen to Ginny?â€

â€œNo.â€ Hermione shook her head sharply. â€œNo. Ginny is fine. Sheâ€™s back at Grimmauld Place. Come with me, thereâ€™s a smaller tent over this way.â€

Harry gave a visible sigh of relief and followed her. His pensive mood had vanished. His eyes were clear. He had an air of intense focus about him, the way he had been when playing Quidditch.

â€œWe found it. The one in Hogwarts. It was in the Room of Requirement. It was Ravenclawâ€™s diadem. Ron cut it in half with the Sword of Gryffindor. Soâ€”it's just the snake now. Neville andâ€”â€

Hermione pulled him into a small tent and blocked Ron and Fred from following. â€œI need to check something privately,â€ she said. â€œIt will just take a few minutes.â€

Ron looked down at her, his eyebrows furrowed. â€œHermione, this really isnâ€™tâ€”Harryâ€™s supposed to beâ€”â€

Her stomach knotted painfully as she stared up into Ronâ€™s worried face. â€œI need a few minutes. This is important,â€ she said.

Ron studied her and gave a slow nod. â€œRight. Weâ€™ll be outside then.â€

Her throat felt thick as she gave a small nod in return. â€œThank you.â€

She warded the entrance, turned, and found Harryâ€™s questioning face.

She drew a shivering breath. â€œHarry, I need you to sit down and let me check something. I know this seems like the wrong time, but I need you to trust me.â€

She pushed him into a chair and rested her fingers gently against his temple, trying to rub away the dirt smeared across his face. As she studied his face, there was an aching sensation across her cheekbones, and her fingers trembled slightly.

She forced her occlumency walls into place and withdrew her hand. Her fingers were steady, and her attention surgically precise as she cast a complex diagnostic projection over him. Then she started muttering incantations under her breath, weaving an analytic web of magic around him.

She stepped back and studied his magical signature carefully. If there had been two separate signatures in the past, there werenâ€™t anymore. They had bonded almost entirely. She carefully tried to tease them apart, trying to make out which parts belonged to which, but they were conjoined and entwined.

Harry was watching her. â€œHermione, what are you doing?â€

Hermione ignored him, carefully watching the variance in the projections as she cast a spell on him. It had no effect. She tried several more.

She studied the magic sheâ€™d woven around him. There was painful, weighted sensation in her chest. She blinked and met Harryâ€™s eyes, reaching out and resting a hand on his shoulder.

â€œHarryâ€”I need to touch your scar.â€

â€œNo, donâ€™t.â€ Harry jerked back.

Hermioneâ€™s hold on his shoulder tightened until she could feel his bones through his jacket. Heâ€™d always been so thin. â€œHarry, I have to do this. Iâ€™m sorry, I know itâ€™s painful. You know I wouldnâ€™t be here if it werenâ€™t urgent.â€

Harry wavered and swallowed as he looked up at her. â€œFine. You can do it. But tell me why.â€

Hermione hesitated, her lips twitching. â€œLet me check this firstâ€”then Iâ€™ll tell you what Iâ€™m doing.â€

His eyes searched her face for a moment before he gave a short nod.

Hermione muttered a spell and pressed the tip of her wand against the lighting bolt scar slicing through his forehead. The instant her wand touched the skin, Harry screamed through his teeth, his head whipping back violently as he nearly collapsed. The magical signature projected in front on him suddenly shivered and parts of it slowly turned blood red, casting into stark relief which parts of the signature were foreign. There were red tendrils twisting and tightening where they were entwined and conjoined with the larger magical signature.

It was identical to the magical signature in Hufflepuffâ€™s Cup.

Hermione jerked her wand back with a low gasp. â€œOh god.â€

â€œWhat is that? Hermione! Whatâ€”is that?â€ Harry was staring at the projection before him, his face deathly pale.

Hermione felt as though she were being ground into dust inside. She parted her lips, but no sound emerged from her throat.

She forced herself to swallow and tried again. â€œItâ€™sâ€”itâ€™s a soul shard, Harry. Thereâ€™sâ€”thereâ€™s a piece of Tomâ€™s soul inside you.â€

Harryâ€™s jaw went slack, and he turned grey as he continued to stare at the projection in front of him.

Hermione swallowed, and her jaw trembled. She twisted her wand in her hands with shaking fingers. â€œTheâ€”the soul gets torn when the Killing Curse is used. Because of the way the curse backfired when you were a baby, a piece must have gotten severed. Normally it would be placed inside an objectâ€”but if it was just left thereâ€”it must have latched itself onto the only living thing there and tried to integrate itself with you.â€

Her chest felt so tight she could barely breathe. â€œIâ€™m so sorry. I should have realised sooner. I should haveâ€”if Iâ€™d realisedâ€”Iâ€™m so sorry, Harry.â€

Harry sat as though frozen as he stared at his magical signature and the parasitic soul fragment that wound around and through it. Hermioneâ€™s tongue was curdled in her mouth, as though she were about to be sick.

She tried to think of something, of anything. There had to be some way to get it out, to remove it without killing Harry.

Draco might have a book in his library that she could use. The Resistance would fall back and leave Hogwarts. She had to get Harry away and buy herself time to research; there might be something she could do. She just needed to get Harry away. Then she could go to Draco.

â€œOf course.â€ Harry gave a small laugh that roused Hermione from her thoughts. â€œOf courseâ€”thatâ€™s how it is. â€˜Neither can live while the other survives.â€™ I should have guessed.â€ He made a sound, and Hermione wasnâ€™t sure if it was another laugh or a sob. He stood up, banishing the projections around him with a flick of his own wand. Then he raised a hand and pressed the heel against his scar.

â€œAll this timeâ€”I thought I was the Chosen One because Tom and I were similar. Half Bloods, orphans, twin wandcores, parselmouths...â€ His voice trailed off, and he gave a low laugh. â€œAll this timeâ€”I thought Iâ€™d defeat him by rejecting Dark Magic and always choosing lightâ€”even when I felt like I was going mad from the draw of it. I thought that was what it was about. That it was something like that.â€ Harry made a choking sound. â€œOf course it wasnâ€™t.â€

There was a silence like a stopped heart.

Then there was an agonized scream in the distance that ripped the air apart.

â€œHarry! Weâ€™ve gotta go,â€ Ron yelled through the warded tent opening.

Harry looked up sharply, but his eyes were far away as though he were in a dream. He looked at Hermione and only seemed to be half-aware of her. â€œYouâ€™ll take care of Ginny, wonâ€™t you? And tell Ron, afterwards, he was the best partner a bloke could ask for.â€

He started towards the door, and Hermione realised with freezing horror what Harry intended to do. She flung herself in front of him, gripping his arms and forcing him to stop.

â€œNo, Harry. No. I can fix this. We got the horcrux in Hogwarts. Weâ€™ll fall back. Give me some time, and Iâ€™ll find a way to remove it. Iâ€™m sure thereâ€™s a way. I will make a way. Harryâ€”Harry.â€ She tried to force him to look into her eyes. â€œYouâ€™re not going to die today.â€

Harry reached up and touched her face with his fingertips. He studied her as though he were memorising her. As though he hadnâ€™t seen her in years and never expected to see her again.

â€œYouâ€™re a good friend, Hermione. Youâ€™ve always believed in me. Even more than I did sometimes.â€

She flinched away from his touch. â€œWeâ€™ll send word to Moody and have everyone pull out before more Death Eaters arrive. Harryâ€”you have to let me try to find a way to remove it.â€

Harry shook his head and gave a wistful smile. â€œHeâ€™s in my head, Hermione. The connection we have, itâ€™s in my brain. Thereâ€™s no safe way to reverse long-term Dark Magic in the brain. Thatâ€™s what you said after you tried to heal Arthur.â€

Hermioneâ€™s fingers twitched.

â€œIâ€™ll find a way. I will invent it if I have to.â€ Hermioneâ€™s voice shook with intensity. â€œYou have to let me try.â€

Harry grasped her wrist and firmly pulled her hands off him. â€œHermioneâ€”I told you this morning, today is the day. This is how itâ€™s supposed to be. Neither can live, neither will survive. This is how it was always supposed to be.â€

â€œNo, itâ€™s not. We can keep fighting. Weâ€™ll pull outâ€”â€

He stared at her, his face serious. â€œPeople died today, Hermione. Theyâ€™ve been dying for years, fighting for me, protecting me, coming here so I could get into Hogwarts. My whole lifeâ€”people have died trying to protect me. I can't let anyone else die for meâ€”not when I know I have the power to stop all of this. This war canâ€™t go longer. It has to end. Thisâ€”is what Iâ€™m supposed to do.â€

He looked down at the ground, and the resolution in his expression fractured somewhat. â€œYouâ€™ll take care of Ginny, wonâ€™t you? And tell herâ€”tell her sheâ€™ll be what Iâ€™m thinking ofâ€”to the very end.â€

He started to move past her, but Hermione grabbed him again. Her throat closed, as though her desperation was strangling her.

â€œHarryâ€”Harryâ€”Ginny is pregnant.â€

Harry froze as though sheâ€™d petrified him. Then he turned and stared at her, his expression uncomprehending.

Hermione gave a small sob. Her heart was beating so hard it felt as though it were being bruised inside her chest. â€œShe realised she was pregnant in February, and she asked me to hide it because she was afraid it would be too much for you to be worrying about. But sheâ€™s pregnant. Itâ€™s a boy. Heâ€™s due in October. So youâ€”you canâ€™t dieâ€”because you have to meet your son. Please, please, come with meâ€”â€ Her voice broke.

Harry shook his head slowly. â€œDonâ€™tâ€”donâ€™t do this to me, Hermione. Donâ€™t say something like that to try to stop me.â€

There were cold tears escaping the corners of her eyes, and her voice shook with intensity. â€œIâ€™m not lying to you, Harry. I swear on my magic. Sheâ€™s almost six months pregnant. Ever since she learned the gender, sheâ€™s called him James.â€

Harry paled and made a pained sound in the back of his throat.

Hermioneâ€™s face twisted as she tried not to cry. She gripped him more tightly. â€œPleaseâ€”Harry. Letâ€™s go find Alastor and have everyone pull back.â€

Harry started shaking. She could see him wavering.

â€œPlease, Harry.â€

The noise, the screaming outside was growing louder. She heard Ron yell again. Harry twitched and looked towards the tent opening.

He dropped his head down for a moment, and he drew a sharp breath.

â€œPromise me youâ€™ll take care of them for me.â€

Hermione felt something inside her shrivel and die. Her hands dropped away, falling limp at her sides. Harryâ€™s fingers darted out; he caught her right hand and gripped it.

His eyes were desperate. â€œPromise me, Hermione. Promise me.â€

â€œI promise.â€ The words felt as though they were torn out of her heart and dragged up her throat. They fell like blood from her lips. â€œIâ€™ll always take care of them, as long as I live.â€

His grip on her hand tightened, and his body slumped with relief. Then he let go and stepped back â€œThank you. Thank you for everything you did for me.â€

He reached into his pocket, pulled out his Invisibility Cloak, and disappeared.

Hermione stood dazedly staring at the spot heâ€™d vanished from. She hardly felt able to think. It was as though her entire life had dropped out from under her feet.

She forced herself to move and stumbled to the entrance of the tent.

â€œHermione, whereâ€™s Harry?â€ Ron stared past her into the empty tent.

â€œGoneâ€”,â€ her voice was broken, rasping. She gripped the canvas of the tent until her knuckles showed white. â€œIâ€™m sorry. I tried to stop him. He put on his cloak and disappeared.â€

â€œWhat did youâ€”? Fuck. Never mind. Get out of here, thereâ€™s more Death Eaters than we thought they had.â€ Ron was looking wildly around at the battle that was closing in on them. â€œIâ€™ll find Harry. You get out of here.â€

Before Hermione could say anything, Ron and Fred had run off towards the castle.

Hermione stood in the opening of the tent, watching, as though she were trapped in a nightmare on the edge of a battlefield.

There were spells flying in every direction. The air was thick with the smell of smoke, spent curses, blood, and burning flesh. A cacophony of screams and the shouted incantations. The Death Eater reinforcements were coming from Hogsmeade, a huge force sweeping up and hemming the Resistance against the walls of Hogwarts.

A witch thirty feet away from Hermione was hit by a purple curse and fell. As she struck the ground, her head turned towards Hermione, face slack, eyes blank. Hermioneâ€™s hand twitched. She recognized the woman. Sheâ€™d healed her, saved her life, a little more than a month ago, after the battle in Surrey.

The Death Eater whoâ€™d killed the witch turned to move on, his face was unmasked. As Hermione caught sight of his features, the blood in her veins ran cold.

She recognised him.

She had seen him before. Heâ€™d been captured, months earlier, during one of the Orderâ€™s prison rescues. He was one of the innumerable Death Eaters sheâ€™d prepped for stasis and administered the Draught of Living Death to. Heâ€™d been handed over to Bill and Fleur to be placed in the Orderâ€™s prison.

Her eyes swept across the battlefield again: five years of prisoners, removed from stasis and sent into battle. That was why there were more Death Eaters than the Order had expected.

How had they found the prison? They should never have been able to find it. The Order had specifically created it with the purpose of ensuring that even if the war was lost, the prison still wouldnâ€™t be compromised.

There was an explosion so violent the ground shook. Dozens of Resistance fighters were flung back by a growing, writhing inferno of flames. The air grew thick and putrid and sulfuric as an enormous burning serpent slithered across the field, forcing the Resistance further back.

Voldemort stood beside it, flanked by a group of masked and unmasked Death Eaters, his snake Nagini draped across his shoulders.

â€œHarry Potter, come and face me.â€

Voldemortâ€™s voice was high and cold, like the edge of a blade dragged along the spine. It was amplified, so Hermione could hear the sibilant edge of his pronunciation as though he were at her shoulder, speaking directly into her ear.

â€œGive yourself up, or I will punish every man, woman, and child foolish enough to follow and protect you.â€

Harry did not appear or step forward.

Hermione had never seen Voldemort in person before. Sheâ€™s heard countless descriptions, but it was the first time sheâ€™d ever seen him.

He was thin and horrifyingly pale; his eyes red as blood and almost glowing.

Dozens of fighters suddenly rushed forward to attack. Voldemort flicked his wand, and they were thrown back violently. The group of Death Eaters behind him moved forward, but Voldemort stilled them with a gesture.

â€œYour beloved Chosen One has brought you here and abandoned you,â€ Voldemort said.

The Resistance kept re-advancing and being forced back. Alastor was among them. He was fighting savagely, flanked by Remus and Tonks. Minerva was dueling alongside them; sheâ€™d left her orphans in order to help Harry infiltrate Hogwarts and find the horcrux. Many of the DA members were in each renewed charge. Parvati. Seamus. Angelina kept fighting forward despite her limp. Neville too. He dodged several spells until he managed to get noticeably close to Voldemort.

After several attacks by the Resistance Voldemort seemed to grow bored of waiting for Harry. He flung most of the Resistance back but caught Neville in a body-bind and stepped closer, studying Nevilleâ€™s face.

â€œRushing forward without a wand in your hand. The Resistance is a disease in the magical world. Nagini, enjoy this one.â€

He extended his arm, and Nagini used it to slither down from his shoulders and drop to the ground. Voldemort turned and directed his fiendfyre serpent to advance on the Resistance.

Nagini reared back to strike, but as she did so, Neville suddenly broke free of the magic restraining him. His hand shot out. As Voldemort had said, he wasnâ€™t holding a wand. Hermioneâ€™s heart stalled as the sword of Gryffindor flashed through the air and severed Naginiâ€™s head.

The snake dropped, and a wave of dark magic rippled out and dissipated into the air.

Voldemort gave a scream of rage that tore through the air with such violence Hermione could feel the pressure against her eardrums. He raised his wand to curse Neville, but, before a spell left his lips, Harry appeared, standing protectively in front of Neville.

â€œHere I am, Tom,â€ Harry said. His voice was almost too quiet to hear compared to Voldemortâ€™s amplification.

The entire field went still.

Harry and Voldemort stood facing each other at the base of the Astronomy Tower.

Voldemort seemed surprised to suddenly find Harry before him. He stared at him for several seconds in silence without moving.

â€œHarry Potter,â€ he finally whispered. â€œThe Boy Who Lived.â€

No one in the Resistance moved. The Death Eaters did not move. They were all waiting. The whole war reduced to a moment.

Harryâ€™s wand hung from his fingers. Not raised. Not prepared to duel. He was simply standing, waiting. Facing death with an expression of grief and resignation.

Voldemort seemed baffled. He tilted his head to one side and stared at Harry for several seconds before extending his wand.

Hermione saw his mouth move.

A flash of green light.

The curse struck Harry, and a backlash of power ricocheted back and struck Voldemort, throwing him off his feet.

Harry dropped to the ground.

Hermione felt as though her heart had ceased beating. She didnâ€™t scream, but she could feel a strangled sob in her chest and throat, like a creature in its death throes, trying to break free.

It felt like she was dying too.

Harry. Please. Youâ€™re the boy who lived.

The entire army was too shocked to make a sound.

Voldemort stood up, almost shakily, but Harry still lay where heâ€™d fallen.

â€œMy Lord.â€ Lucius Malfoy and several other unmasked Death Eaters had gathered around Voldemort.

â€œI do not require assisssstance.â€ Voldemort jerked away from the hands extended towards him. â€œIs the boy dead?â€

Ron and Fred and several others were moving towards Harry, but before they could reach him, Voldemort cast a spell, and Harryâ€™s body was violently jerked across the grass towards him.

â€œAllow me, my Lord,â€ Lucius said, giving a low bow to Voldemort before approaching Harryâ€™s body.

Lucius was gaunt, even from a distance. It was as though his skin were tightly drawn over his bones. His blond hair was longer than it had been when Hermione had fought him in the Ministry so many years before. He still moved with an easy grace almost reminiscent of Draco, but there was an edge of eager unpredictability woven into the way he moved. An aristocratic bloodlust.

He knelt down next to Harry and slowly slid a hand up Harryâ€™s throat.

Luciusâ€™ hand jerked back, and he stood as though burned.

â€œHeâ€™s alive.â€

As the words were uttered, Harry suddenly moved, his wand whipping up.

Voldemort was quicker and already poised to strike.

â€œAvada Kedavra.â€

The curse struck Harry in the chest, and his green eyes went blank.

Voldemort wasnâ€™t done. His face contorted with rage.

â€œAvada Kedavra.â€ The curse struck Harryâ€™s body again.

There was screaming now. The Resistance screamed Harryâ€™s name, over and over. Hermione gave a low sob, torn from deep in her chest, gripping the canvas of the tent in order to keep from dropping with despair onto the ground.

â€œHarry!â€ Ron threw himself towards Harry.

A scarlet curse shot out from among the Death Eaters and struck Ron. He flew through the air and crashed into the Astronomy Tower with a sickening crunch that Hermione could hear across the field.

Other Resistance fighters were moving towards Harry too, as though they didnâ€™t know what to do but try to reach his body.

Run. Hermione wanted to scream it, beg it, plead it. Leave the dead behind.

Run.

â€œAvada Kedavra!â€ Voldemort cast another killing curse on Harry.

Hermione started to flee but flinched as she heard another â€œAvada Kedavra!â€

She looked back one last time and watched Voldemort walk over, casting the Killing Curse on Harry a sixth time. Voldemortâ€™s right hand was extended, his wand hanging from his fingertips, but his left hand was pressed lightly against the centre of his chest.

The gesture was strangely human. As though he were injured but trying to hide it.

There was still a horcrux left. Harryâ€™s plan would have worked, it should have worked, but there was still a horcrux left.

Hermioneâ€™s eyes swept across the battlefield. The fighting had resumed, but the Resistance had lost. They were too shocked and despairing as they tried to defend themselves.

Hermioneâ€™s hand twitched forward. Then she set her jaw and slammed her occlumency walls into place.

You canâ€™t save them. Someone has to find the last horcrux. She turned and bolted towards the apparition point.

As soon as she was away from the disillusioned tents, she was spotted. Several spells shot past her as she made for the treeline.

A curse grazed her shoulder, but her cloak blocked it. She flung herself into the forest. As she reached the anti-apparition marker, a Death Eater suddenly appeared, blocking her path and catching hold of her arm.

Hermione twisted and broke free, driving her elbow into his diaphragm and flinging herself past the disapparition point.

She was vanishing as she felt herself crushed under a body.

She reappeared and choked as her lungs filled with water. She was face-down in water. Her lungs burning as she tried to fight free. There were stones digging into her as the Death Eaterâ€™s weight pinned her underwater. She pulled her head up, choking and gasping. The water and blood roaring in her ears. A hand gripped her hair and wrenched her head further back. Her hands scrabbled through the water, she snatched up a rock and twisted her body to smash it into the Death Eaterâ€™s head before he drowned her.

She managed to strike him once before the rock was knocked from her grip.

A moment later everything went black.

Chapter End Notes

This chapter contains several lines and paraphrased excerpts of Harry Potter and the Dealthy Hallows Chapters 33, 34, and 36.

Also, Manacled now has a Facebook Group.

Flashback 37

Chapter Notes

Two notes: First, regarding my making a summary of the first twenty-five chapters before the present chapters resume, I have decided to create one. However, in order to avoid breaking up the story unnaturally, it's an external googledoc, found here. However, the readers who have reread say that the recontextualization of the flashbacks makes rereading the story an entirely different experience.
Second: Manacled now has a Facebook group discussing theories. Itâ€™s a closed group called Granians and Paper Cranes.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

July 2003

She woke with a start and found herself lying on a low, makeshift bed, Draco leaning over her.

She jerked back and then stilled and looked around, realising she was in his safe house in Whitecroft. She looked back at Draco, and everything came rushing back. She drew a sharp breath and felt as though she were being crushed to death. â€œWhatâ€”What happened?â€

His mouth twitched as he straightened and stared down at her. His expression was a mask, but she could see the restrained rage in his eyes.

â€œDespiteâ€â€”the word was bitten outâ€”â€œyour reassurance to me yesterday, you were at Hogwarts. When I discovered it, I tried to grab you, and you proceeded to apparate into a creek. I had to stun you; I thought you might drown yourself before you realised it was me.â€

She sat up gingerly, still slightly sore and dazed. She shook her head, trying to clear it of the remaining grogginess. â€œYou were masked; I didnâ€™t recognize you.â€

She looked down. Her clothes were dry. Her lungs felt clear, as though it had been a long time since sheâ€™d been knocked out. She glanced at her watch, and her stomach dropped sharply. Hours had passed. It was nearly evening.

â€œHow long did you leave me here, unconscious?â€ Her voice was disbelieving as she looked up at Draco.

His expression was cold. â€œI wasnâ€™t available to disappear with you. Once I had the water out of your lungs and you were safe, I had to return to fulfill my duties.â€

Hermione looked away.

Harry.

Ron.

Almost everyone had been at Hogwarts. Aside from Severus, she might be the only remaining active member of the Order.

She pressed her lips together for a minute, collecting herself before she looked up. â€œI donâ€™t understand. What happened? How did they find our prison?â€

He looked away, his hands were clenched into fists. She could almost feel the seething rage rippling around him.

â€œI donâ€™t know the details of how precisely it occurred. I told you, the Dark Lord is suspicious now. He barely confides in anyone, and he provides different information to each general in an attempt to identify where the intelligence is getting out. I was informed of ten different plans for attack, and none of them were legitimate. I do know he was in Sussex last night, working alone according to all the reports I had. By the time I learned we had your prison, the Resistance was already at Hogwarts. There was no opportunity to send word.â€

Hermione sat on the edge of the bed as she absorbed it. She felt too dazed and devastated to even think clearly.

Draco was seething. His hands kept opening and closing as though he were suppressing the urge to break something.

He stood beside her for another moment and then turned and began pacing around the room as though he were a caged animal. â€œI thought this was supposed to be the Orderâ€™s final blow? Did Potter think letting the Dark Lord kill him would somehow win the war? Or did he just decide to give up?â€

Hermione twitched.

â€œHarry was a horcrux,â€ she said in a dead voice.

Draco frozen and looked at her sharply. She dropped her eyes and stared at her lap. Her jeans were torn on both knees.

She swallowed and drew her feet back. â€œI didnâ€™t knowâ€”until today. I only realised it after the battle had started. There was a prophecy made twenty years ago, â€˜either must die at the hand of the other for neither can live while the other survives.â€™ Harry thought if all the other horcruxes were destroyed, that having the Dark Lord kill him would cause them both to die.â€

The sight of Harryâ€™s expression going blank flashed before her eyes. Her throat contracted, and her whole body shook. Her cheekbones and chest ached. She felt as though she were on the verge of breaking into pieces.

She was glass, only a breath away from shattering.

She gripped the edge of the bed and watched her knuckles turn white. â€œWe missed one. Thereâ€™s another horcrux. I thoughtâ€”I thought weâ€™d found them allâ€”but I was wrong.â€

There was a stabbing pain in the back of her throat as she swallowed. â€œWe have to find it.â€

â€œThe Resistance has lost,â€ Draco said in a flat voice. â€œThe war is over.â€

Hermione jerked sharply at Dracoâ€™s words, and there was a flush of heat that burst through her.

â€œI know. You donâ€™t need to tell me. I know we lost!â€ Her voice was ragged.

She drew a sharp breath, and it burned in her lungs. She pressed her lips together and pressed her hands against her eyes as she exhaled and tried control herself.

â€œIâ€™m not saying the war isn't over.â€ Her voice was still shaking slightly. â€œIâ€™m saying we have to find the horcrux. We have to find it. If we can destroy it, heâ€™ll dieâ€”maybe not immediately, but if he loses all his horcruxes, heâ€™ll die.â€ She kept speaking, faster and faster. â€œThe Death Eaters don't share goals with the Dark Beings, the regime will crumble without him. Itâ€™s not as though heâ€™ll ever groom a successor. We justâ€”we have to find it.â€

There was physically fractured sensation laced through her as she sat there. She felt as though her heart had broken, but she was still too shocked to feel it.

She dropped her head down and pressed her jaw against her shoulder. â€œThe Resistanceâ€”is lost. I know. There are maybe a few cells left that were less involved with the Order, but most of our able force was at Hogwarts today. A few people may escape, but otherwise, Severus and I are the only active members of the Order left. Weâ€”â€ she felt as though she were being ground into dust. The weight of everything was too much. â€œUntil we find the remaining horcrux, we canâ€™t try to rescue anyone. Theyâ€™ll all be traced, we canâ€™t risk both you and Severus trying to get them free. The horcrux has to be the priority. Thatâ€™s the only way for us to actually end this and really save them.â€

â€œThereâ€™s no us. Youâ€™re leaving Britain.â€

Hermione looked up at Draco.

His eyes were still burning with rage, but his expression was set. â€œIâ€™ll find it. Youâ€™re leaving. Thereâ€™s no Order left to keep you. Potter is dead.â€

She flinched.

He paused for a moment and seemed to be weighing what he was about to say next. â€œWeasley will be dead within the week. Thereâ€™s no reason for you to stay. You canâ€™t remain active; it will be easier for me to work if the Dark Lord assumes a victory. If he thinks the Order is still a threat, it will make finding any remaining horcruxes more difficult.â€

Hermioneâ€™s mouth twitched. â€œFine,â€ she finally said in a tight voice. â€œI can collaborate long-distance initially.â€

Dracoâ€™s eyes flickered for the briefest moment, and she knew it was his intention to make the arrangement permanent. He would do everything in his power to prevent her from ever returning to Britain if he thought there was any risk from it.

She swallowed and stared at him.

â€œIâ€™ll go on one condition.â€

She watched Draco tense and calculate.

â€œGinny Weasley, she has to come with me.â€

â€œNo.â€ His expression was cold. â€œYou said no rescues.â€

â€œItâ€™s not a rescue. Sheâ€™s at a safe house. Only Ginny. I wonâ€™tâ€”â€ she wavered, and her throat caught, â€œI wonâ€™t ask you to save anyone else. But I have to take Ginny with me. I wonâ€™t go without her. Sheâ€™s just at a safehouse. I can go get her.â€

His jaw clenched, and there was something unreadable in his expression.

Hermione pressed forward. â€œI have to send word to the safe houses, make sure they know that the Order is compromised and tell them to go to ground. Then Iâ€™ll get Ginny, and weâ€™llâ€”weâ€™ll go.â€

She stood. She was leaning so heavily into her occlumency she felt almost removed from her body. Physically, she was shattered with grief. There was a pain in her chest as though her sternum were refractured. A phantom pain that always seemed to occur when she was stressed.

But she was managing to occlude the mental aspects somewhat. Â 

Draco shifted as she extended her wand to cast a patronus.

She flicked her hand in the familiar motion and said the words.

Nothing.

She swallowed hard and forced her occlumency walls more firmly into place, taking a deep breath before she tried again.

â€œExpecto Patronum.â€ She said it firmly.

Nothing.

Not even a wisp of silver light.

She stared down at her wand.

Harry had taught her how to cast a patronus. Her otter.

As she stood there, she realised sheâ€™d probably never see it again. Her throat hurt from the effort it took not to cry.

Harry was dead. He was dead. There was nothing she could do to bring him back. Even in the magical world, calling back the dead was nothing more than fairytale.

Every happy memory sheâ€™d had was tainted, turned to ashes. Her past was an endless expanse of loss. Her childhood, with parents with new lives and new names and no recollection that theyâ€™d ever had a daughter theyâ€™d been proud of.

All her years at Hogwarts were defined by a war sheâ€™d now lost; by people sheâ€™d lost.

She gripped her wand until her knuckles turned white, and slowly lowered it, swallowing hard.

Donâ€™t think about it. Make it through the day. She had to get Ginny. Sheâ€™d promised Harry sheâ€™d always take care of Ginny.

That was all she could focus on.
