    â€œWhat did he do to you?â€ Hermione said, drawing Topsyâ€™s hand from behind her back. They were blistered and raw.

    â€œTopsy was to iron her hands for one minute each and strike herself ten times with a coal bucket.â€ Topsy twitched a bony shoulder. â€œTopsy is being alright. Master Lucius is never liking elves, Topsy is used to it from the years ago.â€

    Hermioneâ€™s throat felt thick, and her eyes burned as she swallowed.

    â€œI wish I could heal you.â€ Her mouth twisted. â€œI used to be a healerâ€”back when I had magic. Do you have potions? I have some murtlap essence. Itâ€™s not very much, but it will soothe the burns and help the bruising.â€

    Topsy patted Hermione gently on the cheek. â€œThe elves is having Potions, but if we is using them too soon, Master Lucius is wanting to punish us again.â€

    Draco was visibly pale and tense when he came to her room later that night. He walked rapidly across the room, held her face in his hands, and studied her eyes the way he used to during the war.

    â€œI made it clear to him that youâ€™re pregnant and that the Dark Lord is using it as a mechanism to recover your memories,â€ he said after a minute. â€œI donâ€™t imagine heâ€™d hesitate to harm you despite the rules regarding surrogates, but the Dark Lordâ€™s specific interest in the pregnancy will hopefully be enough.â€

    Hermione raised her hand to his cheek. He was worryingly cool to touch. â€œWhat did you do, Draco?â€

    He shrugged her hand off. â€œI added a few more wards. I want to know if he tries to access the North Wing. It would raise his suspicion if I kept him out entirely, but I can slow him enough to get here first.â€

    â€œYou used blood magic, didnâ€™t you? You look ready to faint.â€ She pulled him towards the bed. â€œSit down. Topsy! I need a Blood Replenishing Potion. Iâ€™m sure you have them.â€ She pressed her fingertips against his pulse. â€œAnd a strengthening potion.â€

    She pulled his wand out of its holster on his arm and slipped it into his hand. â€œCast a diagnostic for me. I need to know how much blood you used.â€

    He waved his wand, and she studied the results carefully. When Topsy reappeared, Hermione asked for several restoratives.

    She watched him carefully as he took the potions and the colour slowly return to his features. She pressed her hand again his cheek and felt the warmth seep back into his skin as she pressed her lips against his forehead. â€œI wonâ€™t go out of my room without you. You donâ€™t need to worry.â€

    His shoulders slumped with exhaustion and he gave a slow nod.

    Draco arrived after lunch for her daily walk. As they stood at the doorway of her room, she looked at his hand. â€œI suppose we shouldnâ€™t touch anymore. Just walk, like we used to last winter.â€

    He nodded, his expression tense.

    They walked through the rose garden. The buds were just starting to bloom.

    As they came around the side of the manor, they both froze. There was a wide trail of blood leading from iron gates of the estate; the white gravel was soaked in it.

    Lucius stood at the front doors of the manor with a centaur at his feet.

    The centaur had been struck in the torso with the necrosis curse; the rot was slowly spreading across the stomach. The tendons in every leg had been brutally severed. The centaur was moaning quietly and kept struggling to stand, his skin grey from blood loss. The centaur tried to push himself up from his knees and collapsed heavily to the ground with an agonised groan.

    Lucius was dressed in leather and dripping blood. His pale hair was stained red. â€œAh, Dracoâ€¦ I had hoped you were here. Put your Mudblood away. If you could change the wards to allow me to take captives directly to my wing, that would be useful. Then I wonâ€™t be obliged to drag them across the estate.â€

    â€œSetting up a zoo, father?â€ Draco stood surveying the scene with a carefully closed expression.

    Lucius snorted. â€œThis beast came from the Forbidden Forest. Iâ€™m sure it knows something about where that arrow came from, or if it doesnâ€™t, it can tell me who does.â€

    Hermione chest contracted painfully as Lucius continued â€œUnfortunately theyâ€™re such uncooperative creatures, I expect the process will requireâ€”persuasion.â€

    Draco sighed and raised an eyebrow. â€œThere are prisons you could interrogate in. It keeps the blood off the gravel.â€

    â€œAh yes,â€ Lucius said, waving his wand around in lazy circles. His voice became vaguely singsong. â€œThe prisons. The prisons full of guards and ambitious Death Eaters eager to see our family toppled. Those prisons. Perhaps if you were more careful, you would have apprehended our quarry by now. Why should I use a prison when I have my very own redecorated wing of the manor? No. The manor will do very well. Itâ€™s been so long since Iâ€™ve been home. Now, Draco, perhaps you could be so good as to transport my project the rest of the way. Unless you prefer I drag it through the halls as well.â€

    There was a pause as Draco stood between Hermione and his father.

    â€œTopsy,â€ Draco called, his voice hard.

    Topsy appeared before Draco with a pop. Her bruises had faded to yellow and green.

    â€œTake the Mudblood back to her room and see that she stays there.â€ Draco unbuttoned the cuffs of his sleeves and rolled them up. â€œI have more important matters to attend to.â€

    Topsy bobbed and took Hermioneâ€™s hand, leading her quickly away. Hermione glanced over her shoulder and watched Draco walk towards his father, his wand dangling from his fingertips.

    Hermione has been in her room only half an hour when the screaming started.

    Even from the other end of the manor, the sound was audible. Inhuman agony reverberated through the house as though it were emerging from the walls.

    Narcissa started violently, jumping to her feet, her face turning grey as she gave a choked gasp of horror.

    It was the first sound Hermione had ever heard from the portrait.

    â€œItâ€™sâ€”itâ€™s a centaur,â€ Hermione said. â€œLucius caught it.â€

    Narcissa stared at Hermione for a moment and then dropped back into her chair, her hands falling to her lap.

    The screaming kept going on and on.

    Hermione looked away and tried to swallow, but her saliva was sour. Her hands were shaking as she tried to turn the page in her book. The words swam before her eyes.

    She wondered if it was the flaying curse. The way the screaming continued on and on reminded her of Colin.

    The book slipped from her fingers and onto the floor. She barely noticed.

    She wished she had her occlumency. Or a least the ability to put her mind back together so that all the deaths didnâ€™t stay so forefront.

    She pressed her hands over her eyes and tried to clear her mind.

    All the blood. There would be so much blood. And skin. And muscle. Eventually organs. Layer after layer. To the bones.

    She wanted to go huddle in the corner of her room. To hide from the sound and the knowledge that it was happening and she had no ability to do anything about it.

    If she tried to do anything, tried to go and beg Draco to stop it, it would endanger him, her, their daughter, Severus, Ginny, James.

    She started across the room towards the corner, trying not to listen to the screaming that wouldnâ€™t stop.

    As she went, she glanced towards the portrait. Narcissaâ€™s expression kept flinching, as though she were trying not to cry as she sat stoically in her chair.

    Hermione stopped and hesitated for a moment before stepping towards the portrait.

    Hermione extended her hand. Her fingers spasmed as she rested them against the canvas. Narcissa looked up at Hermione, and her expression was stiff. Her nose scrunched up, and her lip curled defensively as she drew back in her chair.

    Hermione waited.

    Then Narcissaâ€™s blue eyes flickered, and her mouth twisted as her jaw trembled. She moved to the edge of her chair and extended her hand until her painted fingers rested on the canvas beneath Hermioneâ€™s.

    Hermione stood at the portrait until the screaming stopped.

    Once the manor fell silent, Hermione's hand slipped away from the frame, and she turned away. Her stomach felt so twisted it was as though she were being strangled from the inside. She made her way dazedly over to her bed and stood beside it for several minutes. She could still hear the screams, as though they were tattooed into her eardrums.

    She curled up tightly in the corner between the bed and the wall and stared blankly at the floor.

    She blinked and found Draco kneeling in front of her. His expression was hesitant and worried, his eyebrows furrowed as he studied her, his mouth set in a thin, flat line.

    He was wearing different clothes, and she could tell heâ€™d showered. His hair was combed back and still damp.

    She stared at him in silence. She didnâ€™t know what to say.

    His expression grew more and more drawn as he met her eyes.

    He didnâ€™t reach towards her. He didnâ€™t speak. They simply looked at each other and felt the weight of it all.

    He seemed to be waiting for her to initiate something, to reach for him or look away.

    â€œEverything you do is on my head too. Every spell.â€

    Â

    She glanced over at him as she was pulling an encyclopedia of fifteenth-century arithmancy formulas down from the shelf, and her fingers wavered against the spine as she caught sight of his expression.

    Wistful.

    To him, she was stealing time from them. If she didnâ€™t find anything, it was all just wasted. All that time she could have had with him.

    Her jaw trembled. She looked down and bit her lip as she slipped the encyclopedia off the shelf, as well as the four books beside it, adding them to a stack.

    â€œThese too.â€

    Â 

    Â 

    â€œI found what I was missing to remove your Dark Mark,â€ Hermione said when Draco walked through the door to her room after lunch the next day. She was sitting on the edge of the bed, empty-handed, her meal untouched.

    He stopped at the door. â€œOh?â€

    The corners of her mouth twitched, and she looked down at her hands.

    â€œI figured it out with arithmancy. I even had Topsy write down all the numbers for meâ€”to make sure Iâ€™d calculated it right.â€ Her voice was empty.     She might as well have said she needed the moon.

    Draco stood staring at her for a minute before he blinked.

    Phoenixes rarely cried. When they did, it was always over an injury, not into a vial so that the tears could be saved or used in a potion. Trying to buy Phoenix tears would cost a fortune, and the buyer would be more likely to end up with watered down unicorn blood. It could take years to manage to track down a seller with actual Phoenix tears.

    She swallowed and fidgeted, rolling the fabric of her robes between her fingers. â€œMaybeâ€”if I start over, I can find something. I might have just come at it from the wrong angle...â€

    She twitched and her shoulder jerked.

    â€œOrâ€”a bomb. I could build a bombâ€”like the ones I used at Sussex.â€ She caught her lower lip between her teeth and gnawed at it. â€œI thinkâ€”I mostly remember how.     Dracoâ€™s expression was closed, but his gaze was enragingly patient as he walked over to her. â€œCan you build a bomb without magic?â€

    Hermione swallowed, and her mouth twisted. â€œN-no... Butâ€”I could tell you howâ€”â€

    â€œCan you safely handle the materials while pregnant?â€

    Her jaw trembled, and she realized that this was an idea heâ€™d likely already considered and discarded at some previous point.

    â€œNo. But you could place wards around me, it would mute the effects and I can show you the techniques beforehand. We could work togetherâ€”â€

    â€œWhich of us has hands steady enough to build a bomb?â€

    Hermione pulled her hand away, curling it into a fist so tight she could feel her metacarpal bones under her fingertips. She could feel the blood draining from her head, and she felt as though she might topple off the edge of the bed.

    She pressed her other hand firmly against the mattress to steady herself. â€œMaybe I canâ€”â€

    â€œHermione, Iâ€™m tired.â€

    She looked up at him and saw it in his eyes.

    The war had eaten him; there was so little of him left. The ghosts in his eyes, the war, it was almost all there was. Â 

    The other Death Eaters had retired from the war after the Battle of Hogwarts, but Draco hadnâ€™t had the ability, had never been afforded the luxury. He had continued, because he couldnâ€™t find her, because heâ€™d made a vow to defeat Voldemort.

    His best to defeat Voldemort.

    His best.

    Always his best.

    Day after day.

    He just wanted an endpoint to look towards.

    â€œDracoâ€¦ Iâ€”â€

    He took her hand in his, running his thumb over her ring. â€œI would like to say goodbye to you before youâ€™re leaving.â€

    Her throat caught as she stared up at him. Her jaw was trembling visibly, and he swam in her eyes when she nodded slowly and buried her face against his chest. He wrapped his arms around her shoulders and sighed.

    She wrapped her arms around him, but her mind raced.

    The minute he left she went back to researching. She asked for more books from the house-elves. When he returned in the late evening, sheâ€™d put them all away. She didnâ€™t mention it. She knew he knew anyway.

    She kissed him. She pushed him back against the bed and slid her leg up until she was on his lap, her fingers threaded through his hair as she caressed his lips with hers.

    His hands gripped her. His thumb pressed against her lowest rib, and he arched her against his chest. His other hand rose up and wrapped around her throat, pulling her impossibly close and tilting her head back as he deepened the kiss.

    She started unbuttoning her dress. Her hands were trembling, and her fingers fumbled with the buttons. He drew back and tried to close his hands over hers. She jerked them free.

    â€œI want this,â€ she said in a tight, shaking voice. â€œI want this. I want this on our terms before I go.â€ Her voice wavered. â€œThis was ours...â€

    She swallowed and blinked hard before meeting his silver eyes. â€œIt was ours.â€

    She twitched her shoulders, and her dress slipped off and pooled at her waist. She wrapped her arms around his neck, pulling him close and kissing him again.

    Mine.

    His eyes werenâ€™t like a wolfâ€™s. They were a dragonâ€™s, deadly and possessive. He stared at her as though she were all that mattered in the world. It made her blood burn.

    Her thighs bracketed his hips as she sat astride him and shifted. She met his eyes. Her heart was pounding in her chest and her pulse was racing, and she knew he could feel it.

    It wasâ€”familiar, in both good ways and bad.

    Over the table, sheâ€™d tried not to pay attention, not to how it felt, how it touched her inside, the sensation or the movement.     It had always been a matter of experiencing it as little as possible.

    Now she wanted to notice what it was like. They were connected. He was in her and under her. His hands guiding her hips as she moved with him.

    It was good. It had felt this way when they used to have sex, she was certain. Â 

    The heat of his touch was like a fire. It wasnâ€™t too fast or too much for her. He went as slow as she needed him to.

    It used to be slow. She remembered that. Slow and intimate as he whispered against her skin. The burning reverence of his touch as he used to make love to her.

    Thatâ€™s what it had been. Making love.

    Thatâ€™s what theyâ€™d had.

    Her eyes burned, and she dropped her head down as her shoulders shook.

    â€œI love you.â€ She gripped his hand in hers so tightly it hurt. â€œI wanted my whole life to show you.â€

    Chapter 69

    June 2005

    Severus is coming. Severus is coming.

    Hermione felt as though she were turning to lead. There was constant aching pain in her chest, and a stone seemed to be lodged in her throat; she felt it each time she swallowed.

    A palpable sense of horror and despair spreading around and through her. It was as if she was drowning with the rising tide; the water had reached her face, sliding slowly across her skin, lapping a little higher each minute. She was locked in place and could do nothing but sit, feeling it draw over her.

    She wanted her occlumency back.

    Now that she remembered having it, she felt its loss. Death and mutilation, everyone sheâ€™d seen die, right in the forefront of her mind. It hadnâ€™t always been that way. There used to be space from the emotional agony, but now there wasnâ€™t.

    Soon Draco would be another person whoâ€™d died because she couldnâ€™t save him.

    She didnâ€™t think any amount of occlumency would ever make the pain of it fade.

    If she could just occlude a bit, she thought sheâ€™d be able to say everything she felt she needed to say, to ask him what she wanted to know. Instead, each time she tried to broach the subject, her voice would break, her shoulders would begin shaking, and sheâ€™d start crying and then hyperventilating.

    Draco would stoically let her cry and then wrap his arms around her and calm her when she started overbreathing.

    Sheâ€™d jerk away angrily.

    She wanted to scream at him. Stop accepting this. Stop being resigned. You're breaking my heart. Stop acting like itâ€™s alright. Itâ€™s not alright. Itâ€™s never going to be alright. Stop being resigned.

    It was easy to be angry at himâ€”at least she was still trying. He was just going along with it.

    She finally broke down and raged at him until she had a panic attack. His plans were stupid and selfish. It wasnâ€™t fair that he got to die, and she was left to live with everything. If heâ€™d just let her help him rescue Ginny, none of this might have happened. He should have let them work together. If he hadnâ€™t been so controlling and not tried to do everything by himselfâ€”everything might have been different.

    He just stood there without a word while she vented it all. Until she started hyperventilating and collapsed on the floor with her arms protectively wrapped around her stomach. He shushed her and rubbed circles on her back while she cried and tried to shake him off.

    â€œDonâ€™t do this to me, Draco. Donâ€™t do this. Donâ€™tâ€”donâ€™tâ€”donâ€™tâ€”donâ€™tâ€”â€

    Afterwards, he was called away, and she was left to seethe and obsess and realise he was doing it intentionally.

    He could read her thoughts. He knew the ways her mind tilted. Prior to Montagueâ€™s attack, heâ€™d gone out of his way to needle her and make her hate him. Heâ€™d given her a target, something to focus on; a way to channel her stress. If she was angry at him, she was less self-destructive. Her rage dampened her guilt.

    Then leaving would be easier for her.

    She didnâ€™t want to be managed.

    She swallowed her anger after that. She didnâ€™t want to waste the time she had by being angry.

    But when she was alone, she wanted to scream and break everything within reach. The manacles physically prevented her from doing anything but cry. She was burning with rage, and devastation, and guilt without any capacity to channel it. She felt as though it was poisoning her from the inside, as though the emotions were corroding the blood in her veins.

    She obsessively kept going through all the stacks of books that covered the floor of more than half of her room. If she read them enough times, maybe sheâ€™d have a breakthrough, maybe she might see something sheâ€™d overlooked before.

    When Draco visited, she tried to ignore the fact she was leaving.

    He had an unusual amount of availability leading up to the anniversary of the Battle of Hogwarts. Lucius was responsible for â€œhuntingâ€, and executions had been placed on hold until the anniversary celebration.

    Draco was able to spend most of his time with her. Â 

    She poured herself into him. She wanted every detail of him.

    They made love several more times. After the first time, it was easier. She was confident that she could handle it, that she could stop if she needed to. She could communicate things to him physically that she struggled to verbalise without crying.

    She could hold onto him and wish to never let go.

    He held her in his arms and kissed down her body. He touched and tangled his fingers in her hair. He traced along her neck and shoulders as though he were measuring and memorising the way she fit in his hands. He pushed into her, and she stared into his eyes, watching the way they flickered and changed colour when the pupils dilated.

    Mine. Mine. Mine. She felt it like a heartbeat.

    Mine.

    To have and to hold...

    She pulled his lips desperately against hers, wrapping her arms around his shoulders, tangling her fingers in his hair, absorbing the sensation of being with him, the rhythm of his heartbeat with her.

    For better, for worse...

    In sickness and in health...

    She ran her fingers along his runes, feeling the implacable magic that resided there. She kissed each of his scars, and he kissed hers. They entwined their hands, brushing their noses together, and whispering to each other.

    They took every moment slowly. They had barely any time left; they didnâ€™t want to waste it by rushing.

    Afterwards, Hermione lay curled up in his arms, her back against his chest.

    Home. This is what home feels like.

    She took his left hand and pressed it against the swell in her lower pelvis.

    â€œThatâ€™s her,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™llâ€”â€ her throat tightened, â€œâ€”Iâ€™ll probably be able to feel her move within the next month. The book says it feels like fluttering at the beginning.â€

    She stood speechless at the doors and stared in at all of them; enormous Abraxans, Granians, and Aethonens. All of which stared down at her and Draco through barred stalls. They stomped their hooves and tossed their heads, nickering as Hermione ventured forward.

    Draco looked down and straightened the cufflinks on his shirt.

    Hermione studied him for a moment. â€œWhat?â€

    Draco looked up from his sleeve, and his expression closed. â€œWell, she was informed of the context in which you were being sent here to the manor, unfortunately sheâ€”she assumed I had greater ability to subvert instructions and protect you than I did.     He cleared his throat. â€œI hadnâ€™t anticipated the Dark Lord knowing about you when I was trying to get you out of Europe.     He abruptly seemed to realise he was rambling and cut himself off. Â â€œSoâ€”portkeys were the best I could do.â€

    Hermione stared up at him.

    â€œI have to say, youâ€™ve ended up being quite expensive, Granger.â€

    There was a reason why international portkey travel was restricted. Intercontinental portkey displacement could drop a Wizard into outer-space if incorrectly calculated. There was elaborate and specialized expertise necessary for intercontinental portkey creation, to the extent that most were government sponsored and owned in order to be affordable.

    Hermione knew because the Order had pursued the idea of obtaining a portkey to Australia or Canada in order to evacuate the children and refugees. Legally purchased, it would have used an eighth of Harryâ€™s vault. On the black market, the price would have easily been double or triple.

    â€œIt wonâ€™t be as untraceable as the route with Severusâ€”â€ Draco was saying. Heâ€™d caught her hand in his, and one of his fingers slipped along her inner-wrist and twitched at the manacle locked there, â€œâ€”you should use the extra time to regain more weight and build up your stamina."

    She furrowed her eyebrows as she stared up at him. â€œHow will you get the manacles off without Severus?â€

    Draco gave a dry laugh. â€œRemoving them was never really an obstacle. The difficulty has always been getting you safely out of Europe immediately afterwards. There are plenty of Death Eaters who will do anything theyâ€™re told once you find the right pressure point.â€

    Hermione nodded stiffly. â€œHow longâ€”until Ginny comes?â€

    Draco furrowed his eyebrows and then quirked one up as he calculated. â€œThe house-elves will have to apparate to the safe-house by a series of jumps since they canâ€™t use portkeys.     More time , whispered Hermioneâ€™s desperate, greedy heart, but the instant it occurred to her, the guilt struck her.

    Now that she was no longer primarily dreading him, the reality of Severusâ€™ death was slowly washing over her.

    Severus, her mentor. Her colleague. One of the few people she had regarded as having truly known her. Heâ€™d been chained to the war even longer than Hermione and Draco. Sheâ€™d often wondered what the reason was for his switch in allegiance.

    Whatever it had been, the secret died with him.

    Draco went and dropped into the chair.

    â€œDid youâ€”know Severus well?â€ she asked.

    He looked up at her. His eyes were cool grey, but a thin smile played at the corner of his mouth. â€œNo. He didnâ€™t like me.â€

    Hermione looked down. â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

    â€œWhen he wasnâ€™t giving me orders, he spent most of his time telling me that I didnâ€™t deserve to have someone like you care about me; that you were worth ten of me.â€ He raised an eyebrow. â€œWhen it wasnâ€™t Severus saying it, it was Ginny; although she placed the number somewhat higher.â€

    Dracoâ€™s availability abruptly ended with Severusâ€™ death. He was called away less than an hour later. Hermione didnâ€™t see him until he arrived briefly the next afternoon in order to introduce Hermione to Topsyâ€™s replacement.

    Bobbin was a younger elf. Hermione wasnâ€™t sure how old any of the elves were, but Topsy had easily been older than Kreacher, and Bobbin seemed to be about the age Dobby had been.     Bobbin gave a low curtsy. â€œBobbin will be doing her best.â€

    â€œTell Bobbin anything you want. Sheâ€™s aware of the restrictions you have.â€ Dracoâ€™s mind was clearly elsewhere. He walked away without a word.

    Hermione didnâ€™t see Draco again for more than a day.

    She forced herself to eat even though it made her stress nausea worse.

    She started working out again.

    A longer, harder journey. Multiple portkeys while pregnant.

    The pregnancy guide had included a long section explaining the risks of displacement transport during pregnancy. Portkeys were preferable to apparition, but either form tended to make witches violently ill and could cause contractions or premature labour. A potion to settle the stomach and a dose of Calming Draught beforehand were strongly recommended if the use of a portkey was necessary.

    Hermione had no idea how sheâ€™d handle portkeying. In a worst case scenario, repeatedly portkeying could send her into premature labour.

    If she lost the baby in the process of escaping without Draco, she thought she would probably die.

    It might make a difference if she were less physically fragile.

    She started with basic lunges and crunches. She couldnâ€™t push herself off the floor to do a push-up, but she made herself begin doing regular repetitions of everything she could manage.

    Three weeks. She had three weeks to come up with something better than Dracoâ€™s new plan.

    She just needed to get his Dark Mark off. If she could get it off, there would be numerous methods of escape available to them.

    If they killed Voldemort, the Dark Mark would vanish. Potentially so would the only existing mechanism for removing the manacles. The manacles needed the Dark Marks to activate the release mechanism; without marked Death Eaters, everyone manacled might wait years before a way of overriding or recreating Voldemortâ€™s Dark Mark was invented.

    It might save Draco though. However, Hermione had no idea how to go about it. Draco refused to discuss any ideas that endangered her or ran the risk of his cover being blown before her manacles were removed.

    She didnâ€™t even know where Voldemortâ€™s castle was.

    If she could just get Dracoâ€™s mark off.

    The anniversary celebration came, and the manor sat silent. Hermione spent the day reading, gnawing her fingernails to the quick, and doing exercise repetitions when she felt so anxious she thought she might start panicking. Draco had left the previous afternoon and not returned, that was all Bobbin knew.

    Lucius had been back to the manor, apparently no worse off for having murdered Astoria.

    Hermione knew because early in the morning she saw him standing in the path outside her window, staring up at the North Wing.

    Sheâ€™d ducked quickly out of sight.

    The day of the anniversary passed without event for Hermione. Her room felt claustrophobic, as though she were going to suffocate while waiting there.

    It was the middle of the night when Draco abruptly appeared in the room next to her door.

    He stalked across the room and nearly collapsed on top of her as he wrapped his arms around her waist and dropped his forehead on her shoulder.

    Hermioneâ€™s spine bowed slightly as she held him up. The spent dark magic hanging off him was almost enough to make her gag.

    â€œAre you alright? Whatâ€™s wrong? Has something happened?â€ she asked, her voice frantic as she ran her fingers over him trying to find an injury.

    â€œMmmfine.â€ His voice was muffled in her robes. â€œIâ€™m just tired.â€

    He lifted his head and straightened as he stared down at her. â€œIt was a long day.â€

    â€œSit down.â€ She pulled him over to the bed, and he sat heavily on the edge of it. She studied him. He looked frayed. â€œWhat happened?â€

    He stared up at her, his expression was drained but there was a sort of cold triumph in his eyes. â€œThe Dark Lord didnâ€™t take news regarding Romania well and over-exerted himself yesterday.     Hermione studied him. The light in her room was dim but he seemed ghastly pale, as though heâ€™d been drained of colour. â€œButâ€”?â€

    He shrugged a shoulder. â€œWellâ€”Iâ€™m his supposed successor. I had to fill both roles in his absence.â€ The triumph in his expression faded into exhaustion. â€œIt was a few more Killing Curses than Iâ€™d expected.â€

    He suddenly looked young. A flicker of boyish vulnerability appeared for a moment. â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€”â€

    He cut himself off and was silent for several seconds.

    â€œIâ€™ll be fine. Iâ€™m just tired,â€ he finally said.

    Hermione tangled her fingers in his hair. â€œOh, Draco.â€

    She wondered sometimes if there would be an eventual point when the Heart of Isis would fail. Surely it couldnâ€™t function indefinitely. It was already absorbing all the dark magic that should have been seeping out of Dracoâ€™s runes, that combined with everything else Draco regularly didâ€”

    Hermione banished the thought. He had a far more immediate fate to escape before she needed to worry about Dark Magic corrosion killing him.

    She brushed her fingers against his cheek. His skin was icy cold. In the moonlight, with his pale hair, skin, and eyes, he almost seemed like a ghost she was clinging to.

    She was magicless. She had no spells or healing to offer.

    â€œGo to sleep. You should sleep,â€ she said. â€œYouâ€™ll feel better if you can rest.â€

    He gave a nod and slumped down.

    She ran her fingers through his hair, twisting it around her fingers and watching it slip free. She traced along his knuckles, and then rubbed her hands against his, trying to impart some warmth from wherever it had leeched out of him. His hands spasmed from time to time when he moved his sleep.

    He had such long fingers. In another life, he could have been a healer or a musician. He would have had the perfect hands for it.

    Just another thing Voldemort ruined.

    She sat beside him watching him sleep, feeling him grow slowly warmer.

    He jerked abruptly awake, snatching his fingers away from hers and gripping his left forearm as he sat up. He pressed a kiss against her forehead and left without a word.

    Hermione didnâ€™t see him again for two days. She read the Daily Prophetâ€™s recap of the anniversary celebration. Predictably Voldemortâ€™s absence was barely mentioned and heavily excused. There was more time devoted to Astoriaâ€™s failure to appear.

    Draco had killed seventy-five prisoners over the course of the day. Speeches and entertainment and then he was called up to kill traitors and resistance fighters. It had happened in three sets. Twenty-five prisoners all lined up for him to execute. Again. And Again.

    It was an unbelievable quantity of killing curses.

    The revolution in Romania was dismissed as a minor, local uprising, not related to Voldemortâ€™s regime at all.

    Hermione read the paper through twice and then went back to her books, back to her exercise repetitions. While she was forcing herself to do any unbearable quantity of crunches on the floor, she refined and perfected the theory of the potion until it was flawless.

    In another life, if she could have become a researcher, inventing the theory would have been a distinguishing success. Like the twelve uses of dragon's blood, even if four were entirely theory-based, the deepened understanding of magical theory would have been notable in its own right.

    But Hermione didnâ€™t care about a theoretical potion. She needed a real one with ingredients she could actually obtain.

    She had no idea how to get hold of phoenix tears.

    Fawkes had vanished after Dumbledoreâ€™s funeral at Hogwarts and never been seen again. Phoenix werenâ€™t even native to Europe.

    The only two known domesticated phoenix in the last century were Fawkes and Sparky, the mascot of the New Zealand Quidditch team. Domestication had been more common a few hundred years before, but whatever the art of reliably earning a phoenixâ€™s loyalty was, it had been lost to history.

    She lay in the middle of the floor, panting and thinking while she caught her breath. Her abdominals and legs were burning.

    If Draco tried to run with her, theyâ€™d be hunted down. Voldemort could find him through the Dark Mark. Theyâ€™d be hunted from refuge to refuge, and the travel would be more and more difficult for her as the pregnancy progressed. Assuming she didnâ€™t eventually miscarry from the stress of living on the run, there would later be a baby they were trying to flee with.

    There was no place to run to. There would be few Wizarding countries powerful enough to deter Voldemortâ€™s pursuit that wouldnâ€™t immediately arrest Draco themselves.     It was as Lucius had said. Draco was Voldemortâ€™s hunting dog. He could utilise Draco better if he werenâ€™t so afraid of Draco usurping him.

    â€œWhy canâ€™t you travel alone now? Why are you restricted but not anyone else?â€ sheâ€™d asked Draco during one of the days before Severus had been killed.

    Heâ€™d sighed and glanced away. â€œThe Dark Lord began receiving reports that I was privately visiting the homes of Death Eaters and powerful allies.     â€œI travelled all over Europe. Death Eaters and allies with certainâ€”reputationsâ€¦â€

    Her throat had tightened. â€œIt was because you were looking for me.â€

    Heâ€™d just nodded.

    Their attempts to hold onto each other had carved their hope for escape into a shard so narrow she sometimes wondered if she was imagining its existence.

    No. She could save him, she was certain there was some way to do it, she just needed to figure out what it was. Sheâ€™d never been a very good chess player. Even when sheâ€™d had occlumency, sheâ€™d never been able to stay detached about using people. That was where she and Draco diverged.

    If she wanted to save Draco, she needed to be more ruthless. As ruthless as he was.

    She sank back into thought, pacing in slow circles and geometric patterns around her room, until she felt an almost indescribable sensation occur in her lower abdomen. In some ways, it was not an actual sensation but a feeling that something had occurred.

    Fluttering.

    She froze and stared down at her stomach. There was the beginning of a small swell between the jut of her hip bones.

    She almost forgot sometimes that she was pregnant. The fact felt too overwhelming to process in light of all the more immediate concerns she had. When focused on the immediate future, a pregnancy felt more like a medical diagnosis that she had to account for than a baby.

    She had never planned to have children. When sheâ€™d been in school, motherhood had been an eventual goal so far removed from the present sheâ€™d barely contemplated it. Children, someday; after sheâ€™d graduated, and had a job, and found someone sheâ€™d consider a partner.

    Then the war came, and having children then had felt almost criminal to Hermione.

    Ginny had seen James as a promise and a beacon of hope, but to Hermione a child in a war was someone vulnerable; someone entirely helpless to protect themselves from the incalculable pain that existed. Selfish. Not worth the danger.

    Get married. Have children.

    Sheâ€™d stopped expecting to ever have those things years ago when sheâ€™d kept secretively using more and more dark magic. Sheâ€™d coldly smothered the idea when she gave her word to be a Death Eaterâ€™s willing war prize. It was little more than fantasy by the time sheâ€™d become complicit in war crimes and eventually volunteered to coordinate and manage them.

    She had meant it when she told Draco about the world she wanted but never expected to have a part in.

    She didnâ€™t have any idea how to be a mother. None of the decisions sheâ€™d made in her life had entertained the idea of children. She wasnâ€™t sure if wanting to have a child wasnâ€™t just her desperate selfishness rearing its head.

    â€œPoor little healer with no one to take care of. No one who needs you or wants you. You canâ€™t bear being alone. You donâ€™t know how to function. You need someone to love; youâ€™ll do anything for the people that let you love them.â€

    Her jaw trembled as she looked down.

    Maybe Draco had been right. Maybe that was what she was like. Sheâ€™d always obstinately attached herself to those sheâ€™d thought might need her. Maybe she just wanted to keep the baby so she wouldnâ€™t be alone.

    She pressed her fingers against her abdomen and stood unmoving for several seconds until she felt another flutter, quick as a heartbeat and then gone again.

    â€œIâ€™ll take care of you,â€ she whispered. â€œIâ€™ll do everything I can to be a good mum. Thereâ€™s a potion I can make when youâ€™re older.     The doorknob abruptly rattled and then went still. Hermione started violently with surprise and then stood, pressing her hands against her chest as her heart pounded, staring at the door.

    Nothing else happened.

    She waited and waited, but her world had fallen silent again.

    She crossed the room on her toes and rested her ear against the door.

    Silent.

    She couldnâ€™t hear even the faintest sound through the door, but she knew Draco had warded it.

    Someone could be shouting on the other side, and she wouldnâ€™t know. The door didnâ€™t move again as she rested her hands against the wood and strained to hear.

    It could be Lucius.

    It was possible he was unwilling to wait six months for Draco to remarry and hoped by killing off the â€˜Mudblood whore,â€™ he might accelerate the process.

    She bit her lip and stepped back, pressing her ear more closely to the crack between the door and the frame.

    She shouldnâ€™t.

    She shouldnâ€™t.

    Draco would tell her not to.

    Her hand wrapped slowly around the knob, and she turned it as silently as she could, cracking the door open. She peered out, and her heart stopped.

    Draco was lying face down on the floor. She flung the door open, rapidly glanced up and down the hall, and knelt down, dragging him into her room. She kicked the door shut as she rolled him onto his back and pressed her fingers against his pulse.

    He was unconscious.

    He was freezing cold. He was going into shock. His robes were shiny and smelled of rot. There were darkened silvery smears on his face. He was still breathing. She checked his eyes and found the pupils unevenly dilated.

    She ran her hands over his shoulders and touched his face gently. â€œDraco? Dracoâ€¦what happened to you?â€

    She started muttering curses under her breath. She was burning to have her magic back.     â€œBobbin!â€ she called sharply.

    The elf popped into the room and gave a squeak of horror when her eyes landed on Draco.

    â€œWhoâ€™s Dracoâ€™s healer?â€ Hermione asked. The elf stared blankly at Hermione. â€œWho does he call when he comes back hurt?â€

    Bobbin looked down at her hands. â€œBobbin is not knowing. Bobbin is mostly being in the kitchens and cleaning. The Master is not calling Bobbin when he is being hurt. Only Topsy or Kreacher.â€

    Hermione looked down in frustration and drew a deep breath before looking back up. â€œDo you know where he keeps his medical supplies? Healing potions and things like that?â€

    Bobbin brightened and nodded eagerly.

    â€œGood,â€ Hermione said in a tight voice. â€œBring me pain relief potions then. Every variety you have. And any other medical supplies you have access to. Bring them all here so I know what I have to work with.â€

    Bobbin vanished with a loud pop, and Draco twitched.

    Hermione looked down at him.

    He was dazedly staring up towards her, his eyes were unfocused, without any signs of recognition. Â 

    â€œDraco?â€

    â€œDracoâ€”â€ she touched him gently on the cheek and held her voice steady. Calming. â€œWhat did he do to you? How long were you crucioâ€™d?â€

    There was a pop and Bobbin appeared, surrounded by potions and medical supplies.

    â€œBobbin can.â€ The elf snapped her fingers and floated Draco carefully over towards the bed.

    Hermione went over and started sorting through all the supplies. They were all labeled, many of them in a sharp, spiky script she knew had been Severusâ€™.

    Hermione leaned over him, studying his eyes and taking note of all the physical symptoms she could detect. He was ghastly pale, and his chest kept hitching as he tried to breathe in a way that wasnâ€™t painful. She rested a hand against his forehead.

    The corner of his mouth twitched.

    Draco blinked and she could tell he was trying to force his eyes to focus on her as she handed him the third potion.

    She picked up his empty hand and pressed it against her cheek. â€œYou already know what I look like, rest your eyes. Your head will hurt less if you keep them closed.â€

    He obstinately narrowed them, trying to make out her face for a moment longer before obeying.

    She watched as some of the lines of tension around his eyes and mouth slowly faded and his breathing gradually evened.

    When she was sure the potions had taken effect, she moved on. â€œWhoâ€™s your healer? Who treats you after he tortures you? You need to call them. Youâ€™re not going to be able to move for weeks without treatment.â€

    Dracoâ€™s face remained neutral, but his fingers twitched. Hermione felt her chest tighten after he failed to answer for several seconds.

    â€œDracoâ€”â€

    â€œI deal with it myself unless itâ€™s life-threatening,â€ he finally said, the words were so low they were almost under his breath. He didnâ€™t open his eyes. â€œSeverus used to help occasionallyâ€”when it was something I didnâ€™t know how to healâ€”but otherwiseâ€”itâ€™s my job.â€

    Hermione stared at him in horror. Draco cracked an eye open and squinted at her before snorting.

    He raised one eyebrow and closed his eyes again, his expression tightening. â€œYou may recall you once put a rather rare stone into my heart.     Hermione felt as though heâ€™d gutted her. â€œI didnâ€™tâ€”I didnâ€™t realise.â€

    â€œItâ€™s fine, Granger.â€ He didnâ€™t open his eyes but still waved her off with his free hand. The corner of his mouth quirked up. â€œIâ€™ve been told several times now that I have a natural talent for healing.â€

    Her jaw kept trembling, and she ground her teeth together for a moment before she slipped his wand into his fingers. â€œCanâ€”can you do the spell for me then?â€

    He muttered the spells while she guided his fingers, tapping across the pressure points of his right hand and up his forearm. His fingers spasmed repeatedly as she helped him send the mild vibrations into the drawn muscles, easing the tension.

    His fingers finally fell open after several minutes, and she lay his wand aside. She picked up his right hand and began trying to fix all the damage. Her fingers began cramping, and she ignored it and kept working until his hand stopped twitching and would lay still.

    She picked up the last potion sheâ€™d brought over and poured a small amount of the embrocation onto her palm. Starting at the ball of his thumb, she began rubbing it in gently, working down to his wrist and forearm and then up to his shoulders. The potion was warm and made her skin tingle as she massaged it into his skin, trying to repair all the rigid knots and torn muscles.

    When she looked up after finishing both arms, Draco was asleep, his eyebrows tightly furrowed.

    She studied him for several seconds before reaching out and brushing her fingertip lightly between his eyes, trying to banish the tension.Â 

    Without Draco to cast the spells, trying to massage away the knots and tremors took longer. She continued anyway.

    Without him awake, she could safely cry while she worked.

    He slept for nearly forty-eight hours. Hermione stayed with him almost the entire time. His expression relaxed when she was in bed beside him, talking to him quietly about anything that came to mind, running her fingers through his hair and working on his muscle damage. She nearly depleted his entire supply of embrocation potions.

    When she became too restless to sit beside him, she would quietly pace. She looked out the window the next morning and spotted Lucius walking the length of the North Wing as though he were trying to measure it in paces. He looked up, and their eyes met.

    Hermioneâ€™s blood ran cold. She met his gaze for only a moment before shrinking back from sight.

    Everytime Draco woke, Hermione checked his eyes and had him perform basic healing spells for her. He kept dozing until Bobbin came to report that Lucius was at Dracoâ€™s door and threatening to break it down if he didnâ€™t see Draco.

    Draco forced himself up. â€œHow long have I been here? I was only given three days off. Bobbin, bring me a full set of robes.â€

    Hermione tried to hold him back. â€œDraco, wait. Your eyes still havenâ€™t recovered. You still have half a day. You need to rest for as long as possible.â€

    He rolled his eyes and stood up stiffly as Bobbin popped back in with a pile of robes. â€œThatâ€™s what I keep pain relief for.â€

    He dressed and made his way over to all the potions Bobbin had brought. He squinted as he held them a few inches from his face, trying to read the labels. He knocked back five of them in quick succession, ignoring Hermioneâ€™s objections that certain types of pain relief shouldnâ€™t be combined.

    He rolled his eyes. â€œIâ€™m well-versed in pain relief. I can almost guarantee it wonâ€™t be the thing that kills me.â€

    He blinked repeatedly and shook his head.

    Hermione could tell he still couldnâ€™t see reliably. â€œBe careful, Draco.â€

    He smiled briefly as he met her eyes. â€œIâ€™ll be fine.â€

    She still caught the tensed, braced expression on his face the split second before he apparated.

    Bobbin came a few hours later and took away all the medical supplies. Master Draco was fine, she said while avoiding Hermioneâ€™s eyes, he just wanted to inventory which potions Hermione had used.

    Hermione was left alone to occupy herself in her cage, worrying and wondering what was happening beyond her bedroom door.

    Chapter End Notes

    Hermione pregnant by thegirlthatreadsfantasybooks.

    Chapter 71

    July 2005

    She would save Draco.

    Luciusâ€™ mouth hardened into a flat line.

    Hermione held his gaze and let her desperation show on her face. Her heart felt like a fluttering bird caged inside her chest, beating itself to death as it kept fighting to escape.

    Her lips twitched. â€œVoldemort will kill him.     She touched the bars of the cage with her fingertips. â€œIâ€™m sure you realised that he became a spy to avenge Narcissa. He knew we probably wouldnâ€™t win.     Hermione shifted forward. â€œIâ€™ve tried everything I can to find a way to save him. Iâ€™ve had so many ideas but I never had the pieces I needed to make them work. If you really have Phoenix tears, I can save his life, but only if youâ€™ll help me. If saving him is enough for you.â€

    She wrapped her fingers around the bar. â€œI canâ€™t promise to leave him because Iâ€™ve already given him my word that I never will. But I can promise this: once heâ€™s free, if he ever wants to leave meâ€”Iâ€™ll let him go.â€

    Lucius leaned closer until their faces were only inches away from each other. His silver eyes were cruel and burning. â€œSwear it on your magic.â€

    Her mouth twitched, and her fingers spasmed where they were gripping the cold steel.

    She didnâ€™t give herself time to hesitate. â€œI swear it on my magic. If Draco ever wants to leave me, Iâ€™ll let him go. You have my word.â€

    Lucius stared at her a moment longer and then sighed and leaned back. â€œThe chest is in my wardrobe. My wand will unlock the door. Iâ€™ll open it once itâ€™s brought, and you can see if there are even enough tears.â€

    He looked back at the portrait and seemingly forgot about Hermione entirely.

    She studied the starved, desperate adoration on his face for a moment before she stood slowly. It wasnâ€™t surprising that Draco had never thought his father had space to care for anyone but his mother.

    She walked unsteadily across the room. Everything hurt. Even her heartbeat felt painful. The room was so unnaturally cold.

    Draco watched her approach from the doorway. His eyes were worried. She gave him a wan smile. Â 

    â€œHe says you can use his wand to open the door of his wardrobe,â€ she said. â€œThe chest is there, he said heâ€™ll open it.â€

    Draco pulled her away from the drawing room. â€œIâ€™m taking you back to your room.â€

    Hermione had barely nodded before he was carrying her again.

    â€œI can walk,â€ she said, trying to slip down, â€œyouâ€™re still recovering.â€

    â€œYou should be in bed,â€ Draco said in a cold voice.

    Hermione was too tired to argue. She buried her face in his robes and half-dozed as he carried her through the manor. She should have been manic with adrenaline, but instead she was tired. She was so tired.

    â€œHe does love you,â€ she said as they neared her room. â€œI just donâ€™t think he knows how to look at you without seeing your mother.â€

    â€œI know.â€ He set her on the bed. â€œRest, Granger. If I come back and youâ€™re reading, I will call a mind-healer in, I donâ€™t care what your plan is.â€

    She nodded cooperatively. Her head was hurting so much she didnâ€™t think she was actually capable of reading.     â€œYou explained it earlier, Granger. Stop talking and rest.â€

    Draco was silent for a moment. â€œIâ€™ll take care of everything.â€

    Â 

    It was evening when Draco woke her. There were half a dozen diagnostics conjured around her that he was studying.

    Her hand and leg had healed fully, and the baby was still a bright golden light. The light made her head ache.

    â€œI need to call a mind healer,â€ Draco said when she sat up wincing.

    His expression tightened.

    She looked up at him, her heart pounding rapidly in her chest. â€œDo you have it? Are they really Phoenix tears?â€

    Draco withdrew a vial of silvery liquid from his robes and handed it to her.

    â€œThereâ€™s an analytic spell, to confirm theyâ€™re really tears,â€ she said, her voice tight and nervous as she turned it over in her hand. â€œThey might not work. If theyâ€™re really that old. Thereâ€™s no research on preserving tears more than a few years.â€

    Draco cast the spell.

    Hermioneâ€™s vision doubled, but she squinted through it and studied it carefully.

    It was a vial of pure tears. The reading was perfect; the efficiency was still exact. They had been perfectly preserved.

    There were enough. She could tell just by looking at the irregular size of the vial that there were at least fifteen tears.

    She stared down at the vial in her hands for several seconds, trying to absorb the reality of what she held. Her stomach was fluttering, and she felt breathless.

    She could do it. Draco was going to live.

    She was going to save him.

    â€œWeâ€™ll need to do everything in the drawing room,â€ she finally said. â€œThereâ€™s so much magic already there that new spell signatures will be lost. Is everything ready? Did you contact Ginny?â€

    Draco nodded slowly. â€œSheâ€™s aware of what weâ€™re going to attempt. The elves have everything ready. Myâ€”my mother intends to stay. She doesnâ€™t want to leave my father.â€

    Hermione studied his face for a moment before standing and reaching out for him. The room swam. Draco caught her by the elbow.

    She held his robes until she found her bearings again. She drew a deep breath before forcing a smile. â€œI never ate breakfast. I should probably take a few potions.â€

    Her stomach rebelled, but she forced herself to keep down a strengthening potion and a nutritional potion long enough for her body to absorb them. Her head stopped feeling cracked and hollow.

    She stood up again and walked slowly around the room. Her calf was still sore, but her hand was fully healed. She bent and unfurled her fingers to check their dexterity. A Calming Draught would help manage her tremors once she needed to do spellwork.

    Her vision slowly stopped doubling.

    As long as the lights werenâ€™t too bright, sheâ€™d be alright.

    Draco stood watching her. His expression was closed, but his eyes were pensive and worried. â€œGranger, youâ€”â€

    â€œWeâ€™re going to do this, Draco,â€ she said, cutting him off. â€œIf it were me, would it even be a question?â€

    He reluctantly shook his head.

    â€œI can do this. Iâ€™ll be fine. Once we escape, I can recover for as long as I need to. After I save you.â€

    She went over to the doorway and walked through without hesitation.

    Lucius was still in the cage in the drawing room.

    Hermioneâ€™s stomach curdled as she entered the room for the third time that day.

    â€œBobbin,â€ said Draco, his tone still vicious.

    The elf appeared at the entrance of the drawing room.

    â€œBring everything here, and get the horse ready.â€

    Hermione chewed nervously on her lip. â€œOnce my manacles are off, how long do you think weâ€™ll safely have until itâ€™s noticed?â€

    â€œI doubt youâ€™ll have more than half an hour,â€ Lucius said.

    Hermione nodded. â€œThatâ€™s about what I thought. So, twenty minutes to get the Dark Mark off, and then a few extra minutes to leave.     She looked at Lucius. â€œIn order for this to work, everyone has to believe that Draco has died, that we all died. Can you do that?â€

    He glowered at her. â€œEasily. Assuming that my wand is returned.â€

    She nodded and turned away. The elves had brought in a large table that extended across nearly the length of the room. On one half, there were potion supplies laid out. On the other end, healing supplies: bandages, dozens of vials of Blood-Replenishing potion, Essence of Dittany, eye wateringly expensive pain relief, and several spools of acromantula silk. Hermione arranged it all carefully.

    There was a smaller table nearby with a pile of wands and a satchel on it.

    Her heart skipped a beat.

    Her satchel. She reached out and opened it. It was still packed with all her alchemy and potion supplies, as well as a full assortment of healing potions and supplies.

    â€œYou kept it,â€ she said as her fingers ran across the waxed canvas.

    â€œIt was useful,â€ said Draco in a dry voice. He watched her intently as she inspected the contents.

    There was a set of travel clothes, with riding breeches set with buttons to accommodate her stomach.     She laced up her boots and looked up at Draco. â€œYou have everything? Youâ€™re ready?â€

    He nodded and she stood.

    â€œYouâ€™re not going to be in any state to guide a horse. Not until some of the potions wear off. Where should I have the horse go until youâ€™re lucid?â€

    Dracoâ€™s expression grew more tense than it already was. â€œIt knows the way. Just tell her to go home. Her mate is at the safe house. She wonâ€™t fly anywhere else.â€

    Hermione nodded, her fingers twitching nervously. She hadnâ€™t ridden a horse since she flew a Thestral to the Ministry of Magic in her fifth year of school.

    She braced herself, she refused to have a panic attack.

    She turned back to the table and placed the silver cauldron on the stand. â€œIâ€™ll need you to do the spellwork for me, Draco.â€

    Her heart raced, but brewing a potion felt as natural as breathing.

    She started with white cedar oil, warming it gently as she added crushed valerian roots. When it grew aromatic, she poured honeywater slowly down the sides of the cauldron until it was halfway full.

    â€œI need the most intense flame you can conjure now,â€ she told Draco as she turned to inspect the Dittany leaves that the house-elves had minced and placed under stasis.

    She used a spoon to shift the minced leaves and verified every piece was surgically precise and uniform.

    The cauldron was boiling almost violently as the base was reduced to a syrup.

    She set to grinding the dried nettle and yarrow until they were a fine powder. Her ears were ringing slightly, and she blinked and shook her head as she focused on the mortar and pestle in her hands.

    She ground a half-dozen fairy wings in another pestle until they shone like silver dust and then sifted all the powder together.

    She dipped a copper stirring rod into the potion, and when she withdrew it, she counted to three before a thickened drop collected and fell back into the cauldron.

    â€œCool it to room temperature as rapidly as you can,â€ she said in a tight voice.

    The instant the surface of the liquid was still, she poured the powders across the surface in a slow figure eight. Count to ten. She placed thirty rose petals across the surface over the powder which was beginning to crystallise. Draco removed the stasis, and she added an even layer of Dittany on top.

    The potion sat still for several seconds before the entire surface turned translucent. Hermione immediately added crushed geranium and stirred rapidly with an ash stir rod, dropping pickled murtlap tentacles in with every fourth rotation. The potion turned a brilliant blue.

    â€œSimmering. It needs to barely move.â€

    She used a dropper to carefully measure out the tears. Fifteen. Exactly fifteen. There were two drops left in the vial.

    She stared at the simmering potion. It looked flawless. Exactly the way it should.

    Her hands shook slightly.

    â€œDraco, I need a Calming Draught.â€

    He handed it to her without a word. She swallowed it in a single gulp. Her hands stopped shaking.

    She added the tears. Even with Calming Draught, her heart was in her throat.

    When the last drop was added, she stood frozen as she watched. The silvery tears slid beneath the surface, luminous, as though they were falling stars. They slowly turned blood red. The colour spread through the rest of the potion and held.

    â€œFlagon.â€

    A silver ladle, dusted in powdered unicorn horn, transferred the potion into a glass flagon.

    Hermione stoppered it and released a slow breath. â€œThatâ€™s it.â€

    â€œThat removes the Dark Mark?â€ Lucius said, staring curiously at the potion in her hands.

    She looked over at him, and her stomach twisted. â€œNo. This stops the curse from killing him after I cut his arm off.â€

    Lucius stared at her blankly before his expression grew murderous.

    â€œYou intend to maim my son?â€ He lunged against the bars of the cage as he sneered at her. â€œYou claimed to be an ingenious healer and cutting off his arm is the best you can do?â€

    Hermioneâ€™s heart was pounding painfully in her chest as she gripped the flagon and stared at him. A burst of heat flared in the pit of her stomach. â€œYou may have noticed I donâ€™t have magic at the moment. Itâ€™s been two years since I cast a spell, and the instant my manacles are removed, Iâ€™m on a countdown. Iâ€™ll have twenty minutes to perform a procedure that should take an hour with a surgical team. I wonâ€™t even have my own wand.â€

    Her hands started shaking violently. She set down the potion on the table. â€œIf I had a better idea, I would be trying it. Do you thinkâ€”I want to cut off his armâ€”?â€ Her voice was vibrating.

    She wanted to scream at him.

    She turned away and pressed her hands again her sternum, fighting to breathe.

    Sheâ€™d never performed an amputation on anyone whose limbs werenâ€™t entirely destroyed beyond all hope. The Phoenix tears had been such an impossible missing piece. Sheâ€™d been so relieved to have them she hadnâ€™t fully processed the reality that she was about to cut Dracoâ€™s arm off.

    She felt as though she was about to be violently sick.

    She could vaguely hear Draco saying something to his father.

    Her throat was closing.

    She stumbled across the room to the far wall and pressed herself against it as she struggled to breathe. She choked back a sob, smothering it with her hands, and stood shaking.

    She felt fingertips brush lightly across her shoulder and flinched as the guilt almost shattered her.

    â€œIâ€™m so sorry, Draco. Iâ€™m sorry. Iâ€™m sorry. Iâ€™m so, so sorry.â€ Her voice was broken as she turned to look at him. â€œI swear if there was another way quick enough, Iâ€™d do it. Iâ€™m so sorryâ€”â€

    Her voice cut off as she sobbed. â€œYou have such beautiful hands. I always thoughtâ€”you had such beautiful handsâ€”â€

    Draco held her face in his hands, and she gripped his wrists tightly while she stood crying for several minutes. He wrapped his arms around her shoulders, and she sobbed and tried to memorise it.

    â€œGranger, I always assumed if I escaped, Iâ€™d lose my hand,â€ he said in a low voice, dropping his head against hers and tucking a curl behind her ear. â€œIf I could have, I would have cut it off myself years ago.â€

    She swallowed a sob and nodded. â€œI know. I justâ€”I really did try to find another way. I really did. I donâ€™t want you to think I would if I had any other choice.â€

    She brushed her tears away, drawing a deep breath as she turned back.

    She forced herself not to look at Lucius as she walked over and reviewed all the medical supplies, painstakingly laid out in the order that she needed them. She ran the procedure through her mind, verifying that she had everything sheâ€™d need.

    Her manacles were burning around her wrists.

    â€œIâ€™m ready.â€ She turned to face Draco and Lucius, extending her hands.

    â€œIf I harm her, you will undoubtedly blaspheme your motherâ€™s memory, torture me most horribly, and we will all die dreadfully.     Draco just sneered at him before looking back at Hermione. He took her hands gently in his and pressed her inner wrists together.

    â€œHold the manacles like this,â€ he said.

    She nodded without a word.
