    â€œMorsmordre.â€

    The Dark Marks slithered from their wands, but instead of traveling upwards, the green mist encircled Hermioneâ€™s manacles and disappeared beneath the shining copper. There was a brief pause.

    A quiet click and the manacles unclasped, falling to the ground.

    Hermione gave a low gasp and nearly fell over as her magic suddenly came roaring back to her.

    It was as though every cell in her body were glowing and the compulsions were jerked free of her consciousness.

    She felt high. She hadnâ€™t realised how sheâ€™d adapted to the lack of magic until it returned like a tidal wave.

    There was a sense of euphoria. She had magic. She could cast and cast and cast. She would bend the world to her will. Create and form, dissolve and destroy, andâ€¦ save Draco.

    She focused through the exhilaration rushing through her veins.

    She pulled on her magic, and it didnâ€™t fade, or vanish, or turn on her. She wrenched it inward, drew towards her mind, and slammed her occlumency walls into place. Blocking out everything. Â 

    Cold. Crystal clear.

    She picked up one of the wands and flicked it. It was like forcing something down a blocked channel. The wand gave a few halfhearted sparks. She tried the next, trying to find one that felt right. A wand that was responsive and attuned to her.

    Nothing. Nothing. Very little.

    Her shoulders grew more and more tense as she began running out of options. Draco even handed her Luciusâ€™ wand to try. Her stomach began twisting with dread.

    She started to pick up the last wand and then hesitated, looking up at Draco. â€œThis was your old wand from school.â€

    â€œIt was. Hawthorn and unicorn hair. They donâ€™t turn to the Dark Arts.â€

    As her fingers slipped around the handle, she felt her magic stir, warming her fingertips. She picked it up and waved it through the air.

    The room filled with lights.

    There was an itching in her fingers to experiment; to cast something superfluous or transfigure a few vials on the table. She ignored the temptation.

    Sheâ€™d already lost three minutes finding a wand.

    She conjured a twenty minute hourglass and flipped it, starting her countdown.

    â€œLie on the table,â€ she instructed Draco in a sharp voice. She flicked the wand and summoned several vials to herself. She felt a rush through her entire body but forced herself to ignore it.

    â€œTake all of these. Then Iâ€™m going to stun you.â€

    â€œNo,â€ Draco said in a flat voice as he downed the line up of potions.

    Hermione didnâ€™t look at him as she summoned the bandages and cut off the entire sleeve of his shirt. â€œDraco, I donâ€™t want you to watch me cut off your arm.â€

    â€œI doubt it could possibly be more traumatic than anything I havenâ€™t already experienced,â€ he said through his teeth. â€œDonâ€™t you dare stun me, Granger.â€

    She glanced up at him for a moment and found that he was nearly grey and his eyes were burning with determination. And terrified.

    Nine attempts.

    Heâ€™d seen nine Death Eaters die while trying to remove their Dark Marks. If she stunned him and it went wrong, he wouldnâ€™t wake up, heâ€™d just die. This would be goodbye.

    She pressed her lips together into a flat line and summoned an additional potion. â€œFine. Take this now, then.â€

    While the potions activated, she took his left hand in hers and used the wand tip to trace several glowing lines across his skin around the circumference of his forearm, trying to save as much of his arm as she could while still carefully avoiding the Dark Mark burned into his skin. Then she anesthetised his arm from the shoulder down.

    â€œAre you certain thereâ€™s no other way of removing his mark?â€ Luciusâ€™ condescendingly vicious voice interrupted her concentration. â€œHow much research did you actuallyâ€”â€

    Draco silenced his father with a sharp flick of his wand, still gripped in his right hand.

    Hermione was casting spells faster than she had ever done spellwork in her life. She knew his health and vitals intimately. She conjured over a dozen diagnostic and monitoring spells around him. His heart rate was elevated but steadily slowing as the potions took affect.

    One of the diagnostics turned blue, indicating that all the potions were fully integrated. She brought his left hand up to her lips, squeezing it and pressing her lips against it once before meeting his eyes.

    â€œI love you. I love you,â€ she whispered. â€œThis will work, I swear.â€

    Then she pinned his arm to the table and immobilised him.

    Â 

    *****

    Â 

    She began with the process of internally ligating and then cauterising the veins and arteries in his forearm. The fewer places he could bleed from when she started cutting, the lower the risk. The curse was designed to force him to bleed to death; any opportunity for blood loss increased the risk, even with the Phoenix tears.

    When the diagnostic scan showed that the blood flow to his forearm had been completely stopped, she drew a slow breath and ran the wand along one of the lines sheâ€™d drawn across the skin.

    Draco jerked involuntarily as she ligated and then severed the nerves in his arm. She didnâ€™t let herself look up.

    She angled the wand at a sharp diagonal angle and began cutting through his skin and muscle down to the bone.

    She vaguely registered the sound of Narcissa sobbing. She kept working.

    Draco gave a ragged gasp and suddenly there was blood everywhere, the cauterised veins and arteries forcibly beginning to open themselves. The diagnostic spells began flashing and turning dangerous warning hues. Dracoâ€™s heart rate sky-rocketed. Â 

    She cast a powerful stasis spell on his arm and snatched up the Phoenix tear potion.

    She tilted Dracoâ€™s head up and upended the contents down his throat, casting a spell to prevent his body from regurgitating it. She could feel him shaking through the immobilisation.

    She met his eyes as her wand spun rapidly in her fingers, and she cast spell after spell on him.

    â€œHold on. Stay with me. Iâ€™m going to save you. Trust me. Youâ€™re not going to die.â€

    His eyes were locked on her face as she cast spells on his heart to stabilise and slow it until the potion took affect.

    She touched his cheek as she studied the diagnostics. â€œYou and me and our baby. Weâ€™re all going to be free. I'm going to save you. Weâ€™ll go so far away no one will ever find us. You have to hold on.â€

    The diagnostics stabilised, and she dosed him immediately with a vial of blood-replenishing potion.

    Hermione didnâ€™t have time to even register her relief. She started re-cauterising all the ruptured veins and arteries as quickly as she could. Â 

    â€œDraco, look away,â€ she said in a voice as taut as a bowstring. She didnâ€™t have time to verify that he had.

    She turned back, muttered a spell, and cut through his radius and ulna.

    His arm was removed.

    Her hand shook slightly, and she countered the sticking charm, clinically moving the severed limb away, covering it with a cloth.

    She could feel the time running out.

    She smoothed the bones, drilled several tiny holes and then washed the entire area with Essence of Dittany before summoning a spool of acromantula silk and rapidly suturing the tendons to the bones. Sheâ€™d visualised, practiced, and reviewed the procedure a thousand times in her room, the precise order of every movement. Once sheâ€™d completed the myodesis, she began wand-suturing layer after rapid layer of stitches. They were quicker to perform and more forgiving than the spellwork sheâ€™d used on his runes. Her fingers twitched, and she didnâ€™t have time to fix the crooked stitches.

    She was running out of time.

    Stitch after stitch, layer after layer until the fascial tissue met neatly.

    *****

    Â 

    â€œFerula,â€ she said, drawing her wand along his skin. Bandages wrapped firmly around his arm nearly up to his shoulder.

    â€œThere,â€ she said, stepping back and giving herself a moment to breathe raggedly. There were drops of perspiration on her face. She was still gasping with relief as she countered the immobilisation on Draco. He was barely conscious. She began carefully inspecting all the diagnostics and monitor spells surrounding him as the sand in the hourglass ran out.

    He was stable, although drained both physically and magically. There were still traces of the curse, but the most deadly aspects were countered. She gave him a potion meant for countering vampire antivenin, and it improved his blood platelet count.

    Lucius banged his shackles loudly against the bars of the cage. Hermione turned sharply, and countered the silencing spell Draco had used on him.

    â€œI hope youâ€™re done. Youâ€™ve run out of time. Iâ€™m being summoned,â€ he said in a tight voice. Â 

    Her stomach plummeted, and she nodded. She pulled on her coat, cloak and gloves, and, with a flick of her wand, cast a spell on Draco to make him lighter. She wrapped his robes and cloak tightly around him, muttering warming charms, and put a dragonhide glove onto his remaining hand before taking hold of his right arm, pulling it over her shoulder to help him stand.

    She picked up Luciusâ€™ wand from the table where it lay and held it towards him. â€œYou can do it? Youâ€™ll do it?â€

    He sneered at her as he jerked his wand from her hand. â€œGet out of my house, Mudblood.â€

    Hermione spelled all the supplies and extra wands into her satchel and slung it over her shoulder, turning and half-carrying Draco across the room towards the door.

    â€œDracoâ€¦â€ Lucius spoke when they were nearly out of the room.

    Hermione wavered over whether to pause or keep going. Draco twitched.

    She swallowed hard and stopped, turning him back.

    Lucius was staring across the room with the same starved expression heâ€™d worn looking at Narcissa.

    â€œFather. Mother,â€ Draco said, his voice low and forced.

    Lucius rested a hand on the bars of the cage. â€œI was proud of you.â€

    Draco was silent for a moment.

    â€œRightâ€¦â€ he said, the word barely more than a whisper.

    Narcissa stared at Hermione. â€œSave him.â€

    Hermione nodded. â€œYes.â€

    Lucius looked at Draco for a moment longer before his eyes dropped to Hermione. â€œGet him out.â€

    Hermione tightened her hold on Draco and walked quickly out the doors of the South Wing.

    Bobbin and several other elves were standing outside, holding the reins of the Granian. It was saddled and pawing the gravel impatiently, prancing as it stood waiting at the doors.

    The elves helped Draco up into the saddle, and Hermione mounted behind him. She looked down at Bobbin.

    â€œGet all of the elves out of the manor. Donâ€™t let any of the Death Eaters find you. Donâ€™t ever tell anyone what happened.â€

    Bobbin nodded.

    Hermione took the reins and drew a deep breath before snapping her wrists and kicking.

    â€œTake us home!â€ She shouted the words. Â 

    The Granian bolted forward like a racehorse released from the gate. Its flight muscles tensed tightly as it galloped the length of the manor and took a powerful leap, wings extending. The smoky grey feathers beat surely against the wind, and they were airborne. The Granian circled, carrying them higher and higher as it gained altitude. The wind was whistling around them as they shot through the protective wards of the estate.

    There was a roar from below that shook the air.

    Hermione glanced over her shoulder as the roof of Malfoy Manor exploded in flames. An enormous fiendfyre dragon rose up, screaming with soul-rending rage as it tore the building apart.

    Chapter End Notes

    Additional Illustrations:

    • Let's run away by minxchester.
    • "Save him"by Jaxx in a box.

    Chapter 73

    Chapter Notes

    See the end of the chapter for notes

    The air was cold and the wind constant as the Granian sped across England and over the North Sea.Â 

    The horse moved impossibly fast through the air, faster than a Thestral, faster than Hermione thought it was possible for any living animal to move.Â 

    She gripped Draco until her hands ached. "Don't die, Draco. Hold on."

    She kept whispering diagnostic spells and verifying that the curse hadnâ€™t evolved, that there wasnâ€™t fluid accumulation, reassuring herself that his heart rate remained steady.Â 

    They were going so fast and so high that the ground was a blur. She refused to look. She couldn't falter.Â 

    "Don't die, Draco,â€ she said again as she buried her face against his back.Â 

    Her head was throbbing.Â 

    The horse kept flying, on and on.Â 

    Hour after hour.Â 

    The sensation of freefalling suddenly made Hermioneâ€™s stomach flip as the Granian hit the ground at a run. Its wings were held out wide, carrying it up off the ground in long flying leaps as it slowed down.Â 

    Hermione lifted her head and stared dazedly. It was night, and only a crescent moon illuminated the sky.Â 

    The horse had landed in an open field.Â 

    She squeezed Dracoâ€™s hand as the Granian cantered to a stop. â€œDracoâ€¦ Draco, weâ€™ve landed. I donâ€™t know how to find the safe house.â€

    She shook him gently until she felt him stir. â€œDraco. I think weâ€™re here.â€

    He lifted his head slowly.

    â€œNix...â€

    There was a pop, and a tiny and positively ancient-looking house-elf appeared.Â 

    â€œMaster Draco, Nix did not expect you,â€ the elf said. Its voice was creaky with age.

    Draco stared at him and finally nodded slowly. â€œTake the horse.â€

    Hermione let the reins slip from her fingers. She started to shift to dismount, but her leg in the stirrup wouldnâ€™t hold her. She started to topple off the horse.Â 

    Draco abruptly jerked from barely lucid to awake. His right hand shot out and caught her by the cloak.

    â€œNix!â€

    Hermione felt herself caught magically, and Dracoâ€™s hand let go. She was levitated gently to the ground and lay in the grass, too exhausted to move. She stared up at the sky. The stars were bright and glittering overhead.

    A moment later Draco brought his leg over the saddle and slid off the Granian, dropping down heavily beside the horse. He patted its neck for a moment before turning and kneeling down next to Hermione. He was as pale as the moonlight, and his expression was dazed but worried as he stared down at her. He pulled the glove off with his teeth and pressed his hand against her cheek.Â 

    She forced herself to give him a wan smile. â€œWe did it, Draco.â€

    The corner of his mouth quirked up, and his hand slipped down to take hers. She stood, slowly and unsteadily, and they leaned against each other as they walked forward. Draco stopped and extended his hand. There was a clicking sound, and a ray of pale candle light appeared as a door swung open.Â 

    They didnâ€™t even bother to pull their cloaks off; they just collapsed into the bed and slept. Hermione gripped his hand tightly between both of hers. Dracoâ€™s chin brushed against her forehead, and she buried her face against his chest, breathing him in.

    It was nearly evening the next day when she woke. Her headache was still a constant grinding pain in the back of her mind. She blinked it away, looking carefully around.Â 

    They were in a small A-frame cabin. It smelled of raw timber and was mostly unfurnished. A stove. The bed and a small table. A bright brass key hung from a hook on the wall. There were eyelet lace curtains hanging from the windows, and the sunlight streamed down over them where they lay curled up together on the bed.Â 

    There was no cold and sterile manor. No creeping sensation of dark magic in the walls and soil. No manacles. No compulsions.

    They were safe. Free. Far away from the war.

    She studied Draco, her heart in her throat, as she absorbed everything.Â 

    It was too good to be true. It had to be. Things in her life were never this beautiful.Â 

    She pulled a hand away from Draco in order to search the lining of her cloak for the unicorn wand. As her fingers closed around it, Draco shifted and she glanced over to find him staring at her.

    She gripped the wand tightly in her hand as she looked at him.Â 

    Her pulse was racing, and she could almost hear the blood roaring in her ears. It felt as though the wrong movement or sound might break everything apart. The warmth and safety would bleed away, and once again sheâ€™d find herself as a shadow in the dark, cold manor or swallowed by the darkness under Hogwarts.

    â€œI feel like this is going to shatter somehow,â€ she finally said, reaching out and brushing her fingers through his hair, trying to make herself believe that he was truly there. That the warmth and light and feeling of safety were real.Â 

    He nodded slowly. As she studied him, she could see the tension around his eyes and in the way his jaw was set.Â 

    She reached and unclasped his cloak, gently pushing it off his left shoulder so she could see his bandaged arm. â€œItâ€™s hurting, isnâ€™t it?â€

    He shook his head. â€œItâ€™s fine.â€

    Her throat tightened. She sat up quickly, and the sunlit world swam in her vision as she blinked rapidly, drawing his unicorn wand from her cloak. â€œDonâ€™t lie about it, I canâ€™t care for you properly if youâ€™re lying.â€

    She ignored her headache and pulled off her cloak and coat so that she could move her arms more easily.

    There was a tray of food on a small table beside them. Draco sat up and speared a burnt sausage with a fork and began nibbling at it while Hermione was rapidly casting diagnostic spells on him. She checked his heart and other vital signs. She examined his blood readings. She cast a complex diagnostic on his left arm and carefully inspected every vein, artery, and major nerve. She spent several minutes siphoning away accumulating fluid.

    She reached out and grasped the strap of her satchel, dragging it over before she remembered she could use summoning spells. She rummaged through its contents until she found all the potions she needed.Â

    She took his hand in hers and started treating his tremors for several minutes in silence.Â 

    â€œDonâ€™t hurt yourself for me, Draco,â€ she finally said in stiff voice. â€œStop hurting yourself. I am so tired of that being the way we care for each other.     He still didnâ€™t say anything. He didnâ€™t look penitent either.

    While she was working on his hand, a tray with more inedible food appeared. They both took nutritional potions instead. Hermioneâ€™s stock of them was beginning to run low.Â 

    She took a careful inventory of everything she had left, mentally calculating how many more days they could stay if they chose to.Â 

    â€œI could brew more if we want to stay longer,â€ she said, looking up at Draco.Â 

    â€œWhatever you want.â€ He smiled at her, but heâ€™d dressed and put on his cloak while she was taking inventory. As she was staring at him, she noticed his eyes flicker over towards the window subtly.Â 

    â€œWe should go.â€ She pulled the satchel onto her shoulder and shoved the rest of their belongings into it. â€œIâ€™m sureâ€”Iâ€™m sure it will be alright. Itâ€™ll just be once.â€Â 

    She pulled out a vial of Calming Draught and stared at it for several seconds before taking it. She entwined her fingers tightly with Dracoâ€™s and drew a deep breath, forcing herself to occlude the anxiety rushing through her like a tidal wave before the potion activated.Â 

    She squeezed Dracoâ€™s hand, running her thumb over his knuckles and stopping at the ring he wore. She looked up at him and gave a tentative smile before she reached out, grasping the brass key hanging on the wall.Â 

    There was a sharp tug behind her navel. She was snatched up, pulling Draco with her.Â 

    She tried to stay on her feet as she landed, but she stumbled forward and collapsed, retching. She wrenched her hand from Dracoâ€™s and pressed the heel of her hand against her stomach as it contracted taut.

    â€œOh god,â€ she groaned as she pushed herself up and struggled to breathe.Â 

    She felt Dracoâ€™s hand on the small of her back as she squeezed her eyes shut and forced herself to inhale slowly. Slowly. The rigidity in her abdomen gradually faded.

    She could smell earth and bracken.Â 

    She opened her eyes and found that they were kneeling in a forest. â€œAre we there?â€

    There was a sliding sound and a crack as wood struck wood. Hermione looked over her shoulder. There was a large wooden house behind them.Â 

    Ginny stood in the doorway, staring at them, a wand gripped in her hand.Â

    He stared at her, his eyes skeptical. â€œWas healing ever a career you considered before you realised the Resistance needed healers?â€

    â€œWell,â€ she fidgeted with the hem of her shirt, â€œthere were only a few options available for anyone.â€

    â€œAnd by complete coincidence you ended up in the one that no one else wanted.â€ His voice was caustic.Â 

    A large tray of food appeared, with heaping platefuls of vegetables, steak and kidney pie, and mashed potatoes, and apple turnovers.Â 

    Comfort food.Â 

    Draco made a sound of dismay as he stared at the food. â€œWeasleyâ€™s still interfering in the kitchen.â€

    Hermione ignored him and served them both platefuls of more food than either of them could possibly eat.Â 

    Draco kept muttering complaints under his breath while Hermione gorged herself. She couldnâ€™t remember when she had eaten so much. It was all so familiar-tasting. Food sheâ€™d eaten growing up. Dinners at the Burrow during the summers before school started.Â 

    The reminiscence nearly made her cry.Â 

    In spite of all his complaints about wasting French gourmet-trained house-elves, Draco was not inclined to skip the meal. He glanced up at her when she finally began eating more slowly. â€œYou should lie down once youâ€™ve eaten.â€

    Hermione shook her head. â€œNo. I want to meet James.â€

    â€œYou can meet him tomorrow. Heâ€™s not going anywhere.â€

    â€œI want to meet him today. I was supposed to take care of him, but heâ€™s nearly two and Iâ€™ve never even met him.â€

    Draco stared as her while she met his eyes and obstinately forced down another mouthful of apple turnover. He gave an irritated sigh. â€œFine. Iâ€™ll call an elf and have it tell Ginny to bring him.â€

    Hermione nodded and set down her plate. â€œDoâ€”are there other clothes here for me? Orâ€”did you just bring books?â€

    His eyes narrowed and the corner of his mouth twitched. â€œThere are clothes. Iâ€™m not sure how many accommodate a pregnancy. If nothing fits, Ginny has some.â€

    Hermione nodded and went to explore the dresser. There was a huge quantity of clothes, much in the way there seemed to be unreasonable amounts of everything else. The dresser drawers seemed to go on and on as she pulled them out.Â 

    There were some robes, but most of the clothing was Muggle. Hermione hunted until she found a jumper and trousers that fit without needing adjustment charms.

    Â 

    James had dark auburn-red hair that stood on end and shockingly green eyes.Â 

    Aside from his hair, he looked exactly like Harry. Hermione stared at him and felt like she was having her heart crushed.Â 

    His emerald green eyes studied her suspiciously while he clung tightly to Ginny.Â 

    The same eyes. The same mouth. Harry. It was Harry all over again.Â 

    â€œJames, this is your godmother, Aunt Hermione. Remember, I told you about her? She was your dadâ€™s best friend at school.     James leaned in closer to Ginny, burying his face against his mumâ€™s throat and peeking at Hermione and Draco shyly.Â 

    â€œHello, James,â€ Hermione said once she found her voice. â€œI knew you a bit before you were born. Iâ€™m so glad to finally meet you.â€

    James snorted and covered his face with a hand.Â 

    â€œHeâ€™s never seen any humans in person but me and Malfoy,â€ Ginny said, resting her head against Jamesâ€™. â€œButâ€”if the way he is with the elves means anything, once he gets over being shy, heâ€™ll never leave you alone again. James, can you say â€˜Aunt Hermioneâ€™?â€

    â€œNo.â€ Jamesâ€™ voice was piping and obstinate.Â 

    â€œDo you want to say, hello?â€

    â€œNo.â€

    Ginny sighed and poked his ribs. â€œRude boy.â€

    James buried his face more determinedly into Ginnyâ€™s shoulder and laughed.Â 

    â€œItâ€™s fine,â€ Hermione said in a thick voice, feeling overwhelmed just staring at him. â€œHe looks so much like Harry.â€

    Ginny nodded with a tight smile and pressed a kiss in Jamesâ€™ hair. â€œHe really does. It blindsides me sometimes. Heâ€™ll make faces sometimes and it just hits me like a bludger, and for a moment Iâ€™ll forget Iâ€™m staring at him becauseâ€”itâ€™s Harry.     James abruptly popped his head up and stared at Hermione. â€œMine-y.â€ He pointed at her. â€œMine-y.â€

    â€œHermione,â€ Ginny said slowly, dragging out the consonants.Â 

    James shook his head. â€œMine-y.â€

    â€œI couldnâ€™t say it when I was little either,â€ Hermione said with a smile.

    â€œHeâ€™s a pretty good little chap.â€ Ginny shifted him to her other hip. â€œDoesnâ€™t sleep much, and we had colic at first. But heâ€™s pretty happy now. Although, ever since he started walking, heâ€™s been a lot naughtier. Grabs everything he can reachâ€”â€Â 

    Hermione nodded automatically as she kept staring at James.Â 

    She wasnâ€™t sure how to interact with a baby. She was so used to thinking of them in the abstract. Actually meeting one who talked and had opinions about things made Hermione feel adrift.Â 

    She couldnâ€™t remember when sheâ€™d last seen or held a child. It had probably been when sheâ€™d helped transport orphans during the war.Â 

    The world Ginny existed in suddenly felt alien.Â 

    Hermione had forgotten about how expressive people could be. That she didnâ€™t need to primarily read people by the ways their eyes flickered and what they didnâ€™t say.Â 

    Babies, colic, development landmarks. If she and Draco were really free, that would be the kind of world they would be part of.Â 

    If it had worked.Â 

    If they were safe.Â 

    If Draco was free.Â 

    Hermioneâ€™s chest tightened, and she nodded again at whatever Ginny was saying.Â 

    Her head was beginning began to throb.Â 

    â€œGinny, Granger needs to rest now,â€ Dracoâ€™s cold voice suddenly broke in.Â 

    Hermione blinked.

    Ginnyâ€™s expression froze and then fell. â€œSorry. I get carried away.â€ She forced herself to smile again. â€œJames needs lunch anyway. Rest. The elves will bring more food. If youâ€”if you need anything, weâ€™re here.â€

    Ginnyâ€™s eyes and mouth were strained as she shifted James back onto her other hip and turned away, heading back to their wing of the rambling house.Â 

    Hermione watched them go. â€œSheâ€™s so lonely, Draco. You could have let her tell me more about James.â€

    â€œYou need to rest. You have years to get to know him.â€

    Hermione wanted to argue, but she did feel ready to fall asleep standing.Â 

    She curled up in bed and closed her eyes.Â 

    Draco sat beside her, holding her hand the same way he had during her morning sickness, his thumb running along the ridges of her knuckles.Â 

    She was just drifting off when she felt her hand gently set down on the bed. The mattress shifted.Â Â 

    She watched through her lashes as he looked down at her a moment longer and slowly turned, resting his hand against the wall as though he were feeling something inside it.Â 

    He drew his wand and started muttering spells.Â 

    Hermione watched him as he added enchantment after enchantment to the room. Some were simple, innocuous spells and others elaborate, magical incantations. She cringed when he slipped a knife out of his robes and held the handle between his teeth as he sliced his hand open and used the blood to draw scarlet runes on the walls. The symbols glowed as he kept adding more and more until they finally faded into the wall and disappeared.Â 

    He pulled out a vial of Blood-Replenishing Potion and took it before fishing out a vial of Essence of Dittany which he used to close the cut. He stared at his blood-covered hand and wiped it off on his robes before scourgifying his clothing.Â 

    He rested his hand on the wall again.Â 

    His shoulders slumped down for a moment before he squared them and headed for the door.Â 

    â€œDraco?â€

    He froze and slowly turned back to her. His expression was closed.Â 

    She just studied him for several seconds, her heart felt like a lead weight. â€œAre we safe here Draco?â€

    â€œYes,â€ he said immediately.Â 

    She sat up, and his expression tensed.Â 

    â€œReally?â€

    He stood in the doorway, his wand in his hand. â€œItâ€™s safe here. You have my word.â€

    She nodded. â€œIf you say so, I believe you.â€

    He gave a stiff nod of his own.Â Â 

    She licked her lips. â€œDo you need to keep adding wards then? If weâ€™re safe.â€

    He stood staring at her, apparently uncertain about how to reply.

    She gave him a wan smile as a throbbing sense of grief swallowed her chest. â€œWeâ€™re supposed to get to rest now. Youâ€™re not supposed to keepâ€”soldiering on and on like weâ€™re still chained to the war.â€

    He just kept standing by the door.Â 

    She studied him sadly as she realised the difference between them: he had never had dreams about what heâ€™d do or be after the war. Unlike her, he had few expectations to be disappointed by.Â 

    He also had no idea what to do but continue with what heâ€™d always done.Â 

    She reached out towards him. â€œStay with me. This is supposed to be the part where we get to rest.â€

    He kept standing at the door, his eyes flickering towards the next room.Â 

    â€œIf thereâ€™s something you need to do, Iâ€™ll wait for you.â€

    She saw his hand twitch before he gripped his wand in a fist. His eyes were suddenly boyish and uncertain.Â 

    He had no idea how to do anything but be a soldier.

    He glanced towards the next room again.Â 

    She reached towards him. â€œStay here, Draco. Youâ€™re supposed to rest now too.â€

    He nodded slowly but didnâ€™t move from where he stood in the doorway. Hermione got up and walked over. She met his eyes as she slipped his wand out of his hand, placing it on the dresser.     She wasnâ€™t sure if heâ€™d brought any belongings with him but weapons.

    He grimaced as she removed everything and piled it on the dresser.Â 

    She paused and looked up into his eyes. â€œWeâ€™re safe, right?â€

    He swallowed and nodded slowly.Â 

    She took his hand. â€œThen put it down.â€

    She stared at him as they lay face to face on her bed. His eyes kept flickering past her to the weaponry sheâ€™d taken off him.Â 

    â€œWhat did you want to beâ€”before you were forced to become a Death Eater? What would you have done if the war hadnâ€™t happened?â€

    â€œOh... Well, what was your favourite subject in school?â€

    Somehow sheâ€™d never asked him that question before, and she wasnâ€™t sure she could guess the answer. They only knew each other through the facets that had been polished by war.Â

    The corner of her mouth quirked up. â€œI should have guessed that. I remember that you were good at them. You could take it up again. Alchemy uses charmwork quite heavily. Maybe we could work together on projects someday.â€

    The corner of his mouth twitched. â€œMaybe.â€

    He looked tired. Hermione burrowed against him, and he tangled his hand in her hair, pulling her closer.Â 

    â€œWeâ€™re safe here?â€ she asked again, running her fingers along the placket of his shirt. â€œYouâ€™re notâ€”youâ€™re not just saying that we are so Iâ€™ll stay calm, are you?â€Â 

    Draco drew back and looked at her. â€œWeâ€™re safe, Hermione.â€

    A catching sensation in her chest faded away. â€œAlright then.â€Â 

    She drew a deep breath and closed her eyes.

    When she woke hours later, he was asleep too. It was as though nine years of exhaustion had finally risen up and swallowed him.Â 

    He slept for days, nearly insensate. Hermione could unbandage his arm and treat it, and he wouldnâ€™t twitch.Â 

    She slept with him for the first week.     Her headaches gradually went away for the most part. She found some parchment and a quill and carefully wrote down everything she could recall of the fading memories, and when she reviewed them several days later, many of the details were unfamiliar.Â 

    But her mind felt as though it had found a precarious type of equilibrium.Â 

    Draco kept sleeping steadily into the next week. Heâ€™d wake briefly to get up and eat, check the wards, and then collapse back into the bed, gripping Hermione. Sometimes she worried he must be ill to sleep so much. Sheâ€™d check him with diagnostics to reassure herself.Â 

    He didnâ€™t sleep if she left.Â 

    She tried slipping quietly into the next room to explore the bookshelves, but he appeared in the doorway within two minutes, wand in hand. She grabbed several books off the shelves and returned to their bed.Â 

    â€œI can get up now,â€ he said, still standing in the doorway.Â

    Heâ€™d been sleeping for nine days when there was a light tapping on the door.Â

    Hermione closed the book and nodded. Theyâ€™d sent each other several notes via house-elves, but she hadnâ€™t seen Ginny for more than a few minutes since the day theyâ€™d arrived.

    Hermione could see the concern in Ginnyâ€™s eyes. She didnâ€™t say anything.Â

    Hermioneâ€™s chest tightened, it was as though Ginny had touched an agony sheâ€™d forgotten she still carried. She pressed her lips together and squeezed Dracoâ€™s hand.

    Ginny stood up sharply. â€œI just needed to say all of that. I needed to say it at least once.     â€œGrangâ€”â€

    Epilogue 1

    Chapter Notes

    See the end of the chapter for notes

    Â 

    High Reeve Killed in Fiendfyre Accident

    Draco Malfoy killed by father in shocking murder-suicide case at Malfoy Manor.

    Draco Malfoy, a prominent figure in the Dark Lord's government, and his father, a widower, are suspected to have died in a house fire.

    Aurors are still investigating the case. The official statement from the Department of Magical Law enforcement is that the cause of the fire remains unknown, but officials speaking off-record have confirmed the fire possesses all signs of having been fiendfyre that was intentionally set and sustained.Â 

    Photos of the Malfoy Manor ruins are almost identical to the ruins of the Lestrange Manor fire from several years before. â€œEveryone knew Lucius was obsessed with that fire,â€ an unnamed source says, â€œhe obtained all the records and files and revisited the Lestrange ruins dozens of times. It's almost undeniable that the fire was a recreation. It's so tragic: he never got over Narcissa's death.â€

    Close family friends say that Lucius abandoned most of his obligations following his wifeâ€™s death, handing over the title and estate to Draco, who was twenty years old at the time. Lucius has rarely returned to Britain in the years following, but during his most recent visit his behavior had been notably erratic. Aurors speaking off-record confirm that Lucius is now suspected in several cases of missing persons, including Astoria Malfoy, who vanished less than twenty-four hours after returning from a summer holiday in France.

    There were persistent rumours of tension between father and son. Although outwardly cordial, they were rarely seen together, and Lucius did not return from his post abroad for Dracoâ€™s wedding in 2003.Â 

    The title and responsibilities of High Reeve are expected to be transferred to another Death Eater within the week. There are several Generals under consideration. However, at the time of printing, there is no official statement from the Dark Lord regarding a successor or about the deaths of Draco and Lucius.Â 

    The loss of a family line as old and distinguished as the Malfoy Family is a devastating blow to the wizarding world. Draco was the last of both the Malfoy and Black families. A healer from the Repopulation Program has confirmed that the surrogate to Draco Malfoy also died in the fire. She was four months pregnant with a Malfoy heir.Â 

    Â After two weeks of sleeping, Draco and Hermione finally emerged. Draco immediately went to check all the wards on the island. After he came back, he gave Hermione a full tour of the house. She gripped his hand when they went into the gardens.Â 

    They walked around a corner and found Ginny watching James attempt to scale a pagoda. She gave a tight smile when she saw them.Â 

    â€œGood, youâ€™re up. I wasnâ€™t sure when youâ€™d stop hibernating.â€ She eyed Draco. â€œThereâ€™s someone whoâ€™s been waiting to see you. Topsy!â€

    There was an immediate pop as Topsy materialised. She stood staring up at Draco for a moment, her hands clasped together and her enormous eyes shining. Then she stepped forward and kicked Draco.Â 

    â€œTopsy is so angry at you!â€ she said as her toes collided with his shin. â€œTopsy is never been so angry in all her life.â€

    It felt surreal. Theyâ€™d been cut out of one reality, dropped into another one, and just left to find their way.Â 

    It didnâ€™t feel like a dream. It was real. She could smell the salt in the air, hear the leaves shift in the breeze and the water trickling. She could smell camphor and pine needles. Dracoâ€™s hand was warm and entwined with hers.Â 

    And yet there was an edge of paranoia that she couldnâ€™t shake. There had to be something lurking, something waiting, something that was going to go wrong. Inevitable ruin was dangling over her head like the sword of Damocles.Â 

    The island felt as though it were built upon a razor thin sheet of ice. If Hermione stepped wrong or forgot to the careful for a moment, it would crack, and sheâ€™d plunge back into the black, cold, world sheâ€™d just escaped from, dragging Draco and everyone else with her.Â 

    Every step. Every breath.Â 

    Careful. Be so careful.Â 

    You always lose the things you love. Always.Â 

    Her jaw started trembling. She wanted to go back inside; it felt safer to be inside. Where was her wand?

    Once she wasnâ€™t worried about waking Draco, Hermione set to work in her lab. It took her a week to build a basic prosthetic for him. The amputation had healed perfectly, but his blood stayed permanently thin unless he was regularly taking a potion for it.Â 

    He sat on the edge of her lab table while she carefully fitted the base of the prosthetic onto his forearm.Â 

    â€œThis first prosthetic isnâ€™t much,â€ she said as she muttered the spells. â€œIt will only connect with major nerves, so youâ€™ll only have a vague sense of the movement and touch.     Hermione ran her hand along the forearm up to the fingers. â€œThatâ€™s about as much as youâ€™ll be able to feel with this.â€ She looked at him seriously. â€œYouâ€™ll have to be careful.     They had so much time.Â 

    They explored the island. Draco showed her the trails and old, mossy paths that wound through the forests. They went down to the rocky beach, and Hermione stood at the edge of the water and stared at the vast ocean stretching out as far as she could see.

    It felt like they were the only people on earth. Hidden a world away from the war.Â 

    Hermione went foraging. Draco had bought books about the edible and magical vegetation in the area at some point. The island was somewhere off the coast of Japan.     After months of revolutions breaking out in Death Eater controlled countries, the International Confederation announced its intention to â€œinterveneâ€ in the European situation in October of 2005.     Voldemort barely had the troops to attempt even a semblance of a resistance. Even the Death Eaters had no confidence in their ability to win another war.     There was too much discontent and too few Death Eaters. Without Draco as High Reeve, there was no one who could inspire the same terror.Â 

    The International Confederation landed in Denmark in late October and swept down from Northern Europe in a curve towards Britain.Â 

    Watching the International Confederationâ€™s Liberation Front effectively crush Voldemortâ€™s regime had all the feeling of vindication, but there was also a profound sense of betrayal to see how differently things could have been if the International Confederation had been willing to aid the Resistance during the war.Â

    Harry and Ron and everyone else might have been alive then.Â 

    Every time they received the newspapers, reading was a flood of both relief and poisonous grief.Â 

    Hermione devoted most of her time to creating a better prosthetic for Draco. It was like building a several thousand piece puzzle. She had to make all the components herself and fit them together in a way that didnâ€™t interfere with the other elements.Â 

    She finished it in November. Draco studied it as she detached the metal prosthetic and then clicked the new prosthetic into place. Draco hissed and then flinched as all the nerves connected to the new prosthetic.

    â€œHow did youâ€”?â€

    She traced her fingers along the porcelain plating, a smile playing at her mouth. â€œYou can feel it then?â€

    Hermione held the prosthetic in her hands, brushing her thumbs across the palm and watching the fingers twitch in response. â€œSee the swirls? The porcelain is laced with silver threads.     â€œClever. Although,â€ he picked up a pencil and twirled it between his fingers before rotating his wrist and observing how the hand moved, â€œyou could have just given me a silver hand. It would have been quicker.â€

    â€œYou have an appalling sense of humour.â€ She tapped her wand against a porcelain fingertip, giving it a small electric shock.Â

    â€œNow, serious testing, try a spell.â€

    â€œNo. Not with your wand, just like this.â€ She extended her left hand demonstratively, pointing her index finger and mimed the Wingardium Leviosa hand motion.

    She smiled up at him and tucked a curl behind her ear. â€œI did. Then I figured it out.     The feather lifted off the table and floated easily through the air.Â 

    Draco stared at the hand again and then over to her, his eyes glittering. â€œThatâ€™sâ€”How did you make this work?â€

    Hermioneâ€™s throat tightened slightly, and she looked over and straightened her set of screwdrivers. â€œOhâ€”well, I actually used my research from deconstructing the manacles.â€Â 

    She glanced up at Draco and found that heâ€™d gone still as though heâ€™d been frozen.Â 

    She cleared her throat. â€œSussex had a lot of really exceptional alchemy and wand core research, you know, the way they stripped and channeled magic, soâ€”â€ she lifted her chin and met his eyes, â€œI took the fundamentals of what they developed and used it to make something that wasnâ€™t horrible.â€

    He kept staring at her for several seconds, and then he looked down at the prosthetic.Â 

    Hermione looked down at her bare wrists. â€œThe worst things are always created during wars; thatâ€™s the way it is in the Muggle world too. Thereâ€™s never any way of putting them back in Pandoraâ€™s box once theyâ€™re let out. In a few years, Iâ€™m sureâ€”every Wizarding government in the world will use manacles to suppress prisonersâ€™ magic. I thought it should be used to create something that helps people too.â€ She gave him a faint smile and then picked up her wand. â€œMaybe someday I could send some of the designs to a hospital somewhere. Assuming not everyone maimed during the war was killed during imprisonment, there are a lot of people who could benefit from better magical prosthesis.â€

    She looked up at Draco again, and he was still standing where heâ€™d frozen. Then he stepped towards her and hesitantly captured her face in both hands, turning it upwards, and cradling it in his palms the way he used to. He traced his thumbs lightly across the arch of her cheekbones; one was cooler to the touch than the other. She shivered.Â 

    He pressed his lips against her forehead. â€œYouâ€™re better than anyone,â€ he said quietly, the words brushing against her skin. â€œThis world doesnâ€™t deserve you at all.â€Â 

    It snowed in December. It was beautiful. It blanketed their world in white and Hermione would sit beside Draco and they would listen to the sound of it falling.Â 

    Hermione felt as though she were as big as a house, and eight months of pregnancy made her want to hibernate, but Draco pulled her out of bed and coaxed her to go outside anyway.Â 

    â€œItâ€™s cold. Walking makes my feet and back hurt,â€ she said sulkily while he wrapped scarves around her.Â 

    â€œIâ€™ll carry you.â€

    She snorted. â€œYou will not, youâ€™ll break your back. I weigh as much as an erumpent.â€

    â€œIâ€™ll reinforce my hand so it doesnâ€™t break,â€ he said with a smirk.Â 

    Hermione gasped indignantly, her eyes growing wide. â€œYouâ€™re terrible.â€

    â€œYou told me to make you go outside every day even when you didnâ€™t feel like it.â€

    Hermione scowled and pulled on her cloak, â€œI didnâ€™t expect it to mean you were going to interrupt my nap.â€

    â€œI tried to wait it out, but it was unending.â€

    Hermione sniffed and let him lace up and tie her boots.Â 

    They walked on carefully cleared paths. The sky, trees and the ground were all glittering white from the freshly fallen snow.Â 

    â€œItâ€™s almost Christmas,â€ she said. Her breath rose like a cloud as she spoke.Â 

    Draco nodded.Â 

    â€œI didnâ€™t know Iâ€™d be this sick of being pregnant, but itâ€™s hard to imagine that weâ€™re going to have a baby soon.â€ She glanced over at Draco. â€œItâ€™s going to be different once there are three of us.â€

    Draco gave another terse nod. Hermione squeezed his hand. â€œHopefully she wonâ€™t inherit our combined stubbornness.â€

    Draco snorted. â€œIf I were a betting man, Iâ€™d say the odds are heavily against us.â€

    Hermione smiled. â€œProbably.â€

    The baby was indeed stubborn.Â 

    Hermioneâ€™s due date came and went without so much as a Braxton Hicks contraction. Hermione went from hibernating to determinedly climbing every flight of stairs in the house and hiking up the steepest paths on the island in the hopes that it would make something happen. Anything.Â Â 

    She was nearly forty-one weeks pregnant and positive she could not endure being pregnant for another day when she finally had a contraction. Then another. They came at irregular intervals for two days before gradually occurring every eight to ten minutes and staying there.Â 

    Topsy lingered, bobbing excitedly on her toes as she eyed Hermione knowingly. Ginny handed James off to a house-elf and provided everyone tea. Hermione tried to read and not feel hopeful that the contractions were going to ever stop being eight minutes apart. They were just intense enough that she couldnâ€™t ignore them.

    Draco appeared ready to die from chronic stress. Heâ€™d tense every time Hermione shifted or drew a sharp breath when a contraction peaked. His eyes never left her.

    Hermione or Ginny cast diagnostics every hour to see if sheâ€™d even effaced fully and kept finding that she somehow hadnâ€™t.

    Finally, Hermione stood up with a despairing sigh. Ginny and Draco shot to their feet.

    She pulled her cloak on and slipped her feet into her boots before casting a spell to lace them up. â€œIâ€™m going to take another walk. Maybe it will make the labour actually start. If that doesnâ€™t workâ€”â€ she eyed Draco but didnâ€™t mention the other options she was considering.

    Ginny nodded, her mouth quirking. â€œIâ€™ll go see how James is. You can send word when you want me to come back.â€

    Draco opened his mouth but then shut it soundlessly.Â 

    He gave Hermione his arm and let her lead him up as many staircases as she wanted.Â 

    She stood at the top of a bridge, gripping his hand while she tried to suppress a moan and breathe through a contraction.Â 

    â€œGrangerâ€”I could go get a midwife.â€

    â€œAbsolutely not,â€ Hermione said through her teeth as she doubled over. â€œGinny and I can manage. Iâ€™m not having you risk itâ€”and Iâ€™m not having you bring anyone here and then kill them afterwards in order to cover your tracks.â€

    Draco was guiltily silent.Â 

    Hermione released a low breath. â€œWeâ€™re not doing that anymore. Weâ€™re safe. Weâ€™re safe here. Donâ€™t you dare.â€

    â€œI hate this.â€

    â€œI know.â€

    â€œIt hurts.â€

    â€œYes.â€

    â€œIâ€™m tired. I've been pushing for hours.â€

    â€œI know.â€

    â€œStop agreeing with me.â€

    Draco was silent for a very long time after that.Â 

    Hermione wasnâ€™t sure whether she were breaking his hand, or he were breaking hers.Â 

    Ginny was between Hermioneâ€™s legs beside Topsy.Â  â€œHermione, are you sure donâ€™t want a mirror so you can see?â€

    â€œI do not,â€ Hermione said in a flat voice as she caught her breath before another contraction rolled through her. She curled forcefully forward with a groan.Â 

    â€œGood job. Headâ€™s out. One more to get the shoulders through.â€ Ginny looked up at Draco. â€œDo you want to catch her?â€

    Draco just stared at Ginny until she looked back down between Hermioneâ€™s legs again.Â 

    Hermione gritted her teeth and squeezed her eyes shut. She bore down again, focusing her entire body and mind on getting the baby out.Â 

    â€œThatâ€™s it. Thatâ€™s it. Yes! Shoulders are out, just breathe now. Donâ€™t push.â€

    There was a mewling wail and suddenly a wet, squirming bundle was deposited upon Hermioneâ€™s bare chest.

    Hermione gave a small gasp as her daughterâ€™s tiny, scrunched up face nuzzled against her sternum. The babyâ€™s head matted with dark wet curls.Â 

    Her exhaustion was instantly forgotten. Hermioneâ€™s hands were shaking as she wrapped her arms around the babyâ€™s vernix smeared body and rested her fingers on the sodden head. The baby looked up towards Hermioneâ€™s face, her mouth twisting as a vibrating wail emerged forcefully from her mouth.

    Hermione felt speechless. Ginny and Topsy were both speaking, but Hermione paid no attention. The baby furrowed her feather light eyebrows and widened her eyes briefly.Â 

    They were as bright silver as a lighting storm.Â 

    Hermione gave a sob and held her tighter. â€œDracoâ€”she has your eyes.â€

    Epilogue 2

    Chapter Notes

    See the end of the chapter for notes

    Hermione sat in bed counting her daughterâ€™s fingers, looking at the tiny pink fingernails and tracing her fingers along the squashed profile. The baby had been weighed, checked all over with diagnostic spells, and then Topsy had swaddled her expertly. The matted brown hair was beginning to dry and stand in little tufts about her head.

    â€œI think sheâ€™s going to end up with my hair, poor thing. Although maybe sheâ€™ll go platinum at six months,â€ Hermione said. She glanced up, smiling, and found that Draco was standing near the wall, looking as though he were on the verge of apparating out of the room.Â 

    Hermione stilled and stared at him in confusion. Heâ€™d been right beside her through the labour to the moment sheâ€™d been handed the baby. She wasnâ€™t sure when heâ€™d backed away.

    Ginny and Topsy both slipped unobtrusively out of the room.Â 

    Hermione vaguely registered the sound of the door sliding shut as she studied Draco. Heâ€™d turned white, and his expression was more devastated than anything else. His fingers kept twitching.Â 

    â€œDracoâ€¦ come see her.â€

    He swallowed. â€œGrangerâ€”â€

    â€œSheâ€™s your daughter.â€Â 

    His hands twitched, and she could see the muscles in his jaw clench.Â 

    â€œI know.â€ His teeth flashed as he spoke through them. â€œI remember it happening.â€

    The smile on Hermioneâ€™s face faded away, and she flinched, holding the baby closer. It was like being slapped or plunged into ice water.Â 

    The happiness evaporated as though it had been an illusion. A dream sheâ€™d hidden herself inside.

    She swallowed and looked down at the baby in her arms. Â The silence in the room was so heavy, she felt as though she were being crushed under it.

    There were certain wounds that never fully faded. That likely never would.

    â€I think I should go,â€ Draco finally said.

    â€œCome here,â€ she said in a flat voice, looking up at him again.

    He looked despairing as he stared at her and so pale it was as though his heart had been carved out of his chest and he was bleeding to death in front of her. He wasnâ€™t making any move to get closer.Â 

    â€œDraco, come here,â€ she said again.Â 

    He hesitated a moment before he moved forward slowly. She slipped her left arm free and took his hand, pulling him closer until he sat down on the edge of the bed beside her. Â 

    Hermione drew a deep breath as she tried to determine what to do. Sheâ€™d thought heâ€™d gotten used to the idea of the baby, that theyâ€™d mostly managed to reconcile what had happened before her memories returned.

    He hadnâ€™t wanted to rape her. He would never have done so if thereâ€™d been any other way to save her. Heâ€™d never expected her to forgive him for it.

    Maybe he still didnâ€™t.

    She squeezed his hand tighter. He seemed unwilling to have any kind of physical proximity to Hermione or his daughter.

    Her mouth was dry. â€œYouâ€”you promised to care about her. If youâ€”if youâ€”â€ her jaw started trembling, â€œIf you were going to leave after she was bornâ€”you should have told me. This was a new beginning. All three of us. Remember? We left it all behindâ€”all of itâ€”so we could be together. You havenâ€™t even looked at her.â€

    She shifted the baby to show her face better, but Draco stiffened and looked away. It was like being cut through, the rejection was physically painful.Â 

    â€œLook,â€ her voice was fierce. â€œYou have to look at her.â€Â 

    Draco reluctantly glanced down.

    â€œSheâ€™s just a baby. Sheâ€™s not going to hurt you, and you arenâ€™t going to hurt her. Just look.â€

    Dracoâ€™s head jerked sharply up and he gave a short, ragged laugh as he tried to pull his hand free. Hermione refused to let go. His expression was strained, as though he wanted to be anywhere, anywhere else on earth but where he was.Â 

    â€œGrangerâ€”â€ he said in a voice so tight it was shaking, â€œthe only thing I do is kill things.â€

    Hermione stared at him and then gripped his hand more tightly.

    â€œNo,â€ she said forcefully. â€œThatâ€™s a lie. You saved me. You saved Ginny and James. You could have been a healer. You can be a good father, I know it. Itâ€”it might not ever be natural for either of us, but weâ€™ll both try our best. Youâ€”â€

    â€œHermioneâ€”â€ he released a sharp breath as though heâ€™d been kicked. His voice was raw, and he still wasnâ€™t looking at her.Â 

    â€œGrangerâ€¦â€ he tried again to pull his hand away. â€œGranger, Iâ€™veâ€”Iâ€™ve killed children before. The lastâ€”infant I touched, I used the Killing Curse on after I executed its mother.â€

    Hermione froze, staring up at his face.

    At some point she had known that heâ€™d likely killed children, but sheâ€™d dissociated from the knowledge. Ignored it.

    Wizarding folk and Muggles. Friends and strangers. Men and womenâ€¦ and children.Â 

    Sheâ€™d known it all, but sheâ€™d also forgotten it.Â 

    Then she remembered Stroudâ€™s matter-of-fact tone when sheâ€™d offered to relieve Draco of an unwanted female child: â€œThe ones with good potential will be raised to contribute to the programâ€™s next phase, and the others will be useful lab subjects. Thereâ€™s still so little understood about early magical developmentâ€¦â€

    She swallowed, trying to find her voice. â€œYou didnâ€™t have a choice. You didnâ€™t. You didnâ€™t have any choice.â€ She looked down at their daughter. â€œWeâ€™re starting over now. Sheâ€™s going to grow up away from the war, and weâ€”weâ€™re going to leave all that behind. Weâ€™re going to take care of her and keep her safe. Both of us. Weâ€™re both going to take care of her.â€

    Hermione turned towards Draco so that the baby lay in her arms between them. Their daughterâ€™s silver eyes peered up at them. Her hair had dried into a halo of brown curls around her head. Her face was pink and still looked slightly squashed. Both of her hands had escaped swaddling and were up near her face. She was aggressively sucking on the knuckles of her right hand.

    She was the loveliest thing Hermione had ever seen.Â 

    â€œLook at her, Draco. Sheâ€™s ours. Sheâ€™s all ours. Youâ€™re not going to hurt her.â€

    He stared down at his daughter for several seconds.Â 

    When he moved, she could tell that heâ€™d stopped breathing. His fingers spasmed as he started to reach out. He hesitated and then just barely brushed the babyâ€™s palm as though he expected his touch to poison or break her. The tiny hand reflexively closed around his finger, gripping it.Â 

    Draco sat frozen.Â 

    Hermione watched him and recognised the expression in his eyes as he looked down at the little person who was clinging tenaciously to him.Â 

    Possessive and adoring.Â 

    Aurore Rose Malfoy was, according to Ginny, the easiest baby ever born. In appearance she was an almost perfect replica of Hermione, except for her astonishingly bright silver eyes and Dracoâ€™s mouth.

    She slept beautifully and rarely cried. She would lie for hours in her overly-indulgent fatherâ€™s arms, snoozing on his chest while he watched Hermione work in the lab. Aurore would gaze owlishly at pictures in herbology encyclopedias and sit very seriously while she teethed on her fatherâ€™s prosthetic fingers.

    She was a quiet, solemn baby who matched her parentsâ€™ seriousness, but her eyes had fire in them.Â 

    Hermione would carry her around in a sling, tucked up against her chest, where she could wrap her arms tightly and protectively around Auroreâ€™s tiny body whenever she felt nervous because the forest was too quiet or sky too wide.Â 

    Once Aurore could safely sit up, she would spend half the day sitting on Dracoâ€™s shoulders, riding about with him while he checked the wards near the house.Â 

    Draco talked to Aurore more than he talked to anyone, even Hermione.Â 

    He would monologue to her about anything, about the trees, and the furniture, all the shops where heâ€™d bought books for Hermione, about what the weather might be, and what all the colours and hues of the analytic spells meant. Aurore would listen to him intently and fret when he got distracted or fell silent for too long.Â 

    Despite Hermioneâ€™s philosophical opposition to co-sleeping, Aurore slept in the middle of the bed between Draco and Hermione. It was not because Aurore needed her parents in order to sleep, but because they needed her. Hermione regularly fell asleep on the floor next to Auroreâ€™s cot, holding her hand. Draco would get up several dozen times at night to reassure himself that Aurore was still breathing.Â 

    Aurore barely touched the ground for the first year of her life. When Hermione or Draco put her down, Topsy would instantly appear and bustle away with her, or Ginny would sweep her off to play with James.Â 

    Aurore would sit with Hermione, stuffing quill feathers into her mouth and discovering what kinds of sounds she could make if she struck Hermioneâ€™s collection of cauldrons with wooden stir rods.Â 

    When she learned to walk, she would trail after people like a little shadow, watching Ginny in the kitchen and gardens, Hermione in her lab, and Draco on his daily route testing the wards. She only needed to be told a rule once, and she would follow it perfectly.Â 

    She would have been almost angelic, if not for the influence of James Potter.Â 

    From James, Aurore learned race around the house on a toy broomstick at such breakneck speed that Draco would turn white; how to climb the hills and trees and scrape her knees and tear her clothes, and make soups and mudpies in the creek. She also learned how to wrestle, to Dracoâ€™s eternal chagrin.

    Hermione often woke in the night to find a tiny, serious face gazing intently at her, so close that their noses were nearly touching. It would have been almost terrifying if it had not been a regular occurrence since Aurore had been moved into her own bed.Â 

    â€œMummy, can I cuddle you?â€

    Aurore always asked Hermione because the only rule Draco managed to enforce was that Aurore was not allowed to sleep with them any more.Â 

    â€œDonâ€™t wake your father,â€ Hermione whispered, scooting back against Dracoâ€™s chest in order to make more room.Â 

    Aurore clambered into the bed, curling up tightly in Hermioneâ€™s arms, her hands resting on Hermioneâ€™s neck. She was asleep again in seconds.Â 

    Hermione nuzzled their noses together and closed her eyes.Â 

    â€œThere are rules, Granger,â€ Draco muttered into her hair.Â 

    Hermione ducked her head forward. â€œI thought that was my line,â€ she said. â€œBesides, I didnâ€™t want to wake you.â€

    â€œI was awake the moment the door opened.â€ Dracoâ€™s tone was disgruntled. â€œAs long as she knows youâ€™re going to say yes, sheâ€™s going to keep coming every night.â€

    Hermione hugged Aurore more tightly. â€œShe wonâ€™t want to cuddle forever.â€

    Draco shifted and slid a hand along Hermioneâ€™s hip. â€œYouâ€™ve been saying that for over a year now.â€Â 

    Hermione buried her nose in Auroreâ€™s hair. It smelled like moss and tree bark. â€œWell, itâ€™s been true the whole time. Sheâ€™ll grow out of it someday. Iâ€™ll never know which is the last time sheâ€™ll ask.â€

    Draco sighed. His hand slid possessively around Hermioneâ€™s waist, holding her as tightly as she was holding Aurore.Â 

    Life on the island was idyllic, like something from a fairytale. Gradually, it lasted long enough that Hermione began to tentatively trust it. The only disruption to their hidden world was the regular arrival of the news, which Draco, Hermione, and Ginny would read in the evening when James and Aurore were in bed.Â 

    Hermioneâ€™s panic attacks slowly became a thing of the past.Â 

    When Aurore was weaned, Draco and Hermione glamoured their appearances and very cautiously left the island in order to take Hermione to a mind-healer to find out what had happened to her brain.Â 

    According to the mind-healer, there was so much anomalous magical activity in Hermioneâ€™s mind it was difficult to determine everything that had occurred. The memory structure was so precariously maintained there was little to be done. The healer strongly advised a low-stress environment and as little magical interference in her brain as possible for the rest of her life. There were a few mild potions she could take for her anxiety, but there were too many conflicting sources of Magic permanently present for there to be any easy solutions. The damage had been exacerbated by her ongoing use of Dark Magic prior to her injury.Â 

    Draco was quiet for a long time during their return trip.Â 

    â€œThe Heart of Isis generally works by proximity, doesnâ€™t it?â€ he finally asked.Â 

    Hermione was staring out the window of the train, and she closed her eyes, cringing. This was a conversation she had hoped to never have with him, hoping it was detail heâ€™d miss.

    After a minute she nodded slowly. â€œYes. For minor amounts of Dark Magic temporary proximity is sufficient.â€

    â€œAnd for larger quantities? Sayâ€”repeatedly casting spells to analyse and deconstruct Dark Magic And even casting the curses themselves in order to determine a method of reversal, how much Dark Magic would that be, in your expert opinion?â€ His voice was deceptively casual.Â 

    Hermione leaned away, crossing her feet as she kept staring out the window. â€œIt would depend.â€

    There was a heavy pause, and Hermione looked down, adjusting the hem of her shirt so that it would lay flat. She could feel Dracoâ€™s gaze boring into her.Â 

    She cleared her throat. â€œIt could accumulate quickly if an individual was required to do it frequently because there were so many new curses that required analysis and they didnâ€™t have the time or resources to perform regular purification rituals.â€

    She could see Draco nod from the corner of her eye.Â 

    â€œWhere did you keep the Heart of Isis before you used it on me?â€

    Her throat tightened. â€œUnder my bed sometimes, butâ€”usually I had it on a chain around my neck. It wasâ€”â€ she swallowed, â€œit was hidden inside a protective amulet that I used to wear.â€

    â€œWhat happened to the amulet?â€

    â€œWell,â€ she twitched her shoulder, her voice dismissive, â€œI had to break it, in order to access the heart. So I threw the pieces away afterwards.â€

    Draco was silent for several minutes.

    â€œI wish youâ€™d told me,â€ he finally said, his voice muted. Â 

    Hermioneâ€™s mouth pressed into a wistful smile. â€œNeither of us were much good at asking for help. I donâ€™t think either of us made many choices with the expectation weâ€™d survive the war long enough to regret them.â€Â 

    Hermione turned to look at him. He was staring blankly across the train compartment, his gaze faraway. It was the expression he wore when he was replaying the past, trying to place what he could have done differently.Â 

    She reached out and took his hand, entwining their fingers. â€œIf I could change the past, Iâ€™d save you every time.â€

    His expression didnâ€™t brighten or change. She rested against his shoulder and closed her eyes. â€œLetâ€™s love each other forever, Draco.â€

    She felt him kiss the top of her head.Â 

    â€œAlright.â€

    Hermione shattered a flagon of potion when a piercing scream tore through the house, followed by another.Â 

    The entire war rushed over her like a flood at the blood-curdling sound. She snatched up her wand and a nearby knife and raced through the house, nearly colliding with Draco and Ginny as they all burst into the room, wands drawn, and found Aurore with James pinned beneath her as she walloped him over the head with hardbound book while screaming with incandescent rage.

    Hermioneâ€™s knees nearly gave out with shock and relief as she put the knife down on a shelf and stumbled across the room. Her chest was spasming as she struggled to breathe.Â 

    Aurore whacked James across the head one final time as Hermione dragged her off and carried her into a corner while Ginny picked up a howling James and hugged him.Â 

    â€œWhat. Happened?â€ Dracoâ€™s voice was deadly.Â 

    â€œHe ripped it!â€ Aurore was shrieking. Her face was white with rage. â€œHe ripped my new book!â€

    Hermione and Draco froze and stared at one another, eyes wide with disbelief. Draco was as pale as Aurore, and his fingers were spasming around his wand.

    â€œI was just trying to see! Aurore wasnâ€™t letting me see!â€ James shouted across the room through his tears, while Ginny was trying to check him for bruises. â€œI told her to share, and she didnâ€™t listen!â€

    Aurore gave another scream of rage. â€œIt was mine!â€ She turned and flopped into Hermione's arms. â€œMuuuuum, he ripped my book. My new book! He ripped the page with h-h-horses!â€Â 

    Hermione hugged her and willed herself to stop shaking from terror.

    She hugged Aurore more tightly, burying her face in the tangled curls, while she kept struggling to breathe calmly.Â 

    â€œI know. I know.â€ She stroked Auroreâ€™s head through her thick, curly hair. â€œBut we donâ€™t hit people, not with our hands or with a book.â€

    â€œHe ripped my book!â€ Auroreâ€™s rage transformed into despair, and she burst into tears.

    â€œI JUST WANTED TO SEE IT!â€ James screamed across the room.Â 

    â€œIt was mine!â€Â 

    â€œAurore!â€ Hermione said, her voice sharpening as her shock wore off, â€œWe do not hit! You are not allowed to hit; you know that rule. What is more important, people or things?â€

    Auroreâ€™s grey eyes widened. She dropped her head down and studied her feet. â€œPeople,â€ she said in a reluctant voice.

    â€œYes. People.â€ Hermione forced herself to take a deep breath. â€œPeople are always the most important. A book we can fix or replace, but people arenâ€™t replaceable. We donâ€™t get them back after we lose them. We never hurt them. If something upsets us, we use our words, not our bodies. I amâ€”so, so disappointed right now.â€

    Auroreâ€™s face screwed up, and she tilted back her head and bawled.Â 

    Hermione picked up Aurore and hugged her while she crossed the room to check on James.Â 

    Jamesâ€™ face was buried in Ginnyâ€™s shoulder.Â 

    â€œIs he alright?â€

    Ginny nodded. â€œNot even bruised. I think heâ€™s mostly in shock that Aurore was the one who lost her temper.â€

    Hermione sighed with relief. â€œIâ€™m in shock.â€

    Ginny gave a nervous laugh, but her eyes looked as strained as Hermione still felt. â€œWell, Iâ€™m just glad to know Iâ€™m not the only one with a naughty child. I was beginning to worry it was my parenting.â€

    Hermione gave a tight, relieved laugh and shook her head. â€œI think weâ€™re due for a nap and then some serious conversations. Aurore, do you want to say sorry to James for hitting him?â€

    Aurore peered through her tangled hair. â€œIt was my book,â€ she said in a quavering voice.

    Hermione winced. â€œRight. Weâ€™ll have to do that apology a little later. Iâ€™m so sorry, James.â€

    Jamesâ€™ face was still buried in Ginnyâ€™s shoulder, and he didnâ€™t respond.

    When Aurore was sleeping in her room, Hermione turned and collapsed into Dracoâ€™s arms.Â 

    â€œI thought someone had found us,â€ she said, her voice shaking. â€œWhen I heard her scream, I thoughtâ€”I thought sheâ€™d been cursed. I thought when I went through the door that I was going to find her dying.â€

    Draco held her tightly, and his hands still spasming. She felt him nod and he rested his head against hers. She gave a low sob and tried to compose herself. She could hear his heartbeat, racing to match her own.Â 

    â€œI didnâ€™t realise how I was still waiting,â€ she said after they stood in silence for several minutes. â€œItâ€™s all still there. I grabbed a knife. I didnâ€™t pause to think, I just grabbed a knife and ran.â€

    Â 

    The Liberation Front had reached Britain a few days before Jamesâ€™ third birthday, but it took nearly a year before Voldemortâ€™s final stronghold was toppled. Thicknesse and most other Ministry officials were arrested, along with all marked Death Eaters. In exchange for more lenient sentencing, several Death Eaters cooperated in removing the manacles from the freed prisoners in Hogwarts and all the surrogates in the Repopulation Program.Â 

    Voldemort never even appeared. He hid inside his castle and after dozens of failed attempts to attack it, the Liberation Front left him there. It was kept under heavy guard, and the hope was expressed that heâ€™d just die; his fortress eventually becoming his sarcophagus. Like Grindlewald, the newspapers said repeatedly, as though it put the entire matter to rest.

    Some trials and convictions happened rapidly. The Death Eater regime had detailed records documenting their atrocities. According to The New York Seer â€œfollowing the death of Antonin Dolohov in the Sussex Lab Explosion, Death Eater Severus Snape had a heavy influence on the records and structure within the Death Eater regime. The cause of the explosion was never officially confirmed, and most of the labâ€™s records were destroyed. According to Snape, the accident, which killed hundreds of Europeâ€™s most prized minds, could have been prevented with more cohesive oversight. In the aftermath, prisons and laboratories were required to keep detailed records at an external location, with meticulous details and the signatures of anyone involved, creating a crystal clear paper-trail listing anyone involved and making it undeniable who was responsible in every branch. Snape was assassinated in a coup dâ€™etat in Romania in Summer 2005 and never realised that his exacting requirements post-war built air-tight legal cases against hundreds of his colleagues and fellow Death Eaters.â€

    Other aspects of the regime were messier and more horrifying, and as they emerged, the political spinning began.Â 

    The International Confederation couldnâ€™t deny knowledge of the Repopulation Program, but they claimed complete ignorance about the circumstances. The Supreme Mugwump gave a speech insisting that the International Confederation had been told that participation as a surrogate was voluntary, and that if theyâ€™d known prisoners were being used as lab rats, raped, and forcibly impregnated, they would have intervened years sooner.Â 

    Healer Stroud had fled Europe and disappeared long before the Repopulation Program trials began.Â 

    Hermione had to take anxiety potions in order to read about everything without hyperventilating. Sheâ€™d known it had been horrific, but reading the testimonies in the trials that began was so devastating she felt as though she might break under the guilt. All the surviving surrogates were brought in to testify. Hannah Abbott was a shadow, cowering at the witness stand and hiding the left side of her face when asked questions about the compulsions and what had been done to her.Â 

    Due to the low virility of most Death Eaters, many surrogates had been dosed heavily with fertility potions, resulting in multiple births. Parvati Patil was brought to court heavily pregnant and had two children, barely walking, clinging to her robes.

    When the surrogates conceived foetuses that showed low magic potential, the pregnancies were aborted and then attempts immediately resumed with more damaging fertility potions in attempts to â€œcontrolâ€ the results. Many of the surrogates had been rendered infertile with severe internal damage. Those that remained fertile were given six weeks to recover postpartum before being returned to the program for another baby. Angelina Johnson had an empty, tattered swaddling blanket that she held in her arms and refused to let go of.

    To Hermioneâ€™s outrage, the International Confederation was conflicted over what should be done. There were efforts being made to restructure the Ministry of Magic into something more democratic, which would leave less room for someone like Voldemort to slip in behind the scenes and begin controlling it, but despite their horror over the trial testimonies, the British Wizarding society was keenly attached to their pureblooded â€œaristocracy.â€Â 

    Voldemort hadnâ€™t even been a pureblood, said one editorial. It would be a travesty to see Britainâ€™s ancient families pay the price. The important thing was to settle things in court, make necessary reparations, and move on.Â 

    Hermione found her mouth curling in a snarl, and she put the paper down to consciously force herself to breathe.

    The children and pregnancies from the repopulation program were all related to some of Britainâ€™s oldest families, most of whom now had parents serving multiple life-long prison sentences. Who should raise the children? What should be done with the surrogates? The editorials opined about it endlessly.Â 

    Some of the women wanted nothing to do with the children theyâ€™d been forced to bear, some wanted abortions, while others were ferociously protective of their pregnancies and refused to let their children out of their arms. After nearly three years of living with compulsions, many of the surrogates had internalised them so deeply they fluctuated between compulsive subservience and vicious rebelliousness.Â 

    The courts began moving in favour of the Wizarding families, which were very keen to see their bloodlines maintained and their heirs raised suitably. Their lawyers argued that the surrogates were deeply unstable; it would be in the best interest of everyone to remove the children, provide some monetary compensation to the surrogates, and let everyone â€œmove onâ€.

    â€œIâ€™m going to go back,â€ Ginny said abruptly after reading the most recent newspaper about the Repopulation Program trials. â€œIâ€™ve been thinking about it for a few months now, and I think I have to.â€

    Lord Voldemort died in January 2009, a week after Auroreâ€™s third birthday.

    According to the papers, his castle was breached by an elite team of MACUSA aurors accompanied by Ginny Weasley, the last surviving member of the Order of the Phoenix.     Most of the aurors were killed in the process, and Ginny nearly died. The auror leading the attack ordered that everyone fall back, but Ginny refused. She went in and cast her first and last Killing Curse.Â 

    The newspapers around the world featured a picture of Ginevra Weasley emerging from the rubble of a castle, her face filthy and streaked with blood.     There was no denying Ginnyâ€™s heroism, despite the pointed questions about where sheâ€™d hidden during the last several years.     The reconstruction efforts slowly shifted from the staunch lines about â€œmoving onâ€ to memorialising the fallen: the Resistance, the Order members, the surrogates.     The courts tentatively decided to grant custody to mothers who wanted it.
